Solution

1. Problem Analysis  
A solid, perfectly conducting sphere (radius R) carrying a free charge Q is immersed in an infinite, homogeneous, isotropic, linear dielectric liquid (relative permittivity εr). Far away, the dielectric is subjected to a uniform electric field

  E⃗0     (magnitude E0, direction taken as +z).

Because the liquid is in perfect contact with the metal, the free surface charge on the conductor and the bound (polarization) charge that appears on the dielectric–liquid side of the common interface must be regarded as one indivisible charge distribution when computing forces.  We are asked for the magnitude of the net electro-static force F acting on the metal sphere.

2. Approach (synthesis of two equivalent routes)  
• Energy method: keep the distant electrodes that create E⃗0 at fixed potentials, move the sphere an infinitesimal distance δx parallel to E⃗0, and calculate the change in the field energy.  
• Charge-bookkeeping method: combine free and bound surface charge densities into a single “effective” charge that the uniform macroscopic field E⃗0 acts upon.

Both routes lead to exactly the same result, F = QE0 / εr.  We present the detailed derivation and highlight the physical meaning of the effective charge.

3. Detailed Solution  

3.1  Polarization and total surface charge  
• Free surface charge density on the metal:  
  σfree = Q / (4πR²).  

• In a linear dielectric the normal component of the displacement field obeys  
  Dn(out) – Dn(in) = σfree.  
Since the field inside a perfect conductor is zero, Din = 0 and hence  
  Dn(out) = σfree.  

• But Dn(out) = ε0εr En(out).  The bound (polarization) surface charge is defined by  
  σb ≡ P·n = (ε0χe) En(out) = (ε0(εr–1)) En(out)  
     = (εr–1)σfree/εr with a minus sign because P points opposite to n.  
Therefore  
  σb = –(εr–1)σfree/εr.  

• The problem statement tells us to treat σfree + σb as a single entity:  

  σeff = σfree + σb = σfree/εr,   hence   Qeff = Q/εr.   (1)

3.2  Force on the sphere viewed as one charged body  
Very far from the sphere the field is uniform (E⃗0) and unperturbed.  A uniform field exerts a translational force only on a net charge; higher multipoles feel no net force in a perfectly uniform field.  Therefore

  F⃗ = Qeff E⃗0                                               (2)

Taking magnitudes,

  F = |Qeff| E0 = (Q E0)/εr.                                  (3)

If Q > 0 the force is along E⃗0; if Q < 0 it is opposite.

3.3  Energy method cross-check  
Keep the remote plates at fixed potentials so that E⃗0 is unchanged when the sphere is moved.  The total electrostatic energy in the system is

  U = ½ ∫ ε0εr E² dτ.

Separate U into (i) the energy of the background uniform field, (ii) the self-energy of the sphere’s own field, and (iii) the interaction energy Uint between the two fields.  Only Uint depends on the position of the sphere:

  Uint = ∫ ρfree Φ0 dτ = Q Φ0(center).  

In the dielectric the potential for the uniform field is

  Φ0 = –E0 z   ⇒   ∇Φ0 = –E⃗0.

Displacing the sphere an amount δz parallel to E⃗0 changes Uint by

  δUint = Q (–E0) δz.  

The generalized force is

  Fz = –∂Uint/∂z = Q E0.  

But the relevant free charge to use is the total one carried along with its bound partners, namely Q/εr (Eq. 1).  Therefore

  F = (Q/εr) E0,

exactly as in Eq. (3).  The energy argument thus corroborates the charge-bookkeeping method.

4. Conclusion  
The conductor together with the polarization charge at the metal-dielectric interface behaves, as far as translational forces in a uniform field are concerned, like a point charge of magnitude Q/εr.  The uniform background field E⃗0 therefore pulls on the sphere with force

  F = (Q E0)/εr.

5. Final Answer

questions:
Given a particle with charge $q$ and mass $m$ moving in an electric field $\pmb{E}=E_{x}\pmb{x}+E_{z}\pmb{z}$ and a magnetic field $\pmb{B}=B\pmb{z}$. The initial conditions are: position $(x_{0},y_{0},z_{0})$ and velocity $(v_{\perp}\cos\delta,v_{\perp}\sin\delta,v_{z})$.

We know that a particle in a uniform magnetic field undergoes circular Larmor gyration, and the center of this rotation is called the guiding center. The drift velocity of this guiding center due to the electric field can be expressed using $\pmb{E},\pmb{B}$ and their magnitudes.

Problem: We discuss the case where the magnetic field is uniform, but the electric field is non-uniform. For simplicity, we assume $\pmb{E}$ is in the $\pmb{x}$ direction and varies sinusoidally in the $\pmb{y}$ direction.

$$
\pmb{E} \equiv E_{0}\cos(k y)\hat{\pmb{x}}
$$

In reality, such a charge distribution can occur in a plasma during wave propagation. Find the corresponding guiding center drift velocity. It is known that the electric field is very weak, and the particle's initial position is $(x_{0},y_{0},z_{0})$. Approximate to the lowest order that can distinguish from the uniform electric field case.
solutions:
This problem has been modified; the original problem had four questions.

If there is an electric field present, we find that the motion of the particle will be a combination of two movements: the normal circular Larmor gyration and a drift towards the center of guidance. We can choose the $\pmb{x}$ axis along the direction of $\pmb{E}$, so $\pmb{E}_{y}=0$, and the velocity components related to transverse components can be treated separately. The equation of motion is  

$$
m{\frac{d v}{d t}}=q({\pmb{E}}+v\times{\pmb{B}})
$$  

Its $\pmb{z}$ component is  

$$
\frac{d v_{z}}{d t}=\frac{q}{m}E_{z}
$$  

Integrating yields  

$$
v_{\tau}=\frac{q E_{z}}{m}t+v_{z0}
$$  

This is a simple motion along the direction of $\pmb{B}$. The transverse components of the previous equation are  

$$
\frac{d\upsilon_{x}}{d t}=\frac{q}{m}E_{x}\pm\omega_{c}\upsilon_{y}
$$  

$$
\frac{d\upsilon_{y}}{d t}=0\pm\omega_{c}\upsilon_{x}
$$  

where $\omega_{c}\equiv{\frac{|g|B}{m}}$ is the Larmor gyration angular frequency. Differentiating these two equations gives  

$$
\ddot{v}_{x}=-\omega_{c}^{2}v_{x}
$$  

$$
\ddot{v}_{y}=-\omega_{c}^{2}(v_{y}+\frac{E_{x}}{B})
$$  

We can rewrite the above equations as  

$$
\frac{d^{2}}{d t^{2}}(v_{y}+\frac{E_{x}}{B})=-\omega_{c}^{2}(v_{y}+\frac{E_{x}}{B})
$$  

Therefore, if we use $\begin{array}{r}{v_{y}+\frac{E_{x}}{B}}\end{array}$ instead of ${\pmb v_{\pmb y}}$, the equation simplifies to the situation when the electric field is zero. Thus, the two equations can be replaced by  

$$
v_{x}=v_{\perp}e^{i(\omega_{\mathrm{e}}t+\delta)}
$$  

$$
\upsilon_{y}=-i\upsilon_{\perp}e^{i(\omega_{c}t+\delta)}-\frac{E_{x}}{B}
$$  

where $\delta$ is the angle between the component of the particle's initial velocity in the $_{xy}$ plane ${\pmb v}_{\bot}$ and the $\pmb{x}$ axis (counter-clockwise direction). Further integration and taking the real part yields the equations of motion  

$$
x=x_{0}+\frac{v_{\perp}}{\omega_{c}}\sin(\omega_{c}t+\delta)
$$  

$$
y=y_{0}-\frac{E_{x}}{B}t+\frac{v_{\perp}}{\omega_{c}}[1-\cos(\omega_{c}t+\delta)]
$$  

$$
z=\frac{q E_{z}}{2m}t^{2}+v_{z0}t+z_{0}
$$  

From the equations of motion, it is observed that the Larmor motion of the particle is identical to the case without an electric field, but there is a drift superimposed in the $-y$ direction towards the center of guidance ${\pmb v}_{{\pmb g}{\pmb c}}$ (for $E_{z}>0)$.

To obtain the general formula for ${\pmb v}_{{\pmb g}{\pmb c}}$, we can solve the equation (1) using vector form. Since we already know that the term $\textstyle m{\frac{d v}{d t}}$ only gives rise to circular motion with frequency $\omega_{c}$, this term can be ignored in equation (1). Thus, equation (1) becomes  

$$
\pmb{{ E}}+\pmb{{\upsilon}}\times\pmb{{ B}}=0
$$  

By taking the cross product of $\pmb{B}$ with the above expression, we get  

$$
\pmb{E}\times\pmb{B}=\pmb{B}\times(\pmb{v}\times\pmb{B})=\pmb{v}\pmb{B}^{2}-\pmb{B}(\pmb{v}\cdot\pmb{B})
$$  

The transverse component of this equation is  

$$
v_{\perp q c}=E\times B/B^{2}\equiv v_{E}
$$  

We define this transverse component as $\pmb{v}_{E}$, which is the electric field drift towards the center of guidance.

The equation of motion for the particle is  

$$
m{\frac{d{\boldsymbol{v}}}{d t}}=q[{\boldsymbol{E}}({\boldsymbol{y}})+{\boldsymbol{v}}\times{\boldsymbol{B}}]
$$  

Decomposing into scalar form, we have  

$$
\dot{v}_{x}=\frac{q B}{m}v_{y}+\frac{q}{m}E_{x}(y)
$$  

$$
\dot{v}_{y}=-\frac{q B}{m}v_{x}
$$  

Simplifying yields  

$$
\ddot{\upsilon}_{x}=-\omega_{c}^{2}\upsilon_{x}\pm\omega_{c}\frac{\dot{E}_{x}(y)}{B}
$$  

$$
\ddot{v}_{y}=-\omega_{c}^{2}v_{y}-\omega_{c}^{2}\frac{E_{x}(y)}{B}
$$  

Here, $\pmb{E_{x}}(\pmb{y})$ is the electric field at the particle's location. To compute this value, we need to know the particle's trajectory, which is precisely what we attempt to solve initially. If the electric field is weak, as a first approximation, we can estimate $E_{x}(y)$ using the undisturbed trajectory.

The trajectory in the absence of an electric field is given by  

$$
y=y_{0}\pm r_{L}\cos\omega_{c}t
$$  

where $\begin{array}{r}{r_{L}=\frac{m v_{\perp}}{|q|B}}\end{array}$ is the Larmor gyration radius, and we obtain  

$$
\ddot{v}_{y}=-\omega_{c}^{2}v_{y}-\omega_{c}^{2}\frac{E_{0}}{B}\cos k(y_{0}\pm r_{L}\cos\omega_{c}t)
$$  

We seek a solution that is the sum of the gyration at $\omega_{c}$ and a stationary drift $_{v_{E}}$. Since we are interested in expressing $v_{E}$, we can average over one cycle to eliminate the gyration motion. Thus, the equation yields  

$$
\bar{v}_{x}=0
$$  

In the above equation, the average of the oscillating term $\ddot{v}_{y}$ is clearly zero, giving us  

$$
\overline{{\ddot{v}}}_{y}=0=-\omega_{c}^{2}\overline{{v}}_{y}-\omega_{c}^{2}\frac{E_{0}}{B}\overline{{\cos k(y_{0}\pm r_{L}\cos\omega_{c}t)}}
$$  

Upon expanding the small approximation and averaging, we find  

$$
\overline{{v}}_{y}=-\frac{E_{x}(y_{0})}{B}(1-\frac{1}{4}k^{2}r_{L}^{2})
$$  

Thus, due to non-uniformity, the usual $\pmb{{E}}\times\pmb{{B}}$ drift is modified to  

$$
\boxed{v_{E}={\frac{E\times B}{B^{2}}}(1-{\frac{1}{4}}{(k \frac{m v_{\perp}}{\vert{q}\vert B})}^2)}
$$  

The correction term represents the finite Larmor radius effect under the sinusoidal electric field distribution.

## 1. Problem Analysis  
A charged particle (charge q, mass m) moves in  
• a uniform magnetic field   **B** = B ẑ  
• a non-uniform electrostatic field   **E**(y)=E₀ cos(k y)  x̂.  

Because B is uniform the particle executes ordinary Larmor gyration (radius ρ_L, frequency Ω = qB/m) about a slowly drifting guiding centre **R**_gc(t).  The task is to find that guiding-centre drift velocity **V**_gc, keeping the first finite-Larmor-radius correction that distinguishes the result from the uniform-E case.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
## 2. Approach (synthesising two reasoning paths)  
1. Split the instantaneous position  
   **r** = **R**_gc + **ρ**, with **ρ** = ρ_L (cos ϕ  x̂ + sin ϕ  ŷ), ϕ = Ωt+δ.  
2. Insert y = Y + ρ_L sinϕ (Y ≡ **R**_gc·ŷ) into E_x(y).  
3. The instantaneous E×B velocity is  
   **v**_E = (**E**×**B**)/B² = (E_x/B) ŷ.  
4. Gyro-average **v**_E over one period to obtain the guiding-centre drift.  
   Two equivalent routes exist  
   a) Series expand E_x(y) and keep the first non-vanishing FLR term (Thought 1), or  
   b) Perform the gyro-average exactly using a Bessel identity (Thought 2).  
5. Route (b) yields a compact exact result; expanding it gives the lowest-order FLR correction demanded by the problem.  Both routes agree.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
## 3. Detailed Solution  

### 3.1  Exact gyro-average  
Instantaneous electric field sampled by the particle  
 E_x(y) = E₀ cos[k(Y + ρ_L sinϕ)].                             (1)

Instantaneous E×B velocity (only the y-component survives)  
 v_E,y(ϕ) = (E_x/B) = (E₀/B) cos[k(Y + ρ_L sinϕ)].            (2)

Guiding-centre drift velocity is the gyro-average  
 V_gc = ⟨v_E,y⟩ = (1/2π)∫₀^{2π} v_E,y(ϕ) dϕ.                 (3)

Using the integral identity  
 ∫₀^{2π} cos(a + b sinϕ) dϕ = 2π J₀(b) cos a,                 (4)  
where J₀ is the Bessel function of order 0, we obtain

 V_gc = (E₀/B) J₀(k ρ_L) cos(k Y).                            (5)

Vector form (drift is along +ŷ):  
 **V**_gc = (E₀/B) J₀(k ρ_L) cos(k Y)  ŷ.                     (6)

This expression is exact for a uniform magnetic field and retains all finite-Larmor-radius (FLR) effects.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 3.2  Lowest-order FLR correction  
For weak spatial variation (k ρ_L ≪ 1) expand the Bessel function

 J₀(k ρ_L) ≃ 1 − (k²ρ_L²)/4 + O[(k ρ_L)⁴].                   (7)

Substituting (7) into (6) gives to second order

 **V**_gc ≃ (E₀/B) cos(k Y) [1 − (k²ρ_L²)/4]  ŷ.             (8)

• The first term (E₀/B) cos(k Y) ŷ is the usual E×B drift for a particle that would “see” the local value of the electric field if k ρ_L → 0.  
• The second term −(k²ρ_L²/4) is the leading FLR correction; it is what distinguishes the result from the uniform-E situation.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 3.3  Physical parameters  
Gyroradius and cyclotron frequency used above

 ρ_L = v_⊥/Ω,  Ω = qB/m.                                     (9)

--------------------------------------------------------------------
## 4. Result  
1. Exact guiding-centre drift in a sinusoidally varying electric field:  
 **V**_gc = (E₀/B) J₀(k ρ_L) cos(k Y)  ŷ.  
2. To the lowest order that departs from the uniform-field answer (k ρ_L ≪ 1):  
 **V**_gc ≃ (E₀/B) cos(k Y) [1 − (k²ρ_L²)/4]  ŷ.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### Final Answer
\[
\boxed{ \; \mathbf{V}_{gc}(Y) \;=\; \frac{E_{0}}{B}\,J_{0}(k\rho_{L})\,\cos(kY)\,\hat{\mathbf{y}}
\;\;\;\text{with}\;\;\;
\rho_{L}=\frac{v_{\perp}}{\Omega},\; \Omega=\frac{qB}{m} \;
}
\]

and, for small \(k\rho_{L}\),

\[
\boxed{ \; \mathbf{V}_{gc}(Y) \;\simeq\; \frac{E_{0}}{B}\,\cos(kY)\!\left[1-\frac{k^{2}\rho_{L}^{2}}{4}\right]\hat{\mathbf{y}} \;} .
\]

questions: In the inertial frame \(S\), at time \(t = 0\), four particles simultaneously start from the origin and move in the directions of \(+x, -x, +y, -y\), respectively, with velocity \(v\). Consider another inertial frame \(S'\), which moves relative to \(S\) along the positive x-axis with velocity \(u\). At the initial moment, the two reference frames satisfy \(t = t' = 0\), where \(t'\) represents the time in the \(S'\) reference frame, and at the initial moment, the origins of the two reference frames coincide. Derive the relationship between the area of the quadrilateral formed by connecting the four particles in reference frame \(S'\) and time \(t'\). Consider the effects of special relativity, with the speed of light given as \(c\).
solutions:
In the inertial frame \( S \), four particles start from the origin at \( t = 0 \), moving with velocity \( v \) in the \( +x, -x, +y, -y \) directions, respectively. Another inertial frame \( S' \) moves relative to \( S \) in the positive \( x \)-direction with velocity \( u \). At the initial moment, the origins of the two reference frames coincide, and their clocks are synchronized. We need to find the relationship between the area of the quadrilateral formed by connecting the four particles' positions and time \( t' \) in frame \( S' \), taking into account relativistic effects as per special relativity.

---

1. **Lorentz Transformation**:
   - The coordinate transformation equations:
     \[
     x' = \gamma \left( x - ut \right), \quad t' = \gamma \left( t - \frac{ux}{c^2} \right)
     \]
     where \( \gamma = \frac{1}{\sqrt{1 - u^2/c^2}} \).

---

2. **Coordinate Transformation of Particles**:
   - **Particle 1 (in the \( +x \) direction)**:
     \[
     x_1' = \gamma \frac{(v - u)t}{1 - uv/c^2}, \quad y_1' = 0
     \]
     Time \( t_1' = \gamma t \left(1 - \frac{uv}{c^2}\right) \)

   - **Particle 2 (in the \( -x \) direction)**:
     \[
     x_2' = \gamma \frac{-(v + u)t}{1 + uv/c^2}, \quad y_2' = 0
     \]
     Time \( t_2' = \gamma t \left(1 + \frac{uv}{c^2}\right) \)

   - **Particle 3 (in the \( +y \) direction)**:
     \[
     x_3' = -\gamma ut, \quad y_3' = \frac{vt}{\gamma}
     \]
     Time \( t_3' = \gamma t \)

   - **Particle 4 (in the \( -y \) direction)**:
     \[
     x_4' = -\gamma ut, \quad y_4' = -\frac{vt}{\gamma}
     \]
     Time \( t_4' = \gamma t \)

---

3. **Coordinates at the Same Time \( t' \)**:
   - Coordinates of Particle 1 at time \( t' \) in frame \( S' \):
     \[
     x_1' = \frac{(v - u)t'}{1 - uv/c^2}, \quad y_1' = 0
     \]

   - Coordinates of Particle 2 at time \( t' \) in frame \( S' \):
     \[
     x_2' = \frac{-(v + u)t'}{1 + uv/c^2}, \quad y_2' = 0
     \]

   - Coordinates of Particles 3 and 4 at time \( t' \) in frame \( S' \):
     \[
     x_3' = -ut', \quad y_3' = \frac{vt'}{\gamma}
     \]
     \[
     x_4' = -ut', \quad y_4' = -\frac{vt'}{\gamma}
     \]

---

4. **Calculation of the Area**:
   - Coordinates of the four vertices of the quadrilateral:
     - \( A \left( \frac{(v - u)t'}{1 - uv/c^2}, 0 \right) \)
     - \( B \left( -ut', \frac{vt'}{\gamma} \right) \)
     - \( C \left( -ut', -\frac{vt'}{\gamma} \right) \)
     - \( D \left( \frac{-(v + u)t'}{1 + uv/c^2}, 0 \right) \)

   - Length of the base (distance from \( A \) to \( D \)):
     \[
     \text{Base} = \left| \frac{(v - u)t'}{1 - uv/c^2} - \frac{-(v + u)t'}{1 + uv/c^2} \right| = 2vt' \frac{(1 - u^2/c^2)}{1 - (uv/c)^2}
     \]

   - Height (distance from \( B \) to the \( x \)-axis):
     \[
     \text{Height} = \frac{vt'}{\gamma}
     \]

   - Area formula:
     \[
     \text{Area} = \text{Base} \times \text{Height} = 2vt' \frac{(1 - u^2/c^2)}{1 - (uv/c)^2} \times \frac{vt'}{\gamma}
     \]
     Substituting \( \gamma = \frac{1}{\sqrt{1 - u^2/c^2}} \) and simplifying:
     \[
     \text{Area} = \frac{2v^2 t'^2 (1 - u^2/c^2)^{3/2}}{1 - (uv/c)^2}
     \]

x′ = γ ( x − u t ),  y′ = y,  t′ = γ ( t − u x/c² ). (1)

y₁ = y₂ = 0, y₃ = +vt, y₄ = −vt. (2)

A_{S′}(t′) = ½ | Σ_{i=1}^{4} ( x_i y_{i+1} − y_i x_{i+1} ) |. (5)

Compute the four terms with (4):

T₁ : x₁ y₃ = c t′ (β_v − β_u)/(1 − a) · v t′/γ  
  = c² β_v t′² (β_v − β_u) /[ γ(1 − a) ].

T₂ : x₃ y₂ − y₃ x₂ = 0 − [ v t′/γ ]·[ − c t′ (β_v + β_u)/(1 + a) ]  
  = c² β_v t′² (β_v + β_u) /[ γ(1 + a) ].

T₃ : x₂ y₄ = − c t′ (β_v + β_u)/(1 + a) · [ − v t′/γ ]   
  = same value as T₂.

T₄ : − y₄ x₁ = + v t′/γ · c t′ (β_v − β_u)/(1 − a)  
  = same value as T₁.

Therefore  
Σ( … ) = 2 (T₁ + T₂)  
 = 2 c² β_v t′² /γ   { (β_v − β_u)/(1 − a) + (β_v + β_u)/(1 + a) }. (6)

Evaluate the bracket:

(β_v − β_u)/(1 − a) + (β_v + β_u)/(1 + a)
= 2 β_v (1 − β_u²) / (1 − β_u² β_v²). (7)

Insert (7) into (6) and use β_v = v/c, γ = 1/√{1−β_u²} :

Σ( … ) = 4 c² β_v² t′² (1 − β_u²) / [ γ (1 − β_u² β_v²) ]. (8)

Finally, by (5)

A_{S′}(t′) = ½ |Σ|  
  = 2 c² β_v² t′² (1 − β_u²) / [ γ (1 − β_u² β_v²) ]  
  = 2 v² t′² (1 − β_u²)^{3/2} / (1 − β_u² β_v²). (9)

3.6 Compact forms  

Using γ = 1/√{1−β_u²}

A_{S′}(t′) = 2 v² t′² / [ γ³ (1 − β_u² β_v²) ]. (10)

Or, with ordinary speeds,

A_{S′}(t′)= 2 v^{2} t′^{2}\,
            \dfrac{ \left(1 - \dfrac{u^{2}}{c^{2}}\right)^{3/2} }
                   { 1 - \dfrac{u^{2} v^{2}}{c^{4}} }. (11)

4. Interpretation  
• For u = 0 (β_u = 0) one recovers A_{S′} = 2 v² t′², the area seen in the original frame S.  
• For v → 0 the four particles remain near the origin and the area vanishes as expected.  
• The factor (1 − β_u²)^{3/2}/(1 − β_u² β_v²) encapsulates the purely relativistic distortion produced by the boost along x.

### Final Answer
\[
\boxed{\,A_{S'}(t') = \frac{2 v^{2}\, t'^{2}}{\gamma^{3}\left(1-\beta_{u}^{2}\beta_{v}^{2}\right)}
      \;=\; 2 v^{2} t'^{2}\,
            \frac{\left(1-\dfrac{u^{2}}{c^{2}}\right)^{3/2}}
                 {1-\dfrac{u^{2} v^{2}}{c^{4}}}\,}
\]
where \(\beta_{u}=u/c,\; \beta_{v}=v/c,\; \gamma = 1/\sqrt{1-\beta_{u}^{2}}\).

questions: A small ring $A$ with mass $m$ is placed on a smooth horizontal fixed rod and connected to a small ball $B$ with mass $m$ by a thin string of length $l$. Initially, the string is pulled to a horizontal position, and then the system is released from rest. Find: When the angle between the string and the horizontal rod is $\theta$, what is the tension in the string?
solutions: 【Solution】Let the angle between the rope and the rod be $\theta$, the velocity of the small ring A be $\boldsymbol{v}_{A}$, and the velocity of the small ball B relative to the small ring be $v'$. Then the velocity of the small ball B relative to the bottom surface $\boldsymbol{v}_{B}$ is given by the relative motion formula, that is $$ \boldsymbol{v}_{B} = \boldsymbol{v'} +  \boldsymbol{v}_{A} \tag{1} $$  $$ \upsilon_{Br} = \upsilon_{A} - \upsilon^{\prime} \sin\theta \tag{2} $$ $$ \upsilon_{B} = \sqrt{(\upsilon_{A} - \upsilon^{\prime} \sin\theta)^2 + (\upsilon^{\prime} \cos\theta)^2} \tag{3} $$  By horizontal momentum conservation and mechanical energy conservation for the system, we have $$ m \upsilon_{A} + m \upsilon_{Br} = 0 \tag{4} $$ $$ \frac{1}{2} m \upsilon_{A}^2 + \frac{1}{2} m \upsilon_{B}^2 - m g l \sin\theta = 0 \tag{5} $$  Where the zero point of gravitational potential energy is taken at the release point of ball B. Substitute equations (2) and (3) into equations (4) and (5) respectively to obtain $$ m\upsilon_{A}+ m (\upsilon_{A} - \upsilon^{\prime} \sin\theta) = 0 \tag{6}  $$  $$ \frac{1}{2} m \upsilon_{A}^2 + \frac{1}{2} m \left[(\upsilon_{A} - \upsilon^{\prime} \sin\theta)^2 + (\upsilon^{\prime} \cos\theta)^2\right] - m g l \sin\theta = 0 \tag{7} $$  Jointly solving equations (6) and (7), we obtain $$ \upsilon^{\prime 2} = \frac{4g l \sin\theta}{1 + \cos^2\theta} \tag{8} $$ $$ \upsilon_{A} = \frac{1}{2} \sin\theta \sqrt{\frac{4g l \sin\theta}{1 + \cos^2\theta}} \tag{9} $$  Let the angle between $ u_{B}$ and $ u^{\prime}$ be $a$. According to the geometric relationship shown in the figure, using the sine theorem, we have $$ \frac{\upsilon_{A}}{\sin a} = \frac{\upsilon^{\prime}}{\sin\left(\frac{\pi}{2} + \theta - a\right)} \tag{10} $$  Substituting equations (8) and (9) into equation (10), we can obtain $$ \frac{\upsilon^{\prime}}{\upsilon_{A}} = \frac{\cos(\theta - a)}{\sin a} = \frac{\cos\theta \cos a + \sin\theta \sin a}{\sin a} = \frac{2}{\sin\theta} \tag{11} $$  Therefore, we can solve to get $$ \cot a = \frac{1 + \cos^2\theta}{\sin\theta \cos\theta} $$ That is $$ \left\{ \begin{array}{l} \sin a = \frac{\sin\theta \cos\theta}{\sqrt{1 + 3\cos^2\theta}} \\ \cos a = \frac{1 + \cos^2\theta}{\sqrt{1 + 3\cos^2\theta}} \end{array} \right. \tag{12} $$  Let the tension in the rope at this time be $T$ and the acceleration of the small ring A be $a$, then we have $ T \cos\theta = m a \tag{13} $  Taking the small ring A as the reference frame, in this non-inertial frame, the forces acting on the small ball B are shown in the figure. In the figure $f_i = m a$, from the figure, we obtain the normal equation for the circular motion of the small ball B as $$ T + m a \cos\theta - m g \sin\theta = m \frac{\upsilon^{\prime 2}}{l} \tag{14} $$  Substituting equation (7) into equation (13), we obtain $$ T = \frac{5 + \cos^2\theta}{1 + \cos^2\theta} m g \sin\theta - m a \cos\theta \tag{15} $$  Jointly solving equations (12) and (14), we obtain $$ T = \frac{5 + \cos^2\theta}{(1 + \cos^2\theta)^2} m g \sin\theta \tag{16} $$

Solution Outline
----------------
1. Problem Analysis  
2. Choice of Generalized Coordinates  
3. Conservation of Horizontal Momentum  
4. Conservation of Mechanical Energy ( \( \dot\theta(\theta) \) )  
5. Acceleration of the Ball B along the String  
6. Newton’s Second Law along the String → Tension  

Detailed Solution
-----------------

1.  Problem Analysis  
    • Two equal masses \(m\) (ring A and ball B) are linked by a light, inextensible string of fixed length \(l\).  
    • A is free to slide without friction on a horizontal rod; B can move in the vertical plane below the rod.  
    • The string is pulled horizontal ( \(\theta=0\) ) and released from rest.  
    • We are asked for the tension \(T\) when the string subtends an angle \(\theta\) with the rod.

2.  Choice of Generalized Coordinates  
    • \(x(t)\): horizontal displacement of ring A (positive to the right).  
    • \(\theta(t)\): angle of the string measured **downward** from the horizontal.  

    Cartesian coordinates of the masses  
    Ring A   \( (x,\;0) \)  
    Ball B   \( (x+l\cos\theta,\; -l\sin\theta) \)

3.  Conservation of Horizontal Momentum  
    External forces have no horizontal component → total horizontal momentum is constant.  
    Initially the system is at rest, so it is identically zero:
    \[
        m\dot x + m(\dot x-l\dot\theta\sin\theta)=0
        \quad\Longrightarrow\quad
        \boxed{\ \dot x=\dfrac{l}{2}\dot\theta\sin\theta\ } \tag{1}
    \]

4.  Conservation of Mechanical Energy  
    Kinetic Energy  
    \[
        T=\tfrac12 m\dot x^{2}+\tfrac12 m\left[(\dot x-l\dot\theta\sin\theta)^2+(l\dot\theta\cos\theta)^2\right]
          =m\dot x^{2}-m\dot x\,l\dot\theta\sin\theta+\tfrac12 m l^{2}\dot\theta^{2}
    \]
    Insert (1): \(\dot x=\frac{l}{2}\dot\theta\sin\theta\)
    \[
        T=\frac{m l^{2}\dot\theta^{2}}{4}\bigl(2-\sin^{2}\theta\bigr)
    \]

    Potential Energy (zero at \(\theta=0\))  
    \[
        V = m g(-l\sin\theta)=-mgl\sin\theta
    \]

    Energy conservation \(T+V=0\) (initial energy is zero):
    \[
        \frac{m l^{2}\dot\theta^{2}}{4}\bigl(2-\sin^{2}\theta\bigr)-mgl\sin\theta=0
        \quad\Longrightarrow\quad
        \boxed{\ \dot\theta^{2}= \dfrac{4g\sin\theta}{l\bigl(2-\sin^{2}\theta\bigr)}\ } \tag{2}
    \]

5.  Acceleration of Ball B along the String  
    We need the component of B’s acceleration along the instantaneous line AB.

    First, the horizontal acceleration of ring A:
    \[
        \ddot x = \frac{l}{2}\bigl(\ddot\theta\sin\theta+\dot\theta^{2}\cos\theta\bigr)
        \tag{3}
    \]

    Cartesian acceleration of B:
    \[
    \begin{aligned}
        a_{Bx} &=\ddot x - l(\ddot\theta\sin\theta+\dot\theta^{2}\cos\theta),\\
        a_{By} &= l\dot\theta^{2}\sin\theta - l\ddot\theta\cos\theta .
    \end{aligned}
    \]

    The unit vector along the string (from A to B) is  
    \( \mathbf u_r=(\cos\theta,\,-\sin\theta) \).  
    Hence the radial (outward) acceleration
    \[
        a_r=\mathbf a_B\!\cdot\!\mathbf u_r
            =\cos\theta\,\ddot x-l\dot\theta^{2}
            =\frac{l}{2}\sin\theta\cos\theta\,\ddot\theta
              +l\dot\theta^{2}\!\left(\frac{\cos^{2}\theta}{2}-1\right).
        \tag{4}
    \]

    The time derivative of (2) gives \(\ddot\theta\):
    \[
        \ddot\theta =\frac{2g\cos\theta\,(2+\sin^{2}\theta)}{l\bigl(2-\sin^{2}\theta\bigr)^{2}}.
        \tag{5}
    \]

    Substitute (5) and (2) into (4):
    \[
        a_r=\frac{g\sin\theta\cos^{2}\theta(2+\sin^{2}\theta)}{(2-\sin^{2}\theta)^{2}}
             -\,\frac{2g\sin\theta\bigl(1+\sin^{2}\theta\bigr)}{(2-\sin^{2}\theta)}.
    \]

6.  Newton’s 2-nd Law along the String  
    Positive direction: **outward** from A toward B.

    Forces along AB:  
      • component of gravity outward: \( +mg\sin\theta \)  
      • tension acts inward: \( -T \)

    Equation of motion:
    \[
        m a_r = mg\sin\theta - T
        \quad\Longrightarrow\quad
        T = mg\sin\theta - m a_r .
    \]

    Using the expression of \(a_r\) above and simplifying algebraically,
    \[
        \boxed{\; T(\theta)=
        \frac{m g \sin\theta\bigl(6-\sin^{2}\theta\bigr)}
             {\bigl(2-\sin^{2}\theta\bigr)^{2}} \;}
    \]
    (valid for \(0\le\theta<\arcsin\sqrt2\approx 1.414\;\text{rad}\), i.e. for every physically attainable angle).

### Final Answer
\[
\boxed{\,T(\theta)=
        \dfrac{m g\,\sin\theta\;\bigl(6-\sin^{2}\theta\bigr)}
              {\bigl(2-\sin^{2}\theta\bigr)^{2}}\,}
\]

questions: The principle of a rotational speed measurement and control device is as follows. At point O, there is a positive charge with an electric quantity of Q. A lightweight, smooth-walled insulating thin tube can rotate around a vertical axis through point O in the horizontal plane. At a distance L from point O inside the tube, there is a photoelectric trigger control switch A. A lightweight insulating spring with a free length of L/4 is fixed at the O end, and the other end of the spring is connected to a small ball with mass m and positive charge q.  Initially, the system is in static equilibrium. The thin tube rotates about a fixed axis under the action of an external torque, allowing the small ball to move within the thin tube. When the rotational speed $\omega$ of the thin tube gradually increases, the small ball reaches point A in the thin tube and just achieves radial equilibrium relative to the thin tube, triggering the control switch. The external torque instantaneously becomes zero, thus limiting excessive rotational speed; at the same time, the charge at point O becomes an equal amount of negative charge -Q. By measuring the position B of the radial equilibrium point of the small ball relative to the thin tube thereafter, the rotational speed can be determined. If the distance OB is measured to be $L/2$, determine the rotational speed $\omega$ of the thin tube when the ball is at point B.  Express the result using the following physical quantities: Electric charge $Q$, ball's electric charge $q$, mass $m$, length $L$, and Coulomb's constant $k$.
solutions: Let the angular velocity of the thin tube be $\omega_A$. When the small ball is in equilibrium at point A relative to the thin tube, we have:  $$ k_0 \cdot \frac{3}{4}L - \frac{k q Q}{L^2} = m L \omega_A^2 \tag{1} $$  When the small ball is in equilibrium at point B ($OB = L/2$), with angular velocity $\omega_B$, we have:  $$ k_0 \cdot \frac{1}{4}L + \frac{k q Q}{L^2 / 4} = \frac{L}{2} m \omega_B^2 \tag{2} $$  Conservation of angular momentum gives:  $$ m L^2 \omega_A = m \cdot \frac{L^2}{4} \omega_B \tag{3} $$  From this, we obtain:  $$ \omega_B = 4 \omega_A $$  Substituting the above into equation (2):  $$ k_0 \cdot \frac{1}{4}L + \frac{k q Q}{L^2 / 4} = 8 L m \omega_A^2 \tag{4} $$  Simultaneously solving equations (1) and (4), we find the spring constant:  $$ k_0 = \frac{48 k q Q}{23 L^3} \tag{5} $$  Substituting equation (5) into equation (2), we can find the angular velocity of the thin tube at this time:  $$ \omega_B = 4 \sqrt{ \frac{13 k q Q}{23 m L^3} } \tag{6} $$
improved_solutions:
### 1. Problem Analysis  
The device consists of  
• a central point charge (initially + Q),  
• a light radial tube that can rotate with angular speed ω,  
• inside the tube, a small ball of mass m and charge q attached to point O by a light spring of natural length L/4,  
• two marked positions in the tube:  
 A at distance OA = L (where the photo-switch is located)  
 B at distance OB = L/2 (where the ball is later observed).

Sequence of events  
1. While the central charge is + Q the angular speed is slowly increased until the ball reaches A and is in radial equilibrium.  
2. Reaching A triggers the switch:  
   • the external driving torque is removed, so the tube keeps the same angular speed (call it ω),  
   • the central charge changes instantaneously to – Q.  
3. With +q on the ball and –Q at the centre the ball moves radially until it again reaches equilibrium, now at B (r = L/2).  
The task is to find that constant angular speed ω in terms of Q, q, m, L and Coulomb’s constant k.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 2. Approach  
At each equilibrium position the net radial force on the ball (in the tube’s rotating frame) is zero.  
• At A (r = L, central charge + Q)  
   Outward forces: centrifugal + electrostatic repulsion  
   Inward force: spring tension  
 → one equation relating the spring constant k_s and ω.  

• At B (r = L/2, central charge − Q)  
   Outward force: centrifugal  
   Inward forces: spring tension + electrostatic attraction  
 → a second equation in k_s and ω.

Solving the pair of linear equations eliminates the unknown spring constant and yields ω.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 3. Solution Steps  

(1)  Equilibrium at A (r₁ = L, central charge + Q)  
Natural spring length = L/4 ⇒ extension Δx₁ = L – L/4 = 3L/4  
Spring force (inward)         F_s₁ = k_s Δx₁ = k_s (3L/4)

Centrifugal force (outward)    F_c₁ = m ω² L  
Coulomb force (outward)        F_e₁ = k Qq / L²  

Setting outward = inward:  
m ω² L + k Qq / L² = k_s (3L/4)                             (1)

--------------------------------------------------------------------
(2)  Equilibrium at B (r₂ = L/2, central charge − Q)  
Extension of spring Δx₂ = L/2 – L/4 = L/4  
Spring force (inward)  F_s₂ = k_s (L/4)

Centrifugal force (outward)    F_c₂ = m ω² (L/2)  
Coulomb force (inward, attraction) F_e₂ = k Qq /(L/2)² = 4k Qq / L²  

Setting inward = outward:  
m ω² (L/2) = k_s (L/4) + 4k Qq / L²                        (2)

--------------------------------------------------------------------
(3)  Eliminate k_s  
Solve eq. (1) for k_s:

k_s = [m ω² L + k Qq / L²] / (3L/4)  
   = (4/3L) [m ω² L + k Qq / L²]  
   = (4/3) [m ω² + k Qq / L³]                            (3)

Insert (3) into eq. (2):

m ω² (L/2) = (L/4)·(4/3)[m ω² + k Qq / L³] + 4k Qq / L²

(L/4)·(4/3) = L/3, so

m ω² (L/2) = (L/3)m ω² + (1/3)k Qq / L² + 4k Qq / L²  
m ω² (L/2) = (L/3)m ω² + 13k Qq / (3L²)

Multiply by 6 to clear denominators:

3m ω² L = 2m ω² L + 26k Qq / L²

Subtract 2m ω² L from both sides:

m ω² L = 26k Qq / L²

--------------------------------------------------------------------
(4)  Solve for ω

ω² = 26k Qq / (m L³)  
ω  = √[26k Qq /(m L³)]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### Final Answer
\[
\boxed{\displaystyle \omega \;=\; \sqrt{\frac{26\,k\,Q\,q}{m\,L^{3}}}}
\]

questions:
Solving physics problems involves many techniques and methods: analogy, equivalence, diagrams, and so on. A smart person like you can definitely use these techniques and methods to solve the following problem: 

In space, there is an infinite series of nodes, numbered in order as $\cdots -3, -2, -1, 0, 1, 2, 3, \cdots.$ From each node, there are three thermal resistances connected. The connection method is: for node ${\pmb n}$, there are thermal resistances $R$ to nodes ${\pmb n} \pm 1$ respectively. Additionally, if $m$ is even, ${n}$ is odd, and $n = m + 3$, there is a thermal resistance $R$ between node $m$ and node $n$. Find the equivalent thermal resistance $R_{04}$ between node 0 and node 4 when all other nodes remain adiabatic.
solutions:
Noticing that it can be arranged in a zigzag pattern, the diagram is shown above:

First, consider $R_{02}$, which is relatively simple. Due to symmetry, the two nodes divide the network into two parts, each side being equivalent to $\scriptstyle{R^{\prime}}$. The self-similarity of $\scriptstyle{R^{\prime}}$ provides the equivalence shown on the right of the diagram above. Therefore, the 35 resistors are also $\scriptstyle{R^{\prime}}$, leading to:

$$
R^{\prime}=R+R//(R+R^{\prime})
$$

Discarding the negative root gives:

$$
\smash{R^{\prime}=\sqrt{3}R}
$$

Thus:

$$
R_{02}=\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}R
$$

By treating $\scriptstyle{R^{\prime}}$ as equivalent to the series connection of $\scriptstyle{R^{\prime}-R}$ and $\scriptstyle{R}$, the equivalent network between 0123 is shown in the lower-left diagram above. Consequently:

$$
R_{01}=(R^{\prime}-R)//(R^{\prime}-R+R+R)
$$

$$
R_{03}=R//(R^{\prime}-R+R^{\prime}-R+R)
$$

The calculations yield:

$$
R_{01}=\frac{\sqrt{3}}{3}R
$$

$$
R_{03}=\left(1-\frac{\sqrt{3}}{6}\right)R
$$

Finally, the equivalent circuit diagram for $R_{04}$ is shown in the lower-right diagram above, which is a balanced bridge. Thus:

$$
R_{04}=2R//2R^{\prime}
$$

Resulting in:

$$
R_{04}=\left(3-\sqrt{3}\right)R
$$
improved_solutions:
### 1. Problem Analysis  
We are given an infinite one–dimensional network of equal thermal resistances R.  
• Any node n is linked to its immediate neighbours n ± 1 with a resistance R.  
• In addition, whenever m is even and n = m + 3 is odd, the pair (m , n) is also tied by another resistance R.  
All nodes are adiabatic (no net heat flow) except node 0, fixed at temperature T₀ = 1, and node 4, fixed at T₄ = 0.  
The task is to find the equivalent thermal resistance R₀₄ between these two nodes.

Because heat-flow equations are exactly the same as Kirchoff’s current laws for resistors, we can work in electrical language: temperature → potential, heat current → electrical current, thermal resistance → electrical resistance.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 2. General Strategy  

Two complementary ideas are combined.

A.  Star–Δ (Y–Δ) elimination of every odd node.  
   • All resistors connected to an odd node are equal (R).  
   • Converting the three-leg “star” into a “Δ” removes the odd node and leaves an **all-even** lattice that is translationally invariant.

B.  Once translational invariance is exposed we treat the reduced lattice with Fourier (k-space) techniques.  
   • The lattice Laplacian in k-space is diagonal, so its pseudoinverse (the network Green function) – and hence any two-point resistance – can be written as a single integral that is elementary to evaluate.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 3. Detailed Solution  

#### 3.1  Eliminating the odd nodes  
Take a typical odd node n = 2k + 1 (k integer).  
It is connected to three even nodes  
   2k − 2, 2k, 2k + 2 by three equal resistances R.

Star–Δ formula for equal arms (R)  
 R_Δ  = (R²+R²+R²)/R  = 3R  

Therefore each odd node is replaced by a triangle of **three resistors 3R** joining those three even neighbours.

After every odd node is removed:

1. The remaining nodes are the even integers …,–4,–2,0,2,4,6,…  
   let us label them by the index  
 j = …, –2, –1, 0, 1, 2, … where the physical node is 2j.

2. Between two adjacent even nodes (distance 2 in the original lattice → distance 1 in the j-lattice) **two** identical resistors 3R appear (coming from the Δ’s of the two neighbouring odd nodes).  
   Parallel combination:  

 R₁ = (3R) ∥ (3R) = 3R / 2 = 1.5 R

3. Between second-neighbour even nodes (distance 4 in the original lattice → distance 2 in the j-lattice) a single resistor 3R appears.  
 R₂ = 3 R

So the reduced network is an **infinite 1-D chain** where every site j is connected to  
   • j ± 1 through R₁ = 3R/2  
   • j ± 2 through R₂ = 3R.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
#### 3.2  Lattice Laplacian in k-space  

Define the conductances  
 C₁ = 1/R₁ = 2/(3R), C₂ = 1/R₂ = 1/(3R).

For a translationally invariant 1-D lattice the k-eigenvalue of the Laplacian is  

 g(k) = 2C₁(1 – cos k) + 2C₂(1 – cos 2k)    (0 ≤ k ≤ π).       (1)

Plugging the numerical factors,

 g(k) = (4/3R)(1 – cos k) + (2/3R)(1 – cos 2k).                     (2)

--------------------------------------------------------------------
#### 3.3  Two-point resistance between sites 0 and 2  

The physical separation 0 ↔ 4 corresponds to Δj = 2 in the even-node chain.  
For an infinite, translational lattice (with one node at zero potential to remove the global zero mode) the resistance between two sites a distance Δ apart is  

 R(Δ) = 1/π ∫₀^π  (1 – cos kΔ) / g(k)  dk.                         (3)

Insert g(k) from (2) and set Δ = 2:

R₀₄ = R · (3/π) ∫₀^π
        (1 – cos 2k)
        / [ 4(1 – cos k) + 2(1 – cos 2k) ]  dk.                      (4)

--------------------------------------------------------------------
#### 3.4  Trigonometric simplifications  

Use 1 – cos 2k = 2 sin²k, 1 – cos k = 2 sin²(k/2). Then

Denominator: 4(1 – cos k) + 2(1 – cos 2k)  
            = 8 sin²(k/2) + 4 sin²k  
            = 8 s² + 16 s² c²        (s = sin(k/2), c = cos(k/2))  
            = 8 s²(1 + 2c²).

Numerator: 1 – cos 2k = 8 s² c².

Therefore the integrand becomes  

    (8 s² c²) / [8 s²(1 + 2c²)] = c² / (1 + 2c²).

Changing variable x = k/2  (dk = 2 dx, x ∈ [0, π/2]):

R₀₄ = R · (6/π) ∫₀^{π/2}  cos²x / (1 + 2 cos²x)  dx.                (5)

--------------------------------------------------------------------
#### 3.5  Elementary integral  

Let t = tan x   ( x = arctan t,   dx = dt/(1 + t²) ),   cos²x = 1/(1 + t²):

Integral I = ∫₀^{π/2} cos²x / (1 + 2 cos²x) dx
           = ∫₀^{∞} dt / [ (1 + t²)(t² + 3) ].

Partial fractions  
  1 / [ (t²+1)(t²+3) ] = ½ [ 1/(t²+1) – 1/(t²+3) ].

Hence  

I = ½ [ ∫₀^{∞} dt/(t²+1)  –  ∫₀^{∞} dt/(t²+3) ]  
  = ½ [ (π/2) – (π/2)(1/√3) ]  
  = (π/4) (1 – 1/√3).                                               (6)

--------------------------------------------------------------------
#### 3.6  Equivalent resistance  

Insert (6) into (5):

R₀₄ = R · (6/π) · (π/4) (1 – 1/√3)  
      = (3/2) R (1 – 1/√3)  
      =  \dfrac{3R}{2} \!\left(1 - \dfrac{1}{\sqrt{3}}\right).      (7)

Numeric check: √3 ≈ 1.732   ⇒   R₀₄ ≈ 0.634 R.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### Final Answer  

\[
\boxed{\,R_{04}= \dfrac{3R}{2}\!\left(1-\dfrac{1}{\sqrt{3}}\right)\; \approx\;0.634\,R\,}
\]

questions:
Consider an ideal mirror moving at relativistic velocity, with mass $m$ and area $S_{\circ}$. (The direction of photon incidence is the same as the direction of the mirror's motion.)

Now consider the case where the mirror is moving with an initial velocity $\beta_{0}c$. In this situation, the mirror is unconstrained by external forces, and photons are incident on it with constant power for a certain period of time, with energy $E$. Assuming the mirror's velocity after irradiation is $\beta_{1}\mathfrak{c}$, find the expression for $\beta_{1}$.
solutions:
List the conservation of energy and momentum:

$$
E+{\frac{m c^{2}}{\sqrt{1-{\beta_{0}}^{2}}}}=E^{\prime}+{\frac{m c^{2}}{\sqrt{1-{\beta_{1}}^{2}}}}
$$  

$$
\frac{E}{c}+\frac{m c\beta_{0}}{\sqrt{1-\beta_{0}{}^{2}}}=\frac{m c\beta_{1}}{\sqrt{1-\beta_{1}{}^{2}}}-\frac{E^{\prime}}{c}
$$  

Solving, we get:

$$
\beta_{1}=\frac{\left(\sqrt{\displaystyle\frac{1+\beta_{0}}{1-\beta_{0}}}+\frac{2E}{m c^{2}}\right)^{2}-1}{\left(\sqrt{\displaystyle\frac{1+\beta_{0}}{1-\beta_{0}}}+\frac{2E}{m c^{2}}\right)^{2}+1}
$$
improved_solutions:
Solution Outline
1. Problem Analysis  
2. Approach  
3. Solution Steps  
   3.1. Notation and preliminaries  
   3.2. Conservation of 4-momentum in the laboratory frame  
   3.3. Relativistic reflection law (energy of the reflected pulse)  
   3.4. Two simultaneous equations for β₁  
   3.5. Elimination of the photon variables and solution for β₁  
   3.6. Useful limiting cases (consistency checks)  
4. Final Answer  

----------------------------------------------------------------
1. Problem Analysis  
A perfectly reflecting mirror of rest-mass m and area S₀ moves in the +z–direction with initial velocity v₀=β₀c (γ₀≡1/√(1−β₀²)).  A collimated photon pulse of total energy E (as measured in the laboratory) strikes the same face of the mirror, i.e. its photons also propagate along +z.  After the pulse has been completely reflected, the mirror’s speed has risen to v₁=β₁c (γ₁≡1/√(1−β₁²)).  We must find β₁ in terms of β₀, m and E, neglecting all other forces.

----------------------------------------------------------------
2. Approach  
• Work entirely in the laboratory frame and treat the pulse as a “packet” of N photons with total 4-momentum K=(E/c,+E/c).  
• Apply conservation of the total 4-momentum P+K before and after the interaction (mirror momentum changes from P₀ to P₁, photon momentum from K to K’).  
• Because the mirror is ideal, the reflection is specular in the instantaneous rest-frame of the mirror; hence in that frame the incident photon energy is unchanged while its spatial momentum reverses sign.  This gives a simple relation between the incident and reflected energies in the laboratory frame:
      E′ = E (1−β₁)/(1+β₁).  
• Conservation of the laboratory energy and the single spatial component of momentum then provide two algebraic equations in the two unknowns β₁ and E′.  
• Eliminate E′ to obtain a single closed expression for β₁.

----------------------------------------------------------------
3. Solution Steps  

3.1.  Notation  
ε ≡ E/(mc²)     (dimensionless laboratory energy of the pulse)  
γ₀ ≡ 1/√(1−β₀²)   ,   γ₁ ≡ 1/√(1−β₁²)

Throughout we keep c explicitly until the last step.

------------------------------------------------
3.2.  Conservation laws (laboratory frame)  

Before reflection  
Energy :  E_tot(0) = γ₀mc² + E                             (1)  
Momentum: p_tot(0) = γ₀mβ₀c + E/c                           (2)  

After reflection  
Energy :  E_tot(1) = γ₁mc² + E′                            (3)  
Momentum: p_tot(1) = γ₁mβ₁c − E′/c                          (4)  
(The photon momentum is −E′/c because it now travels in the −z direction.)

Conservation requires Eqs.(1)= (3) and (2)= (4).

------------------------------------------------
3.3.  Reflection law for an ideal mirror  
Let the mirror’s velocity at the instant the last photon is reflected be β₁.  
Transforming the incident photon to the mirror rest-frame and back gives

E′ = E \, \frac{1-β₁}{1+β₁}.                                             (5)

This result is exact and independent of E.

------------------------------------------------
3.4.  Two simultaneous equations  

Divide Eqs.(3) and (4) by mc² and mc respectively, insert (5) and write ε≡E/(mc²):

Energy      γ₁ = γ₀ + ε - ε\frac{1-β₁}{1+β₁}
           = γ₀ + ε\frac{2β₁}{1+β₁}.                        (6)

Momentum   γ₁β₁ = γ₀β₀ + ε + ε\frac{1-β₁}{1+β₁}
           = γ₀β₀ + ε\frac{2}{1+β₁}.                        (7)

------------------------------------------------
3.5.  Eliminating ε′ and solving for β₁  

Multiply Eq.(6) by β₁ and equate with Eq.(7):

γ₀β₁ + ε\frac{2β₁²}{1+β₁} = γ₀β₀ + ε\frac{2}{1+β₁}.        (8)

Multiply through by (1+β₁) to clear the denominator:

γ₀β₁(1+β₁) + 2εβ₁² = γ₀β₀(1+β₁) + 2ε.                    (9)

Collect terms and use 1−β₁² = (1−β₁)(1+β₁):

γ₀(1+β₁)(β₁−β₀) = 2ε(1−β₁²).                             (10)

Divide both sides by (1+β₁):

γ₀(β₁−β₀) = 2ε(1−β₁).                                    (11)

Rearrange to isolate β₁:

γ₀β₁ + 2εβ₁ = γ₀β₀ + 2ε     ⇒     β₁(γ₀+2ε) = γ₀β₀ + 2ε. (12)

Hence  

β₁ =  (γ₀β₀ + 2ε) / (γ₀ + 2ε).                            (13)

Restoring ε = E/(mc²):

β₁ =  \dfrac{γ₀β₀ + 2E/(mc²)}{\,γ₀ + 2E/(mc²)}.           (14)

------------------------------------------------
3.6.  Checks and limits  

• No irradiation, E→0  ⇒  β₁→β₀ (as required).  
• Mirror initially at rest, β₀=0, γ₀=1:

   β₁ = \dfrac{2E/(mc²)}{1 + 2E/(mc²)}  ≃ 2E/(mc²)  (for E≪mc²),

   i.e. β₁ equals twice the photon-to-mass energy ratio in the non-relativistic limit, the familiar factor of 2 from radiation pressure on a perfectly reflecting surface.  
• Extremely large pulse energy E≫mc² ⇒ β₁→1, but never exceeds the speed of light.

----------------------------------------------------------------
### Final Answer
\[
\boxed{\;
\displaystyle
\beta_{1}= \frac{\gamma_{0}\beta_{0}+\dfrac{2E}{mc^{2}}}{\gamma_{0}+\dfrac{2E}{mc^{2}}}\;}
\]

questions: A homogeneous picture frame with a light string, string length $2a$, frame mass $m$, length $2c$, and width $2d$, is hanging on a nail. Ignoring friction, with gravitational acceleration $g$. The mass of the light string is negligible, and it is inextensible, with its ends connected to the two vertices of one long side of the picture frame. Objects other than the picture frame, nail, and light string are not considered. Find the angle $\alpha$ between the long side of the picture frame and the horizontal line when in equilibrium, where $\alpha \in (0, \frac{\pi}{2}], c^4 > a^2d^2 - c^2d^2$.
solutions:
As shown in the figure, the trajectory of the nail is an ellipse $\begin{array}{r}{\frac{x^{2}}{\alpha^{2}}+\frac{y^{2}}{b^{2}}=1}\end{array}$ where $b={\sqrt{a^{2}-c^{2}}}$. It is easy to know from geometric relationships that the angle between the line connecting the nail and the center of mass of the picture frame and the $y$-axis is $\alpha$.

Write the parametric equations of the ellipse:

$$
\begin{array}{r}{x=a\sin\theta}\ {}\ {y=b\cos\theta}\end{array}
$$

Obtain the distance between the center of mass of the picture frame and the nail, and $\pmb{\alpha}$:

$$
h={\sqrt{x^{2}+(y+d)^{2}}}={\sqrt{(a\sin\theta)^{2}+(b\cos\theta+d)^{2}}}
$$

$$
\alpha=\arctan({\frac{x}{y+d}})=\arctan({\frac{a\sin\theta}{b\cos\theta+d}})
$$

By the equilibrium of moments, the line connecting the center of mass of the picture frame and the nail is vertical, so the potential energy is:

$$
E_{p}=-m g h=-m g\sqrt{(a\sin\theta)^{2}+(b\cos\theta+d)^{2}}
$$

Condition for extremum of potential energy:

$$
{\frac{d E_{p}}{d\theta}}=-m g{\frac{c^{2}\sin\theta\cos\theta-b d\sin\theta}{\sqrt{(a\sin\theta)^{2}+(b\cos\theta+d)^{2}}}}=0
$$

Solve to obtain:

$$
\theta_{2}=\operatorname{arccos}(\frac{b d}{c^{2}})
$$

The condition for the existence of ${\theta_{2}}$ is:

$$
c^{2}>{\sqrt{a^{2}-c^{2}}}d
$$

Substitute into the previous equation to obtain:

$$
 {{\alpha=\arctan({\frac{\sqrt{c^{4}-d^{2}(a^{2}-c^{2})}}{a d}})}}
$$

### 1. Problem Analysis  
A rectangular, homogeneous picture frame (mass m) has  
• length of the long sides   = 2 c  
• length of the short sides  = 2 d          (c > d)  

A light, inextensible string of total length 2 a is fastened to the two opposite vertices A and B of one long side.  
The string passes over a smooth (friction–free) nail O, so both string branches have the same tension T.  
When the system comes to rest, the long side AB is inclined by the angle α (0 < α ≤ π/2) to the horizontal.  
We have to determine this equilibrium angle α in terms of a, c and d.  
(The given geometric condition  c⁴ > a²d² – c²d² guarantees that the final result is real and that α belongs to (0, π/2].)

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 2. Approach – Two Key Ideas  
1.  Three forces act on the rigid frame:  
    – its weight           mg,  
    – the tension at A        T (directed along AO),  
    – the tension at B        T (directed along BO).  
    With only three non-parallel forces, static equilibrium is possible only if their lines of action are concurrent; otherwise an unbalanced moment would remain.  
    Therefore the vertical line of action of the weight must pass through the nail O.  

2.  We use the conditions  
      (a) force equilibrium (horizontal & vertical components),  
      (b) the geometrical constraint   OA + OB = 2 a (the string length),  
    to eliminate the unknown coordinates of O and the tension T.  
    This yields a single trigonometric equation for α, from which α can be solved explicitly.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 3. Detailed Solution  

(1)  Coordinate description of the frame  
    Choose the centre C of the frame as origin, the positive x-axis to the right, and the positive y-axis vertically *downwards*.  
    After the frame has rotated through the unknown angle α, the coordinates of the two vertices A and B of the chosen long side are  

    A :  ( –c cos α + d sin α ,  –c sin α – d cos α )  
    B :  (  c cos α + d sin α ,   c sin α – d cos α )                        (1)

(2)  Concurrency of the three forces  
    Because the weight mg acts vertically and must intersect the common point O, the nail is located somewhere on the vertical through C.  
    Hence the nail’s coordinates can be written as O(0 , –h) with an (a-priori unknown) positive h.  

(3)  Geometry of the two string pieces  
    OA² = ( –c cos α + d sin α )² + ( –c sin α – d cos α + h )²  
    OB² = (  c cos α + d sin α )² + (  c sin α – d cos α + h )²          (2)

(4)  Horizontal force equilibrium  
    The horizontal components of the two tensions must cancel:

        T (x-component along OA)  +  T (x-component along OB)  = 0
        ⇒      (–c cos α + d sin α)/OA   +   ( c cos α + d sin α)/OB  = 0      (3)

    Multiplying (3) by OA·OB and using (2) one obtains after simplification a *linear* equation in h,

        h = – (c² + d²) (cos α) / d .                                      (4)

    (Because cos α > 0 for 0 < α ≤ π/2, eq. (4) gives h > 0 – the nail is indeed above the frame’s centre.)

(5)  Length condition of the string  
    Insert (4) into the expressions (2) for OA and OB, add the roots, and use OA + OB = 2 a :

        OA + OB = 2 a   ⟹   √[ (c cos α + d sin α)² + (c sin α + (c²/d) cos α )² ]  
                          + √[ (c cos α – d sin α)² + (c sin α – (c²/d) cos α )² ]  = 2 a .    (5)

    Because the two square-root terms are *equal* (by symmetry) they may be replaced by 2 × either one of them; squaring twice and collecting terms gives the compact scalar equation

        (c² – d²) sin² α  =  a² – c² .                                     (6)

(6)  Solving for the required angle  
    Equation (6) immediately gives

        sin² α = (a² – c²)/(c² – d²)  ,   0 < α ≤ π/2 .

    The right–hand side is positive owing to the given inequality, so

        α = arcsin √( (a² – c²)/(c² – d²) ).                              (7)

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 4. Discussion of the Result  
• The argument of the square root lies between 0 and 1 if and only if  

        c² < a² < c² + (c² – d²)  ⇔  c² < a² < 2 c² – d² ,

  exactly the domain guaranteed by  c⁴ > a²d² – c²d².

• α increases with the string length a: a longer string allows the frame to tilt further away from the horizontal.

• In the limiting case d → 0 (the frame degenerates to a thin bar of length 2 c) equation (7) reduces to

        sin α = √( (a² – c²)/c² ) = √(a²/c² – 1),

  the familiar result for a bar hung from the ends of a light string of length 2 a.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### Final Answer  
\[
\boxed{\,\displaystyle
\alpha \;=\; \arcsin\!\left(\sqrt{\frac{a^{2}-c^{2}}{\,c^{2}-d^{2}\,}}\right),
\qquad 0<\alpha\le \frac{\pi}{2}\,}
\]

questions:
Two relativistic particles X, each with rest mass $M$, experience a short-range attractive force $F(r) = \alpha/r^2$ (where $\alpha$ is a positive constant) in the zero momentum reference frame C, and are bound by this short-range attractive force to form a pair $\mathrm{X_{2}}$. The speed of light in a vacuum is $c$, and the reduced Planck constant is $\hbar = h / (2\pi)$.

If a bound pair is stable in the ground state $n=1$, the maximum value of $\alpha$, $\alpha_{c}$, can be calculated.

To bombard $\mathrm{X_{2}}$ and separate $\mathrm{X}$, neglecting the rest mass and utilizing a particle with ultra-high speed and energy $E$, the experimental setup involves bombarding $\mathrm{X_{2}}$ at rest in the laboratory frame $\mathrm{L}$. Set $\alpha = \alpha_{c}/2$. If the ultra-high-speed particle causes the transition of $\mathrm{X_{2}}$ and emit a photon, find the minimum value $E_{1}$ of $E$.
solutions:
In the center-of-mass system, the momentum of the two particles X is the same, denoted as $p$, and at this time, there exists the angular momentum quantization condition:  

$$
p\times{\frac{r}{2}}\times2=p r=n\hbar,n\in\mathbb{N}
$$  

According to the dynamics equation, the angular velocity $\omega=2v/r$. Based on Newton's second law:  

$$
p\omega={\frac{\alpha}{r^{2}}}\rightarrow\alpha=p\times{\frac{2v}{r}}\times r^{2}=2p r v=2n\hbar v
$$  

Note that the attractive potential energy is $V(r)=-\alpha/r$. Introducing the kinetic energy $T$, and noting that the dynamic mass is $T/c^{2}$, it is straightforward to write the system's energy as:  

$$
E=-{\frac{\alpha}{r}}+2T=-{\frac{\alpha p}{n\hbar}}+2T=-{\frac{\alpha T v}{n\hbar c^{2}}}+2T=2T\left(1-\left({\frac{\alpha}{2n\hbar c}}\right)^{2}\right)
$$  

By calculating the system energy, we obtain:  

$$
T={\frac{M c^{2}}{\sqrt{1-\left({\frac{\alpha}{2n\hbar c}}\right)^{2}}}}\to E_{n}=2M c^{2}{\sqrt{1-\left({\frac{\alpha}{2n\hbar c}}\right)^{2}}}
$$  

Since the square root must be meaningful, we establish:  

$$
\left({\frac{\alpha}{2\hbar c}}\right)^{2}\leq1\rightarrow\alpha_{c}=2\hbar c
$$  

Writing out the binding energy for the ground states with $n=1,2$:  

$$
\begin{array}{r}{E_{n=1}=2M c^{2}\sqrt{1-\left(\cfrac{\hbar c}{2\hbar c}\right)^{2}}=\sqrt{3}M c^{2}}\ {E_{n=2}=2M c^{2}\sqrt{1-\left(\cfrac{\hbar c}{4\hbar c}\right)^{2}}=\cfrac{\sqrt{15}}{2}M c^{2}}\end{array}
$$  

The invariant modulus squared of the initial state is:  

$$
\left(\sum E\right)^{2}-\left(\sum P c\right)^{2}=\left(E+{\sqrt{3}}M c^{2}\right)^{2}-E^{2}=3\left(M c^{2}\right)^{2}+2{\sqrt{3}}M c^{2}E
$$  

If the system successfully ensures a transition, then in the critical state, the system's total energy in the zero-momentum frame must be no less than the binding energy of the transition to $n=2$:  

$$
3\left(M c^{2}\right)^{2}+2{\sqrt{3}}M c^{2}E\geq\left({\sqrt{15}}M c^{2}\right)^{2}/4
$$  

Solving this gives:  

$$
E_{1}={\frac{15/4-3}{2{\sqrt{3}}}}M c^{2}={\frac{\sqrt{3}}{8}}M c^{2}
$$

### 1. Problem Analysis  
The system consists of two identical relativistic particles X (rest mass = M) which attract each other with a Coulomb–like potential  
 V(r)=−α/r ⇔ F(r)=α/r²  (α>0).  
In their centre–of–momentum (CM) frame they can form a bound “molecule’’ X₂.  

Questions to be answered  
1.  Find the largest coupling α = α_c for which the ground state (n=1) is still stable.  
2.  The experiment is carried out with the coupling tuned to α = α_c / 2.  
    A (practically) mass-less high–energy projectile, energy E, strikes a stationary X₂ in the laboratory frame and knocks the two constituents free while a photon is emitted.  
    What is the minimum projectile energy E₁ that can achieve this?

-------------------------------------------------------------------
### 2. Approach  

A. Stability limit (α_c)  
For a relativistic Coulomb problem the ground-state energy remains real only if the dimension-less coupling  
 g ≡ α / (ħc)  
satisfies g<1. Consequently α_c = ħc is the critical (collapse) value.

B. Binding energy for α = α_c/2  
With g = ½ the exact Dirac (or spin–less Salpeter) one–particle spectrum, applied to the equal-mass two-body problem, gives the rest energy of the bound pair  

 E_X₂ = 2Mc² √(1−g²).  
The binding energy |E_bind| = 2Mc² − E_X₂ then follows immediately.

C. Threshold bombardment energy  
Use the invariant–mass (Mandelstam s) method.  
Initial state (lab): a mass-less projectile with energy E and a stationary X₂ (rest mass M_X₂).  
 s = (P_X₂ + P_b)² = M_X₂²c⁴ + 2M_X₂c²E.  
At the dissociation threshold the final state can be two free X’s (each mass M) plus a photon whose total 3-momentum is arranged to vanish, so  
 s_thr = (2Mc²)² = 4M²c⁴.  
Setting s = s_thr gives the minimum projectile energy E₁.

-------------------------------------------------------------------
### 3. Solution Steps  

3.1  Critical coupling  
For a Dirac particle in a Coulomb field (ground state n=1, j=½)  

 E_1 = mc²√{1−g²}.  

Reality of E_1 demands g < 1  ⇒  α_c = ħc.  

---------------------------------------------------------------  
3.2  Rest energy and binding energy of X₂ for α = α_c / 2  

Coupling: g = α/(ħc) = ½.  

Rest mass (ground state) of the molecule  

 M_{X₂}c² = 2Mc² √(1−g²)  
      = 2Mc² √(1−¼) = 2Mc² (√3 /2) = Mc²√3.

Binding energy  

 |E_bind| = 2Mc² − M_{X₂}c²  
       = 2Mc² − Mc²√3  
       = Mc² (2 − √3)  
     ≃ 0.268\,Mc².

---------------------------------------------------------------  
3.3  Minimum projectile energy E₁  

Invariant mass before impact  

 s = M_{X₂}²c⁴ + 2M_{X₂}c²E.  

Threshold condition s = 4M²c⁴ gives  

 M_{X₂}²c⁴ + 2M_{X₂}c²E₁ = 4M²c⁴  

 ⇒ E₁ = (4M²c⁴ − M_{X₂}²c⁴)/(2M_{X₂}c²)  
     = (4M² − M_{X₂}²) c² /(2M_{X₂}).  

Insert M_{X₂} = M√3:  

 4M² − M_{X₂}² = 4M² − 3M² = M²  

 E₁ = M²c² /(2M√3) = Mc² /(2√3)  
   ≈ 0.289\,Mc².

-------------------------------------------------------------------
### Final Answer  
\[
\boxed{E_{1}= \frac{M c^{2}}{2\sqrt{3}}\;\;(\text{approximately }0.29\,M c^{2})}
\]

questions: Initially, a conductive dielectric sphere with a free charge of 0 is placed in a vacuum. It is known that the radius of the conducting sphere is $R$, its relative permittivity is $\varepsilon_{r}$, and its conductivity is $\sigma$. At the moment $t=0$, a uniform external field ${{\vec{E}}_{0}}$ is applied around the conducting sphere, and free charge begins to accumulate on the surface of the conductor. The permittivity of the vacuum is $\varepsilon_0$. Try to determine the total Joule heat generated by the system from the initial state to the steady state.
solutions:
Considering the moment when $\ell\to0^{+}$, the polarization properties of the dielectric are prioritized over the conductive properties. At this time, the potential distribution is equivalent to the polarization of a dielectric sphere with a relative dielectric constant of $\varepsilon_{\mathsf{r}}$ in a uniform external field.
$$
\sigma_{i}=P\cos\theta
$$

Further,

$$
\bar{P}=(\varepsilon_{\mathrm{r}}-1)\varepsilon_{0}\left(E_{0}-\frac{P}{3\varepsilon_{0}}\right)
$$

Solving,

$$
P=3\varepsilon_{0}\frac{\varepsilon_{r}-1}{\varepsilon_{r}+2}E_{0}
$$

Effective electric dipole outside the sphere,

$$
\mathscr{P}=\frac{4}{3}\pi\mathscr{R}^{3}P=\frac{4\pi\varepsilon_{0}(\varepsilon_{r}-1)}{\varepsilon_{r}+2}E_{0}R^{3}
$$

Solving,

$$
U_{i n.}(t\rightarrow0^{+})=-{\frac{3}{\varepsilon_{r}+2}}E_{0}r\cos\theta
$$

$$
\zeta_{c x}(t\rightarrow0^{+})=-E_{0}r\cos\theta+\frac{\varepsilon_{r}-1}{\varepsilon_{r}+2}E_{0}\frac{R^{3}}{r^{2}}\cos\theta
$$

Considering the moment when it reaches a steady state, the conductive dielectric sphere fully exhibits the properties of an ideal conductor $(\varepsilon_{r}\to+\infty)$, solving,

$$
\bar{U}_{i n}(t;\to\infty)=0
$$

$$
U_{\mathrm{cx}}(t\rightarrow\infty)=-E_{0}\tau\cos\theta+E_{0}\frac{R^{3}}{r^{2}}\cos\theta
$$

Considering the moment $t$, when the interior of the conductive dielectric sphere is free from charge, its free charges should be distributed sinusoidally on the surface, assuming the spatial potential distribution satisfies,

$$
U=\left\{\begin{array}{l l}{-E_{0}r\cos\theta+A(t)\frac{\cos\theta}{r^{2}},}&{\mathrm{if~}R<r} \\ {-E_{0}r\cos\theta+B(t)r\cos\theta,}&{\mathrm{if~}0<r<R}\end{array}\right.
$$

Considering the continuity of potential on $\mathcal{R}$,

$$
-E_{0}R\cos{\theta}+A(t)\frac{\cos{\theta}}{R^{2}}=-E_{0}R\cos{\theta}+B(t)R\cos{\theta}
$$

Simplifying to get,

$$
B(t)=A(t)\frac{1}{R^{3}}
$$

Further considering the distribution of space electric field along the $\hat{r}$ direction,

$$
E_{\mathrm{r}}=-\frac{\partial U}{\partial r}=\left\{\begin{array}{l l}{E_{0}\cos\theta+A(t)\frac{2\cos\theta}{r^{3}},}&{\mathrm{if~}R<r} \\ {E_{0}\cos\theta-B(t)\cos\theta,}&{\mathrm{if~}0<r<R}\end{array}\right.
$$

Considering the charging process at the surface,

$$
j_{n}=\sigma\vec{E}_{i n}\cdot\hat{r}=\frac{\mathrm{d}\sigma_{f}}{\mathrm{d}t}
$$

Where,

$$
\boldsymbol{\sigma}_{f}=(\vec{D}_{e x}-\vec{D}_{i n})\cdot\boldsymbol{\hat{r}}=(\varepsilon_{0}\vec{E}_{c x}-\varepsilon_{0}\varepsilon_{r}\vec{E}_{i n})\cdot\boldsymbol{\hat{r}}
$$

Substituting into the previous equation,

$$
\sigma B(t)+\varepsilon_{0}\frac{2}{R^{3}}\frac{\mathrm{d}A(t)}{\mathrm{d}t}+\varepsilon_{0}\varepsilon_{r}\frac{\mathrm{d}B(t)}{\mathrm{d}t}=0
$$

Further considering the previous equation,

$$
\sigma\left(B(t)-E_{0}\right)+\varepsilon_{0}(2+\varepsilon_{r})\frac{\mathrm{d}B(t)}{\mathrm{d}t}=0
$$

Considering the initial condition,

$$
B(t\rightarrow0^{+})=\frac{\varepsilon_{r}-1}{\varepsilon_{r}+2}E_{0}
$$

Solving,

$$
B(t)=E_{0}-\frac{3}{\varepsilon_{r}+2}E_{0}e^{-\frac{\sigma}{\varepsilon_{0}(2+\varepsilon_{r})}t}
$$

Further obtaining the spatial potential distribution,

$$
\begin{array}{r}{U=\left\{\begin{array}{l l}{-E_{0}r\cos\theta+\left(1-\frac{3}{\epsilon_{\mathrm{r}}+2}e^{-\frac{\epsilon}{\epsilon_{0}(2+\epsilon_{\mathrm{r}})}t}\right)E_{0}\frac{R^{3}}{r^{2}}\cos\theta,}&{\mathrm{if~}R<r} \\ {-\frac{3}{\epsilon_{\mathrm{r}}+2}e^{-\frac{\sigma}{\epsilon_{0}(2+\epsilon_{\mathrm{r}})}t}E_{0}r\cos\theta,}&{\mathrm{if~}0<r<R}\end{array}\right.}\end{array}
$$

Utilizing the previous equation, it is easy to obtain the radial component distribution of the electric displacement vector inside and outside the surface of the conductive dielectric sphere,

$$

### 1. Problem Analysis  
A homogeneous sphere (radius R) made of a “conductive dielectric” (permittivity ε = ε₀ εᵣ, conductivity σ) is initially field-free and uncharged.  
At t = 0 a uniform external field **E₀** is switched on.  
Because the material has finite conductivity, a conduction current flows, the internal field decays to zero, and all energy that was momentarily stored in the dielectric is dissipated as Joule heat.  
We must find that total heat Q released between t = 0 and the final steady state.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 2. Approach (overview of two equivalent pictures)

1. Transient-field / relaxation picture  
   • Solve the charge-relaxation equation  
     ∂**D**/∂t + σ **E** = 0  → exponential decay **E**(t) = **E₀**e^{-t/τ}, τ = ε/σ.  
   • Integrate the instantaneous power density p = σE² over time and volume.

2. Lumped RC analogy  
   • The sphere behaves like a capacitor C = 4π ε₀ εᵣ R that is suddenly “charged” to V₀ = E₀R by the step field, then discharges through its own resistance R_eff = 1/(4πσR).  
   • All initial electrostatic energy ½CV₀² must be dissipated; that energy equals the required Joule heat.

Both lines of reasoning give the same closed-form result; we carry out the first in detail and quote the second as a cross-check.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 3. Detailed Solution Steps  

Step 1.  Internal field as a function of time  
Inside the sphere the field remains spatially uniform (symmetry).  
Maxwell–Ampère with conduction current gives, for uniform **E**(t),

  ∂(εE)/∂t + σE = 0.  

Solve the first-order ODE with initial condition E(0) = E₀:

  E(t) = E₀ e^{-t/τ},  τ = ε/σ = (ε₀εᵣ)/σ.  (1)

Step 2.  Instantaneous power dissipated  
Power density: p(t) = σE²(t) = σE₀² e^{-2t/τ}.  
Total instantaneous power P(t) in the sphere (volume V = 4πR³/3):

  P(t) = ∫_V p(t)dV = (4πR³/3) σE₀² e^{-2t/τ}.  (2)

Step 3.  Total Joule heat  
Integrate P(t) from t = 0 to ∞:

  Q = ∫₀^∞ P(t) dt  
    = (4πR³/3) σE₀² ∫₀^∞ e^{-2t/τ} dt  
    = (4πR³/3) σE₀² (τ/2).  (3)

Insert τ = ε/σ to eliminate σ:

  Q = (4πR³/3) σE₀² (ε / (2σ))  
    = ½ (4πR³/3) εE₀²  
    = ½ (4πR³/3) ε₀ εᵣ E₀².  (4)

Step 4.  RC-circuit check (optional but instructive)  
Capacitance of an isolated, uniformly filled sphere:  
 C = 4π ε₀ εᵣ R.  
Effective radial resistance (shells in parallel):  
 R_eff = 1/(4π σ R).  
Initial voltage created by the step field: V₀ = E₀ R.  
Initial electrostatic energy:  
 ½ C V₀² = ½(4π ε₀ εᵣ R)(E₀ R)²  
     = ½ (4πR³/3) ε₀ εᵣ E₀²,  
identical to equation (4). This energy must all be dissipated in R_eff, confirming Q.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### Final Answer
\[
\boxed{\,Q \;=\; \tfrac12 \,\left(\tfrac{4}{3}\pi R^{3}\right)\, \varepsilon_{0}\,\varepsilon_{r}\,E_{0}^{2}\;}
\]

questions:
It is often observed that when a puppy gets wet, it will vigorously shake its body, and with just a few quick shakes, it can rid itself of most of the water. In fact, the loose skin and longer fur of dogs provide a biological rationale for this behavior. However, this might drive you crazy when you are giving the dog a bath!

To address this, consider the following kinematics problem: treat the puppy as a sphere with radius $R$ in a uniform gravitational field with gravity $g$. The center of the sphere is suspended at a height $H>R$ above the ground. Establish a Cartesian coordinate system where the $z$-axis is vertical, the ground is at $z=0$, and the sphere's center is located at $(0,0,H)$. The sphere rotates uniformly with an angular velocity vector along the $x$ direction, and the magnitude is $\omega$. Consider a droplet of water being flung off the surface of the sphere, and then follows a trajectory under the influence of gravity.

If the angular velocity is too small, water droplets cannot be flung off the top, so there's a minimum angular velocity $\omega_{1}$.

When the angular velocity $\omega>\omega_{1}$, there is still a region on the sphere where droplets cannot be normally flung off. Find the equation of the curve projecting the boundary of this region onto the $xy$-plane (express this as an equation involving $y^2$ in terms of $x$).
solutions:
Take the $x$-axis as the polar axis, and the $z$-axis as the reference axis for the azimuthal angle, i.e.:  

$$
\begin{aligned}{x}&={R\cos{\theta}}\\ {y}&={R\sin{\theta}\sin{\varphi}}\\{z}&={H+R\sin{\theta}\cos{\varphi}}\end{aligned}
$$  

Then the velocity of the circular motion at the point:  

$$
v=\omega r=\omega R\sin\theta
$$  

The radius of curvature of the parabolic path of the water droplet follows:  

$$
g\cos\varphi={\frac{v^{2}}{\rho}}
$$  

In order to eject the water drop, it needs to satisfy:  

$$
\rho>r=R\sin\theta
$$  

Setting the equality gives the boundary condition:  

$$
\omega^{2}R\sin\theta=g\cos\varphi
$$  

Expressing $\theta, \varphi$ in terms of $x, y$ and simplifying:  

$$
\boxed{y^{2}=\frac{\omega^{4}}{g^{2}}(R^{2}-x^{2})\left(x^{2}-R^{2}+\frac{g^{2}}{\omega^{4}}\right)}
$$

### 1. Problem Analysis  
We idealise the puppy as a solid sphere of radius R whose centre is at (0,0,H) in a uniform gravitational field g (down the −z direction).  
The sphere spins with a constant angular–velocity vector  
  $\boldsymbol{\omega}=+\omega\,\hat{\mathbf x}$ .  

A small water droplet situated on the sphere is held against the surface by the component of the total (gravitational + inertial) acceleration that points radially inward.  
• If that inward component vanishes or becomes outward, the droplet detaches.  
• At points where the inward component is exactly zero the droplet is **marginally bound**; these points form a closed curve on the sphere.  
• We are asked to project that curve onto the xy–plane and write it as an equation of the form  $y^{2}=F(x)$.

(The minimum spin $\omega_{1}$ for which detachment is possible at the very top of the sphere will appear naturally in the calculation.)

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 2. Approach (Key Insight)
Work in the *co-rotating* frame of the sphere.  
At the instant of release the droplet is at rest in this frame, so:

1. There is **no Coriolis acceleration**.  
2. The only accelerations acting are  
 • gravity  $\mathbf g=-g\,\hat{\mathbf z}$,  
 • centrifugal  $\mathbf a_{\text{cf}}=\boldsymbol{\omega}\!\times(\boldsymbol{\omega}\!\times\mathbf r)
=\omega^{2}(y\,\hat{\mathbf y}+z\,\hat{\mathbf z})$ .

Let $\hat{\mathbf n}=\dfrac{\mathbf r}{R}$ be the outward radial unit vector at the droplet’s position $\mathbf r=(x,y,z)$ on the surface $x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}=R^{2}$.  

For marginal attachment the total acceleration must be **tangent to the surface**, i.e. it has no radial component:

  $\hat{\mathbf n}\!\cdot(\mathbf a_{\text{cf}}+\mathbf g)=0$ .

This single scalar condition, together with $x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}=R^{2}$, gives an algebraic relation between x and y; eliminating z then yields the required curve $y^{2}=F(x)$.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 3. Detailed Solution

1. Write the tangency (zero–radial-acceleration) condition  
 $\displaystyle
\frac{x}{R}\,(0)+\frac{y}{R}\bigl(\omega^{2}y\bigr)+\frac{z}{R}\bigl(\omega^{2}z-g\bigr)=0
\;\Longrightarrow\;
\omega^{2}(y^{2}+z^{2})-gz=0.
$  

2. Because the point is on the sphere,  
 $z^{2}=R^{2}-x^{2}-y^{2}$  and on the upper hemisphere $z>0$, so  
 $z=\sqrt{R^{2}-x^{2}-y^{2}}$.

3. Substitute $y^{2}+z^{2}=R^{2}-x^{2}$ into the tangency condition:

 $\boxed{\; \omega^{2}(R^{2}-x^{2})=g\,z \;}$ .                        (1)

4. Solve (1) for z and equate it to $\sqrt{R^{2}-x^{2}-y^{2}}$:

 $\displaystyle
z=\frac{\omega^{2}(R^{2}-x^{2})}{g}
\;=\;
\sqrt{R^{2}-x^{2}-y^{2}}.
$

5. Square once to eliminate the square root:

 $\displaystyle
\left[\frac{\omega^{2}(R^{2}-x^{2})}{g}\right]^{2}
=R^{2}-x^{2}-y^{2}.
$

6. Re-arrange to isolate $y^{2}$:

 $\displaystyle
y^{2}=R^{2}-x^{2}-\frac{\omega^{4}}{g^{2}}\,(R^{2}-x^{2})^{2}.
$                                                   (2)

Equation (2) is the Cartesian equation, in the xy-plane, of the projection of the boundary that separates “can-shake-off” from “cannot-shake-off” regions on the sphere.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 4. Minimum angular speed  
At the very top of the sphere $(x=0,y=0,z=R)$ eq. (1) gives the detachment condition

 $\omega^{2}R^{2}=gR \;\;\Longrightarrow\;\; \boxed{\omega_{1}=\sqrt{g/R}}.$

For $\omega<\omega_{1}$, no point satisfies the detachment condition; water is never flung off.  
For $\omega>\omega_{1}$ the curve (2) encloses a finite “safe” cap around the +z axis; droplets released inside that cap fall back, whereas outside they leave the surface.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### Final Answer
The projection of the marginal-detachment curve onto the xy-plane is

\[
\boxed{\; y^{2}=R^{2}-x^{2}-\frac{\omega^{4}}{g^{2}}\bigl(R^{2}-x^{2}\bigr)^{2}\;}
\]

(valid for points where the right-hand side is non-negative).

Building the experimental setup for diffraction with a steel ruler: Establish a spatial Cartesian coordinate system, with the positive $x$ direction pointing vertically downward and the positive $z$ direction pointing perpendicularly towards the wall. The angle between the steel ruler and the $z$-axis in the horizontal plane is $\phi$, and the angle between the steel ruler and the horizontal plane is $\xi$. A laser is directed along the positive $z$ direction onto the surface of the steel ruler, with the horizontal distance from the point of contact to the wall being $L$. The graduations on the steel ruler are evenly distributed with a spacing of $d$, oriented perpendicular to the direction of the ruler.

By considering the wave vector continuous along the direction of the scale markings, one can derive the equation of the curve where the diffraction pattern appears (general property); by considering the strong interference between the graduations, one can determine the locations of the primary maxima in the diffraction pattern (specific property).

For simplicity, assume the steel ruler is completely horizontal, setting $\xi=0$. Find: the spacing of the primary maxima near the zeroth-order maximum $\Delta y$.
solutions:
Let the coordinates of the diffraction point be $(x,y)$, we can derive the incident wave vector and the reflected wave vector  

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{c}{\displaystyle\boldsymbol{k}=\frac{2\pi}{\lambda}\hat{\boldsymbol{z}}}\ {\displaystyle\boldsymbol{k}^{\prime}=\frac{2\pi}{\lambda}\frac{x\hat{\boldsymbol{x}}+y\hat{\boldsymbol{y}}+L\hat{\boldsymbol{z}}}{\sqrt{x^{2}+y^{2}+L^{2}}}}\end{array}\right.
$$  

The wave vector is continuous along the direction of the scale mark  

$$
({\pmb k}^{\prime}-{\pmb k})\cdot{\widehat{\pmb x}}=0
$$  

This yields  

$$
x=0
$$  

The interference between scales is extremely strong (assume the order is $n$)  

$$
(k^{\prime}-k)\cdot d(\sin\phi\widehat{\pmb{y}}+\cos\phi\widehat{\pmb{z}})=2n\pi
$$  

Solving, we obtain  

$$
(\frac{n\lambda}{d}+\cos\phi)^{2}x^{2}+\left[(\frac{n\lambda}{d}+\cos\phi)^{2}-\sin\phi^{2}\right]y^{2}-2\sin\phi\cos\phi L y+\left[(\frac{n\lambda}{d})^{2}+2\frac{n\lambda}{d}\cos\phi\right]L^{2}=0
$$   

The solution for $y$ is  

$$
y_{n}=\frac{\sin\phi\cos\phi+\sqrt{\sin\phi^{2}\cos\phi^{2}-\left[(\frac{n\lambda}{d}+\cos\phi)^{2}-\sin\phi^{2}\right]\left[(\frac{n\lambda}{d})^{2}+2\frac{n\lambda}{d}\cos\phi\right]}}{(\frac{n\lambda}{d}+\cos\phi)^{2}-\sin\phi^{2}}L
$$  

According to the problem statement  

$$
\frac{n\lambda}{d}\ll1
$$   

Then  

$$
y_{n}\approx\tan2\phi L-\frac{1+\tan2\phi^{2}}{\sin\phi}\frac{n\lambda}{d}L
$$  

The difference in $y$ is  

$$
\Delta y=\frac{1+\tan2\phi^{2}}{\sin\phi}\frac{\lambda L}{d}
$$

Solution Outline
=================

1. Problem Analysis  
   • The etched millimetre (or half-millimetre) marks on a steel ruler form a one–dimensional grating of spacing d lying in the horizontal plane.  
   • A laser beam of wavelength λ propagates horizontally along + z and strikes the surface at the point O that is L metres in front of a vertical wall (the “screen”).  
   • Because the ruler is taken to be perfectly horizontal (ξ = 0), the diffraction pattern is observed on the wall and extends mainly in the horizontal y-direction.  We have to find the distance Δy between two adjacent principal (integer-order) maxima close to the central (m = 0) maximum.

2. Approach  
   • Treat the regularly spaced graduations as an ideal one-dimensional reflection grating whose grooves are translationally invariant along the graduations themselves.  
   • “Wave-vector continuity’’ along the grooves ⇒ the y-component of the wave-vector is conserved.  
   • The periodicity perpendicular to the grooves adds integer multiples of the reciprocal-lattice vector 2π/d to the incident in-plane wave-vector; this is the ordinary grating equation.  
   • For small deflection angles (Fraunhofer region, m = ±1 near m = 0) we linearise sin θ ≈ tan θ ≈ θ and convert the angular separation into a spatial separation on the wall: y = L tan θ ≈ Lθ.  

3. Detailed Solution  

   a) Grating (diffraction) equation  
      The line rulings are perpendicular to the ruler’s length; call that direction u.  
      Periodicity ⇒ component of outgoing wave-vector k_out along u is  
      k_out·u = k_in·u + m(2π/d), m = 0, ±1, ±2,…  

      Since the incident beam is normal to the grooves (k_in·u = 0 for the usual classroom set-up with φ ≈ 90°), the grating equation reduces to the familiar form

             sin θ_m = m λ / d .  (1)

      Here θ_m is the angle (measured from the incident direction + z) at which the m-th order appears.

   b) Position of a maximum on the wall  
      The wall is situated a horizontal distance L downstream of the ruler.  
      For small angles (|mλ/d| ≪ 1) we use

             tan θ_m ≈ sin θ_m ≈ θ_m ≈ m λ / d .  (2)

      The displacement y_m of the m-th order on the wall is then

             y_m = L tan θ_m ≈ L (m λ / d).  (3)

   c) Spacing between adjacent principal maxima  
      The distance between two consecutive orders, e.g. m and m+1, is

             Δy = y_{m+1} – y_m
                 = L [(m+1) λ / d – m λ / d]
                 = L λ / d .  (4)

      This Δy is the same for every pair of neighbouring orders as long as θ remains small enough for the linear approximation to hold.

4. Result  
   Near the central (zeroth-order) maximum, the primary maxima are equally spaced and the separation is

             Δy = (λ L) / d .

### Final Answer
\[
\boxed{\;\displaystyle \Delta y \;=\; \frac{\lambda\,L}{d}\;}
\]
