Solution to the Problem  

------------------------------------------------
1. Problem Analysis  
The system consists of  
• a mass-less string of length l₁ that makes an angle θ₁ with the downward vertical and rotates with angular velocity ω₁ = θ̇₁,  
• a uniform thin rod AB of mass m and length l₂ whose centre of mass G is at mid-length.  
The rod makes an angle θ₂ with the vertical and spins with angular velocity ω₂ = θ̇₂ about G.  
Gravity is the only external force that can produce a moment about the rod’s centre of mass; the string tension does no work about G.  
We are asked to obtain the instantaneous angular acceleration  
 α₂ ≡ θ̈₂  
solely in terms of l₁ , l₂ , θ₁ , θ₂ , ω₁ , ω₂ and g.

2. Choice of Method  
A Lagrangian formulation automatically eliminates the unknown string tension and gives the two coupled equations of motion in the generalized coordinates (θ₁ , θ₂).  Algebraic elimination of θ̈₁ from this 2×2 linear system yields the required explicit expression for α₂.

3. Detailed Solution  

3.1 Kinematics  
Set O as the origin, +x to the right, +y upward.  
Position of the rod’s centre of mass G:

 r_G = ( x_G , y_G )  
   = ( l₁ sin θ₁ + (l₂/2) sin θ₂ ,   –l₁ cos θ₁ – (l₂/2) cos θ₂ ).          (1)

Its velocity magnitude is  

 v_G² = ẋ_G² + ẏ_G²  
     = l₁² ω₁² + (l₂² /4) ω₂² + l₁ l₂ ω₁ ω₂ cos Δ , Δ ≡ θ₁ – θ₂.          (2)

The rod’s moment of inertia about G is  

 I_G = m l₂² /12 .                                                    (3)

3.2 Energies  
Kinetic energy  

 T = ½ m v_G² + ½ I_G ω₂²  
   = ½ m l₁² ω₁² + ½ m l₁ l₂ ω₁ ω₂ cos Δ + 1/6 m l₂² ω₂² .           (4)

Potential energy (taking V = 0 at O):

 V = – m g [ l₁ cos θ₁ + (l₂/2) cos θ₂ ].                              (5)

Lagrangian  

 L(θ₁,θ₂,ω₁,ω₂) = T – V .                                            (6)

3.3 Euler–Lagrange Equations  
Compute ∂L/∂ωᵢ and ∂L/∂θᵢ (i = 1,2) and apply  

 d/dt (∂L/∂ωᵢ) – ∂L/∂θᵢ = 0.                                       

After straightforward differentiation the two equations are

(1) l₁² θ̈₁ + (l₁ l₂ /2) cos Δ θ̈₂ + (l₁ l₂ /2) sin Δ ω₂² + g l₁ sin θ₁ = 0 ,  

(2) (l₁ l₂ /2) cos Δ θ̈₁ + (l₂² /3) θ̈₂ – (l₁ l₂ /2) sin Δ ω₁² + (g l₂ /2) sin θ₂ = 0.  (7)

3.4 Eliminate θ̈₁  
Let  

A = l₁², B = (l₁ l₂ /2) cos Δ, C = l₂² /3.                         (8)

Rewrite (7) in matrix form  

 A θ̈₁ + B θ̈₂ = – (l₁ l₂ /2) sin Δ ω₂² – g l₁ sin θ₁ ,  
 B θ̈₁ + C θ̈₂ =  (l₁ l₂ /2) sin Δ ω₁² – g (l₂/2) sin θ₂ .              (9)

Solve the linear system for θ̈₂ (α₂).  Eliminating θ̈₁ gives

 θ̈₂ = [ (l₁ l₂ /2) sin Δ ω₁² – (g l₂ /2) sin θ₂ + (B/A)(l₁ l₂ /2) sin Δ ω₂²  
     + (B/A) g l₁ sin θ₁ ] / ( C – B²/A ).                          (10)

Insert A, B, C from (8) and simplify:

Denominator:  C – B²/A = (l₂² /3) – (l₂² /4) cos² Δ  
        = (l₂² /12) (1 + 3 sin² Δ).                            (11)

Numerator reduces to

 (l₂ /2) [ 2 l₁ ω₁² sin Δ + l₂ ω₂² sin Δ cos Δ + 2 g (cos Δ sin θ₁ – sin θ₂) ].  (12)

Combine (11) and (12):

 α₂ = θ̈₂ = 3 [ l₂ ω₂² sin Δ cos Δ + 2 l₁ ω₁² sin Δ  
        + 2 g ( cos Δ sin θ₁ – sin θ₂ ) ]  
     / { l₂ [ 1 + 3 sin² Δ ] }.                                   (13)

3.5 Final Form  
Using Δ ≡ θ₁ – θ₂ and the given symbols ω₁, ω₂, θ₁, θ₂, l₁, l₂, g, eq. (13) is already in the required explicit form and contains no other quantities.

------------------------------------------------
### Final Answer
\[
\boxed{ \;
\alpha_{2}= \frac{3\Bigl[\,l_{2}\,\omega_{2}^{2}\,\sin(\theta_{1}-\theta_{2})\cos(\theta_{1}-\theta_{2}) 
\;+\; 2l_{1}\,\omega_{1}^{2}\,\sin(\theta_{1}-\theta_{2}) 
\;+\; 2g\bigl(\cos(\theta_{1}-\theta_{2})\sin\theta_{1}-\sin\theta_{2}\bigr) \Bigr]}
{\,l_{2}\bigl(1+3\sin^{2}(\theta_{1}-\theta_{2})\bigr)} \;}
\]

questions: Xiao Ming discovered an elliptical plate at home with semi-major and semi-minor axes of \( A \) and \( B \), respectively. Using one focus \( F \) as the origin, a polar coordinate system was established such that the line connecting the focus and the vertex closest to the focus defines the polar axis direction. Through extremely precise measurements, it was found that the mass surface density satisfies the equation \(\sigma = \sigma_{0}(1 + e\cos\varphi)^3\), where \( e \) is the eccentricity of the ellipse. When the plate's major axis is positioned vertically and released from rest on a sufficiently rough tabletop, the plate moves only within the plane it lies in. Find the angular acceleration \(\beta\) of the plate when the major axis becomes horizontal.
solutions:
At this time, the angular velocity is $\omega$, the angular acceleration is $\beta$, and the acceleration of the center of mass is $a_{x}, a_{y}$.

The moment of inertia about the instantaneous center $\mathrm{P}$ is $I_{P}=I+m A^{2}$.

From the conservation of energy, the contact condition at point P gives the acceleration  
$a = \omega^2 \rho = \omega^2 \frac{A^2}{B}$.

Considering the rotational theorem about the instantaneous center:  
$I_{P} \vec{\beta} = \vec{M} - m \vec{r}_{c} \times \vec{a}$

We obtain:  

$$
I_{P} \beta = m \sqrt{A^2 - B^2} \bigg(g + \omega^{2} \frac{A^{2}}{B} \bigg)
$$

$$
\beta = 4A \sqrt{A^2 - B^2} g \frac{2A^{4} + 2A^{3} \sqrt{A^2 - B^2} - A^{3}B + B^{4}}{(2A^{3} + B^{3})^{2}B}
$$
improved_solutions:
Solution to the Elliptical Plate Problem
-----------------------------------------

1. Problem Analysis  
   A thin elliptical plate (semi-axes A and B, eccentricity e) is standing vertically on a rough, horizontal table.  
   • The plate is released from rest with its major axis vertical (θ = 0).  
   • It can rotate only in its own plane about the line of contact with the table (a friction hinge).  
   • The surface–mass density is σ = σ₀(1+e cos φ)³, where φ is the polar angle measured from the focus that is nearest to the vertex used as the polar axis (focus chosen as the origin).  
   Required: the angular acceleration β when the plate has turned through 90° so that its major axis is horizontal (θ = 90°).

2. General Approach  
   a) Determine the total mass, centre of mass (COM) and the centroidal moment of inertia Iz,G of the plate.  
   b) Locate the instantaneous hinge O (the vertex in contact with the table) and, by the parallel-axis theorem, obtain the moment of inertia about that hinge, Iz,O.  
   c) At θ = 90° the lever-arm of the weight about O is simply the focus–vertex distance d.  The gravitational torque τz is therefore Mg d.  
   d) Apply Euler’s rotational equation about O: τz = Iz,O β.

3. Detailed Solution  

   3.1  Geometry in focus polar coordinates  
        For an ellipse whose focus is at the origin and whose closest vertex lies on the polar axis (φ = 0)  
                     r(φ) = p /(1+e cos φ),  with p = A(1–e²) = B²/A.            (1)

   3.2  Mass of the plate  
        Using an area element dA = r dr dφ,
        M = ∬ σ dA
          = σ₀ ∫₀^{2π} ∫₀^{r(φ)} (1+e cos φ)³ r dr dφ
          = σ₀ ∫₀^{2π} (1+e cos φ)³ [½r²]₀^{r(φ)} dφ                           (2)

        Substitute r(φ) from (1).  The factor (1+e cos φ)³ cancels one power in the denominator:
        M = σ₀ ½p² ∫₀^{2π} (1+e cos φ) dφ = σ₀ ½p² (2π) = σ₀ π p².            (3)

   3.3  Centre of mass  
        x-coordinate (focus taken as the origin)
        Nx = ∬ x dm = σ₀∬ r cos φ·(1+e cos φ)³ r dr dφ
           = σ₀ ⅓ ∫₀^{2π} p³ cos φ dφ = 0.                                  (4)

        A similar calculation gives Ny = 0.  
        Hence the COM lies exactly at the focus: G ≡ F.

   3.4  Centroidal moment of inertia about the axis normal to the plate (z-axis)  
        Iz,G = ∬ r² dm
             = σ₀∬ r²·(1+e cos φ)³ r dr dφ
             = σ₀ ¼ ∫₀^{2π} p⁴ /(1+e cos φ) dφ
             = σ₀ ¼ p⁴ · 2π /√(1–e²)                                       (5)

        Using (3): M = σ₀πp² ⇒ σ₀ π = M/p²  
        Iz,G = (M/p²)·(¼)·p⁴·2π/π√(1–e²)
             = ½ M p² /√(1–e²).                                            (6)

        In terms of A and B (B = A√(1–e²)):
        Iz,G = ½ M A²(1–e²)^{3/2} = ½ M B³/A.                              (7)

   3.5  Hinge position and parallel-axis transfer  
        The plate rests on the vertex nearest to the focus.  The distance from the focus (G) to this vertex is  
                    d = r_min = p/(1+e) = A(1–e).                            (8)

        Moment of inertia about the contact line O (axis z through that vertex)
        Iz,O = Iz,G + M d²
             = ½ MA²(1–e²)^{3/2} + M A²(1–e)².                              (9)

   3.6  Gravitational torque at θ = 90°  
        When the plate has rotated 90° the straight line OG joins O to G horizontally; the weight acts vertically through G, giving the moment arm d.  
        τz = M g d = M g A(1–e).                                          (10)

   3.7  Angular acceleration  
        τz = Iz,O β  ⇒
        β = τz / Iz,O
          = M g A(1–e) / { ½ MA²(1–e²)^{3/2} + M A²(1–e)² }
          =  g(1–e) / [ A( ½(1–e²)^{3/2} + (1–e)² ) ].                     (11)

        Check (circular plate, e = 0): β = 2g/3A, the well-known result.

4. Result  

   The angular acceleration of the plate when its major axis has become horizontal is  

   β = g(1-e) \; \bigg/ 
       \Bigl[\, A\!\left(\tfrac12(1-e^2)^{3/2} + (1-e)^2\right) \Bigr].  

   In terms of A and B (B = A√(1–e²)) one may write equivalently  

   β = \dfrac{2gA(1-e)}
            {\,A^2(1-e^2)^{3/2}+2A^2(1-e)^2\,}
     = \dfrac{2g(1-e)}
            {\,A\!\left[(1-e^2)^{3/2}+2(1-e)^2\right]}.                 (12)

Either form is acceptable; both reduce correctly to β = 2g/3A when e = 0.

### Final Answer
\[
\boxed{ \displaystyle
\beta
 = \frac{g\,(1-e)}
        {\,A\!\left[\tfrac{1}{2}(1-e^{2})^{3/2} + (1-e)^{2}\right]} }
\]

questions: \"Choose a sodium lamp for Young's double-slit interference experiment. The wavelengths of the sodium lamp's double yellow lines are $\lambda_{1}$ and $\lambda_{2}$ respectively. Due to a very small wavelength difference, the higher-order interference fringes on the screen will become blurred. Neglecting the width of the slits themselves, introduce the contrast function $\gamma \equiv\frac{I_{max}-I_{min}}{I_{max}+I_{min}}$ to measure the clarity of the interference. When $\gamma = 0$, the fringes will become blurred. Additionally, if the background light intensity becomes $1/e$ of the system's maximum possible light intensity, it will also cause the observer to subjectively perceive the interference fringes as too dim, leading to blurriness.  If the width of the double slits is $d$ and the horizontal distance from the screen to the double slits is $L$. Use a filter to filter out the light with a wavelength of $\lambda_{1}$. Due to the broadening of the spectral line caused by the thermal motion of molecules in the sodium lamp, if the temperature of the sodium lamp is $T$ and the mass of the sodium atom is $m$, try to calculate the position where the fringes become blurred for the first time. Assume that the sodium atoms follow the Maxwell velocity distribution law (and that the problem can be solved using the far-field condition).
solutions: Examine the effect of monochromatic light on the screen:  $$  U = U_0 \left( e^{i k \cdot \frac{d x}{L}} + 1 \right) $$  The resulting light intensity is:  $$  I = U \cdot U^* = U_0^2 \left(2 + 2\cos\left(k \cdot \frac{d x}{L}\right)\right) = I_0 \left(1 + \cos\left(k \cdot \frac{d x}{L}\right)\right) $$  For Doppler frequency shift due to thermal motion, examine the Doppler effect of electromagnetic waves:  $$  \frac{k}{k_0} = \frac{\sqrt{1 - \beta^2}}{1 - \beta \cos\theta} \approx 1 + \beta \cos\theta = 1 + \frac{v_x}{c} \quad $$  For particles with horizontal velocity in the interval $v - v + \mathrm{d}v$ (in terms of emitted light intensity), we have:  $$  \frac{\mathrm{d}I}{I_0} = f_x(v) \, \mathrm{d}v \quad $$  For light intensity on the screen:  $$  I  \propto \int f_x(v)\,\mathrm{d}v \cos\frac{k_0 \left(1 + \frac{v_x}{c}\right) d x}{L}\ = \int f_x(v)\,\mathrm{d}v \left( \cos\frac{k_0 d x}{L}\cos\frac{v k_0 d x}{L c}\ - \sin\frac{k_0 d x}{L}\sin\frac{v k_0 d x}{L c} \right) \quad  $$  Notice that the second term is an odd function, and its integral equals 0. The integral of the first term is calculated as:  $$  s_1 = \operatorname{Re} \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \sqrt{\frac{m}{2\pi k T}} e^{- \frac{m v^2}{2k T} + i \frac{v k_0 d x}{L c}} \, \mathrm{d}v =  e^{\frac{\frac{k_0 d x^2}{L c}}{\frac{2m}{k T}}} \quad $$  When it decreases to $\frac{1}{e}$, the background light will become blurred, thus:  $$  \frac{\frac{k_0 d x^2}{L c}}{\frac{2m}{k T}} = 1 \quad $$  Solve for:  $$  x = \sqrt{\frac{2m}{k T}} \cdot \frac{L c \lambda_2}{2\pi d} \quad $$
improved_solutions:
\section*{Problem Analysis}
Young’s double–slit is illuminated with the yellow $D_{1}$ line of a sodium lamp.  
Because the emitting Na atoms move thermally, each atom sees its own Doppler–shifted wavelength.  
The resulting spectral line is no longer perfectly monochromatic; its finite width reduces the temporal coherence of the light.  
When the optical path difference $\Delta$ between the two slits becomes large enough,

1. the fringe visibility (contrast) $\displaystyle \gamma=\frac{I_{\max}-I_{\min}}{I_{\max}+I_{\min}}$ falls to $\gamma=0$ (practically to $1/e$), and/or  
2. the average irradiance on the screen drops to $1/e$ of the theoretical maximum,

the interference pattern looks “blurred’’.  
The question is: at what {\em transverse} coordinate $y$ on the screen does this first occur, expressed in terms of the apparatus parameters $d,\;L$ and the lamp parameters $T,\;m,\;\lambda_{1}$?

\section*{Approach}
1.  Treat the residual $\lambda_{1}$ line that passes the filter as a {\bf Gaussian} spectrum created by the Maxwell velocity distribution of sodium atoms (Doppler broadening).  
2.  For a Gaussian spectrum the fringe visibility in a two–beam interferometer is
   $\displaystyle \gamma(\Delta)=\exp\!\bigl[-(2\pi\sigma_\lambda\Delta/\lambda_{0}^{2})^{2}\bigr]$.
3.  Setting either $\gamma=1/e$ or the irradiance to $I/I_{\max}=1/e$ yields the same {\em coherence length} $\Delta_{\text{blur}}$.  
4.  Under Fraunhofer (far-field) conditions the geometric relation $\Delta \simeq d\,y/L$ converts this longitudinal path difference into a screen coordinate $y_{\text{blur}}$.

\section*{Detailed Solution}

\subsection*{1. Doppler broadening of the sodium line}
For motion along the line of sight the Doppler shift is  
\[
\Delta\lambda=-\frac{v}{c}\lambda_{0}\;,
\]
where $\lambda_{0}\;(=\lambda_{1})$ is the rest wavelength.  

The longitudinal velocity component $v$ obeys the one–dimensional Maxwell distribution  
\[
P(v)=\sqrt{\frac{m}{2\pi kT}}\,
      \exp\!\Bigl(-\frac{mv^{2}}{2kT}\Bigr).
\]

Because $\Delta\lambda$ is linear in $v$, the spectral line profile in wavelength space is also Gaussian,
\[
S(\lambda)\propto
      \exp\!\Bigl[-\frac{(\Delta\lambda)^{2}}{2\sigma_\lambda^{2}}\Bigr],
\qquad
\sigma_\lambda^{2}=\frac{kT\,\lambda_{0}^{2}}{m\,c^{2}},\;
\Longrightarrow\;
\sigma_\lambda=\frac{\lambda_{0}}{c}\sqrt{\frac{kT}{m}}.
\]

\subsection*{2. Visibility (contrast) as a function of path difference}
For a quasi-monochromatic {\em Gaussian} source the complex degree of temporal coherence is the Fourier transform of the spectrum.  The result is again Gaussian,
\[
\gamma(\Delta)=\exp\!\Bigl[-\bigl(2\pi\sigma_\lambda\Delta/\lambda_{0}^{2}\bigr)^{2}\Bigr].
\]

\subsection*{3. Coherence length that produces blurring}
“Blur’’ is said to occur when either  
(a) $\gamma(\Delta)=1/e$ (contrast criterion) or  
(b) $I(\Delta)=I_{\max}/e$ (brightness criterion).

Because the average irradiance is $I(\Delta)=I_{\max}\gamma(\Delta)$ for a two–beam interferometer fed by the same Gaussian spectrum, the two criteria are identical:

\[
\gamma(\Delta_{\text{blur}})=\frac{1}{e}\;
\Longrightarrow\;
\bigl(2\pi\sigma_\lambda\Delta_{\text{blur}}/\lambda_{0}^{2}\bigr)^{2}=1,
\]
\[
\boxed{\;
\Delta_{\text{blur}}=\frac{\lambda_{0}^{2}}{2\pi\sigma_\lambda}
             =\frac{\lambda_{0}c}{2\pi}\sqrt{\frac{m}{kT}}\;} .
\]

This is the {\bf coherence length} of the filtered sodium line at temperature $T$.

\subsection*{4. Conversion to a screen coordinate}
In the Fraunhofer (far-field) arrangement of Young’s experiment

\[
\Delta\simeq d\,\frac{y}{L}\qquad(\text{with } y\ll L),
\]

so that the first transverse position where the fringes wash out is obtained from $\Delta=\Delta_{\text{blur}}$:

\[
y_{\text{blur}}=\frac{L\,\Delta_{\text{blur}}}{d}
               =\frac{L\,\lambda_{0}c}{2\pi d}
                 \sqrt{\frac{m}{kT}} .
\]

\subsection*{5. Numerical estimate (typical values)}
For illustration we use  
$\lambda_{0}=589.6\;\text{nm}=5.896\times10^{-7}\,\text{m}$,  
$m=23\,u=23\times1.66\times10^{-27}\,\text{kg}=3.82\times10^{-26}\,\text{kg}$,  
$k=1.38\times10^{-23}\,\text{J/K}$,  
$c=3.00\times10^{8}\,\text{m/s}$,  
and a lamp temperature $T\approx600\;\text{K}$.

\[
\sqrt{\frac{m}{kT}}
  =\sqrt{\frac{3.82\times10^{-26}}{1.38\times10^{-23}\times600}}
  \approx 2.15\times10^{-3},
\]
\[
\Delta_{\text{blur}}
  =\frac{\lambda_{0}c}{2\pi}\sqrt{\frac{m}{kT}}
  \approx\frac{(5.896\times10^{-7})(3.00\times10^{8})}{6.283}\,(2.15\times10^{-3})
  \approx6.1\times10^{-2}\,\text{m}.
\]

With, say, $d=0.30\;\text{mm}=3.0\times10^{-4}\,\text{m}$ and $L=1.0\;\text{m}$,

\[
y_{\text{blur}}
   \approx\frac{1.0\;\text{m}}{3.0\times10^{-4}\,\text{m}}\,(6.1\times10^{-2}\,\text{m})
   \approx 2.0\times10^{2}\,\text{m}.
\]

(The large value merely confirms that under ordinary laboratory dimensions the Na $D_{1}$ fringes stay sharp across the whole screen.  Only at very large $y$ would the blur become noticeable.)

\section*{Physical Interpretation}
The thermal motion of sodium atoms determines how quickly the phase relationship between light from the two slits decorrelates.  
Higher temperature or lighter emitters broaden the spectrum, {\it reduce} the coherence length, and move $y_{\text{blur}}$ closer to the optical axis.  
Conversely, a colder lamp or heavier atoms increase the coherence length and allow clear fringes over a wider screen region.

### Final Answer
\[
\boxed{\;
y_{\text{blur}}
      =\frac{L\,\lambda_{1}\,c}{2\pi d}\,
        \sqrt{\frac{m}{kT}}\;}
\]

This is the first (closest to the centre) position on the observation screen where the Young double-slit fringes become unobservable owing to Doppler broadening of the sodium $D_{1}$ line at temperature $T$.

questions: In modern plasma physics experiments, negative particles are often constrained in two ways. In the following discussion, we do not consider relativistic effects or retarded potentials.  Uniformly charged rings with radius $R$ are placed on planes $z=l$ and $z=-l$ in space, respectively. The rings are perpendicular to the $z$ axis, and each carries a charge of $Q_{0}$. A particle with charge $-q$ and mass $m$ is placed at the origin of the coordinate system. Given that $Q_0, q > 0$, the vacuum permittivity is $\epsilon_{0}$ and the vacuum permeability is $\mu_{0}$. To keep the point charge stable in both the $\hat{z}$ and $\hat{r}$ directions, we consider rotating the two charged rings in the $\hat{z}$ direction with a constant angular velocity $\Omega$. Given a small disturbance to the point charge at the origin, provide the minimum $\Omega$ required for the particle to remain stable in all directions.
solutions: Analyzing the magnetic field at a small displacement $z$ along the $z$-axis away from the coordinate origin    $$ \vec{B_{z}}={\frac{\mu_{0}Q\Omega R}{4\pi}}\left({\frac{R}{[R^{2}+(l+z)^{2}]^{\frac{3}{2}}}}+{\frac{R}{[R^{2}+(l-z)^{2}]^{\frac{3}{2}}}}\right) $$    yields    $$ \vec{B_{z}}=\frac{\mu_{0}Q\Omega}{2\pi}\frac{R^{2}}{(R^{2}+l^{2})^{\frac{3}{2}}}\hat{z} $$    Observing that near the origin, $\vec{B}$ can be considered as a uniform field along the $\hat{z}$ direction, denoted as $B_{0}$, consider a particle starting from the origin. By the angular momentum theorem    $$ \frac{\mathrm{d}\vec{L}}{\mathrm{d}t}=-q B_{0}r\dot{r}\vec{\varphi} $$    $$ L+\frac{1}{2}q B_{0}r^{2}=0 $$    $$ v_{\varphi}=-\frac{q B_{0}r}{2m} $$    Substitute into the conservation of energy equation to obtain the system's effective potential energy    $$ V_{e f f}=[{\frac{\mu_{0}^{2}q^{2}Q^{2}\Omega^{2}}{32m\pi^{2}}}{\frac{R^{4}}{(R^{2}+l^{2})^{3}}}-{\frac{q Q}{8\pi\varepsilon_{0}}}{\frac{(R^{2}-2l^{2})}{(R^{2}+l^{2})^{\frac{5}{2}}}}]r^{2}+{\frac{q Q}{4\pi\varepsilon_{0}}}{\frac{(R^{2}-2l^{2})}{(R^{2}+l^{2})^{\frac{5}{2}}}}z^{2} $$   For the system to be stable along $\hat{r},\hat{z}$, the coefficients should both be greater than 0, solving gives    $$ R^{2}>2l^{2} $$    $$ \Omega>\frac{2\pi}{\mu_{0}R^{2}}\sqrt{\frac{m(R^{2}-2l^{2})(R^{2}+l^{2})^{\frac{1}{2}}}{\pi\varepsilon_{0}Q q}} $$  That is, the minimum value is  $$ \frac{2\pi}{\mu_{0}R^{2}}\sqrt{\frac{m(R^{2}-2l^{2})(R^{2}+l^{2})^{\frac{1}{2}}}{\pi\varepsilon_{0}Q q}} $$
improved_solutions:
Solution Outline

1.  Problem Analysis  
    Two identical, uniformly-charged rings (radius R, charge +Q₀) are centred on the z-axis at z = +l and z = –l.  
    A point particle carrying charge –q (q>0) and mass m sits initially at the origin.  
    •  The electrostatic field alone gives a stable equilibrium in the axial (z) direction but an *unstable* one in the radial (r) direction.  
    •  When the rings are rotated rigidly about the z-axis with an angular velocity Ω every ring charge constitutes a current I and hence produces a magnetic field B≈B₀ẑ near the origin.  
    •  The Lorentz force in that magnetic field can stabilise the radial motion, exactly as in a (Penning) electrostatic-magnetic trap.  
    We must find the minimum Ω (≡Ω_min) that renders the origin a stable point for *all* small displacements.

2.  Strategy  
    (a)  Expand the electrostatic potential Φ(r,z) of the two rings up to second order around the origin (quadrupole approximation).  
    (b)  From Φ obtain the axial and radial curvatures (∂²Φ/∂z²)_0 and (∂²Φ/∂r²)_0, and convert them into the corresponding “trap frequencies’’ ω_z and the (imaginary) purely-electrostatic radial frequency.  
    (c)  Compute the magnetic field B₀ at the origin that is produced when each ring rotates with Ω, write down the equations of motion for small (x,y)-oscillations, and demand that all eigen-frequencies be real.  
    (d)  Impose the marginal-stability condition to obtain Ω_min.

3.  Detailed Solution  

   3.1  Electrostatic potential near the origin  
        Potential of one ring on its axis:  
        Φ_ring(0,0,z)= (1/4πϵ₀) Q₀ / √(R²+(z−l)²).  
        Adding the two rings and differentiating twice,

        ∂²Φ/∂z²|₀ = 2 · (1/4πϵ₀)Q₀ · [ − (R²−2l²)/(R²+l²)^{5/2}]  
                    = − Q₀ (R²−2l²) / [ 2πϵ₀ (R²+l²)^{5/2} ].           (1)

        Laplace’s equation (∇²Φ = 0) then gives at r = 0

        ∂²Φ/∂r²|₀ = −½ ∂²Φ/∂z²|₀ = + Q₀ (R²−2l²) / [4πϵ₀ (R²+l²)^{5/2} ]. (2)

        Requirement for a *restoring* axial force on a negative charge (–q) is R² > 2 l², which we assume from here on.

   3.2  “Trap’’ frequencies  
        Axial frequency (stable):

        ω_z² = (q/m)(−∂²Φ/∂z²|₀)
              = (q/m) · Q₀ (R²−2l²) / [2πϵ₀ (R²+l²)^{5/2} ].          (3)

        Radial curvature gives an *anti*-restoring electrostatic term:

        (q/m) ∂²Φ/∂r²|₀ = −½ ω_z² ;  hence the purely-electrostatic radial frequency is  
        ω_r(0)² = −½ ω_z²  (imaginary → unstable).                    (4)

   3.3  Magnetic field from the rotating rings  
        Each ring carries the current  
        I = (total charge per revolution time)  
          = Q₀ Ω / (2π).

        Field on the axis a distance l from the centre of a current loop:  
        B_single = μ₀ I R² / [2(R²+l²)^{3/2}].

        Both rings give

        B₀ = 2 B_single = μ₀ Q₀ Ω R² / [2π (R²+l²)^{3/2}].           (5)

        (Direction along +z if both rotate in the same sense.)

        Cyclotron frequency for the *magnitude* q of charge:

        ω_c = q B₀ / m = q μ₀ Q₀ Ω R² / [2π m (R²+l²)^{3/2}].        (6)

   3.4  Radial equations of motion and stability  
        For small displacements we obtain

        ẍ = +(½)ω_z² x − ω_c ẏ  
        ÿ = +(½)ω_z² y + ω_c ẋ.                                      (7)

        Seeking solutions ∝ e^{iλt} gives the secular equation

        λ² − ω_c λ + ½ ω_z² = 0,  with roots  
        λ = [ω_c ± √(ω_c² − 2 ω_z²)] / 2.                            (8)

        Both λ must be real (oscillatory motion) ⇒

        ω_c² ≥ 2 ω_z².                                               (9)

        The equality in (9) sets the *minimum* magnetic field, hence the minimum Ω.

   3.5  Solving for Ω_min  
        Put ω_c² = 2 ω_z² and insert (3) and (6):

        [ q μ₀ Q₀ Ω_min R² / (2π m (R²+l²)^{3/2}) ]² =   
        2 · (q/m) · Q₀ (R²−2l²) / [2πϵ₀ (R²+l²)^{5/2}].

        Algebra yields

        Ω_min² = 4π m (R²+l²)^{1/2} (R²−2l²) /
                 [ ϵ₀ q μ₀² Q₀ R⁴ ].                                (10)

        Hence

        Ω_min =  2
                 ———  √{ π m (R²+l²)^{1/2}(R²−2l²) / (ϵ₀ q Q₀ R⁴) } .
                μ₀                                                        (11)

        (Remember R² > 2 l² is required; if R² ≤ 2 l² the origin is already unstable axially and no rotation can stabilise it.)

4.  Remarks  
   •  The result is formally identical to the Penning-trap criterion but expressed with the geometric parameters R and l of the two rings.  
   •  Because retardation and relativistic effects were neglected the expression is valid as long as Ω ≪ c/R.  
   •  If the rings rotate in the opposite sense the sign of B₀ reverses; one must then take Ω → –Ω in (11).

### Final Answer
\[
\boxed{\,\displaystyle 
\Omega_{\min}= \frac{2}{\mu_{0}}\,
\sqrt{\frac{\pi m\,
\sqrt{R^{2}+l^{2}}\,(R^{2}-2l^{2})}
      {\; \epsilon_{0}\,q\,Q_{0}\,R^{4}}}\qquad
\Bigl(R^{2}>2l^{2}\Bigr)\,}
\]

questions: In space, there is an axisymmetric magnetic field, with the direction of the magnetic field pointing outward perpendicular to the plane, and its magnitude depends only on the distance from the center of symmetry, $B(r) = B_{0} \left(\frac{r}{r_{0}}\right)^{n}$. A particle with mass $m$ and charge $q$ moves in a circular motion with radius $r_{0}$ around the center of symmetry under the influence of the magnetic field. Find: if the charged particle is given a small radial disturbance, determine the period $T$ of the small radial oscillations.
solutions: According to symmetry, the system in this problem has conserved canonical angular momentum with respect to the magnetic field's center of symmetry. To find the canonical angular momentum, we list the corresponding rate of change equation:  $$ \frac{d L}{d t} = q v_{r} B_{0} \Big(\frac{r}{r_{0}}\Big)^{n} r $$  Rearranging terms and integrating yields:  $$ d L - \frac{q B_{0}}{r_{0}^{n}} r^{n+1} d r = 0 \to L - \frac{q B_{0}}{(n+2) r_{0}^{n}} r^{n+2} = C = \frac{n+1}{n+2} q B_{0} r_{0}^{2} $$  (Conservation quantity 6 points)  Thus, we obtain the function of angular momentum and $r$:  $$ L = L(r) = \frac{q B_{0}}{n+2} \biggl(\frac{r^{n+2}}{r_{0}^{n}} + (n+1) r_{0}^{2}\biggr) $$  The energy conservation of the charged particle gives:  $$ \frac{1}{2} m \dot{r}^{2} + \frac{1}{2} m v_{\theta}^{2} = \frac{1}{2} m \dot{r}^{2} + \frac{L(r)^{2}}{2m r^{2}} = E $$  (Energy conservation 6 points)  Give the particle a radial perturbation, let $r = r_{0} + \delta r$, $\dot{r} = (\dot{\delta r})$, resulting in:  $$ \frac{1}{2} m (\dot{\delta r})^{2} + \frac{q^{2} B_{0}^{2}}{2m(n+2)^{2}} \frac{\left(\frac{(r_{0}+\delta r)^{n+2}}{r_{0}^{n}} + (n+1) r_{0}^{2}\right)^{2}}{(r_{0}+\delta r)^{2}} = E $$  To analyze the oscillation, we need to expand the potential energy and retain terms up to the second order, so we first look at the denominator:  $$ \begin{array}{r l} &\left(\frac{(r_{0}+\delta r)^{n+2}}{r_{0}^{n}} + (n+1) r_{0}^{2}\right)^{2} = \left(r_{0}^{2}\Bigl(1+\frac{\delta r}{r_{0}}\Bigr)^{n+2} + (n+1) r_{0}^{2}\right)^{2} \\ &\qquad = r_{0}^{4} \Biggl(1 + (n+2) \frac{\delta r}{r_{0}} + \frac{(n+2)(n+1)}{2} \Bigl(\frac{\delta r}{r_{0}}\Bigr)^{2} + (n+1) \Biggr)^{2} \\ &\qquad = r_{0}^{4} (n+2)^{2} \Biggl(1 + \frac{\delta r}{r_{0}} + \frac{n+1}{2} \Bigl(\frac{\delta r}{r_{0}}\Bigr)^{2} \Biggr)^{2} = r_{0}^{4} (n+2)^{2} \left(1 + 2 \frac{\delta r}{r_{0}} + (n+2) \frac{\delta r}{r_{0}}\right)^{2} \end{array} $$  In the above equation, we repeatedly used the small quantity approximation formula $\begin{array}{r} (1+x)^{n} = 1 + n x + \frac{n(n-1)}{2}x^{2} + \ldots, \end{array}$ so the potential energy term can be written as:  $$ \frac{\left(\displaystyle\frac{(r_{0}+\delta r)^{n+2}}{r_{0}^{n}} + (n+1) r_{0}^{2}\right)^{2}}{(r_{0}+\delta r)^{2}} = r_{0}^{2} (n+2)^{2} \left(1 + 2 \frac{\delta r}{r_{0}} + (n+2) \Big(\frac{\delta r}{r_{0}}\Big)^{2}\right) \left(1 + \frac{\delta r}{r_{0}}\right)^{-2} $$  $$ = r_{0}^{2} (n+2)^{2} \left(1 + 2 \frac{\delta r}{r_{0}} + (n+2) \Big(\frac{\delta r}{r_{0}}\Big)^{2}\right) \left(1 - 2 \frac{\delta r}{r_{0}} + 3 \Big(\frac{\delta r}{r_{0}}\Big)^{2}\right) $$  Thus the second-order terms of potential energy are:  $$ \frac{q^{2} B_{0}^{2}}{2m(n+2)^{2}} r_{0}^{2} (n+2)^{2} (n+1) \bigg(\frac{\delta r}{r_{0}}\bigg)^{2} = \frac{q^{2} B_{0}^{2}}{2m} (n+1) \delta r^{2} $$  (Correctly expanding small terms 12 points)  Thus, the energy conservation equation is:  $$ \frac{1}{2} m (\dot{\delta r})^{2} + \frac{q^{2} B_{0}^{2}}{2m} (n+1) \delta r^{2} = C $$  According to the formula for simple harmonic oscillation, we know this represents an oscillation period of:  $$ T = \frac{2 \pi m}{q B_{0} \sqrt{n+1}} $$
improved_solutions:
Solution Outline
----------------

1.  **Problem Analysis**  
    A particle of charge $q$ and mass $m$ moves in a circular orbit of radius $r_{0}$ in an axially-symmetric magnetic field  
    $$\mathbf B(r)=B_{z}(r)\,\hat{\mathbf z}=B_{0}\Bigl(\frac{r}{r_{0}}\Bigr)^{n}\hat{\mathbf z}.$$  
    We must find the period \(T\) of the *small* radial oscillations that arise when the particle is given a slight radial displacement from its equilibrium orbit.

2.  **Approach (key physical ideas)**  
    • Use cylindrical coordinates \((r,\theta,z)\) with motion confined to the \(z=0\) plane (no electric field).  
    • Apply the Lorentz force \(\mathbf F=q\,\mathbf v\times\mathbf B\).  
    • Linearise the equations about the equilibrium circle \(r=r_{0}\).  
    • Show that the radial perturbation obeys a simple-harmonic-oscillator (SHO) equation  
      \(\ddot{\delta r}+ \omega_{r}^{2}\,\delta r =0\).  
    • Read off the oscillation frequency \(\omega_{r}\) and hence the period \(T=2\pi/\omega_{r}\).  
    • Discuss the stability criterion that naturally emerges.

Detailed Solution
-----------------

1.  **Velocity and basic kinematics**

    Let the actual radius be  
    $$r(t)=r_{0}+\delta r(t),\qquad |\delta r|\ll r_{0}.$$
    Neglecting any vertical motion, the velocity is  
    $$\mathbf v=\dot r\,\hat{\mathbf r}+r\dot\theta\,\hat{\boldsymbol\theta}
               \approx\dot{\delta r}\,\hat{\mathbf r}+(r_{0}+\delta r)\dot\theta\,\hat{\boldsymbol\theta}.$$

2.  **Lorentz force in cylindrical components**

    With \(\mathbf B=B_{z}(r)\,\hat{\mathbf z}\), the magnetic force is purely transverse to \(\mathbf B\):
    $$\mathbf F=q\,\mathbf v\times\mathbf B
      =q\bigl(\dot r\,\hat{\mathbf r}+r\dot\theta\,\hat{\boldsymbol\theta}\bigr)
        \times B_{z}\hat{\mathbf z}
      =qB_{z}\bigl(r\dot\theta\,\hat{\mathbf r}-\dot r\,\hat{\boldsymbol\theta}\bigr).$$
    Hence the *radial* component is  
    $$F_{r}=q\,r\dot\theta\,B_{z}(r).$$

3.  **Equilibrium (unperturbed circular motion)**  

    For the steady circle \(r=r_{0}\) (\(\dot r=0\)), Newton’s second law in the radial direction gives
    $$m\,r_{0}\,\omega_{0}^{2}=q\,r_{0}\,\omega_{0}\,B_{0}
      \quad\Longrightarrow\quad
      \omega_{0}=\frac{q\,B_{0}}{m}.$$
    Remarkably, \(\omega_{0}\) is *independent* of \(r_{0}\) for a purely magnetic central force.

4.  **Linearising the radial equation**

    The exact radial equation is
    $$m\bigl(\ddot r-r\dot\theta^{2}\bigr)=q\,r\dot\theta\,B_{z}(r).$$
    Substitute \(r=r_{0}+\delta r,\; B_{z}=B_{0}(1+n\,\delta r/r_{0})\) (first-order Taylor expansion), and write \(\dot\theta=\omega_{0}+\delta\dot\theta\).  Keep only terms to first order in the small quantities \(\delta r,\,\delta\dot\theta\).  After some algebra one finds

    • Zeroth order reproduces the equilibrium condition (step 3) and cancels automatically.  
    • First order gives
      $$m\bigl(\ddot{\delta r}-2r_{0}\omega_{0}\,\delta\dot\theta\bigr)
        =q\Bigl[r_{0}\omega_{0}\,n\frac{\delta r}{r_{0}}
                 +(\delta r)\omega_{0}
                 +r_{0}\,\delta\dot\theta\,B_{0}\Bigr].$$
      Using \(\omega_{0}=qB_{0}/m\) to eliminate \(B_{0}\) and solving for \(\delta\dot\theta\) then substituting back, all terms in \(\delta\dot\theta\) cancel, leaving the simple result
      $$\boxed{\;\ddot{\delta r}+\bigl(n+2\bigr)\omega_{0}^{2}\,\delta r=0\;}.$$
      Thus the small radial disturbance executes SHO motion with
      $$\omega_{r}=\omega_{0}\sqrt{n+2}.$$

5.  **Oscillation period and stability**

    • Oscillation period  
      $$T=\frac{2\pi}{\omega_{r}}
         =\frac{2\pi}{\omega_{0}\sqrt{\,n+2\,}}
         =\frac{2\pi m}{q B_{0}\sqrt{\,n+2\,}}.$$

    • Stability requires a *real* frequency, hence  
      $$n>-2.$$
      (For \(n=-2\) the motion is marginal; for \(n<-2\) the perturbation grows exponentially.)

6.  **Physical interpretation (brief)**  
    The magnetic field profile acts like an effective radial “spring”: if the field grows fast enough with distance (larger \(n\)), the restoring force is stronger and the radial oscillations are quicker.  As \(n\to-2^{+}\) the restoring force weakens, the period diverges, and the orbit becomes unstable for \(n\le-2\).

### Final Answer
\[
\boxed{\,T=\frac{2\pi}{\omega_{0}\sqrt{\,n+2\,}}=\frac{2\pi m}{q\,B_{0}\sqrt{\,n+2\,}},\quad\text{valid for } n>-2\,}
\]

questions: A regular dodecahedron resistor network is given. Except for $R_{BC} = 2r$, the resistance between all other adjacent vertices is $r$. Points $B$ and $C$ are the two endpoints of one edge of the dodecahedron. Find the resistance between points $B$ and $C$.
solutions:
Boldly introducing negative resistance, $BC$ is equivalent to a parallel combination of $\pmb{r}$ and $-2r$:  

$$
\frac{1}{r}+\frac{1}{-2r}=\frac{1}{2r}
$$

After extracting $-2r$, the remaining resistance value can be constructed using the forced current method. Inject $19I_{1}$ into node $B$, and each of the other nodes emits a current of 1. Then consider injecting $I$ into each of the other nodes while node $C$ emits $191$. Thus, the current flowing through the branch:  

$$
I_{BC}=20I
$$

Voltage:  

$$
U_{BC}=\frac{19Ir}{3}\cdot2
$$

Thus:  

$$
U_{BC}=I_{BC}R_{BC}^{\prime}
$$

Resulting in:  

$$
R_{BC}^{\prime}=\frac{19}{30}r
$$

Then, parallel it with $-2r$:  

$$
\frac{1}{R_{BC}}=\frac{1}{R_{BC}^{\prime}}+\frac{1}{-2r}
$$

Finally obtained:  

$$
R_{BC}=\frac{38}{41}r
$$
improved_solutions:
Solution Outline

1. Problem Analysis  
   We have a network made from the 30 edges of a regular dodecahedron (20 vertices, degree 3 at every vertex).  
   • Every edge carries a resistance r, except the edge BC whose resistance has been doubled to 2 r.  
   • We must find the equivalent resistance RBC seen between the two end-points B and C of that modified edge.

2. Approach  
   Step A Deal first with the perfectly symmetric dodecahedron in which every edge has the same value r.  
   – Because the dodecahedron is edge–transitive, all edges have the same effective resistance between their end-points.  
   – Foster’s first theorem allows us to obtain this common value immediately, without any large system of equations.  

   Step B Remove the physical resistor that lies on BC.  
   – Call RΔ the effective resistance between B and C when all 30 edges are r (value obtained in Step A).  
   – With that edge removed, call the remaining resistance between B and C R0.  Since the original situation was simply the parallel combination of r (along BC) and R0, we have an elementary two-resistor relation that gives R0.  

   Step C Put a 2 r resistor on BC instead of r, so that BC is now in parallel with the remainder R0.  One further parallel-combination gives the answer.

3. Solution in Detail  

   3.1  The symmetric dodecahedron (all edges = r)  
   • Let Re be the effective resistance of any one edge (for example B–C when its resistor also equals r).  
   • The dodecahedron has  
               n = 20   vertices  
               m = 30   edges .  
   • Foster’s First Theorem (or Foster’s edge theorem) states for any connected network of one-ohm resistors that  
               Σ_{(i,j)∈E} R_{ij} = n – 1 ,  
     where R_{ij} is the effective resistance between the ends i and j of edge (i,j).  
   • Because the graph is edge-transitive, every edge contributes the same amount Re, so  
               m · Re = n – 1   ⇒   Re(one-ohm edges) = (n – 1)/m = 19/30 .  
   • Multiplying by the actual value r instead of 1 Ω gives  
               RΔ  ≡  R_BC  (all edges = r)  = (19/30) r .      (1)

   3.2  Resistance of the rest of the network when edge BC is removed  
   • Let R0 denote the resistance between B and C when the edge BC is open-circuited.  
   • With every edge = r, the two nodes B and C were connected in parallel by (i) the single resistor r   and (ii) the remainder of the graph having resistance R0.  
   • Hence  
         1/RΔ = 1/r + 1/R0   ⇒   R0 = r RΔ /( r – RΔ ).  
   • Insert (1):  
         R0 = r·(19/30) / [ r – (19/30) r ] = (19/30) r / (11/30) = (19/11) r .      (2)

   3.3  Put the real (2 r) resistor on BC  
   • The “rest of the world’’ between B and C is still R0.  Now BC carries 2 r instead of r.  
   • Required equivalent resistance:   two resistors in parallel:  
         R_BC(final) = ( 2 r ) · R0 / ( 2 r + R0 ).  
   • Substitute (2):  
         R_BC(final) = (2 r)(19/11 r) / [ 2 r + (19/11) r ]  
                      = (38/11) r^2 / [ (22/11 + 19/11) r ]  
                      = (38/11) r^2 / (41/11) r  
                      = (38 / 41) r .      (3)

4. Result  
   The effective resistance between the two chosen vertices B and C, with every ordinary edge equal to r and the edge BC equal to 2 r, is

### Final Answer
\[
\boxed{\dfrac{38}{41}\; r}
\]

questions: Consider a small cylindrical object with radius $R$ and height $h$. Determine the expression for the force $F$ acting on the cylinder when a sound wave passes through it. The axial direction of the cylinder is the direction of wave propagation. In the sound wave, the displacement of a particle from its equilibrium position is $\psi = A\cos kx\cos 2\pi ft$, the ambient pressure is $P_0$, and the adiabatic index of air is $\gamma$.
solutions:
The force on the cylinder will be  

$$
F = -\pi R^{2}(p(y+h)-p(y)) = -\pi R^{2}h\frac{d p}{d y}
$$  

For a traveling wave, substitute  

$$
\Delta p(y,t) = -\gamma p_{0}A k\cos(k y-2\pi f t)
$$  

$$
\frac{d p}{d y} = \gamma p_{0}A k^{2}\sin(k y-2\pi f t)
$$  

Therefore, the force is  

$$
F = -\pi R^2 h\gamma p_0 A k^2\sin(ky-2\pi ft)
$$

However, for a standing wave, we have  

$$
\psi = A\cos{k x}\cos{2\pi}f t
$$  

Thus,  

$$
\Delta p = \gamma P_{0}k A\sin k x\cos2\pi f t
$$  


Therefore,  

$$
\frac{d p}{d x} = \gamma P_{0}k^{2}A\cos k x\cos2\pi f t
$$  

Thus, the force is  

$$
F = -\pi R^2 h\gamma P_0 k^2 A\cos kx \cos 2\pi ft
$$
final_answers:
$$
F = -\pi R^2 h \gamma P_0 k^2 A \cos(kx) \cos(2\pi ft)
$$
improved_solutions:
Problem Analysis  
A right circular cylinder of radius R and length h is immersed in a one–dimensional plane sound wave that travels along the cylinder axis (x–direction).  Because only the two plane faces (area = πR² each) are normal to the propagation direction, the net axial force equals the difference between the instantaneous pressures on those two faces.  We must express that force in terms of the given particle-displacement field

  ψ(x,t)=A cos kx cos 2πft ,

the ambient (equilibrium) pressure P₀, and the adiabatic index γ.

Approach  
1. Relate the small acoustic pressure fluctuation p′(x,t)=P(x,t)−P₀ to the displacement field ψ with the linear adiabatic relation p′ = −γP₀ ∂ψ/∂x (equivalently p′ = −ρ₀c² ∂ψ/∂x, where c²=γP₀/ρ₀).  
2. Evaluate p′ at the two faces x and x+h.  
3. The net force equals the area times the difference of the total pressures (ambient + fluctuation) on the two faces; the ambient parts cancel, so only p′ contributes.  
4. Perform the trigonometric algebra and, for completeness, show the small-h (thin cylinder) limit.

Solution Steps  

1. Acoustic pressure fluctuation  
   For a one-dimensional plane wave in an ideal gas, small perturbations satisfy  
  p′(x,t)=−γP₀ ∂ψ/∂x = −ρ₀c² ∂ψ/∂x.  

   Compute the derivative of ψ:  
  ∂ψ/∂x = −A k sin kx cos (2πft).  

   Hence  
  p′(x,t)= γP₀A k sin kx cos (2πft) = ρ₀c²A k sin kx cos (2πft). (1)

2. Pressure at the two faces  
   Face 1 (rear face) at x: p′₁ = p′(x,t)  
   Face 2 (front face) at x+h: p′₂ = p′(x+h,t)

3. Net axial force  
   The inward-normal force on each face is its pressure times area; choosing positive force in the +x direction,

  F = (P₀+p′₁)πR² − (P₀+p′₂)πR²  
   = −πR² [ p′₂ − p′₁ ]. (2)

4. Difference of pressure fluctuations  
   Using Eq. (1),

  p′₂ − p′₁ = ρ₀c²A k [ sin k(x+h) − sin kx ] cos (2πft).

   Apply the identity sin(α+β) − sin α = 2 cos(α+β/2) sin(β/2):

  sin k(x+h) − sin kx = 2 cos[k(x+h/2)] sin(kh/2).

   Therefore  
  p′₂ − p′₁ = 2ρ₀c²A k sin(kh/2) cos[k(x+h/2)] cos(2πft). (3)

5. Final expression for the force  
   Insert Eq. (3) into Eq. (2):

  F(x,t) = −2πR²ρ₀c²A k sin(kh/2) cos[k(x+h/2)] cos(2πft). (4)

   Using c² = γP₀/ρ₀ to eliminate ρ₀ if desired,

  F(x,t) = −2πR²γP₀A k sin(kh/2) cos[k(x+h/2)] cos(2πft). (4′)

6. Thin-cylinder (kh ≪ 1) approximation  
   For small kh, sin(kh/2) ≈ kh/2 and cos[k(x+h/2)] ≈ cos kx, giving

  F ≈ −πR²ρ₀c²A k² h cos kx cos(2πft). (5)

   The force is then proportional to the length h and to the local acoustic pressure gradient.

### Final Answer
\[
\boxed{\,F(x,t)= -\,2\pi R^{2}\,\gamma P_{0}\,A\,k\,\sin\!\left(\dfrac{kh}{2}\right)\cos\!\left[k\!\left(x+\dfrac{h}{2}\right)\right]\cos(2\pi f t)\,}
\]

(Equivalently \(F = -2\pi R^{2}\rho_{0}c^{2}A k \sin(kh/2)\cos[k(x+h/2)]\cos(2\pi f t)\); for \(kh\ll 1\) this reduces to \(F\approx -\pi R^{2}\rho_{0}c^{2}A k^{2} h \cos kx \cos 2\pi f t\).)

questions:
In certain solids, ions have spin angular momentum and can be regarded as a three-dimensional real vector $\vec{S}$ with a fixed length under the semiclassical approximation, where the length $\vert\vec{S}\vert = S$ is a constant. The magnetic moment $\overrightarrow{M}$ of the ions is usually proportional to the spin vector, ${\overrightarrow{M}} = \gamma{\overrightarrow{S}}$, where $\gamma(>0)$ is a constant. The spin-spin interaction between ions $i$ and $j$ is usually the Heisenberg interaction, $-J_{i,j}\vec{S}_{i} \cdot \vec{S}_{j}$. Under a static uniform external magnetic field $\overrightarrow{B}$, the total energy (Hamiltonian) of the system is typically given by $\begin{array}{r}{H = -\sum_{(i,j)}J_{i,j}\vec{S}_{i}\cdot\vec{S}_{j} - }\end{array}$ $\begin{array}{r}{\gamma\overrightarrow{B}\cdot\sum_{i}\overrightarrow{S}_{i}}\end{array}$. Here, $(i,j)$ indicates a sum over all distinct pairs without order, meaning $(i,j)$ and $(j,i)$ represent the same pair and are not counted twice. The semiclassical time evolution of the spin vector satisfies the Heisenberg equation of motion (here $\times{}$ represents the vector cross product):
$$
\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}t}\vec{S}_{i}=\frac{\partial H}{\partial \vec{S}_{i}}\times\vec{S}_{i}
$$
Consider two spins, $H = -J\vec{S}_{1}\cdot\vec{S}_{2} - \gamma\vec{B}\cdot\left(\vec{S}_{1}+\vec{S}_{2}\right)$, where $J>0$. Without loss of generality, let $\overrightarrow{B}$ be along the $\mathbf{Z}$ direction, $\vec{B}=B\hat{\bf z}$, $B \geq 0$. The ground state (lowest energy state) of the system is $\vec{S}_{1}=\vec{S}_{2}=S\hat{\mathbf{z}}$, and this state does not evolve over time. Consider states close to the ground state, $\vec{S}_{1}=S\big(x_{1},y_{1},\sqrt{1-{x_{1}}^{2}-{y_{1}}^{2}}\big)$, $\vec{S}_{2}=S\big(x_{2},y_{2},\sqrt{1-{x_{2}}^{2}-{y_{2}}^{2}}\big)$, where $\left|x_{1,2}\right|\ll1, \left|y_{1,2}\right|\ll1$. Find the product of the final normal mode frequencies.
solutions:
Solution: The Heisenberg equation of motion is
$$
\begin{array}{r}{\displaystyle\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}t}\vec{S}_{1}=-\left(J\vec{S}_{2}+\gamma\vec{B}\right)\times\vec{S}_{1}}\ {\displaystyle\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}t}\vec{S}_{2}=-\left(J\vec{S}_{1}+\gamma\vec{B}\right)\times\vec{S}_{2}}\end{array}
$$
Note that $\vec{S}_{\pm}=\vec{S}_{1}\pm\vec{S}_{2}$ can be defined, then $\begin{array}{r}{H=\frac{J}{2}\big|\overrightarrow{S}_{+}\big|^{2}-J S^{2}-\gamma\overrightarrow{B}\cdot\overrightarrow{S}_{+}}\end{array}$,
$$
\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}t}\vec{S}_{+}=-\gamma\vec{B}\times\vec{S}_{+}
$$
$$
\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}t}\vec{S}_{-}=-\left(\vec{J S}_{+}+\gamma\vec{B}\right)\times\vec{S}_{-}
$$
The equations of motion for $x_{1,2},y_{1,2}$ in the lowest order approximation are
$$
\begin{array}{c}{{\displaystyle\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}t}(x_{1}+x_{2})=\gamma B\cdot(y_{1}+y_{2})}}\ {{\displaystyle\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}t}(y_{1}+y_{2})=-\gamma B\cdot(x_{1}+x_{2})}}\ {{\displaystyle\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}t}(x_{1}-x_{2})\approx(2J S+\gamma B)\cdot(y_{1}-y_{2})}}\ {{\displaystyle\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}t}(y_{1}-y_{2})\approx-(2J S+\gamma B)\cdot(x_{1}-x_{2})}}\end{array}
$$
The product of the characteristic frequencies is
$\gamma B(2J S+\gamma B)$
improved_solutions:
### 1. Problem Analysis  
Two identical spins of fixed length S interact through an (antiferromagnetic) Heisenberg coupling ‑J S₁·S₂ (J > 0) and experience a uniform magnetic field **B** = B ẑ (B ≥ 0).  
The ground state is both spins parallel to the field: S₁ = S₂ = S ẑ.  
We consider small transverse fluctuations
 S₁ ≃ S( x₁ , y₁ , 1 – ½x₁² – ½y₁² ),
 S₂ ≃ S( x₂ , y₂ , 1 – ½x₂² – ½y₂² ),   |x₁,₂|,|y₁,₂| ≪ 1,  
and linearise the semiclassical equations of motion  
       dSᵢ/dt = (∂H/∂Sᵢ) × Sᵢ.  
We must find the two normal-mode frequencies ω₊, ω₋ of the resulting small-oscillation problem and give their product ω₊ ω₋.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 2. Approach  
1. Compute the effective fields acting on the spins:  
     ∂H/∂S₁ = –J S₂ – γ B ẑ, ∂H/∂S₂ = –J S₁ – γ B ẑ.  
2. Linearise the cross-product equations to first order in x’s and y’s.  
3. Instead of handling a 4 × 4 matrix directly, exploit symmetry by forming collective (total) and relative transverse coordinates:  

     X₊ = (x₁ + x₂)/√2,   Y₊ = (y₁ + y₂)/√2  (total mode)  
     X₋ = (x₁ – x₂)/√2,   Y₋ = (y₁ – y₂)/√2  (relative mode)

   In this basis the Zeeman term affects only the total mode while the exchange term affects only the relative mode, so the equations decouple into two independent 2-D oscillators whose frequencies are immediately identifiable.  
4. Read off the frequencies and multiply them.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 3. Detailed Solution  

3.1 Linearised spin components  
Keep only first-order terms in x and y:

S₁ ≈ S( x₁ , y₁ , 1 ),  S₂ ≈ S( x₂ , y₂ , 1 ).

3.2 Effective fields  
B_eff,1 ≡ –∂H/∂S₁ = J S₂ + γ B ẑ  
    ≈ J S( x₂ , y₂ , 1 ) + γ B ẑ.

Similarly  
B_eff,2 ≈ J S( x₁ , y₁ , 1 ) + γ B ẑ.

3.3 Equations of motion  
Using dSᵢ/dt = B_eff,i × Sᵢ and retaining only linear terms:

For spin 1:  
 d/dt ( Sx₁, Sy₁, 0 ) = [ J S( x₂ , y₂ , 1 ) + γ B ẑ ] × S( x₁ , y₁ , 1 ).

Compute z-components only to zeroth order (they give no first-order transverse dynamics); the transverse (x,y) equations are

(1) ẋ₁ = –(γB + JS) y₁ – JS y₂  
(2) ẏ₁ =  (γB + JS) x₁ + JS x₂

Repeating for spin 2 gives

(3) ẋ₂ = –(γB + JS) y₂ – JS y₁  
(4) ẏ₂ =  (γB + JS) x₂ + JS x₁.

3.4 Collective coordinates  

Total mode (symmetric):   X₊ = (x₁ + x₂)/√2, Y₊ = (y₁ + y₂)/√2  
Relative mode (antisymmetric): X₋ = (x₁ – x₂)/√2, Y₋ = (y₁ – y₂)/√2.

Add (1) + (3) and divide by √2:

 Ẋ₊ = –γB Y₊.

Add (2) + (4):

 Ẏ₊ =  γB X₊.

Hence (X₊, Y₊) form a simple planar oscillator with angular frequency

 ω₊ = γB                       (“Larmor” mode of the total spin).

Next subtract (1) – (3) and divide by √2:

 Ẋ₋ = –(γB + 2JS) Y₋.

Similarly for Y₋:

 Ẏ₋ =  (γB + 2JS) X₋.

Thus the antisymmetric pair (X₋, Y₋) oscillates with

 ω₋ = γB + 2JS    (“exchange” or “optical” mode).

3.5 Product of frequencies  
Multiplying the two positive normal-mode frequencies gives

 ω₊ ω₋ = γB (γB + 2JS).

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### Final Answer
\[
\boxed{\,\omega_{+}\omega_{-}= \gamma B\;\bigl(\gamma B + 2 J S\bigr)\,}
\]

questions: Consider an elastic soft rope with original length $a$, and elastic coefficient $k$. With one end fixed, the other end is attached to a particle with a mass of $m$. And the rope remains horizontal. The particle moves on a smooth horizontal surface. Initially, the rope is stretched to a length of $a+b$, and then the particle is released. Determine how much time it takes for the particle to return to the original release position.
solutions:
First consider \( x > a \). At this time, the particle only experiences the elastic force \( -k(x-a) \) in the horizontal direction. According to Newton's second law, the equation of motion for the particle is

$$
m{\ddot{x}} = -k(x-a),
$$

which is the equation of simple harmonic motion. To solve equation (1), make the substitution \(\xi = x - a\), then equation (1) becomes

$$
m\ddot{\xi} = -k\xi.
$$

Further, with the transformation \(\ddot{\xi} = \frac{\mathrm{d}^{2}\xi}{\mathrm{d}t^{2}} = \frac{\mathrm{d}\xi}{\mathrm{d}t} \frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}\xi}\left(\frac{\mathrm{d}\xi}{\mathrm{d}t}\right) = \frac{1}{2} \frac{\mathrm{d}\dot{\xi}^{2}}{\mathrm{d}\xi}\), equation (2) becomes

$$
\mathrm{d}\dot{\xi}^{2} = -2\omega^{2}\xi\mathrm{d}\xi,
$$

where \(\omega = \sqrt{k/m}\). Integrating the above, and setting the initial conditions \(\xi = \xi_{0}, \dot{\xi} = v_{0} \) at \(t=0\), yields

$$
\dot{\xi}^{2} = v_{0}^{2} - \omega^{2}(\xi^{2} - \xi_{0}^{2}) = (v_{0}^{2} + \omega^{2}\xi_{0}^{2}) - \omega^{2}\xi^{2},
$$

which implies

$$
\frac{\mathrm{d}\xi}{\mathrm{d}t} = \pm\sqrt{(v_{0}^{2} + \omega^{2}\xi_{0}^{2}) - \omega^{2}\xi^{2}} = \pm\omega\sqrt{A^{2} - \xi^{2}},
$$

where \({\cal A} = \sqrt{\frac{v_{0}^{2}}{\omega^{2}} + \xi_{0}^{2}}\). Further integration and considering the initial conditions gives

$$
\xi = A\sin(\pm\omega t + \arcsin \frac{\xi_{0}}{A}) = A\cos(\omega t + \alpha),
$$

where \(\alpha = \pm\arcsin{\frac{\xi_{0}}{A}} \mp {\frac{\pi}{2}}\). Thus, the general solution of equation (1) is

$$
x = a + A\cos(\omega t + \alpha).
$$

According to the problem, at \(t=0\), \(x=a+b, \dot{x}=0\). Substituting into equation (3) determines the constants of integration to be \(A=b, \alpha=0\). Substituting back into equation (3), we obtain

$$
x = a + b\cos\omega t.
$$

This shows that the motion of the particle in the domain \(x > a\) is periodic. The time for the particle to move from \(x = a + b\) to \(x = a\) and back is the period, which is

$$
t_{0} = {\frac{1}{2}}\frac{2\pi}{\omega} = \pi\sqrt{\frac{m}{k}}.
$$

When \(x < -a\), the particle experiences an elastic force of \(-k(x+a)\) in the horizontal direction. Note that because \(x < -a\), \( -(x+a) > 0\), so the elastic force points in the positive \(x\) direction, which is consistent with the actual situation. The equation of motion is

$$
m{\ddot{x}} = -k(x+a).
$$

Using a similar method to the above, the general solution of the equation is

$$
x = -a + B\cos(\omega t + \beta),
$$

where \(B, \beta\) are constants of integration. According to analysis in \(\textcircled{2}\), \(\dot{x}|_{x=a} = \dot{x}|_{x=-a}\), we determine \(B=b\). Equation (5) indicates that the motion of the particle in the region \(x < -a\) is also simple harmonic, with the same frequency as in the region \(x > a\). The time for the particle to move from \(x=-a\) to \(x=-(a+b)\) and back is also \(t_{0}\).

In summary, the total time taken for the particle to move from \(x = a + b \) to \(x = a\) and from \(x = -a\) to \(x = -(a + b)\) and back is

$$
t_{1} = 2t_{0} = 2\pi\sqrt{\frac{m}{k}}.
$$

The previous discussion also shows that considering just \(x > a\) is sufficient to determine the characteristics of the particle's motion in the interval \(|x| > a\), especially concerning the motion's time.

\(\textcircled{2}\) When \(|x|<a\), i.e., \(-a<x<a\), the particle is not subject to any external force in the horizontal direction, and thus will move uniformly with the velocity it has at \(x = \pm a\). The speed of the particle at \(x = a\) is

$$
\dot{x}|_{x=a} = \dot{x}|_{t=t_{1}} = -b\omega = -b\sqrt{\frac{k}{m}}.
$$

The time for the particle to travel from \(x=a\) to \(x=-a\) and back to \(x=a\) is

$$
t_{2} = 4\frac{a}{|\dot{x}|_{x=a}|} = \frac{4a}{b}\sqrt{\frac{m}{k}}.
$$

The process for the particle to return to its release point is \(x = a+b \rightarrow x = a \rightarrow x = 0 \rightarrow x = -a \rightarrow x = -(a+b) \rightarrow x = -a \rightarrow x = 0 \rightarrow x = a \rightarrow x = a+b\), so the total time experienced is

$$
t = t_{1} + t_{2} = 2\left(\pi + \frac{2a}{b}\right)\sqrt{\frac{m}{k}}.
$$

Problem Analysis  
We have an ideal horizontal spring–mass system:  
• Natural (unstretched) length of the soft rope (spring): a  
• Spring (rope) force constant: k  
• Mass attached to the free end: m  
• Initial condition: the spring is stretched an additional distance b (total length a + b) and the mass is released from rest.  
Because the table is smooth (no friction) and the rope is light, the only horizontal force on the mass is the spring force. We are asked for the elapsed time until the mass comes back to the very same point from which it was released.

Approach  
1. Use conservation of mechanical energy to obtain the speed v(x) of the mass as a function of its instantaneous extension x.  
2. Convert the time integral t = ∫dx / v(x) into a standard form.  
3. Evaluate the integral to find the total time for the mass to travel from x = +b through x = –b and return to x = +b.  
4. Show that the result is the familiar period of a simple harmonic oscillator, T = 2π√(m/k), and hence the required return time is this period.

Solution Steps  

1. Extension coordinate  
Define x(t) = instantaneous extension measured from the natural length a.  
At the moment of release: x = +b, v = 0.

2. Energy conservation  
Total mechanical energy E is conserved.  
E = elastic potential + kinetic = ½ k x² + ½ m v² = constant.  
At t = 0, x = b and v = 0 ⇒ E = ½ k b².  
Thus for any later time,  
½ m v² + ½ k x² = ½ k b²  
⇒ v² = (k/m)(b² – x²).  
Therefore  
v = dx/dt = ±√[(k/m)(b² – x²)].                     (1)

3. Time to return to the starting point  
Returning to the initial point means the mass goes from x = +b → –b → +b.  
Because of symmetry we can compute the half–cycle (from +b to –b) and double it, or integrate the whole loop directly:

Total time  
t = ∮ dx / |v| = 2 ∫_{x=+b}^{x=-b} dx / √[(k/m)(b² – x²)].            (2)

4. Evaluate the integral  
Factor out constants:

t = 2√(m/k) ∫_{+b}^{-b} dx / √(b² – x²).                                (3)

Make the trigonometric substitution  
x = b sinθ ⇒ dx = b cosθ dθ, and when  
x = +b ⇒ θ = +π/2,  
x = –b ⇒ θ = –π/2.

Substitute into (3):

t = 2√(m/k) ∫_{π/2}^{-π/2} (b cosθ dθ) / [b cosθ]  
  = 2√(m/k) ∫_{π/2}^{-π/2} dθ  
  = 2√(m/k) [–π]  
  = 2π√(m/k).                                                        (4)

Thus the mass needs a time T = 2π√(m/k) to leave x = +b and come back to x = +b; i.e. the complete oscillation period.

5. Independence of amplitude  
Equation (4) shows that b cancels out; as long as the rope obeys Hooke’s law (linear spring), the period depends only on m and k, not on the initial stretch b.

### Final Answer
\[
\boxed{\,t \;=\; 2\pi\sqrt{\dfrac{m}{k}}\,}
\]

questions:
A certain planet has a smooth and elastic surface, perfect for playing bounce games. Let the planet have a radius $R$, and the first cosmic velocity at the surface is $v_{0}$. The ground's restitution coefficient is a fixed value $\varepsilon$. Imagine launching a bouncy ball from the surface at an angle $\theta$ with a speed of $k v_{0}$. The bouncy ball will rotate around the planet's center while continuously bouncing off the surface.

If we take $k<1$ and the launch angle $\theta$ to be a small amount and make reasonable approximations, find the total angle $\varphi$ that the bouncy ball rotates around the planet's center before it stops bouncing on the ground and rolls around the surface.
solutions:
The two components of the initial throw speed are:

$$
v_{r}=k v_{0}\sin\theta\quad,\quad v_{\theta}=k v_{0}\cos\theta
$$  

Based on the symmetry of the starting and landing points with respect to the major axis of the elliptical orbit, and combining the definition of the restitution coefficient under the conditions of a smooth ground. When the object undergoes the $(m+1)$-th segment of projectile motion, the two velocity components at the surface are generally:

$$
v_{m r}=\varepsilon^{m}k v_{0}\sin\theta\quad,\quad v_{m\theta}=k v_{0}\cos\theta
$$  

Using the celestial body's angular momentum formula, we can obtain its semi-latus rectum $p$:

$$
L=m\sqrt{G M p}
$$  

$$
L=m v_{m\theta}R
$$  

Using the mechanical energy formula of the celestial body, we can obtain its orbital semi-major axis $A$:

$$
E=-{\frac{G M m}{2A}}
$$  

$$
E=\frac{1}{2}m\left(v_{m r}^{2}+v_{m\theta}^{2}\right)-\frac{G M m}{R}
$$  

The first cosmic velocity is:

$$
v_{0}={\sqrt{\frac{G M}{R}}}
$$  

Finally, the orbital eccentricity is determined, and the standard equation is written as:

$$
r=\frac{p}{1-e\cos\varphi}\quad,\quad p=(1-e^{2})A
$$  

The reason for choosing the denominator as negative is because we use the highest point of the orbit rather than the periapsis direction as the polar axis direction in polar coordinates. The calculation yields:

$$
r={\frac{k^{2}R\cos^{2}\theta}{1-{\sqrt{(1-k^{2}\cos^{2}\theta)^{2}+\varepsilon^{2m}k^{4}\sin^{2}\theta\cos^{2}\theta}}}}\cos\varphi
$$  

To calculate the angle turned around the Earth's center during each projectile motion, take $r=R$, and obtain:

$$
\cos\varphi={\frac{1-k^{2}\cos^{2}\theta}{\sqrt{(1-k^{2}\cos^{2}\theta)^{2}+\varepsilon^{2m}k^{4}\sin^{2}\theta\cos^{2}\theta}}}
$$  

Thus, the positive and negative acute solutions of $\varphi$ represent the angle turned. Additionally, converting the equation above into arctangent gives the rotation angle for this process:

$$
\Delta\varphi_{m}=2\arctan\frac{\varepsilon^{m}k^{2}\sin\theta\cos\theta}{1-k^{2}\cos^{2}\theta}
$$  

Perform a small angle approximation for $\Delta\varphi_{m}$:

$$
\Delta\varphi_{m}\approx{\frac{2\varepsilon^{m}k^{2}\theta}{1-k^{2}}}
$$  

Perform infinite summation for all angles:

$$
\varphi=\Delta\varphi_{0}+\Delta\varphi_{1}+\Delta\varphi_{2}+\cdot\cdot\cdot=\frac{2k^{2}\theta}{1-k^{2}}\sum_{m=0}^{\infty}\varepsilon^{m}
$$  

Geometric series:

$$
\sum_{m=0}^{\infty}\varepsilon^{m}={\frac{1}{1-\varepsilon}}
$$  

Thus:

$$
\boxed{\varphi=\frac{2k^{2}\theta}{(1-\varepsilon)(1-k^{2})}}
$$
improved_solutions:
### 1. Problem Analysis  
We have a perfectly smooth, perfectly spherical planet of radius  

  R , g = GM/R² , v₀ = √(gR)  (first-cosmic or circular orbital speed at the surface).

A small elastic ball is projected from the surface with speed k v₀ (k<1) at a small angle θ with respect to the local horizontal.  
Because k<1 the orbit is sub-orbital; the ball rises and falls back to the ground.  
Every time it hits the surface

• the component of velocity normal to the surface is reversed and reduced by the ground’s coefficient of restitution ε (0 ≤ ε < 1);  
• the tangential component is unchanged (surface is smooth).  

The ball thus executes a sequence of short ballistic flights whose horizontal projections creep forward around the planet.  
We must find the total central angle φ that the ball sweeps before all bounces cease and the ball finally “rolls” on the ground (i.e. when the vertical component has become negligible).

The problem explicitly asks for the answer in the limit of  
 • small launch angle θ (so sinθ ≈ θ, cosθ ≈ 1) and  
 • k<1 but not extremely close to 1, so a simple geometric sum is adequate.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 2. Approach – Key Ideas  

1. Treat each flight as motion in a **uniform gravitational field g** over a flat patch of the surface (valid because the maximum height is ≪ R for small θ).  
2. Decompose the initial speed k v₀ into  
 • tangential component v_t = k v₀ cosθ ≈ k v₀,  
 • normal component  v_n₀ = k v₀ sinθ ≈ k v₀ θ.  
3. After every bounce, the tangential component stays v_t, while the magnitude of the normal component is multiplied by ε:  

  v_n, n = εⁿ v_n₀ for the n-th flight (n = 0,1,2,…).  
4. For each flight, compute  
 • time aloft t_n = 2 v_n,n / g (up-and-down under uniform g),  
 • horizontal distance s_n = v_t t_n,  
 • central angle Δφ_n = s_n / R.  
5. Sum Δφ_n over all bounces (geometric series) to get total φ.  
6. Use v₀² = gR to eliminate g and R.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 3. Detailed Solution  

1. Velocity components just after launch (n = 0):  
 v_t = k v₀ cosθ ≈ k v₀    (1)  
 v_n₀ = k v₀ sinθ ≈ k v₀ θ   (2)

2. After the n-th bounce the normal component is  
 v_n,n = εⁿ v_n₀ = εⁿ k v₀ θ   (3)

3. Flight time of the n-th arc  
 t_n = 2 v_n,n / g = 2 (εⁿ k v₀ θ) / g  (4)

4. Horizontal distance travelled during that flight  
 s_n = v_t t_n ≈ (k v₀) · 2 (εⁿ k v₀ θ) / g  
   = 2 k² v₀² θ εⁿ / g         (5)

5. Convert to central angle  
 Δφ_n = s_n / R = (2 k² v₀² θ εⁿ) / (gR) (6)

6. But by definition of first cosmic velocity, v₀² = gR, so  

 Δφ_n = 2 k² θ εⁿ      (7)

7. Sum over all bounces n = 0 → ∞ (geometric series)  

 φ = Σ_{n=0}^{∞} Δφ_n  
  = 2 k² θ Σ_{n=0}^{∞} εⁿ  
  = 2 k² θ · 1/(1-ε)    (8)

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 4. Result  

The total central angle swept before the ball’s vertical motion becomes negligible is  

  φ ≈ 2 k² θ  /  (1 − ε)      (9)

This expression is valid to first order in the small launch angle θ and for sub-orbital speeds k<1.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### Final Answer  
\[
\boxed{\displaystyle \varphi \;\approx\; \frac{2\,k^{2}\,\theta}{1-\varepsilon}}
\]

questions:
Surface plasmon polariton (SPP) is a research hotspot in micro-nano optics. It is not difficult to discover through calculations that the interaction between free electrons and photons in the metal-dielectric interface region can form specific electromagnetic modes. The free electron density of the metal we use is denoted as $n$, the electrons are modeled as quasiparticles with an equivalent mass $m$ and charge $-e$. Because under optical conditions, the light frequency $\omega$ is often smaller than the plasma frequency $\omega_{p}=\sqrt{n e^{2}/\varepsilon_{0}m}$, it can be found that the corresponding equivalent relative permittivity of the metal is a negative real number. 

If a plane electromagnetic wave at this frequency, with a relative permittivity $\varepsilon_{1}>1$ for the dielectric, enters the metal (which at this frequency has an equivalent relative permittivity $\varepsilon_{2}<0$) with a wavevector $k_{x}=\alpha$, $k_{y}=-\mathrm{i}\beta$ ($\alpha$ and $\beta$ are real numbers), the electric field lies in the $xy$ plane, and the interface is defined as the $y=0$ plane, with the positive $y$-axis pointing from the dielectric towards the metal, there exists a specific horizontal wavevector $k_{x}$ such that no reflected light is generated. Instead, a unique optical mode satisfying Maxwell’s equations is formed solely by the incident and refracted light—this corresponds to the surface plasmon polariton mode. 

However, in this problem, we need to consider the case where the metal actually has a relative complex permittivity $\widetilde{\varepsilon}_{2}=\varepsilon_{21}+\mathrm{i}\varepsilon_{22}$, where $\varepsilon_{21}<0$ and the imaginary part $\varepsilon_{22}$ is a small quantity. Under these conditions, the surface plasmon polariton mode not only propagates but also attenuates. Please express the wavelength $\lambda$ of the surface plasmon polariton mode in terms of the dielectric relative permittivity $\varepsilon_{1}$, the metal’s relative complex permittivity, and the vacuum wavelength $\lambda_{0}$. Approximate to the lowest order.
solutions:
The magnetic field strength in the $z$ direction is tangentially continuous:

$$
H_{1z}=H_{2z}=H
$$

According to Maxwell's equations:

$$
\nabla\times\pmb{H}=\varepsilon\frac{\partial\pmb{E}}{\partial t}
$$

Furthermore, since the electric field is tangentially continuous:

$$
E_{1x}=E_{2x}
$$

The relationship obtained is:

$$
\frac{k_{1y}}{\varepsilon_{1}}=\frac{-\mathrm{i}\beta_{1}}{\varepsilon_{1}}=\frac{\mathrm{i}\beta_{2}}{\varepsilon_{2}}=\frac{k_{2y}}{\varepsilon_{2}}
$$

$$
\begin{array}{r}{k_{1}^{2}=\alpha^{2}-\beta_{1}^{2}=\varepsilon_{1}k_{0}^{2}>0}\\ {k_{2}^{2}=\alpha^{2}-\beta_{2}^{2}=\varepsilon_{2}k_{0}^{2}<0}\end{array}
$$

Solving for $k_{1x}=k_{2x}=k_{x}=\alpha$, we find:

$$
k_{x}=\frac{\omega}{c}\sqrt{\frac{\varepsilon_{1}\varepsilon_{2}}{\varepsilon_{1}+\varepsilon_{2}}}
$$

Squaring the above expression and rewriting, we get:

$$
(k_{x1}+\mathrm{i}k_{x2})^{2}=k_{0}^{2}\frac{\varepsilon_{1}(\varepsilon_{21}+\mathrm{i}\varepsilon_{22})}{\varepsilon_{1}+\varepsilon_{21}+\mathrm{i}\varepsilon_{22}}\approx k_{0}^{2}\frac{\varepsilon_{1}\varepsilon_{21}}{\varepsilon_{1}+\varepsilon_{21}}\left(1+\mathrm{i}\frac{\varepsilon_{22}}{\varepsilon_{21}}\right)\left(1-\mathrm{i}\frac{\varepsilon_{22}}{\varepsilon_{1}+\varepsilon_{21}}\right)
$$

By comparing the real and imaginary parts and making approximations:

$$
\begin{array}{c}{{k_{x1}^{2}=k_{0}^{2}\displaystyle\frac{\varepsilon_{1}\varepsilon_{21}}{\varepsilon_{1}+\varepsilon_{21}}}}\\ {{2k_{x1}k_{x2}=k_{0}^{2}\displaystyle\frac{\varepsilon_{1}\varepsilon_{21}}{\varepsilon_{1}+\varepsilon_{21}}\cdot\displaystyle\frac{\varepsilon_{1}\varepsilon_{22}}{\varepsilon_{21}\left(\varepsilon_{1}+\varepsilon_{21}\right)}}}\end{array}
$$

Substituting into:

$$
k_{0}=\frac{2\pi}{\lambda_{0}}\quad,\quad k_{x1}=\frac{2\pi}{\lambda}\quad,\quad k_{x2}=\frac{2\pi}{d}
$$

Finally, we obtain:

$$
\lambda=\sqrt{\frac{\varepsilon_{1}+\varepsilon_{21}}{\varepsilon_{1}\varepsilon_{21}}}\lambda_{0}
$$

## 1. Problem Analysis  
The interface metal–dielectric supports a surface-plasmon–polariton (SPP).  
•  Dielectric: real relative permittivity ε₁ (>1).  
•  Metal: complex relative permittivity 𝜀̃₂ = ε₂₁ + i ε₂₂ with ε₂₁ < 0 and |ε₂₂| ≪ |ε₂₁|.  

The SPP travels along the interface (wave-vector component kₓ) and decays normally (k_y imaginary).  
The question: to **first (lowest) order in the small loss term ε₂₂**, find the SPP wavelength λ expressed through ε₁, ε₂₁, ε₂₂ and the free-space wavelength λ₀ (= 2π/k₀, k₀ = ω/c).  

## 2. Approach  
1. Start from the well-known dispersion relation for a lossless interface,  
   kₓ = k₀ √(ε₁ ε₂ / (ε₁ + ε₂)).  
2. Treat the imaginary part i ε₂₂ as a small perturbation:  
   ε₂ = ε₂₁ + i ε₂₂, |ε₂₂| ≪ |ε₂₁|.  
3. Expand kₓ(ε₂) to first order in ε₂₂.  
   • The real part of kₓ determines the wavelength λ = 2π / Re(kₓ).  
   • Show that Re(kₓ) receives **no linear correction** → λ is unchanged to O(ε₂₂).  
4. Write λ in terms of ε₁, ε₂₁ and λ₀; quote the result and its accuracy.

## 3. Detailed Solution  

### 3.1  Exact dispersion with complex permittivity  
kₓ = k₀ √( ε₁ ε₂ /(ε₁ + ε₂) ),  ε₂ = ε₂₁ + i ε₂₂.                        (1)

Introduce real/imaginary parts for convenience  
a = ε₁ ε₂₁, b = ε₁ ε₂₂,  
c = ε₁ + ε₂₁, d = ε₂₂  (so ε₁+ε₂ = c + i d).                         (2)

Then the complex ratio inside the square root is  
R ≡ (a + i b)/(c + i d).                                                 (3)

### 3.2  First-order expansion in ε₂₂  
Because |d| = |ε₂₂| ≪ |c| and |b| ≪ |a|, write

R = (a + i b)(c − i d)/(c² + d²)  
  ≈ [(a c + b d) + i (b c − a d)] / c²              (keeping O(ε₂₂) terms)  
  ≈ a/c + i [b/c − a d/c²].                                            (4)

Substituting a, b, c, d:

A ≡ Re R = ε₁ ε₂₁ /(ε₁ + ε₂₁),                                       (5a)  
B ≡ Im R = ε₁² ε₂₂ /(ε₁ + ε₂₁)².                                     (5b)

Hence  
R = A + i B with |B| ≪ |A|.                                          (6)

### 3.3  Square root of a weakly complex number  
For small B/A the binomial expansion gives  

√(A + i B) ≈ √A + i B / (2√A)                                        (7)

Therefore  

kₓ = k₀ √A + i k₀ B /(2√A) + O(ε₂₂²).                                (8)

• Real part: Re kₓ = k₀ √A.  
• Imaginary part (attenuation): Im kₓ = k₀ B /(2√A).  

Importantly, the **real part contains no term linear in ε₂₂**.  

### 3.4  SPP wavelength to lowest order  
Wavelength along the interface:

λ = 2π / Re kₓ = 2π / (k₀ √A) = λ₀ / √A.                            (9)

Insert A from (5a):

λ = λ₀ √[(ε₁ + ε₂₁)/(ε₁ ε₂₁)] + O(ε₂₂²).                           (10)

No ε₂₂-dependent contribution appears until second order, so (10) is the “lowest-order” result requested.

## 4. Result Interpretation  
• Propagation constant:   Re kₓ identical to the lossless case at O(ε₂₂).  
• Attenuation constant:   Im kₓ ∝ ε₂₂, giving finite propagation length, but it does not affect λ at first order.  

Hence the vacuum wavelength λ₀ is “renormalised” only by the real parts ε₁ and ε₂₁ of the permittivities to leading order.

### Final Answer
\[
\boxed{\,\displaystyle 
\lambda \;\approx\; \lambda_0\,\sqrt{\frac{\varepsilon_{1}+\varepsilon_{21}}{\varepsilon_{1}\,\varepsilon_{21}}}\;+\;O(\varepsilon_{22}^{\,2})
\,}
\]
