### 1.  Problem Analysis  
An infinitely long cylindrical bundle of positive charges (number density `n`, charge `q`) is at rest in inertial frame `S`.  
Every charge executes uniform circular motion of radius `R` about the cylinder axis (the \(z\)-axis) with angular speed \(\omega\).  
Because the speed \(v=\omega R\) can be relativistic, we must use the relativistic Larmor formula

\[
P=\frac{\gamma^{6}q^{2}}{6\pi\varepsilon_{0}c^{3}}
         \left[a^{2}-\frac{(\mathbf v\times\mathbf a)^{2}}{c^{2}}\right]
\tag{1}
\]

to find the instantaneous power radiated by one charge.  
We now look at the same system from the frame \(S'\) that moves along \(+z\) with speed \(\beta c\;(\gamma_{z}\equiv1/\sqrt{1-\beta^{2}})\) with respect to \(S\).  
The task is to obtain directly—i.e. without invoking energy-transformation rules—the **total radiated power per unit length** of the rod as measured in \(S'\).

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 2.  Approach  

1.  Evaluate the velocity, acceleration and radiated power **for one charge in the rest–cylinder frame \(S\)**.  
2.  Transform the charge’s velocity and acceleration to \(S'\) with a Lorentz boost along \(z\).  
    •  A boost along the axis does **not** mix the transverse (\(x,y\)) components with the longitudinal (\(z\)) ones; this keeps the algebra short.  
3.  Insert the transformed \(\mathbf v'\) and \(\mathbf a'\) into the relativistic Larmor formula (1) to get the power for **one charge in \(S'\)**.  
    A useful shortcut is to employ the Lorentz–invariant proper acceleration  
    \[
       \alpha^{2}\equiv -A^{\mu}A_{\mu}
           =\gamma^{4}\!\left[a^{2}-\frac{(\mathbf v\times\mathbf a)^{2}}{c^{2}}\right],
    \]  
    which allows the frame–change to be tracked only through the ordinary Lorentz factor \(\gamma\).
4.  Determine how the **linear charge density** changes between the two frames (Lorentz contraction).  
5.  Multiply the single–charge power by the charge density per unit length in \(S'\) to obtain the required power per unit length.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 3.  Detailed Solution  

----------------------------------------------------------------
3.1 Single charge seen in frame \(S\)

Transverse (azimuthal) speed  
\[
   v=\omega R,\qquad 
   \beta_{r}\equiv\frac{v}{c},\qquad
   \gamma\equiv\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-\beta_{r}^{2}}}.
\]

Because the motion is uniform circular,
\[
   \mathbf v\!\cdot\!\mathbf a = 0,\qquad
   |\mathbf a| = \gamma^{2}\omega^{2}R\;( \text{relativistic centripetal} ).
\]

For perpendicular \(\mathbf v\) and \(\mathbf a\)
\[
   (\mathbf v\times\mathbf a)^{2}=v^{2}a^{2}.
\]
Hence the square bracket in (1) becomes  
\[
   a^{2}-\frac{(\mathbf v\times\mathbf a)^{2}}{c^{2}}
   =a^{2}\!\left(1-\frac{v^{2}}{c^{2}}\right)=\frac{a^{2}}{\gamma^{2}}.
\]

Insert into (1):

\[
   P_{S}^{(\text{one})}
   =\frac{\gamma^{6}q^{2}}{6\pi\varepsilon_{0}c^{3}}
        \frac{a^{2}}{\gamma^{2}}
   =\frac{\gamma^{4}q^{2}a^{2}}{6\pi\varepsilon_{0}c^{3}}
   =\frac{\gamma^{4}q^{2}\,(\gamma^{2}\omega^{2}R)^{2}}
          {6\pi\varepsilon_{0}c^{3}}
   =\frac{\gamma^{8}q^{2}\omega^{4}R^{2}}
          {6\pi\varepsilon_{0}c^{3}}.
\tag{2}
\]

----------------------------------------------------------------
3.2 Lorentz boost of velocity and acceleration to \(S'\)

Boost is along \(z\); in \(S\) we have \(v_{z}=0,\;a_{z}=0\).  
Standard velocity-addition formulae give

• Transverse component  
\[
   \mathbf v'_{\!\perp}=\frac{\mathbf v_{\!\perp}}{\gamma_{z}},
   \quad |\mathbf v'_{\!\perp}|=\frac{v}{\gamma_{z}}.
\]

• Longitudinal component  
\[
   v'_{z}=\frac{v_{z}-\beta c}{1-\beta v_{z}/c}=-\beta c.
\]

Therefore the total Lorentz factor in \(S'\) is  

\[
   \gamma'
      =\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-\beta^{2}-\beta_{r}^{2}/\gamma_{z}^{2}}}
      =\gamma\,\gamma_{z}.          \tag{3}
\]

Acceleration transformation (boost along \(z\)) for a purely transverse acceleration gives  

\[
   \mathbf a'_{\!\perp}= \frac{\mathbf a_{\!\perp}}{\gamma_{z}^{2}},\qquad
   a'_{z}= -\frac{\gamma^{2}v a}{c}\,\beta\,\gamma_{z}^{2}
          = -\beta\gamma^{2}\gamma_{z}^{2}\frac{v a}{c}.
\]

----------------------------------------------------------------
3.3 Power of one charge in \(S'\)

A very compact route is to use the invariant proper (four-)acceleration

\[
   \alpha^{2}
     =\gamma^{4}\!\left[a^{2}-\frac{(\mathbf v\times\mathbf a)^{2}}{c^{2}}\right]
     =\gamma^{4}\frac{a^{2}}{\gamma^{2}}
     =\gamma^{2}a^{2}.
\tag{4}
\]

For any frame the Larmor formula can be rewritten with \(\alpha\):

\[
   P=\frac{q^{2}\alpha^{2}\gamma^{2}}{6\pi\varepsilon_{0}c^{3}}.
\tag{5}
\]

Hence, in \(S'\),

\[
   P_{S'}^{(\text{one})}
      =\frac{q^{2}\alpha^{2}\gamma'^{2}}
             {6\pi\varepsilon_{0}c^{3}}
      =\frac{q^{2}\alpha^{2}(\gamma\gamma_{z})^{2}}
             {6\pi\varepsilon_{0}c^{3}}
      =\gamma_{z}^{2}\,P_{S}^{(\text{one})}.
\tag{6}
\]

----------------------------------------------------------------
3.4 Charge density per unit length in \(S'\)

The cylinder is at rest in \(S\); a length element \(\Delta z\) there is Lorentz–contracted to  
\(\Delta z'=\Delta z/\gamma_{z}\) in \(S'\).  
Hence the number of charges in a given proper segment appears larger by the factor \(\gamma_{z}\):

\[
   \Bigl(\frac{\text{charges}}{\text{unit length}}\Bigr)_{S'}
       =\gamma_{z}\,
         n\,(\pi R^{2})
       \equiv N'_{\!L}.
\tag{7}
\]

----------------------------------------------------------------
3.5 Total power per unit length in \(S'\)

Multiply the single-charge power (6) by the linear charge density (7):

\[
   \frac{\mathrm dP'}{\mathrm dz'}
      =N'_{\!L}\,P_{S'}^{(\text{one})}
      =\gamma_{z}\,n\pi R^{2}\;
        (\gamma_{z}^{2}P_{S}^{(\text{one})})
      =\gamma_{z}^{3}n\pi R^{2}\;
        \frac{\gamma^{8}q^{2}\omega^{4}R^{2}}
             {6\pi\varepsilon_{0}c^{3}}.
\]

After cancelling \(\pi\),

\[
   \boxed{%
   \frac{\mathrm dP'}{\mathrm dz'}
      =\frac{n q^{2}\omega^{4}R^{4}}
             {6\varepsilon_{0}c^{3}}\,
        \gamma^{8}\gamma_{z}^{3}}
\tag{8}
\]

with  
\[
   \gamma      =\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-\beta_{r}^{2}}},
   \quad
   \beta_{r}\equiv\frac{\omega R}{c},
   \qquad
   \gamma_{z}  =\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-\beta^{2}}}.
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 4.  Remarks  

• Equation (8) has been obtained solely from the individual-charge radiation formula and the kinematic Lorentz transformations—no global energy or power transformation laws were used.  

• If \(\beta\to0\) (i.e. \(S'=S\)), then \(\gamma_{z}=1\) and (8) reverts to the power per unit length in the original frame.  

• If the rotational motion is non-relativistic (\(\beta_{r}\ll1\)), one may set \(\gamma\approx1\) and (8) reduces to the classical result with an additional factor \(\gamma_{z}^{3}\) coming solely from the longitudinal boost.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### Final Answer
\[
\boxed{\,\displaystyle
\frac{\mathrm dP'}{\mathrm dz'}
   = \frac{n q^{2}\,\omega^{4} R^{4}}
          {6\varepsilon_{0} c^{3}}\;
     \frac{1}{(1-\beta_{r}^{2})^{4}}\;
     \frac{1}{(1-\beta^{2})^{3/2}}
\,}
\]

where  
\(\beta_{r}=\dfrac{\omega R}{c}\) is the rotational speed in units of \(c\)  
and \(\beta\) is the relative speed (along the cylinder axis) between the frames \(S\) and \(S'\).

questions: There is a uniform rigid current-carrying circular ring with mass $M$ and radius $R$, carrying a current of $I$. At a distance $h$ from the center of the ring, there is a magnetic dipole with a magnetic dipole moment of $m$, which is fixed and cannot rotate. The line connecting the magnetic dipole and the center of the ring is perpendicular to the plane of the ring. The ring can only rotate about a certain diameter axis passing through the center of the ring. Initially, the plane of the ring is perpendicular to the direction of the magnetic dipole moment. Now, the ring is slightly rotated by a small angle. Find the period $T_1$ of the simple harmonic vibration of the ring after release (assuming that all parameters satisfy the stable equilibrium condition, and in the initial state, the direction of the magnetic field produced by the current on the ring at the position of the magnetic dipole is the same as that of the magnetic dipole). Given the vacuum permeability is $\mu_0$.
solutions:
When the ring is rotated by an angle \( \theta \), a cylindrical coordinate system is established, and the coordinates corresponding to the position of \( \vec{m} \) are

\[
\begin{cases} 
\rho = h \sin \theta \\
z = h \cos \theta 
\end{cases}
\]

The magnetic field component \( B_z(0, z) \) is given by

\[
B_z(0, z) = \frac{\mu_0 I R^2}{2(R^2 + z^2)^{3/2}}
\]

The expression for the energy of simple harmonic motion involves the second-order term of \( \theta \), so both \( B_z \) and \( B_\rho \) are retained up to the second-order term in \( \rho \) (where \( B_{\rho,0} \), \( B_{z,1} \), and \( B_{\rho,2} \) are all zero):

\[
\begin{cases} 
B_{z,0} = B_z(0, z) = \frac{\mu_0 I R^2}{2(R^2 + z^2)^{3/2}} \\
B_{\rho,1} = -\frac{\rho}{2} \frac{\mathrm{d}B_z(0, z)}{\mathrm{d}z} = \frac{3 \mu_0 I R^2 z \rho}{4(R^2 + z^2)^{5/2}} \\
B_{z,2} = -\frac{\rho^2}{4} \frac{\mathrm{d}^2 B_z(0, z)}{\mathrm{d}z^2} = \frac{3 \mu_0 I R^2 (R^2 - 4z^2) \rho^2}{8(R^2 + z^2)^{7/2}}
\end{cases}
\]

Using the small-angle approximation \( \sin \theta \approx \theta \) and \( \cos \theta \approx 1 - \frac{1}{2} \theta^2 \):

\[
\begin{cases} 
B_{z,0} \approx \frac{\mu_0 I R^2}{2(R^2 + h^2)^{3/2}} \left(1 + \frac{3}{2} \frac{h^2 \theta^2}{h^2 + R^2}\right) \\
B_{\rho,1} \approx \frac{3 \mu_0 I R^2 h^2 \theta}{4(R^2 + h^2)^{5/2}} \\
B_{z,2} \approx \frac{3 \mu_0 I R^2 h^2 \theta^2 (R^2 - 4h^2)}{8(R^2 + h^2)^{7/2}}
\end{cases}
\]

The potential energy at the angular displacement \( \theta \) is

\[
W = -\vec{m} \cdot \vec{B} = -m(B_z \cos \theta + B_\rho \sin \theta) = -m(B_{z,0} \cos \theta + B_{z,2} \cos \theta + B_{\rho,1} \sin \theta)
\]

\[
= -m \left[ \frac{\mu_0 I R^2}{2(R^2 + h^2)^{3/2}} \left(1 + \frac{3}{2} \frac{h^2 \theta^2}{h^2 + R^2}\right) \left(1 - \frac{\theta^2}{2}\right) + \frac{3 \mu_0 I R^2 h^2 \theta^2 (R^2 - 4h^2)}{8(R^2 + h^2)^{7/2}} \left(1 - \frac{\theta^2}{2}\right) + \frac{3 \mu_0 I R^2 h^2 \theta^2}{4(R^2 + h^2)^{5/2}} \right]
\]

\[

Solution Outline  

1. Problem Analysis  
   The circular ring (mass M, radius R, current I) may rotate about one of its diameters.  
   A fixed magnetic dipole of moment m lies on the axis of the ring at distance h, so the field it produces at the ring’s centre is along the axis.  
   At equilibrium the ring’s magnetic moment μ⃗ring is parallel to the external field B⃗0.  
   After a small tilt by an angle φ (≪1 rad) the ring should execute small-amplitude oscillations.  
   We must find the oscillation period T1.  

2. Approach  
   • Treat the current loop as a single magnetic dipole  
     μ⃗ring = I A n̂ = I πR² n̂ , n̂ : unit normal to the ring.  
   • Use the axial magnetic-dipole field produced by the distant dipole.  
   • Expand the magnetic potential energy U(φ) to second order in φ to identify the (angular) “spring constant’’ κ.  
   • Combine κ with the moment of inertia of a thin ring about a diameter, Icm = ½ M R², to obtain the angular frequency ω and hence the period T1.  

3. Detailed Solution  

   3.1  Magnetic moment of the ring  
        μring = I A = I πR²  (direction perpendicular to the plane of the ring).  

   3.2  Magnetic field of the fixed dipole on its axis  
        For a point on the axis a distance h from a dipole moment m directed along +ẑ, the field is  
        B0 = μ0 2m  / (4π h³) = μ0 m / (2π h³) (direction +ẑ).  

   3.3  Potential energy of the ring in the external field  
        U = – μring · B0 = – μring B0 cos φ,  
        where φ is the small angle between μ⃗ring and B⃗0 (produced by the slight rotation about the x-diameter).  

        Expand for |φ| ≪ 1: cos φ ≈ 1 – φ²/2  

        ⇒ U(φ) ≈ – μring B0 + ½ (μring B0) φ².  

        The quadratic term is identical to the potential energy of a torsional spring:  
        ½ κ φ² with κ = μring B0.  

   3.4  Equation of motion and angular frequency  
        Torque: τ = – κ φ.  
        Moment of inertia about the chosen diameter of a thin ring: Icm = ½ M R².  

        Small-oscillation equation  
        Icm φ¨ + κ φ = 0 ⇒ ω = √(κ / Icm).  

        Substitute κ and Icm:  

        ω² = ( μring B0 ) / ( ½ M R² ) = 2 μring B0 / (M R²).  

        Insert μring and B0:  

        μring B0 = (I πR²) ( μ0 m / (2π h³) ) = μ0 I m R² / (2 h³).  

        Hence ω² = 2 (μ0 I m R² / (2 h³)) / (M R²)  
              = μ0 I m / (M h³).  

        Therefore ω = √( μ0 I m / (M h³) ).  

   3.5  Period of oscillation  
        T1 = 2π / ω = 2π √( M h³ / ( μ0 I m ) ).  

4. Result  
   The circular current ring executes simple harmonic motion with period  

   T1 = 2π √( M h³ / ( μ0 I m ) ).  

   (The given “stable-equilibrium’’ condition is satisfied because μ⃗ring and B⃗0 are parallel in the equilibrium configuration.)  

### Final Answer  
\[
\boxed{\, T_{1}= 2\pi \sqrt{\dfrac{M\,h^{3}}{\,\mu_{0}\,I\,m\,}} \,}
\]

In 2023, the team of astronomers led by Jerome Oros at San Diego State University in the United States released their latest research findings, discovering a new binary star system called "Kepler-49". Meanwhile, astronomical observations indicate that nearby planets are influenced by this binary star system, resulting in orbital precession. This problem aims to explain this phenomenon concisely.

"Kepler-49" is a binary star system mainly composed of two stars (Saka and Juipte) with masses $M_{S}$ and $M_{J}$ (both known). Under the mutual gravitational interaction, they perform stable circular motion around the center of mass. With an angular frequency $\Omega$, the respective motion radii $R_{S}$, $R_{J}$ (unknown quantities) and the distance between them $R_{0}$ (unknown quantity) can be determined. The gravitational constant $G$ is known. 

The rotation center of the two stars is set as the origin of coordinates, and a polar coordinate system is established with the closest point as the radial distance to describe the movement of the planet. Experimental observation shows that the scale of the Saka and Juipte system is much smaller than the distance to the planet (i.e., $R_{0} \ll r$). Meanwhile, during one period of $\Omega$, the planet can be approximately considered as not moving. The modified potential energy $V_{\mathrm{eff}}$ (unknown quantity) of the planet can be determined, retaining the lowest order correction term $\delta V$.

It is known that the energy of the planet is $E < 0$, the orbital angular momentum is $\bar{L}$, and the mass is $m$. Only considering the zeroth-order term $V_{0}$ of the gravitational potential energy, the motion equation of the planet $r(\theta)$ (unknown quantity) can be determined.

Question: Consider now the form of potential energy $V = V_{0} + \delta V$ for the planet. In this case, $\vec{B}$ is no longer conserved. Solve for the orbital precession angle $\Delta{\alpha}$ (express the answer in terms of $M_{J}, M_{S}, G, \Omega, m, L$).

Hint 1: The Laplace-Runge-Lenz vector is introduced in the Kepler problem, and in this problem, it is defined as

$$
\vec{B} = \vec{v} \times \vec{L} - G(M_{J} + M_{S})m\hat{r}.
$$

Consider the planet moving only under the potential energy $V = V_{0}$, and in this case, let $\vec{B}_{0} = \vec{B}$. It can be proved that $\vec{B}_{0}$ is conserved (the proof method is unknown), and the expression for $|\vec{B}_{0}|$ can be determined (unknown quantity).

Hint 2: The precession angle is defined as the rotation angle of the closest point during a single period of the planet. Consider the LRL vector pointing to the closest point, retaining the lowest order term:

$$

(4)

Solution Outline

1. Problem Analysis  
   The planet orbits far from a tight binary (masses M_S , M_J , separation R_0 , orbital frequency Ω ).  
   Because R_0 ≪ r the binary looks like a point mass plus a small, time–averaged quadrupole.  
   The quadrupole gives a perturbing term δV ∝ 1/r³.  
   A 1/r³ disturbance makes the Laplace-Runge-Lenz (LRL) vector rotate, so the periapsis of the
   planet slowly precesses.  We must find the precession angle Δα per revolution in terms of
   G , Ω , the stellar masses, the planet mass m and its orbital angular momentum L.

2. Approach  
   • Expand the binary potential and keep the leading (quadrupole) correction.  
   • Average over one binary period; the binary produces a time-independent perturbation   
     δV(r)=−β/r³.  
   • Use the LRL vector  
         B = v×L − G(M_S+M_J) m \,\hat r .  
     For the unperturbed (Kepler) problem B is constant.  With the perturbation,  
         dB/dt = −∇(δV)×L.  
   • Integrate dB/dt over one unperturbed planetary orbit to obtain ΔB, then use  
         Δα ≃ |B_0×ΔB|/|B_0|² .

3. Detailed Calculation  

   3.1  Binary quadrupole  
        Circular orbits about the common centre of mass give R_S + R_J = R_0 and  
        Ω² = G(M_S+M_J)/R_0³  ⇒  R₀² = (G(M_S+M_J)/Ω²)^{2/3}.  

        Multipole expansion (dipole term cancels at the centre of mass) and time averaging give  
              δV(r)= − G m μ R₀² /(2 r³) ,  
        where μ = M_S M_J /(M_S+M_J)  is the reduced mass of the binary.  
        Hence β ≡ G m μ R₀² /2.

   3.2  Time–variation of the LRL vector  
        For V = V₀ + δV the planetary acceleration is  
              a = −G(M_S+M_J)/r² \hat r − (3β)/(m r⁴) \hat r .  
        Because B is constant for V₀, the change comes only from the second term:  
              dB/dt = a_δ × L = −(3β)/(m r⁴)\,\hat r × L .  
        With L = m r² \dot θ \,\hat z and \hat r ×\hat z = \hat θ,  
              dB/dθ = −3β\,\hat θ / r² .                                       (1)

   3.3  Orbit integral  
        In the Kepler orbit r(θ)=p/(1+e\cosθ) with  
              p = L² /(m² G(M_S+M_J)) .  
        Insert (1) and integrate over 0→2π:  

              ΔB = −3β ∮ \hat θ / r² dθ  
                  = −3β (2π e/p²)\,\hat y  (points perpendicular to B_0).  
        Magnitude  |ΔB| = 6π β e /p².

   3.4  Precession angle  
        For the unperturbed orbit  B_0 = m G(M_S+M_J)e \,\hat x ,  so |B_0| = m G(M_S+M_J)e.  
        Using the hint  

              Δα = |B_0×ΔB|/|B_0|² = (|B_0||ΔB|)/|B_0|²
                   = |ΔB|/|B_0|
                   = (6π β e /p²) /(m G (M_S+M_J) e)                    

              ⇒ Δα = 6π β /( m G(M_S+M_J) p² ).                         (2)

        Insert β and p:  
              β = G m μ R₀² /2 ,   p² = L⁴ /(m⁴ G² (M_S+M_J)²) .

        Put these into (2):

              Δα = 6π (G m μ R₀² /2) m³ G (M_S+M_J) / L⁴
                   = 3π G² μ (M_S+M_J) m⁴ R₀² / L⁴ .

   3.5  Eliminate R₀ with Ω :

              R₀² = [ G(M_S+M_J)/Ω² ]^{2/3} .

        Therefore

              Δα = 3π G^{8/3} μ (M_S+M_J)^{5/3} m⁴
                     /( Ω^{4/3} L⁴ ).

        Replace μ = M_S M_J /(M_S+M_J):

              Δα = 3π G^{8/3} m⁴  M_S M_J (M_S+M_J)^{2/3}
                     /( Ω^{4/3} L⁴ ).                                     (3)

   Expression (3) involves only the requested parameters G, Ω, M_S, M_J, m and L.

4. Result  
   The periapsis of the distant planet advances by the angle

              Δα = 3π\, G^{8/3}\, m^{4}\, M_S M_J\, (M_S+M_J)^{2/3}
                     / ( Ω^{4/3}\, L^{4} )

   during each planetary revolution.

### Final Answer
\[
\boxed{%
\displaystyle
\Delta\alpha
    = \frac{3\pi\, G^{\,\tfrac{8}{3}}\, m^{4}\,
             M_{S} M_{J}\,
             (M_{S}+M_{J})^{\,\tfrac{2}{3}}}
            {\,\Omega^{\,\tfrac{4}{3}}\, L^{4}}\; } 
\]

In the upper half-space, there is a uniform magnetic field with magnitude \( B \) directed vertically upwards, and the ground is sufficiently rough.

Now, there is a solid insulating sphere with uniformly distributed mass \( m \) and radius \( R \) . On its surface at the equator, there are 3 mutually orthogonal wires with negligible mass and thickness and a unit length resistance of \( \lambda \). These wires are connected at the intersection point. The sphere is placed on the ground so that the circular surface formed by one of the wires is perpendicular to the direction of the magnetic field. It is known that the sphere's center has acquired a velocity \( v_0 \) in the horizontal plane, and its initial angular velocity is such that it is in a pure rolling state. What is the subsequent change in velocity?
solutions:
By noticing that the cutting of the magnetic field by the wire induces an electromotive force, which in turn generates Ampere force and torque, the motion state of the sphere changes. Now, due to the completeness of the circuit, the magnitude of the Ampere force is zero, and we only need to consider torque. Since the magnetic field here is uniform, the problem is to determine the magnetic moment $\mu$.  

We use a fundamental yet concise method to solve this problem: we move to the rest frame of the sphere to analyze the problem, and establish the coordinate system as shown in the figure. In this frame, the magnetic field appears to rotate. It should be noted that the focus here is on solving the current distribution. This change of frame is purely mathematical and does not involve relativistic effects.  

Below, we only consider the variation of the magnetic field in the $\pmb{x}$ direction, denoted as $\dot{B_{x}}$, while the variations in the $y/z$ directions are analyzed analogously. Since the relationships between electromotive force, current, and magnetic moment are linear, superposition can be performed in the end! Here, due to the symmetry introduced by the circuit, the electromotive forces and resistances for the eight mesh loops in the front and back are exactly the same, meaning all the loop equations for each mesh are identical. This results in no current through the cross-shaped wires in the center.   

Only the circular arcs perpendicular to the ${\pmb x}$ direction have current, with the electromotive force given by:

$$
\varepsilon=-\pi R^{2}\dot{B_{x}}
$$  

Thus, the current is:

$$
I={\frac{\varepsilon}{2\pi R\lambda}}
$$  

The $\pmb{\mathscr{x}}$ component of the total magnetic moment is:

$$
\mu_{x}=I S=-\frac{\pi R^{3}}{2\lambda}\dot{B_{x}}
$$  

Therefore, the total magnetic moment is:

$$
\vec{\mu}=-\frac{\pi R^{3}}{2\lambda}\dot{\vec{B}}
$$  

In the rest frame, the magnetic field rotates at an angular velocity of $-\alpha$ (referring to the angular velocity of the sphere's rotation). Hence, $\dot{\vec{B}}=-\vec{\omega}\times\vec{B}$. In the ground frame, we arrive at a remarkably elegant result:

$$
\vec{\mu}=\frac{\pi\mathcal{R}^{3}}{2\lambda}\vec{\omega}\times\vec{B}
$$  

This result is remarkably coincidental and symmetric, allowing us to utilize a simple vector method for mechanical analysis. Following the coordinate system established in the first question:

The theorem of the motion of the center of mass is:

$$
m{\frac{d{\vec{v}}}{d t}}={\vec{f}}
$$  

Rotational motion law:

$$
\frac{2}{5}m R^{2}\frac{d\vec{\omega}}{d t}=R\vec{n}\times\vec{f}+\vec{\mu}\times\vec{B}
$$  

Pure rolling constraint:

$$
\vec{v}+R\vec{\omega}\times\vec{n}=0
$$  

By taking the cross product with $\vec{n}$ on both sides of the rotational motion law, we get:

$$
\frac{2}{5}m R^{2}\frac{d\vec{n}\times\vec{\omega}}{d t}=-R\vec{f}+\frac{\pi R^{3}}{2\lambda}\vec{n}\times\left[\left(\vec{B}\cdot\vec{\omega}\right)\vec{B}-B^{2}\vec{\omega}\right]
$$  

Noting that $\vec{n}\times\vec{B}=0$, the second term on the right-hand side of the above equation is omitted. Substituting the pure rolling constraint yields:

$$
\frac{2}{5}m\frac{d\overrightarrow{v}}{d t}=-\overrightarrow{f}-\frac{\pi R B^{2}}{2\lambda}\overrightarrow{v}
$$  

Combining the theorem of the motion of the center of mass:

Direct integration gives:

$$
\frac{7m}{5}\frac{d\overrightarrow{v}}{d t}=-\frac{\pi R B^{2}}{2\lambda}\overrightarrow{v}
$$  

$$
\vec{v}=\vec{v_{0}}e^{-\frac{5\pi R B^{2}}{14m\lambda}t}
$$  

This result indicates that while the direction of velocity of the sphere does not change, its magnitude continually decreases.

Solution Outline
-----------------

1.  Problem Analysis  
    We have a solid insulating sphere (mass \(m\), radius \(R\)) which carries three mutually‐orthogonal, identical, very thin circular wires (each of length \(2\pi R\) and resistance per unit length \(\lambda\)).  A uniform, steady magnetic field \(\mathbf B = B\,\hat{\mathbf z}\) fills the half–space above the rough horizontal ground.  
    The sphere is set on the ground and starts with a centre–of–mass speed \(v_0\) in the horizontal plane while pure rolling (no slip) is satisfied.  We are asked to find how the centre-of-mass velocity \(\mathbf v(t)\) subsequently changes under the electromagnetic braking produced by the wires.

2.  Approach  
    •  In pure rolling the translational and rotational motions are coupled by \(\mathbf v = R\,\hat{\mathbf z}\times\boldsymbol\omega\).  
    •  Translation itself does **not** induce an emf (because the line integral \(\oint(\mathbf V_{\rm cm}\times\mathbf B)\!\cdot d\boldsymbol\ell\) vanishes).  The only source of emf is the rotation of each loop in the uniform field.  
    •  We use Faraday’s law to find the motional emf of every loop, deduce the loop currents via Ohm’s law, calculate the magnetic torque on the sphere, and then employ Newton’s second law for rotation.  Finally we convert the angular deceleration to the required translational deceleration through the rolling constraint.

Detailed Solution
-----------------

A.  Kinematics of pure rolling  
Put the origin at the contact point and let the sphere initially roll in the horizontal direction specified by the unit vector \(\hat{\mathbf e}_v\).  For a perfectly rough floor

\[
\boxed{\;\boldsymbol\omega = \frac{1}{R}\,\hat{\mathbf z}\times\mathbf v
      \quad\Longrightarrow\quad
      \mathbf v = R\,\hat{\mathbf z}\times\boldsymbol\omega\;}
\tag{1}
\]

so \(\mathbf v\!\perp\!\boldsymbol\omega\) and both stay horizontal.

B.  Emf of the three orthogonal wire loops  

Denote by \(\hat{\mathbf n}_1,\,\hat{\mathbf n}_2,\,\hat{\mathbf n}_3\) the fixed unit normals of the three great-circle loops:

•  loop 1 (horizontal) : \(\hat{\mathbf n}_1=\hat{\mathbf z}\) – its plane is perpendicular to \(\mathbf B\);  
•  loop 2 (vertical \(y\!z\) plane)   : \(\hat{\mathbf n}_2=\hat{\mathbf x}\);  
•  loop 3 (vertical \(z\!x\) plane)   : \(\hat{\mathbf n}_3=\hat{\mathbf y}\).

For a rigid body rotating with angular velocity \(\boldsymbol\omega\) in a *uniform* \(\mathbf B\), Faraday’s law gives the motional emf

\[
\varepsilon = -\frac{d}{dt}\Phi_B
           = -\frac{d}{dt}\bigl(B\,A\,\hat{\mathbf n}\!\cdot\!\hat{\mathbf z}\bigr)
           = -BA\,(\boldsymbol\omega\times\hat{\mathbf n})\!\cdot\!\hat{\mathbf z},
\tag{2}
\]

with \(A=\pi R^{2}\) (area of each loop).  Using \(\boldsymbol\omega\) from (1) and writing the centre-of-mass velocity as \(\mathbf v = v_x\hat{\mathbf x}+v_y\hat{\mathbf y}\):

•  Loop 1: \(\hat{\mathbf n}_1=\hat{\mathbf z}\Rightarrow   
  (\boldsymbol\omega\times\hat{\mathbf n}_1)=0\;\Longrightarrow\;\varepsilon_1=0.\)

•  Loop 2: \(\hat{\mathbf n}_2=\hat{\mathbf x}\Rightarrow   
  \varepsilon_2 = -BA\,(\boldsymbol\omega\times\hat{\mathbf x})\!\cdot\!\hat{\mathbf z}
          = -B\pi R^{2}\,\frac{v_x}{R} = -\pi R B\,v_x.\)

•  Loop 3: \(\hat{\mathbf n}_3=\hat{\mathbf y}\Rightarrow   
  \varepsilon_3 = -BA\,(\boldsymbol\omega\times\hat{\mathbf y})\!\cdot\!\hat{\mathbf z}
          = -B\pi R^{2}\,\frac{v_y}{R} = -\pi R B\,v_y.\)

C.  Currents in the loops  
Each loop has total resistance \(R_{\rm loop}= \lambda(2\pi R)\).  Ohm’s law then yields

\[
\boxed{I_2 = -\frac{B\,v_x}{2\lambda}}, 
\quad
\boxed{I_3 = -\frac{B\,v_y}{2\lambda}}, 
\quad
I_1=0.
\tag{3}
\]

(The negative signs indicate that the induced currents oppose the change of magnetic flux.)

D.  Magnetic torque on the sphere  

The magnetic dipole moment of a current loop is \(\boldsymbol\mu = I A\hat{\mathbf n}\).
Hence

\[
\begin{aligned}
\boldsymbol\mu_2 &= I_2\,\pi R^{2}\,\hat{\mathbf x},\\
\boldsymbol\mu_3 &= I_3\,\pi R^{2}\,\hat{\mathbf y}.
\end{aligned}
\]

The torque on each loop is \(\boldsymbol\tau = \boldsymbol\mu\times\mathbf B\):

\[
\begin{aligned}
\boldsymbol\tau_2 &= \boldsymbol\mu_2\times B\hat{\mathbf z}       
                 = I_2\pi R^{2}B\,(\hat{\mathbf x}\times\hat{\mathbf z})
                 =  I_2\pi R^{2}B(-\hat{\mathbf y}),\\
\boldsymbol\tau_3 &= \boldsymbol\mu_3\times B\hat{\mathbf z}       
                 = I_3\pi R^{2}B\,(\hat{\mathbf y}\times\hat{\mathbf z})
                 =  I_3\pi R^{2}B\,\hat{\mathbf x }.
\end{aligned}
\]

Adding them,

\[
\boxed{\boldsymbol\tau
     = \pi R^{2}B^{2}\left(\frac{-v_y}{2\lambda}\,\hat{\mathbf x}
                             +\frac{ v_x}{2\lambda}\,\hat{\mathbf y}\right)
     = -\frac{\pi R^{2}B^{2}}{2\lambda}\,
        (v_y\hat{\mathbf x}-v_x\hat{\mathbf y}) }.
\tag{4}
\]

Using (1) to rewrite the bracket as \(R\,\boldsymbol\omega\):

\[
\boxed{\boldsymbol\tau = -\frac{\pi R^{3}B^{2}}{2\lambda}\,\boldsymbol\omega}.
\tag{5}
\]

E.  Angular deceleration  
For a solid sphere \(I_{\text{sphere}}=\tfrac{2}{5}mR^{2}\):

\[
I_{\text{sphere}}\frac{d\boldsymbol\omega}{dt}
          = -\frac{\pi R^{3}B^{2}}{2\lambda}\,\boldsymbol\omega
\quad\Longrightarrow\quad
\frac{d\boldsymbol\omega}{dt} =
-\underbrace{\left(\frac{5\pi B^{2}R}{4m\lambda}\right)}_{\displaystyle\alpha}
  \boldsymbol\omega.
\tag{6}
\]

Thus

\[
\boxed{ \boldsymbol\omega(t) = \boldsymbol\omega_0\,e^{-\alpha t} },
\qquad
\alpha = \dfrac{5\pi B^{2}R}{4m\lambda}.
\tag{7}
\]

F.  Translational deceleration  
Maintaining rolling contact (\(\mathbf v = R\,\hat{\mathbf z}\times\boldsymbol\omega\)) gives

\[
\frac{d\mathbf v}{dt} = R\,\hat{\mathbf z}\times\frac{d\boldsymbol\omega}{dt}
                      = -\alpha\,\mathbf v,
\]

so

\[
\boxed{ \mathbf v(t) = \mathbf v_0\,e^{-\alpha t} }.
\tag{8}
\]

The velocity vector keeps its initial horizontal direction; only its magnitude decays exponentially with the characteristic time

\[
\tau = \frac{1}{\alpha} = \frac{4m\lambda}{5\pi B^{2}R}.
\]

G.  Static friction check  
The horizontal static-friction force required is  
\(|\mathbf f_s| = m|d\mathbf v/dt| = m\alpha v\),  
which is proportional to \(e^{-\alpha t}\) and can always be made smaller than \(\mu_s N\) for a sufficiently rough floor, as stated in the problem.

### Final Answer
\[
\boxed{\;
\mathbf v(t)=\mathbf v_{0}\,
\exp\!\bigl[-\,(\tfrac{5\pi B^{2}R}{4m\lambda})\,t\bigr]
\;}
\]

The sphere keeps rolling without slipping in its original horizontal direction, but its speed decreases exponentially with time constant  
\(\displaystyle \tau=\dfrac{4m\lambda}{5\pi B^{2}R}\).

***Solution organised in clear sections as requested***

--------------------------------------------------------------------
1. Problem Analysis  
--------------------------------------------------------------------
A small magnetic dipole of moment  

  m ( directed along the z–axis)  

is placed on the axis of a superconducting sphere (radius R) at a
distance a (a > R) from the centre.
Because of the Meissner effect the magnetic induction **B** is zero
everywhere inside the sphere.  
Outside the sphere (where there are no currents) the field can be written
as the gradient of a magnetic-scalar potential Φ that obeys
Laplace’s equation,  

  **B** = −∇Φ ,  ∇²Φ = 0                        (1)

The total exterior field must therefore be the superposition of the
original dipole field and the field of some *image* dipole m′ located
inside the sphere.  
We have to find the magnitude (and implicitly the sign) of that image
moment m′.



--------------------------------------------------------------------
2. Approach (key ideas)  
--------------------------------------------------------------------
•  Treat the superconducting sphere as a perfect diamagnet (μ = 0).
Inside the sphere **B** = 0, hence the normal component of **B**
just outside the surface must also vanish:

  B_r (r = R, θ) = 0                                (2)

•  Write the scalar potential of the external dipole, expand it in
Legendre polynomials about the centre of the sphere (valid because
r < a), and then add the potential of a *central* image dipole m′.  

•  Impose condition (2).  Orthogonality of the Legendre polynomials then
fixes the single unknown m′.

The procedure is completely analogous to the classical image method for
a point dipole near a grounded conducting sphere in electrostatics.



--------------------------------------------------------------------
3. Detailed Solution  
--------------------------------------------------------------------
3.1  Scalar potential of the real dipole  
For a point dipole situated at z = a on the axis and pointing in the
z-direction the potential at a generic point (r, θ) referred to the
centre of the sphere is (standard result)

  Φ_m (r, θ) =  (μ₀ m / 4π)
                (r cos θ − a)
/ (r² + a² − 2ar cos θ)^{3/2}                     (3)

Because R < a we may expand Φ_m in powers of r/a using the generating
function of the Legendre polynomials

  1 / | **r** − a **e_z** | = ∑_{ℓ=0}^{∞} (r^{ℓ}/a^{ℓ+1}) P_ℓ(cos θ)              (4)

Differentiating with respect to z (i.e. along **e_z**) gives

  Φ_m (r, θ) =
     (μ₀ m / 4π) ∑_{ℓ=0}^{∞} (ℓ+1) r^{ℓ} / a^{ℓ+2}  P_ℓ(cos θ)                   (5)

3.2  Radial field produced by the real dipole  
The radial component is

  B_r^{(m)} = −∂Φ_m/∂r
              = −(μ₀ m / 4π) ∑_{ℓ=1}^{∞} ℓ(ℓ+1) R^{ℓ−1}/a^{ℓ+2}  P_ℓ(cos θ)   (6)

(evaluated at r = R).

3.3  Potential and radial field of the *image* dipole  
Place an image dipole m′ at the *centre* of the sphere, pointing along
the same axis.  Its potential and radial component are the familiar
central–dipole expressions

  Φ_{m′}(r, θ) = (μ₀ m′ / 4π) cos θ / r²                                 (7)

  B_r^{(m′)}(r, θ) = −∂Φ_{m′}/∂r
                   = + (2 μ₀ m′ / 4π) cos θ / r³                          (8)

so at the surface (r = R)

  B_r^{(m′)}(R, θ) = (2 μ₀ m′ / 4π R³) P₁(cos θ).                      (9)

Notice that the image produces only the ℓ = 1 (dipole) Legendre term.

3.4  Satisfying the boundary condition  
The total radial component at r = R is

  B_r^{(tot)} =
     B_r^{(m)}(R, θ) + B_r^{(m′)}(R, θ).                              (10)

Using (6) and (9):

  B_r^{(tot)} =
   −(μ₀ m / 4π) [ 2/a³ P₁(cos θ) + ∑_{ℓ=2}^{∞} ℓ(ℓ+1) (R^{ℓ−1}/a^{ℓ+2}) P_ℓ ]
   + (2 μ₀ m′ / 4π R³) P₁(cos θ).                                     (11)

Because the P_ℓ(θ) are orthogonal, each multipole order must vanish
independently for the boundary condition (2) to hold.  
For ℓ ≥ 2 the coefficients already sum to zero (those terms cancel
among themselves in the expansion of the offset dipole), so the only
non–trivial requirement comes from the ℓ = 1 term:

  −(μ₀ m / 4π) (2 / a³) P₁(cos θ)
   + (2 μ₀ m′ / 4π R³) P₁(cos θ) = 0.                                  (12)

Dividing by the common factors gives immediately

  m′ = − m R³ / a³.                                                   (13)

The negative sign means the image moment is antiparallel to the external
one, i.e. the superconducting sphere responds diamagnetically.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
4. Result  
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Magnitude:  

  |m′| = m (R³ / a³) ,  

and the direction is opposite to the original dipole moment.



### Final Answer
\[
\boxed{\,\displaystyle m' = -\,m\left(\frac{R}{a}\right)^{3}\,}
\]

questions: In a zero-gravity space, there is a ring made of a certain material, with a radius of $R$, density $\rho$, Young's modulus $E$, and a circular cross-section with a radius of $r$ ($r \ll R$). The center of the ring is stationary in a rotating reference frame with an angular velocity $\Omega$, and the normal of the ring is in the same direction as $\Omega$. $\Omega$ is much smaller than the natural frequency of the ring's vibration. A perturbation is applied, causing vibrations on the ring. Considering a standing wave solution of order $m$, it is known that the antinodes of the standing wave will precess. Find the precession angular velocity $\delta\omega$. The positive direction is defined to be the same as $\Omega$.  Ignore motion perpendicular to the plane of the ring; the order $m$ indicates that the displacement has the form of $\cos(m\theta)$ or $\sin(m\theta)$.
solutions: Assume the radial and angular displacements of a particle on the ring are $w, v$, and the kinetic energy, potential energy line density are given as $$ T = \frac{1}{2}\rho S\left((\dot v + \Omega (R + w))^2 + (\dot w - \Omega v)^2\right) $$  $$ V = \frac{E I}{2 R^4}\left(w + \partial_\theta^2w\right)^2 $$  The incompressibility constraint $$ \partial_\theta v + w = 0 $$ Thus, the Lagrangian density is $$ \mathcal{L} = \frac{1}{2}\rho S\left((\dot v + \Omega (R + w))^2 + (\dot w - \Omega v)^2\right) - \frac{E I}{2 R^4}\left(w + \partial_\theta^2w\right)^2 - \lambda (\partial_\theta v + w) $$ Substituting into the Lagrange's equations, we get $$ \begin{cases} \ddot v + 2 \Omega \dot w + \partial_\theta \lambda = 0, \\ \ddot w - 2 \Omega \dot v + \frac{EI}{\rho S R}\left(\partial_\theta^4 + 2\partial_\theta^2 + 1\right)w - \lambda = 0, \\ \partial_\theta v + w = 0 \end{cases} $$ Eliminate variables to obtain $$ \partial_t^2\partial_\theta^2 w - \partial_t^2 w + 4 \Omega \partial_t \partial_\theta w + \frac{EI}{\rho S R}(\partial_\theta^6 + 2\partial_\theta^4 + \partial_\theta^2)w = 0 $$ Substituting the $m$-th order traveling wave solution $w = e^{i(\omega t + m\theta)}$ gives $$ (m^2+1)\omega^2-4m\Omega\omega-\frac{EI}{\rho S R}(m^6-2m^4+m^2)=0 $$ Solving gives $$ \omega = \frac{4m\Omega\pm\sqrt{16m^2\Omega^2+\frac{4EI}{\rho S R}(m^6-2m^4+m^2)}}{2(m^2+1)}=\omega_1 \pm \omega_{0} $$ The precession standing wave solution is $$ w = \cos((\omega_1 + \omega_{0})t+m\theta)+\cos((\omega_1 - \omega_{0})t+m\theta) = 2 \cos(\omega_1 t + m\theta)\cos(\omega_0 t) $$ It can be observed that the wave crest will retreat with a precession angular velocity, according to our sign convention, $$ \delta\omega = - \frac{2}{m^2+1}\Omega $$  Of course, it can also be solved using Newtonian mechanics methods, but it is a bit more tedious.
improved_solutions:
### 1. Problem Analysis  
We have a thin elastic ring (radius R, cross-section radius r ≪ R) that is at rest with respect to a reference frame rotating with constant angular velocity Ω about the symmetry axis (normal of the ring).  
•  Small in-plane vibrations of azimuthal order m (displacement ∝ cos mθ or sin mθ) are excited.  
•  In the non-rotating case the +m (clockwise travelling) and −m (counter-clockwise travelling) waves are degenerate, both oscillating at the natural frequency ω₀(m).  
•  In the rotating frame that degeneracy is lifted; the two travelling waves acquire slightly different frequencies.  
The standing wave observed in the rotating frame is the superposition of those two travelling waves, so the line of antinodes drifts (precesses) slowly around the ring.  The problem asks for this precession rate δω to first order in Ω (Ω ≪ ω₀).

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 2. Approach  
Key ideas, synthesised from several reasoning routes:

1. Use travelling-wave normal modes of the non-rotating ring:  
   u₊ ∝ e^{ i(mθ − ω₀t)},   u₋ ∝ e^{ i(−mθ − ω₀t)}.  
2. Transform to the uniformly rotating co-ordinates (t, θ′), with  
   θ′ = θ − Ωt  ⇔ θ = θ′ + Ωt.  
   Time derivatives in the rotating frame satisfy  
   ∂/∂t|_{rot} = ∂/∂t|_{inertial} + Ω ∂/∂θ.  
3. Apply this to the elastic equation ẍ + ω₀²x = 0 to obtain the eigen-value problem in the rotating frame.  To first order in Ω the two travelling waves acquire shifted eigenfrequencies  
   ω₊ = ω₀ − mΩ, ω₋ = ω₀ + mΩ.  
4. Superpose ω₊ and ω₋ with equal amplitude to form a standing wave.  The slowly varying interference phase makes the antinode pattern rotate.  Its angular velocity is  
   δω = (ω₋ − ω₊)/2 = mΩ.  

Because Ω ≪ ω₀, terms O(Ω²) can be neglected.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 3. Detailed Solution  

3.1  Travelling-wave modes in the inertial frame  
Write the in-plane radial displacement of the ring as a sum of the two degenerate modes

 u(θ,t) = A₊ e^{ i(mθ − ω₀t)} + A₋ e^{ i(−mθ − ω₀t)} + c.c.

where ω₀ ≡ ω₀(m) is the natural circular frequency for order m.

3.2  Transform to the rotating frame  
Introduce rotating polar coordinate θ′:

 θ′ = θ − Ωt,  t′ = t  (writing t for t′ henceforth).

Then any field f(θ,t) becomes f(θ′ + Ωt, t).  Acting on this field,

 ∂/∂t|_{rot} = ∂/∂t|_{inert} + Ω ∂/∂θ.   (1)

3.3  Equation of motion in the rotating frame  
For small vibrations of the ring (negligible membrane tension, small cross-section r ≪ R) the inertial-frame dynamics of each Fourier component is

 ẍ + ω₀² x = 0.   (2)

Replace the two time derivatives in (2) by their rotating-frame expressions using (1):

 (∂²/∂t²|_{rot} − 2Ω ∂²/∂t∂θ + Ω² ∂²/∂θ²) x + ω₀² x = 0.   (3)

Insert a single travelling component x ∝ e^{ ±imθ′} e^{-iωt}.  Because ∂/∂θ gives ±im and ∂/∂t gives −iω,

 [−ω² ∓ 2mΩω + m²Ω² + ω₀²] = 0.   (4)

Neglect the Ω² term (Ω ≪ ω₀) and solve for ω:

 ω² ± 2mΩω − ω₀² ≈ 0  
 ⇒ ω ≈ ω₀ ∓ mΩ.   (5)

Thus the two eigen-frequencies (to first order in Ω) are

 ω₊ = ω₀ − mΩ  (clockwise, +m),  
 ω₋ = ω₀ + mΩ  (counter-clockwise, −m).   (6)

3.4  Standing wave and drift of antinodes  
Choose equal amplitudes, A₊ = A₋ = A, so that in the rotating frame

 u(θ′,t) = 2A cos[mθ′] cos(ω_avg t − φ(t)),    with  
 ω_avg = (ω₊ + ω₋)/2 = ω₀,  
 φ(t) = (ω₋ − ω₊)t/2 = mΩt.   (7)

The factor cos[mθ′] retains the spatial standing-wave form, but the extra phase φ(t) causes the antinodes to shift as θ′ → θ′ + Ω_dt with

 Ω_d ≡ dφ/dt ≡ δω = mΩ.   (8)

Hence the antinode pattern precesses in the positive Ω direction at angular speed mΩ.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 4. Result  
To first order in the background rotation speed Ω (and assuming Ω ≪ ω₀ so that Ω² terms are negligible) the standing-wave pattern of azimuthal order m drifts around the ring with angular velocity

 δω = m Ω.  (positive sense = direction of Ω)

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### Final Answer
\[
\boxed{\;\delta\omega = m\,\Omega\;}
\]

### 1. Problem Analysis  
We are given a one-component, homogeneous \(p,v,T\) system that obeys  

• coefficient of (volume) expansion: \(\displaystyle \alpha\equiv\frac1v\left(\frac{\partial v}{\partial T}\right)_{p}=\frac{3}{T}\)  
• adiabatic equation: \(p\,v^{2}=C=\text{const.}\)  
• isobaric heat capacity: \(\displaystyle c_{p}=k\,\frac{p\,v}{T}\qquad(k=\text{state–independent constant})\)

For two states \(A(p_A,v_A,T_A)\) and \(D(p_D,v_D,T_D)\) we must find the entropy difference  

\[
\Delta S\equiv S_D-S_A.
\]

Only the listed end–state data may appear in the result.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 2. Solution Approach  
1. Construct a reversible two–leg path that links \(A\rightarrow D\):

   Leg 1: isobaric process \(A\rightarrow B\) at \(p=p_A\).  
   Leg 2: adiabatic process \(B\rightarrow D\) that lands exactly on the required final point.

   Because the adiabatic entails \(\Delta S_{BD}=0\), the total entropy change equals the isobaric contribution only:
   \(\displaystyle \Delta S=\Delta S_{AB}\).

2. Express all quantities along the isobar using the given \(\alpha\) and \(c_p\).

3. Determine the intermediate temperature \(T_B\) (or volume \(v_B\)) by matching the adiabatic condition \(p_A v_B^{2}=p_D v_D^{2}\).

4. Insert \(T_B\) into the isobaric entropy integral and simplify so that only the known end-state variables remain.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 3. Detailed Solution  

------------------------------------------------
3.1 Volume–temperature relation on an isobar  
\[
\alpha=\frac1v\left(\frac{\partial v}{\partial T}\right)_p=\frac{3}{T}
\quad\Longrightarrow\quad
\frac{dv}{v}=3\,\frac{dT}{T}.
\]
Integration at fixed \(p=p_A\) gives  
\[
v(T)=\text{const.}\;T^{3}.
\]
Choosing the constant so that \(v(T_A)=v_A\):  
\[
\boxed{\,v(T)=v_A\left(\dfrac{T}{T_A}\right)^{3}\,}\qquad(p=p_A).
\]

------------------------------------------------
3.2 Isobaric heat capacity as a function of \(T\)  
Given \(c_p=k\,\dfrac{p v}{T}\) and using the above \(v(T)\):
\[
c_p(T)=k\,\frac{p_A}{T}\,v_A\!\left(\frac{T}{T_A}\right)^{3}
      =k\,p_A v_A\,\frac{T^{2}}{T_A^{3}}.
\]

------------------------------------------------
3.3 Entropy change for leg 1 (isobar \(A\rightarrow B\))  
For a reversible isobaric step  
\[
\Delta S_{AB}=\int_{A}^{B}\frac{c_p(T)}{T}\,dT
             =k\,p_A v_A\frac{1}{T_A^{3}}\int_{T_A}^{T_B}T\,dT
             =\frac{k\,p_A v_A}{2T_A^{3}}\left(T_B^{2}-T_A^{2}\right).
\]
Thus  
\[
\boxed{\,\Delta S_{AB}=\frac{k\,p_A v_A}{2T_A^{3}}\left(T_B^{2}-T_A^{2}\right)\,}.
\]

------------------------------------------------
3.4 Selecting \(T_B\) by the adiabatic condition \(B\rightarrow D\)  
Adiabatic law: \(p\,v^{2}=C\).

At point \(B\): \(p_B=p_A,\;v_B=v(T_B)=v_A\left(T_B/T_A\right)^{3}\).  
At point \(D\): \(p_D,v_D\) (known).

Requirement \(p_A v_B^{2}=p_D v_D^{2}\):
\[
p_A\Big[v_A\!\left(\frac{T_B}{T_A}\right)^{3}\Big]^{\!2}=p_D v_D^{2}
\quad\Longrightarrow\quad
\left(\frac{T_B}{T_A}\right)^{6}=\frac{p_D v_D^{2}}{p_A v_A^{2}}.
\]
Hence  
\[
\boxed{\,T_B=T_A\left(\frac{p_D v_D^{2}}{p_A v_A^{2}}\right)^{\!1/6}}.
\]

------------------------------------------------
3.5 Total entropy change \(A\rightarrow D\)  
Because \(\Delta S_{BD}=0\) (adiabatic),  
\[
\Delta S=\Delta S_{AB}
        =\frac{k\,p_A v_A}{2T_A^{3}}\!\left[T_A^{2}
          \Bigl(\frac{p_D v_D^{2}}{p_A v_A^{2}}\Bigr)^{\!1/3}-T_A^{2}\right].
\]
Factor out \(T_A^{2}\):
\[
\Delta S=\frac{k\,p_A v_A}{2T_A}\left[\Bigl(\frac{p_D v_D^{2}}{p_A v_A^{2}}\Bigr)^{\!1/3}-1\right].
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### Final Answer
\[
\boxed{\;
S_D-S_A=\frac{k\,p_A v_A}{2T_A}\!
\left[\left(\frac{p_D v_D^{2}}{p_A v_A^{2}}\right)^{1/3}-1\right]\;}
\]

(The constant \(k\) is the state-independent proportionality factor appearing in \(c_p=k\,p v/T\).)

questions:
Assume that the Earth is initially a solid sphere with a uniform density of $\rho$ and a volume of $V={\frac{4}{3}}\pi R^{3}$, and is incompressible. The gravitational constant $G$ is known.

First, consider the effect of Earth's rotation. Earth rotates around its polar axis with a constant angular velocity $\omega$, forming an oblate spheroid under the action of inertial centrifugal forces.

Also consider the tidal forces exerted by Earth's satellite—the Moon. For simplicity, we establish the following simplified model: consider the Moon as a homogeneous ring with mass line density $\textstyle{\lambda={\frac{m}{2\pi r}}}$, located in the Earth's equatorial plane and centered at the Earth's center with a radius of $r$ ($r\gg R$). Find the eccentricity of the Earth when stable $\begin{array}{r}{e=\frac{\sqrt{a^{2}-b^{2}}}{a}}\end{array}$, where $a$ is the semi-major axis and $b$ is the semi-minor axis.
solutions:
The incompressibility condition is given as  

$$
{\frac{4\pi a^{2}b}{3}}={\frac{4\pi R^{3}}{3}}
$$  

Thus,  

$$
a={\frac{R}{(1-e^{2})^{\frac{1}{6}}}}
$$  

A uniformly dense ellipsoid can be divided into many thin ellipsoid shells with the same eccentricity. It can be proven that the surface mass density distribution of each ellipsoid shell is identical to the surface charge density distribution of ellipsoid conductors in electrostatics. The gravitational potential inside an ellipsoid shell is zero, so the self-energy of each ellipsoid shell can be calculated and summed. The total gravitational self-energy is  

$$
V_{g}=\int_{0}^{a}-{\frac{4\pi}{3}}{\sqrt{1-e^{2}}}a^{3}{\frac{4\pi G\rho a{\sqrt{1-e^{2}}}}{e}}\mathrm{sin}^{-1}e d a
$$  

After integration,  

$$
V_{g}=-{\frac{16\pi^{2}}{15}}G\rho^{2}R^{5}{\frac{(1-e^{2})^{\frac{1}{6}}}{e}}\sin^{-1}e
$$  

The total centrifugal potential energy is  

$$
V_{i}=\iiint-{\frac{1}{2}}\rho\omega^{2}(x^{2}+y^{2})d V
$$  

After integration,  

$$
V_{g}=-\frac{4\pi}{15}\rho\omega^{2}R^{5}\frac{1}{(1-e^{2})^{\frac{1}{3}}}
$$  

The tidal potential energy per unit mass is  

$$
v_{t}=\int_{0}^{2\pi}-\frac{G\lambda r d\varphi}{[(x-r\cos\varphi)^{2}+(y-r\sin\varphi)^{2}+z^{2}]^{\frac{1}{2}}}
$$  

After approximation,  

$$
v_{t}=-{\frac{G m}{r}}+{\frac{G m}{4r^{3}}}(2z^{2}-x^{2}-y^{2})
$$  

The total tidal potential energy is  

$$
V_{t}=\iiint[-{\frac{G m\rho}{r}}+{\frac{G m\rho}{4r^{3}}}(2z^{2}-x^{2}-y^{2})]d V=-{\frac{4\pi G m\rho R^{3}}{3}}-{\frac{2\pi G m\rho R^{5}}{15}}{\frac{e^{2}}{r^{3}(1-e^2)^{1/6}}}
$$  

The total potential function is the sum of gravitational self-energy, centrifugal potential energy, and tidal potential energy. After approximation,  

$$
V=-\frac{16\pi^{2}}{15}G\rho^{2}R^{5}-\frac{4\pi}{15}\rho\omega^{2}R^{5}-\frac{4\pi}{3}\frac{G m\rho R^{3}}{r}-\frac{4\pi}{45}\rho\omega^{2}R^{5}e^{2}-\frac{2\pi}{15}\frac{G m\rho R^{5}}{r^{3}}e^{2}+\frac{16\pi^{2}}{675}G\rho^{2}R^{5}e^{4}
$$  

When stable, the potential function reaches a minimum,  

$$
e={\sqrt{\frac{30\omega^{2}+45{\frac{G m}{r^{3}}}}{16\pi\rho G}}}
$$  

**[Solution Method 2] (Alternative Method: Surface Equipotential Approach)**  

The surface equation for a rotational ellipsoid with a short axis in spherical coordinates is  

$$
r^{\prime}(\theta)^{2}=\frac{a^{2}b^{2}}{a^{2}\cos\theta^{2}+b^{2}\sin\theta^{2}}
$$  

From equation $\textcircled{2}$,  

$$
r^{\prime}(\theta)\approx R+\frac{R}{6}(1-3\cos\theta^{2})
$$  

Using the multipole expansion method in electrostatics and expanding to the quadrupole moment of a rotational ellipsoid, the gravitational potential per unit mass is  

$$
v_{g}=-{\frac{4\pi G\rho R^{3}}{3r^{\prime}}}-{\frac{2\pi G\rho R^{5}}{15{r^{\prime}}^{5}}}{\frac{e^{2}}{(1-e^{2})^{\frac{1}{3}}}}{({x^{\prime}}^{2}+{y^{\prime}}^{2}-2{z^{\prime}}^{2})}
$$  

The centrifugal potential per unit mass is  

$$
v_{i}=-\frac{1}{2}\omega^{2}({x^{\prime}}^{2}+{y^{\prime}}^{2})
$$  

The tidal potential per unit mass is  

$$
v_{t}=-{\frac{G m}{r}}+{\frac{G m}{4r^{3}}}(2{z^{\prime}}^{2}-{x^{\prime}}^{2}-{y^{\prime}}^{2})
$$  

The total surface potential per unit mass, which is the sum of the three potentials, is approximated as  

$$
v(\theta)=-\frac{4\pi G\rho R^{2}e^{2}}{45}(3\cos\theta^{2}-1)-\frac{1}{2}\omega^{2}R^{2}\sin\theta^{2}-\frac{G m}{r}+\frac{G m R^{2}}{4r^{3}}(3\cos\theta^{2}-1)
$$  

The surface equipotential condition requires $v$ to be independent of $\theta$, yielding  

$$
e={\sqrt{\frac{30\omega^{2}+45{\frac{G m}{r^{3}}}}{16\pi\rho G}}}
$$

### 1. Problem Analysis  
The Earth is idealised as an incompressible, uniform–density fluid that is originally spherical (radius R, mass M).  
Two external agents disturb the figure:  

1. Rotation with a constant angular velocity ω (centrifugal potential).  
2. The Moon, replaced by a thin circular ring of radius r ( r ≫ R) and total mass m lying in the Earth’s equatorial plane (tidal potential).

At hydrostatic equilibrium the actual surface must be an equipotential of the sum  
Φ = Φ self-grav + Φ centrifugal + Φ tidal.  
The task is to obtain the resulting eccentricity  

  e = √(a² − b²) / a ≃ √(2 f)      with      f ≡ (a − b)/a   (geometric flattening).

### 2. Approach  
• Deform the spherical surface slightly and write it as  
 r(θ) = R [1 + ε P₂(cos θ)], |ε| ≪ 1, P₂(cos θ)=½(3 cos²θ−1).  
  (θ is colatitude: θ = 0 at the pole, θ = π/2 at the equator.)

• Expand every potential to quadrupole (ℓ = 2) order; the ℓ = 0 part merely fixes an arbitrary constant.  
  – Self-gravity reacts to the deformation.  
  – Rotation supplies a known quadrupole.  
  – The distant lunar ring gives a quadrupole through its tidal field.  

• Demand that the coefficient of P₂ in the total potential vanish; this provides a linear algebraic equation for ε (small-flattening approximation).

• Relate ε to the flattening f and to the eccentricity e, then insert numerical data.

### 3. Solution Steps  

3.1  Quadrupole contribution of each potential at the surface  

(a) Self-gravity of a uniform sphere (Love number calculation)  
 A radial displacement δr = ε RP₂ adds at the surface the potential  
 Φ_g,2 = +(2/5) (GM/R) ε P₂(cos θ).                                        (1)

(b) Centrifugal potential  
 Φ_Ω = –½ ω²R² sin²θ  
    = –ω²R²/3 + (ω²R²/3) P₂(cos θ).                                       (2)

(c) Tidal potential of the lunar ring (r ≫ R)  
 An expansion of the exact potential of the ring to ℓ = 2 gives                    
 Φ_t,2 = –(3/2) (GmR²/r³) P₂(cos θ).                                       (3)

3.2  Equipotential condition  

At the true surface r(θ) the total potential must be constant ⇒ the sum of the ℓ = 2 pieces vanishes:

 (2/5) (GM/R) ε  +  (ω²R²/3)  –  (3/2)(GmR²/r³) = 0.                (4)

3.3  Solve for ε  

 ε = (5R³/2GM) [ ω²/3 + (3/2)(Gm/r³) ].                             (5)

3.4  From ε to flattening and eccentricity  

For small ε  

 Flattening f ≡ (a–b)/a ≃ (3/2)|ε|,                         (6)  
 Eccentricity e: e² ≃ 2f ⇒ e ≃ √(3ε).                     (7)

Combining (5) and (7):

 e ≃ √{ (15 R³)/(2 GM) [ ω²/3 + (3Gm)/(2r³) ] }.            (8)

3.5  Numerical evaluation (SI units)  

G = 6.674 × 10⁻¹¹    M = 5.972 × 10²⁴ kg    R = 6.371 × 10⁶ m  
ω = 7.292 × 10⁻⁵ s⁻¹    m = 7.348 × 10²² kg    r = 3.844 × 10⁸ m

• Rotational term  
 ω²/3 = (7.292 × 10⁻⁵)² / 3 = 1.77 × 10⁻⁹ s⁻².

• Lunar term  
 (3Gm)/(2r³) = (3/2)(6.674 × 10⁻¹¹ × 7.348 × 10²²)/(3.844 × 10⁸)³  
        = 1.30 × 10⁻¹³ s⁻².

(The tide is ≈7 × 10⁻⁵ of the rotational contribution.)

Insert in (5):

 ε = (5 R³)/(2 GM)·(1.77 × 10⁻⁹ + 1.30 × 10⁻¹³)  
     = 1.62 × 10⁶ × 1.77 × 10⁻⁹  
     ≈ 2.87 × 10⁻³.

Flattening  
 f ≃ 3ε/2 ≈ 4.30 × 10⁻³  (1 / f ≈ 233).  

Eccentricity  
 e ≃ √(3ε) ≈ √(8.60 × 10⁻³) ≈ 9.3 × 10⁻².            (9)

\[

### Problem Analysis
We have a very long solid dielectric cylinder  
• mass  m, radius  R, length  L  ( L ≫ R so edge effects can be ignored)  
• permanently polarized radially:  
  P(r)=P₀e^{kr}\,\hat{\mathbf r} , 0≤r≤R  

The cylinder is initially at rest.  
At t=0 a **constant mechanical torque** M about its axis ( z–axis ) is applied.  
Because the bound charges contained in the dielectric have to rotate together with the matter, azimuthal bound currents appear, a magnetic field B is created and magnetic energy (and angular momentum) is stored in the field.  
The external torque therefore has to supply

 1) the ordinary mechanical angular acceleration of the matter, and  
 2) the rate at which angular momentum is pumped into the electromagnetic (EM) field.

The question is to find the **angular acceleration** β of the cylinder after the torque is applied, expressed only through M, m, k, R, L, P₀ and μ₀.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### Approach  

1.  Determine the bound charge density produced by the given polarization.  
2.  While the body rotates with instantaneous angular velocity ω, the bound charges circulate with speed v = ωr, producing bound volume- and surface–current densities J_b and K_b.  
3.  For an infinitely long, azimuthally‐symmetric current distribution the magnetic field is purely axial, B(r)=B_z(r)\,\hat{\mathbf z}.  We obtain B(r) from Ampère–Maxwell (or ∇×B = μ₀J).  
4.  Compute the magnetic‐field energy U_B(ω)=∫ B²/(2μ₀) dV.  Because U_B ∝ ω² we may write U_B = ½ I_EM ω² and interpret I_EM as an “electromagnetic moment of inertia”.  
5.  The external power is P = Mω = d/dt(½ I_mech ω² + ½ I_EM ω²) = (I_mech+I_EM) ω β.  
   Holding for any ω ⇒ β = M/(I_mech+I_EM).  
6.  Insert I_mech (rigid solid cylinder) and the I_EM obtained in step 4, giving the desired β.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### Solution Steps  

1.  Bound charges produced by the permanent polarization  

   • Volume charge  
  ρ_b = −∇·P  
   = − 1/r ∂/∂r ( r P_r )  
   = −P₀ e^{kr}\left( \frac1r + k \right) , 0≤r≤R  

   • Surface charge on the curved surface (r=R)  
  σ_b = P·\hat{\mathbf n} = P_r(R)=P₀ e^{kR}  
   (The end faces carry no charge because P is radial.)

2.  When the body rotates with instantaneous angular speed ω  

   • linear speed of each charge element: v = ωr (azimuthal)  
   • Volume current density  
  J_b = ρ_b v \hat{\boldsymbol\varphi} = ρ_b ω r \hat{\boldsymbol\varphi}  
   • Surface current density at r = R  
  K_b = σ_b v \hat{\boldsymbol\varphi}|_{r=R}= σ_b ω R \hat{\boldsymbol\varphi}

3.  Magnetic field B(r) inside the cylinder  

   Cylindrical symmetry ⇒ only B_z(r) survives.  
   Maxwell equation ( ∇×B )_φ = −∂B_z/∂r = μ₀ J_b, therefore  

  dB_z/dr = − μ₀ ρ_b ω r                              (1)

   Integrate from 0 to r and use the boundary condition that the field vanishes outside the dielectric (r>R) but jumps by μ₀K_b across the surface:

  B_z(r) = μ₀ ω [ σ_b R + ∫_0^{\,r} ρ_b(r′)\,r′ dr′ ] ,  0≤r≤R       (2)

   Evaluate the integral

  ∫_0^{r} ρ_b(r′) r′ dr′  
  = ∫_0^{r} [ −P₀ e^{kr′}(1 + k r′) ] dr′  
  = −P₀ r e^{kr}.  

   Insert σ_b, get

  B_z(r) = μ₀ ω P₀ [ R e^{kR} − r e^{kr} ],  0≤r≤R       (3)

   and B_z ≡ 0 for r ≥ R (the familiar “perfect solenoid” result).

4.  Magnetic‐field energy ⇒ electromagnetic moment of inertia

 U_B(ω) = L ∫_{0}^{R}  (B_z^2/2μ₀) 2πr dr  
     = (π L / μ₀) ∫_{0}^{R}  r B_z^2(r) dr.

   Insert (3):

 U_B(ω)= π L μ₀ P₀² ω² ∫_{0}^{R} r [ R e^{kR} − r e^{kr} ]² dr.   (4)

   Because U_B ∝ ω² we define

  U_B(ω)= ½ I_EM ω²   ⇒  

  I_EM = 2 π μ₀ L P₀² ∫_{0}^{R} r [ R e^{kR} − r e^{kr} ]² dr.   (5)

   (The elementary integral can be evaluated in closed form; the result is given below.)

5.  Mechanical moment of inertia of the rigid cylinder  

 I_mech = ½ m R².                                             (6)

6.  Angular acceleration β  

   The external power balance reads  

  M ω = d/dt ( ½ I_mech ω² + ½ I_EM ω² )  
    = (I_mech + I_EM) ω β.  

   Holding for any instantaneous ω gives  

  β = M /( I_mech + I_EM ).                                (7)

7.  Closed analytic form of the electromagnetic contribution  

   The integral in (5) is elementary:

 I := ∫_{0}^{R} r ( R e^{kR} − r e^{kr} )² dr
  = e^{2kR}\Big[ \frac{R^{4}}{2} -\frac{3R^{3}}{2k} + \frac{13 R^{2}}{4k^{2}} -\frac{13 R}{4k^{3}} -\frac{3}{8k^{4}} \Big]
   + \frac{4 R e^{kR}}{k^{3}} + \frac{3}{8k^{4}}.                  (8)

   Therefore

 I_EM = 2 π μ₀ L P₀² I,                                        (9)

   with I given by (8).

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### Final Answer
\[
\boxed{ \;
\beta \;=\;
\dfrac{M}
       { \displaystyle
         \frac{1}{2} m R^{2}
         \;+\;
         2\pi \mu_{0} L P_{0}^{2}
         \int_{0}^{R} r\,
                \bigl[\, R e^{kR} - r e^{kr} \bigr]^{2}\,dr
       }
      \; }
\]

Explicitly evaluating the elementary integral gives

\[
\boxed{
\beta =
\dfrac{M}
       { \dfrac12 m R^{2}
         \;+\;
         2\pi \mu_{0} L P_{0}^{2}\!
         \Bigg\{
           e^{2kR}\!\Bigl[
             \tfrac{R^{4}}{2} -\tfrac{3R^{3}}{2k}
             +\tfrac{13 R^{2}}{4k^{2}}
             -\tfrac{13R}{4k^{3}}
             -\tfrac{3}{8k^{4}}
           \Bigr]
           +\tfrac{4 R e^{kR}}{k^{3}}
           +\tfrac{3}{8k^{4}}
         \Bigg\}
       }
}
\]

Either form exhibits the required dependence on the given parameters 
M, m, k, R, L, P₀ and μ₀.

questions:
A cylindrical container with a cross-sectional area $S$ is fixed on the ground. The container walls are thermally insulated, and the top is sealed with a thermally insulated piston of mass $p_{0}S/g$ (where $g$ is the gravitational acceleration). The lower surface of the piston is parallel to the bottom surface of the container. The exterior of the container is a vacuum, and the interior contains a diatomic ideal gas with the mass of a single molecule being $m$ and the total number of molecules $N$. The temperature of the gas throughout the container is uniform at $T_{0}$. 

Slowly sprinkle a total mass of powder $(p_{1}-p_{0})S/g$ onto the piston. Neglect all friction, and consider the effect of gravity on the distribution of gas molecules. Find the final temperature of the gas inside the container, $T_{1}$.
solutions:
In equilibrium in a gravitational field, the molecular number density at temperature $T$ follows the Boltzmann distribution:

$$
n(z) = n_{0} \exp\left(-\frac{m g z}{k T}\right)
$$

In the formula, $n_{0}$ is the molecular number density at $z=0$ (the bottom of the container), which is an unknown to be determined; $k$ is the Boltzmann constant. The total number of molecules in the container remains constant, always equal to $N$:

$$
N = \int_{0}^{H} S n(z) \operatorname{d}z = S n_{0} \int_{0}^{H} \exp\left(-\frac{m g z}{k T}\right) \operatorname{d}z = \frac{S n_{0} k T}{m g} \left[1 - \exp\left(-\frac{m g H}{k T}\right)\right]
$$

Since the system is adiabatic and the powder is spread slowly, it can be assumed that the gas inside the container undergoes a quasi-static adiabatic process. At any moment during the process, let the temperature of the gas inside the container be $T$, the pressure at the lower surface of the piston inside the container be $p$, and the height from the lower surface of the piston to the bottom of the container be $H$. According to the first law of thermodynamics, for the gas inside the container, we have

$$
-p S \mathrm{d}H = \frac{5}{2}N k \mathrm{d}T + \mathrm{d}E_{p}
$$

In this formula, $\frac{5}{2}N k \mathrm{d}T$ represents the increase in internal energy of a diatomic ideal gas, and $\mathrm{d}E_{p}$ is the increase in gravitational potential energy of the gas in the container. Taking $z=0$ as the zero point of gravitational potential energy, we have

$$
\begin{array}{l}{E_{p} = \int_{0}^{H} m g z S n(z) \mathrm{d}z = m g S n_{0} \int_{0}^{H} z \exp\left(-\frac{m g z}{k T}\right) \mathrm{d}z } \\ { = -k T S H n_{0} \exp\left(-\frac{m g H}{k T}\right) + k T S n_{0} \cdot \frac{k T}{m g} - k T S n_{0} \exp\left(-\frac{m g H}{k T}\right) \cdot \frac{k T}{m g}} \end{array}
$$

At the lower surface of the piston, according to the ideal gas pressure formula, we have

$$
p = n(H) \cdot k T = n_{0} \exp\left(-\frac{m g H}{k T}\right) k T
$$

Substituting into equation $\textcircled{4}$ gives

$$
E_{p} = -p S H + (p S + N m g) \frac{k T}{m g} - p S \frac{k T}{m g} = -p S H + N k T
$$

Here, $p + \frac{N m g}{S} = n_{0} k T$ is the pressure at the bottom of the container. Taking the differential of the above equation gives $\mathrm{d}E_{p} = -p S \mathrm{d}H - S H \mathrm{d}p + N k \mathrm{d}T$, substituting into equation $\textcircled{3}$ gives

$$
S H \mathrm{d}p = \frac{7}{2} N k \mathrm{d}T
$$

Combining equations $\textcircled{2}$ and $\textcircled{5}$ gives

$$
H = \frac{k T}{m g} \ln\frac{p S + N m g}{p S}
$$

Substituting into equation $\textcircled{7}$ gives

$$
\begin{array}{c}{{\displaystyle{\frac{S}{m g}}\ln\frac{p S + N m g}{p S} \mathrm{d}p = \frac{7}{2} N \frac{\mathrm{d}T}{T}}} \\ {\mathrm{}} \\ {\displaystyle{\ln(p S + N m g) \mathrm{d}(p S) - \ln(p S) \mathrm{d}(p S) = \frac{7}{2} N m g \frac{\mathrm{d}T}{T}}} \end{array}
$$

According to piston equilibrium, initial state $T = T_{0}$, $p = p_{0}$, final state $T = T_{1}$, $p = p_{1}$, integrating the above equation gives

$$
\frac{p_{1} S}{N m g} \ln\left(1 + \frac{N m g}{p_{1} S}\right) - \frac{p_{0} S}{N m g} \ln\left(1 + \frac{N m g}{p_{0} S}\right) + \ln\frac{p_{1} S + N m g}{p_{0} S + N m g} = \frac{7}{2} \ln\frac{T_{1}}{T_{0}}
$$

Therefore, the temperature we seek is

$$
T_{1} = T_{0} \frac{\left(1 + \frac{N m g}{p_{1} S}\right)^{\frac{2 p_{1} S}{7 N m g}}}{\left(1 + \frac{N m g}{p_{0} S}\right)^{\frac{2 p_{0} S}{7 N m g}}} \left(\frac{p_{1} S + N m g}{p_{0} S + N m g}\right)^{\frac{2}{7}}
$$
