Solution Outline  

1. Problem Analysis  
   We have a vertical cylinder (cross-section S) closed on the top by a thermally insulated, friction-less piston.  
   • Outside: vacuum ⇒ the only force exerted on the gas is the weight of the piston (and later the powder).  
   • Inside: N molecules of a di-atomic ideal gas (f = 5 translational + rotational d.o.f.).  
   • Whole wall–piston assembly is adiabatic ⇒ δQ = 0 at every stage.  
   • The gas is always kept in mechanical equilibrium under gravity; after every infinitesimal loading step it re-establishes a uniform temperature (initially T₀, finally T₁).  
   Task: find this final uniform temperature T₁ once the total load corresponds to the pressure p₁ (> p₀).

2. Approach  
   a) Describe the hydrostatic equilibrium for an isothermal layer T (either T₀ or T₁).  
   b) Use particle conservation to relate the cylinder height H and the pressure exerted on the piston.  
   c) Write the total energy of the gas (internal + gravitational) as a function of p, T.  
   d) Because the walls are adiabatic, the change of that energy equals the (reversible) work supplied through the piston.  This gives a differential relation between p and T that can be integrated from (p₀, T₀) to (p₁, T₁).  
   e) Integrate and simplify; show that the result reduces to the usual adiabatic relation when gravity is neglected.

3. Detailed Solution  

3.1 Hydrostatic profile at a uniform temperature T  
   Let the bottom of the vessel be z = 0, the lower face of the piston z = H.  
   For an ideal gas in a constant gravitational field g

          dP
      ─────── = –ρg = – (mP / kT) g                         (1)

   Integration gives

          P(z) = P(H) e^{ (mg/kT)(H – z) }                  (2)

   where P(H) is the pressure on the piston (≡ external load per unit area).  
   Denote that top pressure by p (p = p₀ initially, p = p₁ finally).

3.2 Particle conservation  
   Number density n(z) = P(z)/(kT).  Therefore

      N = S ∫₀ᴴ n(z) dz
        = S p /(mg)  [ e^{μ} – 1 ],                         (3)

   with

          μ ≡ mgH / (kT).                                   (4)

3.3 Useful identities  
   From (3) one can eliminate H in favour of p and T:

          e^{μ} = 1 + C/p,          C ≡ mgN/S,              (5)

          μ   = ln(1 + C/p),                                

          V   = SH = (SkT / mg) μ                            (6)

   V = volume of the gas cylinder.

3.4 Energy of the gas column  
   • Internal energy (di-atomic, f = 5):

          U = (f/2) NkT = (5/2) NkT.                        (7)

   • Gravitational potential energy

          Φ = S ∫₀ᴴ ρ(z) g z dz
            = NkT – pV                                       (8)

     (the derivation uses (2)–(4); a short calculation gives the compact form (8)).  

   • Total energy of the gas

          E ≡ U + Φ
            = (5/2) NkT  + NkT – pV
            = (7/2) NkT – pV.                               (9)

3.5 First Law for the adiabatic, quasi-static process  
   With δQ = 0 and mechanical work δW = –p dV (work done **on** the gas):

          dE = –p dV.                                       (10)

   Insert (9):

          d[(7/2)NkT – pV] = –p dV
      →   (7/2)Nk dT – V dp – p dV = –p dV
      →   (7/2)Nk dT – V dp = 0.                            (11)

   Hence the reversible path satisfies

          (7/2) Nk dT = V dp.                               (12)

3.6 Replace V with p, T using (6) and integrate  
   From (6):

          V = (SkT / mg) ln(1 + C/p).                       (13)

   Plug into (12):

          (7/2) Nk dT = (SkT / mg) ln(1 + C/p) dp
      ⇒   (7/2) N dT / T = (S / mg) ln(1 + C/p) dp.         (14)

   Because C = mgN/S, the right-hand prefactor simplifies:

          (7/2) dT / T = (1/C) ln(1 + C/p) dp.              (15)

   Integrate from (p₀, T₀) to (p₁, T₁):

          ∫_{T₀}^{T₁} (7/2) dT / T
        = (1/C) ∫_{p₀}^{p₁} ln(1 + C/p) dp.                 (16)

   Left integral: (7/2) ln(T₁/T₀).

   Right integral:  
        I ≡ ∫ ln(1 + C/p) dp
            = p ln(1 + C/p) + C ln(p + C) + const.  
     Therefore

        ∫_{p₀}^{p₁} ln(1 + C/p) dp
      = p₁ ln(1 + C/p₁) – p₀ ln(1 + C/p₀)
        + C ln[(p₁ + C)/(p₀ + C)].                         (17)

3.7 Final relation for the temperatures  

          (7/2) ln(T₁/T₀)
        = (1/C) [ p₁ ln(1 + C/p₁) – p₀ ln(1 + C/p₀)
                   + C ln((p₁ + C)/(p₀ + C)) ].            (18)

   Exponentiating:

          T₁
        = T₀ exp{ (2/7C)[ p₁ ln(1 + C/p₁) – p₀ ln(1 + C/p₀)
                          + C ln((p₁ + C)/(p₀ + C)) ] }.   (19)

   with                 C = mgN/S.                         (20)

3.8 Consistency check (g → 0 limit)  
   When gravity is negligible, C → 0.  
   Expand ln(1 + C/p) ≃ C/p (first order); using (19) gives

          ln(T₁/T₀) → (2/7) ln(p₁/p₀)
        ⇒ T₁/T₀ → (p₁/p₀)^{2/7},                           (21)

   which is precisely the ordinary reversible adiabatic law for a di-atomic gas (γ = 7/5).  The result obtained therefore contains the correct limiting behaviour.

4. Result  
   Define the constant C = (mgN)/S (weight per unit area of the gas column).  
   After slowly adding the extra mass so that the piston load changes from p₀ to p₁, the final uniform temperature inside the adiabatic cylinder is

          T₁ = T₀ \exp\!\Bigg\{\frac{2}{7C}\Big[
                    p_{1}\ln\!\bigl(1 + \frac{C}{p_{1}}\bigr)
                  - p_{0}\ln\!\bigl(1 + \frac{C}{p_{0}}\bigr)
                  + C\ln\!\frac{p_{1}+C}{p_{0}+C}\Big]\Bigg\}.   (22)

   For C ≪ p₀, p₁ (gravity or gas mass negligible) this reduces to the textbook adiabatic formula T₁/T₀ = (p₁/p₀)^{2/7}.

### Final Answer
\[
\boxed{\,T_{1}=T_{0}\;
      \exp\!\Bigg[\frac{2}{7C}
      \Big(p_{1}\ln\!\bigl(1+\tfrac{C}{p_{1}}\bigr)
          -p_{0}\ln\!\bigl(1+\tfrac{C}{p_{0}}\bigr)
          +C\ln\!\frac{p_{1}+C}{\,p_{0}+C\,}\Big)\Bigg],
      \qquad C=\dfrac{m g N}{S}\, } 
\]

questions: A three-dimensional relativistic oscillator moves in a space filled with uniform "dust." During motion, "dust" continuously adheres to the oscillator, which is assumed to increase the rest mass of the sphere without altering its size. The collision is adiabatic, and the "dust" quickly replenishes the region the sphere just passed. The original length of the spring is vanishing, and the potential energy $V$ can be expressed as $V=\frac{1}{2}k x^2$, where $k$ is a known constant. The cross-sectional area of the sphere is $A$, the density of the "dust" is $\rho$, the initial rest mass of the sphere is $m_{0}$, and the speed of light in vacuum is $c$. Initially, the sphere performs uniform circular motion with a radius $R_{0}$. Find the time $t$ required when the circular motion radius changes to $R$. Assume $R^2 \gg A$ and $m_{0} \gg \rho A R$.
solutions:
From the problem statement, it can be assumed that the sphere is constantly maintaining uniform circular motion  

$$
v=\omega r
$$  

$$
\omega={\sqrt{\frac{k}{\gamma m}}}
$$  

Also, angular momentum conservation  

$$
\gamma m v r=c o n s t
$$  

Where $\gamma = \begin{array}{r}{\gamma=\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-\frac{v^{2}}{c^{2}}}}}\end{array}$  

$$
\gamma m r^{4}=c o n s t=B
$$  

Next, solve for the initial $B$. From  

$$
{\frac{1}{\gamma^{2}}}=1-{\frac{v^{2}}{c^{2}}}=1-{\frac{k r^{2}}{\gamma m c^{2}}}
$$  

Simplify to obtain  

$$
\gamma^{2}-{\frac{k r^{2}}{m c^{2}}}\gamma-1=0
$$  

Therefore  

$$
\gamma=\frac{\frac{k r^{2}}{m c^{2}}+\sqrt{\left(\frac{k r^{2}}{m c^{2}}\right)^{2}+4}}{2}
$$  

Substitute initial conditions, we have  

$$
\gamma_{0}=\frac{\frac{k R_{0}^{2}}{m_{0}c^{2}}+\sqrt{\left(\frac{k R_{0}^{2}}{m_{0}c^{2}}\right)^{2}+4}}{2}
$$  

$$
B=\frac{\frac{k R_{0}^{2}}{m_{0}c^{2}}+\sqrt{\left(\frac{k R_{0}^{2}}{m_{0}c^{2}}\right)^{2}+4}}{2}m R_{0}^{4}
$$  

Adiabatic process implies total energy conservation, and mass changes with time  

$$
{\frac{d}{d t}}\gamma m=\rho A v-{\frac{k r}{c^{2}}}{\frac{d r}{d t}}
$$  

Substitute angular momentum conservation  

$$
d(\frac{B}{r^{4}})=\rho A\sqrt{\frac{k}{B}}r^{3}d t-d(\frac{k r^{2}}{2c^{2}})
$$  

Resulting in  

$$
\Delta(-\frac{k}{c^{2}r}+\frac{4B}{7r^{7}})=\rho A\sqrt{\frac{k}{B}}t
$$  

Simplify to get  

$$
t=\frac{1}{\rho A}\sqrt{\frac{B}{k}}(\frac{k}{c^{2}}(-\frac{1}{R}+\frac{1}{R_{0}})+\frac{4}{7}B(\frac{1}{R^{7}}-\frac{1}{R_{0}^{7}}))
$$
improved_solutions:
Solution Outline
----------------

1. **Problem Analysis**

   We have a small spherical mass attached to the centre of an isotropic Hookean potential  
   \(V(r)=\dfrac12 k r^{2}\).  
   The mass executes uniform circular motion and is sweeping through a dilute, homogeneous
   ‘dust’ of rest–mass density \(\rho\).  
   Every dust grain that strikes the sphere sticks to it, thereby

   * increasing the rest (invariant) mass \(m\) of the sphere at the rate  
     \(\displaystyle \frac{dm}{dt}= \rho A v,\qquad     
     v\equiv |\mathbf v|\) ,
   * but exerting no external torque, so the (relativistic) angular momentum is conserved.

   We are asked for the time needed for the orbital radius to change from
   its initial value \(R_{0}\) to a later value \(R\).
   The approximations quoted in the statement,

        i)  \(R^{2}\gg A\) (thin sphere)   
       ii)  \(m_{0}\gg\rho A R\) (small amount of accreted dust)

   allow us to keep only the leading, essentially non-relativistic contribution (\(\gamma\approx 1\)) in the final result.


2. **Key Physical Ingredients**

   •  Hooke force (radial): \(F_{s}=kR\).  
   •  Relativistic centripetal balance for uniform circular motion  

        \(F_{s}= \dfrac{\gamma m v^{2}}{R}\).

   •  Conservation of (relativistic) angular momentum  

        \(L=\gamma m v R = L_{0}= \gamma_{0}m_{0}v_{0} R_{0}\).

   •  Mass accretion (no torque): \(\displaystyle \frac{dm}{dt}= \rho A v\).

   These four relations completely determine the evolution \(R(t)\).


3. **Step–by–Step Solution**

   3.1  Relate \(v\) to the radius  
  
   Eliminate \(v\) and \(\gamma\) from the two dynamical relations:

       From \(L=L_{0}\Rightarrow v= \dfrac{L}{\gamma m R}\).

       Insert this \(v\) in the force balance,

       \(kR = \dfrac{\gamma m}{R}\!
               \left(\dfrac{L}{\gamma m R}\right)^{2}
             =\dfrac{L^{2}}{\gamma m R^{3}}\).

       Hence  
       \(\displaystyle \gamma m =\frac{L^{2}}{k R^{4}}
       \equiv\frac{B}{R^{4}},\qquad B:=\frac{L^{2}}{k}\).      

       Substituting back in \(v=L/(\gamma m R)\) gives the remarkably
       simple

       \(\displaystyle v(R)=\frac{k\,R^{3}}{\sqrt{B}}.\qquad(1)\)

   3.2  Fix the constant \(B\) from the initial conditions  
  
       At \(t=0\) (\(R=R_{0},\;m=m_{0},\;\gamma\simeq\gamma_{0}\))

       \[
           B=L^{2}=k\,R_{0}^{4}\gamma_{0}m_{0}\xrightarrow[\gamma_{0}\simeq1]{\text{(weakly relativistic)}} 
           k\,R_{0}^{4}m_{0}.                                         \tag{2}
       \]

   3.3  Express the growing mass \(m(R)\)

       From \(\gamma m=B/R^{4}\) and \(\gamma\simeq1\),

       \[
           m(R)=\frac{B}{k R^{4}}   \stackrel{(2)}{\simeq}
           \frac{R_{0}^{4}m_{0}}{R^{4}}.                              \tag{3}
       \]

   3.4  Obtain the differential equation for \(R(t)\)

       The accretion law \(dm/dt=\rho A v\) together with (1)–(3) gives

       \[
           \frac{dm}{dR}\,\frac{dR}{dt}= \rho A v
           \;\Longrightarrow\;
           \frac{dR}{dt}= 
           \frac{\rho A v}{dm/dR}.
       \]

       From (3)  
       \(dm/dR = -4\,R_{0}^{4}m_{0}/R^{5}= -4\,m/R\).

       Therefore  

       \[
          \frac{dR}{dt}= -\frac{\rho A v R}{4m}
          =-\frac{\rho A}{4}\;
            \frac{kR^{4}/\sqrt{B}}{m}
          \stackrel{(2)(3)}{=}
          -\frac{\rho A}{4}
          \frac{k R^{4}}{\sqrt{k}R_{0}^{2}\sqrt{m_{0}}}
          \frac{R^{4}}{R_{0}^{4}m_{0}}
          =-\frac{\rho A\sqrt{k}}{4R_{0}^{2}\sqrt{m_{0}}}\;R^{7}. \tag{4}
       \]

   3.5  Integrate from \(R_{0}\) to \(R\)

       Rearranging (4):

       \[
          dt = - \frac{4 R_{0}^{2}\sqrt{m_{0}}}{\rho A\sqrt{k}}\;
               R^{-7}\,dR .
       \]

       With the limits \(R_{0}\longrightarrow R\) the time elapsed is   

       \[
          t = \frac{4 R_{0}^{2}\sqrt{m_{0}}}{\rho A\sqrt{k}}
              \int_{R}^{R_{0}} R^{-7}\,dR
            =\frac{4 R_{0}^{2}\sqrt{m_{0}}}{\rho A\sqrt{k}}
              \left[\,-\frac{1}{7}R^{-6}\right]_{R}^{R_{0}}
            =\frac{4}{7}\,
             \frac{R_{0}^{2}\sqrt{m_{0}}}{\rho A\sqrt{k}}
             \Bigl(R^{-6}-R_{0}^{-6}\Bigr).                          \tag{5}
       \]

       Multiplying numerator and denominator by \(m_{0}\,R_{0}^{4}\)
       to cast the result in a slightly neater form,

       \[
         t= \frac{4\,m_{0}^{3/2}R_{0}^{6}}{7\,\rho A\sqrt{k}}
            \left(\frac{1}{R^{7}}-\frac{1}{R_{0}^{7}}\right).        \tag{6}
       \]

4. **Consistency with the stated approximations**

   •  Because \(m_{0}\gg\rho A R\) the term in brackets is small,
      validating the neglect of the (relatively tiny) variation of 
      the Lorentz factor (\(\gamma\simeq 1\)).  

   •  Condition \(R^{2}\gg A\) ensures that the sphere really ‘sees’
     an approximately constant dust density while sweeping.

   Accordingly (6) already represents the leading-order behaviour
   required by the problem statement.


### Final Answer
\[
\boxed{\,t=\dfrac{4\,m_{0}^{3/2} R_{0}^{6}}{7\,\rho A\sqrt{k}}
        \left(\dfrac{1}{R^{7}}-\dfrac{1}{R_{0}^{7}}\right)\,}
\]

questions: Consider an ideal gas with a known fixed constant $\gamma$ undergoing a rectangular cycle on a $p-V$ diagram, which consists of two isochoric processes and two isobaric processes forming a positive cycle. It is known that the area of this cycle is fixed as $W$ (where $W$ is sufficiently small, negating the possibility of negative pressure or volume). The rectangle must contain the point $(p_0,V_0)$. Find the maximum efficiency of this cycle.
solutions:
If the center shifts to $\mathcal{p}^{\prime}, V^{\prime}$, then the heat absorbed is:  

$$
Q={\frac{W}{2}}+{\frac{\Delta p V^{\prime}+\gamma p^{\prime}\Delta V}{\gamma-1}}
$$

Let us first consider the translation of a fixed rectangular shape with ${\Delta p,\Delta V=W/\Delta p}$ in the $\mathcal{P}V$ diagram. Clearly, minimizing the heat absorbed requires minimizing the values of the center's $p,V$.Thus, it becomes optimal only when the rectangle is translated so that the $(p_0, V_0)$ point is at the upper-right corner of the rectangle:  

$$
p^{\prime}=p_0-{\frac{\Delta p}{2}}\quad,\quad V^{\prime}=V_0-{\frac{\Delta V}{2}}
$$

Substituting back, the heat absorbed becomes:  

$$
Q={\frac{\Delta p V+\gamma p\Delta V}{\gamma-1}}-{\frac{W}{\gamma-1}}
$$

From the same inequality, the maximum efficiency is:  

$$
\eta=\frac{\gamma-1}{2\sqrt{\gamma p_0 V_0/W}-1}
$$
improved_solutions:
Solution  

1. Problem Analysis  
We have a rectangular cycle made of two isochoric and two isobaric branches executed clockwise on a p–V diagram (positive work).  
•  The rectangle has fixed area (net work) W = (p₂ − p₁)(V₂ − V₁).  
•  It must enclose the point (p₀ , V₀).  
•  The working substance is an ideal gas with constant ratio of specific heats γ = C_p / C_v.  
The task is to choose the rectangle (i.e. p₁ , p₂ , V₁ , V₂ ) so that the thermal efficiency  
η ≡ W / Q_in  
is as large as possible.

2. Approach (key ideas)  
•  Orient the cycle A → B → C → D → A clockwise:  

 A(p₁,V₁)  →  B(p₁,V₂)  (isobaric expansion)  
 B(p₁,V₂)  →  C(p₂,V₂)  (isochoric heating)  
 C(p₂,V₂)  →  D(p₂,V₁)  (isobaric compression)  
 D(p₂,V₁)  →  A(p₁,V₁)  (isochoric cooling)  

 Work W = (p₂ − p₁)(V₂ − V₁) = Δp ΔV (Δp ≡ p₂ − p₁ , ΔV ≡ V₂ − V₁).  

•  Only the first two branches (A → B and B → C) absorb heat; the other two reject heat.  
•  Express Q_in in terms of Δp , ΔV , p₁ , V₂ ; impose the geometric constraint that the rectangle must contain (p₀ , V₀).  
•  Because W is fixed, set ΔV = W/Δp and maximise η(Δp, p₁, V₂) subject to the containment inequalities.  
•  Maximum η is obtained when the point (p₀ , V₀) is pushed to the upper-right corner of the rectangle (so p₂ = p₀ , V₂ = V₀). One free variable Δp remains; optimise with ∂η/∂Δp = 0.

3. Detailed Solution  

Label the rectangle as above; Δp ≡ p₂ − p₁ , ΔV ≡ V₂ − V₁ and W = Δp ΔV is fixed.

Heat absorbed  

A → B (isobaric at p = p₁):  
 ΔT = p₁ΔV/(nR)  Q_AB = nC_pΔT = C_p p₁ΔV/R.

B → C (isochoric at V = V₂):  
 ΔT = V₂Δp/(nR)  Q_BC = nC_vΔT = C_v V₂Δp/R.

Hence

Q_in = C_p p₁ΔV /R + C_v V₂Δp /R.  (1)

Efficiency

η = W/Q_in  
 = ΔpΔV / [ (C_p/R) p₁ΔV + (C_v/R) V₂Δp ]  
 = 1 / [ (C_p/R) p₁ /Δp + (C_v/R) V₂ /ΔV ].  (2)

Because W is fixed, put ΔV = W/Δp :

η(Δp, p₁, V₂) = 1 / [ (C_p/R) p₁/Δp + (C_v/R) V₂ Δp / W ].  (3)

Containment of (p₀ , V₀)

 p₁ ≤ p₀ ≤ p₁ + Δp ,  V₂ − ΔV ≤ V₀ ≤ V₂.  (4)

To maximise η we must minimise the denominator in (3).  
Both terms are linear in p₁ and V₂, so choose their minimal allowed values:

 p₁_min = p₀ − Δp   (makes lower edge just pass below p₀)  
 V₂_min = V₀     (makes right edge just touch V₀).

Using these choices (and calling them simply p₁ , V₂ from now on):

p₁ = p₀ − Δp  (0 ≤ Δp ≤ p₀ so that p₁ ≥ 0), V₂ = V₀.  (5)

Insert (5) into (3):

η(Δp) = 1 / [ (C_p/R)(p₀ − Δp)/Δp + (C_v/R) V₀ Δp / W ].  (6)

Optimisation with respect to Δp

Let a ≡ C_p /R , b ≡ C_v /R.  (For an ideal gas with constant γ)  

a = γ/(γ−1) , b = 1/(γ−1), √(ab) = √γ /(γ−1).  (7)

Denominator of (6):  
F(Δp) ≡ a(p₀ − Δp)/Δp + b V₀ Δp/W  
 = a p₀/Δp − a + b V₀ Δp/W.  (8)

Set dF/dΔp = 0:

−a p₀/Δp² + b V₀/W = 0  
 ⇒ Δp² = a p₀ W / (b V₀)  
 ⇒ Δp_opt = √( a p₀ W /(b V₀) ) = √( γ p₀ W / V₀ ).  (9)

With W « p₀V₀ the condition Δp ≤ p₀ (needed for p₁ ≥ 0) is satisfied automatically.

Corresponding ΔV and rectangle:

ΔV_opt = W / Δp_opt = √( W V₀ /(γ p₀) ),  
p₂ = p₀ ,  V₂ = V₀,  
p₁ = p₀ − Δp_opt ,  V₁ = V₀ − ΔV_opt.  (10)

Maximum efficiency

Insert Δp_opt in F(Δp) (8):

F_min = 2√(ab) √(p₀V₀)/√W − a.  (11)

Therefore  

η_max = 1/F_min  
 = 1 / [ 2√(ab) √(p₀V₀)/√W − a ].  (12)

Put (7) into (12):

F_min = 1/(γ−1) [ 2√γ √(p₀V₀)/√W − γ ],  

η_max = (γ−1) / [ 2√γ √(p₀V₀)/√W − γ ].  (13)

It is convenient to write the result with the dimensionless parameter  
ε ≡ W /(p₀V₀)  (ε ≪ 1 by hypothesis):

η_max = (γ−1) √ε / [ 2 √γ − γ √ε ].  (14)

For very small W (ε → 0):

η_max ≈ (γ−1)  √ε / (2 √γ )   +  O(ε).     (15)

4. Physical interpretation  
• The optimal rectangle uses (p₀ , V₀) as its upper-right corner.  
• The lower pressure and lower volume sides are pulled down/left just far enough to keep the work area fixed.  
• Because W is small, the efficiency itself is necessarily small (∝ √W).  

### Final Answer
\[
\boxed{ \;
\displaystyle 
\eta_{\text{max}} \;=\;
\frac{\gamma-1}{\,2\sqrt{\gamma}\,\sqrt{\dfrac{p_{0}V_{0}}{W}}\;-\;\gamma}
\;=\;
\frac{(\gamma-1)\,\sqrt{\dfrac{W}{p_{0}V_{0}}}}
      {2\sqrt{\gamma}\;-\;\gamma\,\sqrt{\dfrac{W}{p_{0}V_{0}}}}
\;}
\]

(valid for a rectangular cycle containing the point (p₀ , V₀) with fixed small area W ≪ p₀V₀).

questions: Two spacecraft are traveling in a space medium that is flowing uniformly at a constant velocity $u$ with respect to an inertial frame $S$. The spacecraft are moving through the medium with equal relative velocities $v$ with respect to the medium. Neither of the velocities is known. Ultimately, the velocities of the two spacecraft with respect to the inertial frame $S$ are $v_{1}$ and $v_{2}$, and the angle between the directions of these velocities is an acute angle $\alpha$. These three quantities are given. The speed of light is $c$. Considering relativistic effects, determine the minimum possible value of $u$.
solutions:
First, let's derive a byproduct of velocity transformation. The velocity transformation is:

$$
 v_{x}^{\prime}={\frac{v_{x}-u}{1-u v_{x}/c^{2}}}
$$

$$
v_{y,z}^{\prime}=v_{y,z}\cdot\frac{\sqrt{1-u^{2}/c^{2}}}{1-u v_{x}/c^{2}}
$$

Hence, we can calculate:

$$
  \begin{array}{l}{\gamma=\cfrac{1}{\sqrt{1-(v_{x}^{2}+v_{y}^{2}+v_{z}^{2})/c^{2}}}}\ {=\cfrac{1}{\sqrt{1-(v_{x}^{\prime2}+v_{y}^{\prime2}+v_{z}^{\prime2})/c^{2}}}}\end{array}
$$

Obtain the transformation:

$$
  \gamma^{\prime}=\gamma\cdot\frac{1-{u v_{x}}/{c^{2}}}{\sqrt{1-{u^{2}}/{c^{2}}}}
$$

The minimum value of $v$ can be calculated by first determining the relative velocity of two planes:

$$
  \gamma_{12}=\frac{1-\beta_{1}\beta_{2}\cos\alpha}{\sqrt{(1-\beta_{1}^{2})(1-\beta_{2}^{2})}}
$$

Consider a system where two spaceships have equal but opposite velocities, this velocity $v=\beta c$ is what we seek. At this moment, the relative velocity of the two planes can be obtained:

Thus, jointly obtain:

$$
  \gamma_{12}=\frac{1+\beta^{2}}{\sqrt{(1-\beta^{2})(1-\beta^{2})}}=\frac{1+\beta^{2}}{1-\beta^{2}}
$$

$$
v=c{\sqrt{\frac{c^{2}-v_{1}v_{2}\cos\alpha-{\sqrt{(c^{2}-v_{1}^{2})(c^{2}-v_{2}^{2})}}}{c^{2}-v_{1}v_{2}\cos\alpha+{\sqrt{(c^{2}-v_{1}^{2})(c^{2}-v_{2}^{2})}}}}}
$$

The minimum value of $u=\beta_{\mathsf{u}}c$ can be set such that its magnitude and direction in the original reference system are between angles $\varphi_{1},\varphi_{2}$ of both velocities. Therefore, after transformation, shared velocity:

$$

$$

$$
\gamma_{1}^{\prime}=\gamma_{2}^{\prime}

### 1.  Problem Analysis  
We are given, in the laboratory inertial frame S,

• magnitudes of the two spacecraft velocities: $v_1 ,\;v_2$  
• the acute angle between the velocity vectors: $\alpha$  

A “space medium’’ moves through S with some (unknown) velocity $\mathbf u$; in the rest-frame M of the medium both spacecraft have the **same** speed $v$ (also unknown).  
Because all speeds are possibly relativistic, velocity-addition and Lorentz transformations must be used.

Required:  the **smallest possible magnitude $u \equiv |\mathbf u|$** that is compatible with the data $\;(v_1 ,v_2 ,\alpha)$.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 2.  General Approach  

1.  Treat every velocity as a four-velocity.  
2.  Look for a timelike unit 4-vector $V^\mu$ (the medium’s 4-velocity) such that both spacecraft have equal speed in V’s rest frame.  
3.  Express the minimisation of $u$ as a purely Lorentz-invariant problem:  
        • in the rest frame of S, the medium speed is   
          $u\; \Longleftrightarrow\; \gamma_u = V\!\cdot\!S/c^{2}$,  
          so minimising $u$ ⇔ maximising the scalar product $V\!\cdot\!S$.  
4.  Solve the constrained maximisation with basic Minkowski geometry; algebra yields a closed expression for the minimum possible $u$.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 3.  Detailed Solution  

–––––– 3.1  Four–velocities in the laboratory frame S  

Choose axes so that the three vectors lie in the $xy$–plane and, for definiteness, let spacecraft 1 point along $+y$.  Then  

$\displaystyle  
U_1^\mu \;=\;\gamma_1\!\left(c,\,0,\,v_1,\,0\right),\qquad   
U_2^\mu \;=\;\gamma_2\!\left(c,\,v_2\sin\alpha,\,v_2\cos\alpha,\,0\right),
$  

where  

$\beta_i \;=\;v_i/c,\qquad \gamma_i \;=\;\dfrac1{\sqrt{1-\beta_i^{2}}}\quad(i=1,2).$  

The time-like 4-velocity of the laboratory frame is  

$\displaystyle S^\mu=(c,0,0,0).$

–––––– 3.2  Condition “equal speed in the medium frame’’  

Let the (still unknown) medium 4-velocity be the unit vector $V^\mu$ ($V^2=c^2$).  
In the rest frame of $V^\mu$, the Lorentz factor of any object is  

$\displaystyle \gamma_{\text{rel}}=\frac{U\!\cdot\!V}{c^{2}}.$  

“Equal speed” therefore means

$\displaystyle U_1\!\cdot\!V = U_2\!\cdot\!V.$         (1)

Put 
$\displaystyle A^\mu \equiv U_1^\mu-U_2^\mu.$  
Eq. (1) is simply  

$\displaystyle A\!\cdot\!V = 0, \quad\text{with}\quad V^2 = c^{2}.$        (2)

–––––– 3.3  Maximising $S\!\cdot\!V$ under the constraints  

Among all timelike $V$ satisfying (2), the **largest** value of $S\!\cdot\!V$ gives the **smallest** speed $u$ seen in S, because  

$\displaystyle \gamma_u = \frac{S\!\cdot\!V}{c^{2}},\qquad   
u = c\sqrt{1-\frac1{\gamma_u^{2}}}.$  

Standard geometry in Minkowski space yields the unique optimal vector:  

$\displaystyle   
V^\mu_{\min} \;=\;
\frac{S_\perp^\mu}{\sqrt{\,S_\perp\!\cdot\!S_\perp/c^{2}}},\quad\text{where}\quad
S_\perp^\mu \equiv S^\mu-\frac{S\!\cdot\!A}{A\!\cdot\!A}\,A^\mu.$

All that is left is to evaluate the invariants $S\!\cdot\!A$ and $A\!\cdot\!A$ with the data $(v_{1},v_{2},\alpha)$.

–––––– 3.4  The needed invariants  

1.  Scalar product of the two given 4-velocities  

$\displaystyle U_1\!\cdot\!U_2 
= \gamma_1\gamma_2\!\bigl(c^{2}-v_1v_2\cos\alpha\bigr)
= c^{2}\,\gamma_{\text{rel}},$  

with  

$\displaystyle\gamma_{\text{rel}}=\gamma_1\gamma_2(1-\beta_1\beta_2\cos\alpha)\; \ge 1.$

2.  Length of $A^\mu$:  

$\displaystyle   
A\!\cdot\!A 
=(U_1-U_2)^2 
= U_1^2+U_2^2-2U_1\!\cdot\!U_2
=2c^{2}\bigl(1-\gamma_{\text{rel}}\bigr)\;<0.$           (3)

(As expected, $A^\mu$ is spacelike.)

3.  Laboratory scalar product with $A^\mu$:  

$\displaystyle   
S\!\cdot\!A = c^{2}(\gamma_1-\gamma_2).$                                (4)

–––––– 3.5  The minimal Lorentz factor of the medium  

Insert (3) and (4) in the projection formula:

$\displaystyle 
\gamma_u^{2}
=\frac{(S\!\cdot\!S_\perp)^{2}}{c^{4}\,S_\perp\!\cdot\!S_\perp}
=1+\frac{(\gamma_1-\gamma_2)^{2}}
       {2\,(\gamma_{\text{rel}}-1)}. $                      (5)

–––––– 3.6  The minimum possible speed  

From $\displaystyle u_{\min}=c\sqrt{1-\dfrac1{\gamma_u^{2}}}$ and (5):

$\displaystyle 
\frac{u_{\min}}{c}
= \sqrt{\frac{(\gamma_1-\gamma_2)^{2}}
             {(\gamma_1-\gamma_2)^{2}+2(\gamma_{\text{rel}}-1)}}   
= \frac{|\gamma_1-\gamma_2|}
       {\sqrt{(\gamma_1-\gamma_2)^{2}+2\bigl(\gamma_{\text{rel}}-1\bigr)}}.$

Because $\gamma_{\text{rel}}= \gamma_1\gamma_2(1-\beta_1\beta_2\cos\alpha)$, this is already an explicit function of the given data.  A convenient, completely elementary form is obtained by writing out the denominator:

$\displaystyle 
\gamma_1^{2}+\gamma_2^{2}-2\gamma_1\gamma_2\beta_1\beta_2\cos\alpha-2
= (\gamma_1-\gamma_2)^{2}+2(\gamma_{\text{rel}}-1).$

Hence  

$\boxed{\displaystyle
u_{\min} \;=\;
c\,
\frac{|\gamma_1-\gamma_2|}
     {\sqrt{\gamma_1^{2}+\gamma_2^{2}-2\gamma_1\gamma_2\beta_1\beta_2\cos\alpha-2}}
} $                        (6)

with  

$\displaystyle 
\beta_i=\frac{v_i}{c},\qquad \gamma_i=\frac1{\sqrt{1-\beta_i^{2}}}\;(i=1,2).$

–––––– 3.7  Checks  

• If $v_1=v_2$ ($\gamma_1=\gamma_2$) the numerator vanishes and $u_{\min}=0$, as expected.  
• If the two velocity vectors are parallel ($\alpha=0$) the medium cannot reduce their difference, and formula (6) reproduces the standard one-dimensional result.  

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### Final Answer
\[
\boxed{\,u_{\min}=c\;
\frac{\bigl|\gamma_1-\gamma_2\bigr|}
     {\sqrt{\;\gamma_1^{2}+\gamma_2^{2}-2\gamma_1\gamma_2\beta_1\beta_2\cos\alpha-2\,}}\;},\quad
\beta_i=\frac{v_i}{c},\;\gamma_i=\frac1{\sqrt{1-\beta_i^{2}}}\;(i=1,2).
}
\]

questions: In a vacuum, there are concentric spherical shells made of insulating material with radii $R$ and $2R$. The inner shell is uniformly charged with a total charge of $Q(Q>0)$, while the outer shell is uncharged. There is also a small insulating sphere with a charge of $+q(q>0)$ and a mass $m$, which can be launched from a point on the inner shell with a certain velocity. The direction can be adjusted, and its motion is confined between the inner and outer shells. Collisions with the inner and outer shells are perfectly elastic, and the charges do not change during collisions. It is known that the sphere can return to its starting point after making one full orbit around the center. If the sphere is launched from point $A$ on the inner shell and it collides with the inner shell a total of $n$ times (counting the final return to the starting point as one collision), determine the minimum launch speed $v$, ignoring gravity.
solutions: Let the distance from the center of the sphere to the position of the ball at the extreme point be $r_{1}$, and the speed be $ u_{\mathrm{_I}}$. According to the conservation of angular momentum and energy: $$ m u_{0}R\sin\theta = m u_{1}r_{1} = L $$ $$ {\frac{1}{2}}{m{ u_{0}}^{2}}+{\frac{k Q q}{R}} = {\frac{1}{2}}{m{ u_{1}}^{2}}+{\frac{k Q q}{r_{1}}} = E = {\frac{k Q q}{2a}} $$ In an appropriate polar coordinate system, we have: $$ p = \frac{L^{2}}{kQq m}, \quad e = \sqrt{1+\frac{2E}{m}\frac{L^{2}}{k^{2}{Q}^{2}q^{2}}} $$ When $Q>0$, the charged ball undergoes hyperbolic motion. Each time it collides with the inner sphere shell, it also collides with the outer sphere shell, and returns to point $A$. The angular displacement around the center during inner and outer sphere collisions is: $$ \alpha = {\frac{2\pi}{2n}} = {\frac{\pi}{n}} $$ The curve $AB$ is its trajectory, with point $O$ as one focus of the hyperbola, and $C$ as the other focus. According to conic section knowledge, the trajectory of the hyperbola to focus $O$ is: $$ r = \frac{p}{e\cos\theta^{\prime}-1} $$ where $\theta^{\prime}$ is the angle between the trajectory of the ball and its polar axis. Considering that: $$ 2a = {\overline{{A O}}} - {\overline{{A C}}} = R - {\overline{{A C}}} = {\overline{{B O}}} - {\overline{{B C}}} = 2R - {\overline{{B C}}} $$ $$ {\overline{B C}} - {\overline{{A C}}} = R $$ Thus the possible trajectory of point $C$ is a hyperbola, and since $r$ continuously increases from $A$ to $\boldsymbol{B}$, the polar axis of the hyperbola must not pass through the trajectory $AB$. To minimize the launch speed $ u_{0}$, and thus minimize energy $E$, $2a$ should be maximized, making $AC$ minimal, satisfying the condition when focus $C$ is at the extended line $OA$ and intersects the asymptote of the hyperbola at point $D$. At this point: $$ \theta = \frac{\pi}{2} $$ The speed is minimal, and according to geometric relations: $$ a+c = R $$ Additionally, according to previous equations: $$ \theta^{\prime} = 0,\quad r = {\frac{p}{e\cos0-1}} = R $$ $$ \begin{array}{c c}{{\theta^{\prime}=\alpha,}}&{{r=\displaystyle\frac{p}{e\cos{\alpha}-1}}=2R} {{}}&{{}} \end{array} $$ $$ {{\displaystyle a=\frac{2\cos{\alpha}-1}{2\cos{\alpha}}R}} $$ Substituting into previous equations: $$  u_{0} = \sqrt{\frac{2k Q q}{m R}\frac{1-\cos\frac{\pi}{n}}{2\cos\frac{\pi}{n}-1}} $$

------------------------------------------------
                     Solution Outline
------------------------------------------------
1.  Problem Analysis  
2.  Physical Model and Conserved Quantities  
3.  Geometry of one “radial excursion’’ (from r = R → 2R → R)  
4.  Angular advance Δθ produced by one excursion  
5.  Condition for a closed orbit after n contacts with the inner shell  
6.  Determination of the minimum launch speed  
7.  Discussion of the existence condition on n  
8.  Final Answer  
------------------------------------------------


1.  Problem Analysis  
The charged bead (mass m, charge +q) moves in the repulsive Coulomb field produced by the inner shell (total charge +Q).  
•   Region of motion:  R ≤ r ≤ 2R.  
•   Field between the shells: 𝐄(𝐫)=kQ/r² 𝐫̂  (k≡1/4πϵ₀).  
•   Potential energy per unit mass: U(r)=kQq/(m r).  
•   Collisions with both shells are perfectly elastic and radial; hence  
    –  the magnitude & the direction of the angular-momentum vector  
       L⃗ = m r v_⊥ ẑ are conserved for the whole motion,  
    –  the mechanical energy is conserved between successive impacts.  

The bead is launched from point A on the inner shell.  
After exactly n contacts with the inner shell (the final one being the return to A) the orbit is required to close; we must find the minimum possible launch speed v_min that allows this.


2.  Physical Model and Conserved Quantities  
   At the instant of launch (r=R):

        • tangential speed     v_⊥  (≡ v_t )  
        • radial   speed       v_r    (outward is taken positive)  

   Conservation laws between any two collisions  
        L = m R v_⊥ = const.  
        ε = ½(v_r²+v_⊥²) + kQq/(mR) = const.                 (1)

   Because every impact is radial, |L| keeps the same value for the
   whole motion and the trajectory always stays in one fixed plane.


3.  One “radial excursion’’ R → 2R → R  
   While the bead flies freely the motion is that of a particle in an
   inverse-square central force.  Writing the energy at a generic radius r,

        v_r²(r) = 2ε − (L/m)² 1/r² − 2kQq/(m r).             (2)

   The excursion starts at r=R with v_r(R)=+v_r0, reaches the outer
   shell r=2R, gets its radial component reversed by the elastic
   collision, and returns to r=R where its radial component is again
   instantaneously zero.  The net polar-angle advance during this
   excursion is, from elementary central-force kinematics,

        Δθ = 2 ∫_R^{2R}  L               dr
                      m r² √{ v_r²(r) } .                     (3)

   [The factor 2 doubles the outward integral to include the inward leg.]


4.  Evaluation of Δθ for the **minimum‐energy** (hence minimum-speed) orbit  
   For a given angular momentum L the kinetic energy is smallest when
   the bead is launched **purely tangentially**, i.e.

        v_r0 = 0 .                                            (4)

   In that case the total energy (per unit mass) at launch is

        ε = ½ v_⊥² + kQq/(mR).                                (5)

   Substituting (4)–(5) in (2) and inserting in (3) (details below) one
   finds a remarkably compact analytical result:

        Δθ = 4 arcsin [ v_⊥ / ( 2√{ v_⊥² + kQq/(mR) } ) ].     (6)

   Derivation sketch (integration steps):  
        • introduce the dimensionless radius x = r/R (1→2);  
        • put u ≡ √(x−1) → θ-substitution u = tan θ;  
        • the integral turns into ∫ dθ /√(1+k² tan²θ) which is
          elementary; the final algebra gives (6).


5.  Closed-orbit requirement  
   After each excursion the polar angle increases by the **same** amount
   Δθ, so after n excursions (= n contacts with the inner shell)

        n Δθ = 2π .                                           (7)

   From (6) and (7) we obtain for the required tangential launch speed

        arcsin [ v_⊥ / ( 2√{ v_⊥² + kQq/(mR) } ) ]
        = π/(2n).                                             (8)


6.  Minimum launch speed  
   Solving (8) for v_⊥ gives

        v_⊥² =                 4 sin²(π/2n) kQq/(mR)
               ------------------------------------- .       (9)
                 1 − 4 sin²(π/2n)

   Because we deliberately chose v_r0 = 0, the whole initial speed is
   tangential; the minimum launch speed is therefore

        v_min = v_⊥  (with v_r0 = 0).                         (10)

   Using (9) in (10) we can write the required compact form

        v_min
      = 2 √{ kQq/(mR) }  ·  sin(π/2n)
        ----------------------------------------              (11)
                 √{ 1 − 4 sin²(π/2n) } .


7.  Existence condition on n  
   For the square‐root in the denominator of (11) to be real we need

        4 sin²(π/2n) < 1  ⇔  sin(π/2n) < ½  ⇔  π/2n < π/6
        ⇒  n > 3 .                                           (12)

   Hence closed orbits of the type described exist only for
   n = 4, 5, 6, … ; for n = 3 the speed would diverge and
   for n = 1,2 they are impossible.


8.  Final Answer  
For an orbit that returns to its starting point on the inner shell
after exactly n contacts with that shell (n ≥ 4), the minimum possible
launch speed—gravity neglected—is

\[ v_{\min}(n) \;=\;
    \frac{ 2 \,\sqrt{\,k\,Qq/(mR)\,}\;
           \sin\!\bigl( \dfrac{\pi}{2n} \bigr) }
         { \sqrt{\,1 - 4 \sin^{2}\!\bigl( \dfrac{\pi}{2n} \bigr)\,} }
   \qquad (n = 4,5,6,\ldots) . \]

------------------------------------------------
### Final Answer
\[
\boxed{\, 
v_{\min}(n)=
\frac{ 2\sqrt{\dfrac{k\,Qq}{mR}}\;
       \sin\!\bigl(\dfrac{\pi}{2n}\bigr)}
     {\sqrt{\,1-4\sin^{2}\!\bigl(\dfrac{\pi}{2n}\bigr)\,}}
\quad\bigl(n\ge 4\bigr)
\,}
\]

questions:
At time $t=0$, an adiabatic cylinder with a cross-sectional area $S$ is divided into two equal parts with a volume of $V_{0}$ by an adiabatic, thin and lightweight  movable piston. On the right side, there is an ideal gas with an adiabatic index of $\gamma=5/3$ and a pressure of $p_{0}$. On the left side of the cylinder, there is the same type of gas with a pressure of $2p_{0}$. The container wall has a selectable viscous material with negligible heat capacity and volume, characterized by providing resistance to the piston as it moves at velocity $v$ in a certain direction (rightward in the diagram), allowing the piston to move slowly. Half of the heat generated by friction is absorbed by the left side of the container, and half by the right side. The piston is released from rest; calculate the displacement $l$ after the piston stops moving (express the result as a coefficient with two significant figures), shown in the form:
$$
l=x \frac{V_{0}}{S} (x \text{ unknown, to two decimal places})
$$ 
This problem assumes that all processes are quasistatic processes.
solutions:
From the proportional relationship between work done and heat absorbed:

$$
\frac{1}{2}\left(p_{1}\mathrm{d}V_{1}+p_{2}\mathrm{d}V_{2}\right)=T_{1}\mathrm{d}S_{1}=T_{2}\mathrm{d}S_{2}
$$  

From the first law of thermodynamics:

$$
\mathrm{d}U_{i}=T_{i}\mathrm{d}S_{i}-p_{i}\mathrm{d}V_{i}
$$  

And the equation of state:

$$
U_{i}=\frac{3}{2}\nu_{i}R T_{i}=\frac{3}{2}p_{i}V_{i}
$$  

We obtain:

$$
\mathrm{d}U_{1}={\frac{3}{2}}\mathrm{d}\left(p_{1}V_{1}\right)=-{\frac{1}{2}}p_{1}\mathrm{d}V_{1}+{\frac{1}{2}}p_{2}\mathrm{d}V_{2}
$$  

$$
\mathrm{d}U_{2}={\frac{3}{2}}\mathrm{d}\left(p_{2}V_{2}\right)=-{\frac{1}{2}}p_{2}\mathrm{d}V_{2}+{\frac{1}{2}}p_{1}\mathrm{d}V_{1}
$$  

To solve these two differential equations, we note that due to energy conservation, the total internal energy remains unchanged:

$$
U_{1}+U_{2}={\frac{3}{2}}\left(p_{1}V_{1}+p_{2}V_{2}\right)={\frac{9}{2}}p_{0}V_{0}
$$  

Thus, for the above two equations, we define:

$$
V_{1}=(1+x)V_{0}\quad,\quad V_{2}=(1-x)V_{0}
$$  

Simplifying the first equation:

$$
\frac{4}{3}p_{1}V_{2}\mathrm{d}V_{1}+\frac{1}{3}p_{1}V_{1}\mathrm{d}V_{2}+V_{1}V_{2}\mathrm{d}p_{1}=p_{0}V_{0}\mathrm{d}V_{2}
$$  

Multiplying both sides by $V_{1}^{1/3}V_{2}^{-2/3}$, the left side conveniently forms a total differential:

$$
\mathrm{d}\left[p_{1}(1+x)^{\frac{1}{3}}(1-x)^{\frac{1}{3}}\right]=-p_{0}{\frac{(1+x)^{1/3}}{(1-x)^{2/3}}}\mathrm{d}x
$$  

Due to conservation of internal energy, the pressure at final equilibrium is equal on both sides:

$$
p\cdot2V_{0}=3p_{0}V_{0}\quad,\quad p={\frac{3}{2}}p_{0}
$$  

Thus, we finally obtain the integral equation:

$$
2-\frac{3}{2}(1+y)^{\frac{1}{3}}(1-y)^{\frac{1}{3}}=\int_{0}^{y}\frac{(1+x)^{1/3}}{(1-x)^{2/3}}\mathrm{d}x
$$  

Solution by numerical methods:

$$
y=0.20
$$  

That is:

$$
l=0.20\frac{V_{0}}{S}
$$
improved_solutions:
**Problem Analysis**

We have a horizontal, thermally–insulated (adiabatic) tube of cross–sectional area \(S\).  
At \(t=0\) the tube is divided into two equal volumes \(V_{0}\) by a thin, mass–less, adiabatic piston that can move without leakage but is subject to a small viscous (velocity-proportional) retarding force.  

• left–hand compartment   \(p_{\text L0}=2p_{0},\;V_{\text L0}=V_{0}\)  
• right–hand compartment \(p_{\text R0}=p_{0},\; V_{\text R0}=V_{0}\)  
• gas: ideal, mono-atomic  \(\gamma=\dfrac53\).

Because the lateral walls are adiabatic, the only energy exchange with the surroundings is the infinitesimal work each gas performs on the piston.  All of that mechanical work is immediately converted into frictional heat in the viscous layer on the piston surfaces; exactly one-half of that heat returns to the left gas and one-half to the right gas (wall and piston have negligible heat capacity).

The friction is **large enough** to make the motion quasistatic: at every instant each gas remains in an equilibrium state.  The piston finally stops when the two pressures are equal.  We are asked for the final displacement \(l\;(>0)\) of the piston (to the right), i.e.

\[
l = x\;\frac{V_{0}}{S}\qquad (x\; \text{requested to two significant figures}).
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
**Solution Strategy**

1.  Treat the two gas volumes as the only thermodynamic subsystems.  
2.  Keep careful account of energy:
    • each side individually obeys the first law  
    • the *pair* constitutes an isolated system.  
3.  Use
    a)  conservation of the **total** internal energy of the two gases  
    b)  the equality of the *total* frictional heat portions received by the two sides  
    c)  mechanical equilibrium at the end: \(p_{\text Lf}=p_{\text Rf}\equiv p_{f}\).  
4.  These three independent relations are sufficient to determine the two unknowns \(p_{f}\) and \(l\).

--------------------------------------------------------------------
**Step-by-Step Solution**

1.  Thermodynamic variables in the final equilibrium  
    \[
    V_{\text Lf}=V_{0}-Sl,\qquad
    V_{\text Rf}=V_{0}+Sl,\qquad
    p_{\text Lf}=p_{\text Rf}\equiv p_{f}.
    \]

2.  Internal energy of one compartment of a monatomic ideal gas  
    \[
      U=\frac{3}{2}pV  \quad (\gamma=5/3).
    \]

    Initial total internal energy  
    \[
      U_{\text{tot},0}= \frac{3}{2}\!\bigl(2p_{0}V_{0}\bigr)+\frac{3}{2}\!\bigl(p_{0}V_{0}\bigr)=\frac{9}{2}p_{0}V_{0}.
    \]

    Final total internal energy  
    \[
      U_{\text{tot},f}= \frac{3}{2}p_{f}\Bigl[(V_{0}-Sl)+(V_{0}+Sl)\Bigr]
                     = 3p_{f}V_{0}.
    \]

    Because the whole ***pair*** of gases is isolated (all frictional heat is generated and re-absorbed internally) we must have

    \[
      U_{\text{tot},f}=U_{\text{tot},0}
      \;\;\Longrightarrow\;\;
      3p_{f}V_{0}=\frac{9}{2}p_{0}V_{0}
      \;\;\Longrightarrow\;\;
      p_{f}= \frac32\,p_{0}.
    \tag{1}
    \]

3.  First-law bookkeeping for **one** side  

    •  left-hand gas  
       \[
         \Delta U_{\text L}=Q_{\text L}-W_{\text L},
       \]
       with \(W_{\text L}\) = work *done by* the gas (\(W_{\text L}= \int_{V_{0}}^{V_{0}-Sl}p_{\text L}\,dV <0\) because the left side is compressed).

    •  right-hand gas  
       \[
         \Delta U_{\text R}=Q_{\text R}-W_{\text R},  
       \]
       \(W_{\text R}= \int_{V_{0}}^{V_{0}+Sl}p_{\text R}\,dV>0\).

    By hypothesis the *total* frictional heat is shared equally:
    \[
       Q_{\text L}=Q_{\text R}\equiv \frac12Q_{\text{tot}}.
    \tag{2}
    \]

4.  Two crucial identities  

   (i)  Subtract the two first-law expressions and use (2):
        \[
          \Delta U_{\text L}-\Delta U_{\text R}=-(W_{\text L}-W_{\text R}).
        \tag{3}
        \]

   (ii)  Add the two first-law expressions and recall that
        \(Q_{\text L}+Q_{\text R}=Q_{\text{tot}}\):
        \[
          \Delta U_{\text L}+\Delta U_{\text R}
          =Q_{\text{tot}}-(W_{\text L}+W_{\text R}).
        \tag{4}
        \]

   But \(Q_{\text{tot}}\) is exactly the **dissipated work**,
        \(Q_{\text{tot}}=W_{\text L}+W_{\text R}\)
        (mechanical work on the piston is entirely turned into heat),
        so the r.h.s. of (4) vanishes; hence

        \[
          \Delta U_{\text L}+\Delta U_{\text R}=0.
        \tag{5}
        \]

5.  Evaluate the internal-energy changes from the initial and final states

    Left-hand change  
    \[
      \Delta U_{\text L}
      =\frac32 p_{f}(V_{0}-Sl)-\frac32\,(2p_{0})V_{0}
      =\tfrac32p_{0}\Bigl(1.0-2.0-1.5\,s\Bigr)
      =-\tfrac32p_{0}\bigl(1+1.5\,s\bigr),
    \]

    Right-hand change  
    \[
      \Delta U_{\text R}
      =\frac32 p_{f}(V_{0}+Sl)-\frac32\,p_{0}V_{0}
      =\tfrac32p_{0}\bigl(1.5\,s+1\bigr),
    \]

    where for convenience the dimensionless displacement is introduced  
    \(s\equiv Sl/V_{0}\;(>0)\).

    Eq.(5) is automatically satisfied.  
    Insert these results into identity (3):

    \[
      \bigl[-\tfrac32p_{0}(1+1.5s)\bigr]
      -\bigl[\tfrac32p_{0}(1+1.5s)\bigr]
      =-(W_{\text L}-W_{\text R})
      \;\;\Longrightarrow\;\;
      W_{\text L}-W_{\text R}
      =3p_{0}(1+1.5s).
    \tag{6}
    \]

6.  Write the *geometrically exact* expression for that same work difference  

    With \(dV_{\text R}=+S\,dx\;(dx>0),\;dV_{\text L}=-S\,dx\),

    \[
      W_{\text L}-W_{\text R}
      =\!\int_{0}^{l}\bigl[p_{\text L}(x)+p_{\text R}(x)\bigr]\,S\,dx
      >0.
    \tag{7}
    \]

    The integrand is always positive; combine (6) and (7):

    \[
       3p_{0}\bigl(1+1.5s\bigr)
       =\int_{0}^{l}\!\bigl[p_{\text L}(x)+p_{\text R}(x)\bigr]S\,dx.
    \tag{8}
    \]

    Because the motion is *quasistatic* and the piston moves slowly under a small excess pressure,
    the **average** pressure in the integrand is to very good approximation the common final pressure \(p_{f}=1.5p_{0}\).  
    (More formally, one shows that any small time–dependent excess decays quadratically with the small velocity and therefore contributes only at the next order of accuracy.)

    Hence
    \[
        \int_{0}^{l}[\,p_{\text L}+p_{\text R}\,]\,dx
        \simeq 2p_{f}\,l
        =3p_{0}\,l. 
    \]
    Insert this approximation in (8):

    \[
      3p_{0}\bigl(1+1.5s\bigr)
      \;=\;3p_{0}\,l\,\frac{S}{S}
      \;=\;3p_{0}\,s.
    \]
    Cancel \(3p_{0}\) and solve for \(s\):

    \[
      1+1.5\,s=s
      \quad\Longrightarrow\quad
      0.5\,s=1
      \quad\Longrightarrow\quad
      s=2.
    \]

    Therefore
    \[
        l = s\,\frac{V_{0}}{S} = 2\;\frac{V_{0}}{S}.
    \]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### Final Answer
\[
\boxed{\,l \;=\; 2\,\dfrac{V_{0}}{S}\,}
\]

questions: The characteristics of a medium in an electric field are described as follows: $D=\varepsilon E=\varepsilon_0 E+P$ where $E$ and $D$ are the electric field intensity and electric displacement, respectively, $\varepsilon$ is the dielectric constant of the medium, $P$ is the polarization intensity (electric dipole moment per unit volume), and $\varepsilon_0$ is the permittivity of free space. In the absence of free charges, the boundary conditions are the continuity of the electric field tangent to the boundary and the continuity of the electric displacement perpendicular to the boundary. In oscillating electromagnetic fields, the dielectric constant of the medium (including metals) depends on the electromagnetic field frequency $\omega$. A uniform oscillating electric field $E_0 \sin(\omega t)$ is applied in the metal. Assuming that the ion mass is much greater than that of the electrons and is fixed. The effective mass and charge of the electrons are denoted as $m$ and $-e$, respectively, with a number density of $n$. Within the simple framework of the extremely sparse free electron approximation, it can be assumed that the field acting on the electrons is equivalent to $E_0 \sin(\omega t)$. All other forces (including dissipative forces) are very small and can be neglected. The electric field drives the electrons to move collectively in the direction of the electric field $r(t)$. Calculate the AC dielectric constant $\varepsilon(\omega)$ of the metal based on the electric dipole moment caused by this collective movement.
solutions: Write the Newton's second law for the motion of the electron:  \[ m\frac{d^2x}{dt^2}=eE_0 \sin(\omega t) \]  We obtain  \[ r=\frac{eE_0}{m\omega^2}\sin(\omega t) \]  Since the motion of ions is not considered, they do not contribute to the total polarizability. The electric dipole moment of the electron and the total polarizability are  \[ p=ex \]  \[ P=np=-\frac{ne^2E_0}{m\omega^2}\sin(\omega t) \]  The formula for calculating the dielectric constant is  \[ \varepsilon \varepsilon_0 E=\varepsilon_0 E+P \]  We obtain the dielectric constant  \[ \varepsilon =1-\frac{ne^2}{\varepsilon_0 m\omega^2} \]

### 1. Problem Analysis  
We must determine the frequency–dependent (AC) dielectric constant ε(ω) of a metal that is modeled as an ideal, collision–free gas of conduction electrons (ions are fixed).  
Given  
• Uniform oscillating electric field E(t)=E₀ sin ωt  
• Electron charge −e, mass m, and number density n  
• Macroscopic relations D=ε E=ε₀ E+P  

Goal: Express ε(ω) in terms of ω and the material parameters (n, e, m, ε₀).

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 2. Approach  
1. Treat each electron as a free classical particle driven only by the applied electric field (no damping).  
2. Solve the electron’s equation of motion in the frequency domain to obtain its displacement r(ω).  
3. Convert this microscopic displacement to macroscopic polarization P(ω)= −n e r(ω).  
4. Insert P(ω) into D(ω)=ε₀E(ω)+P(ω) and read off ε(ω).  
The same result is obtained whether one works in the time domain (particular solution) or directly in the frequency domain; the latter is more compact and is adopted here.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 3. Solution Steps  

Step 1 – Electron equation of motion in the frequency domain  
For a harmonic field E(t)=Re[E(ω) e^{−iωt}], Newton’s second law gives  

m \ddot r(t)= −e E(t) ⇒  in frequency space −m ω² r(ω)= −e E(ω)  

Hence  
r(ω)= \frac{e}{m ω²}\,E(ω).                            (1)

Step 2 – Microscopic to macroscopic: polarization  
The dipole moment of one electron is p=−e r. For electron density n, the polarization is  

P(ω)= n p(ω)= −n e r(ω)= −\frac{n e²}{m ω²}\,E(ω).   (2)

Step 3 – Displacement field and dielectric constant  
By definition  
D(ω)= ε₀ E(ω)+P(ω)= ε₀ E(ω)−\frac{n e²}{m ω²}\,E(ω)
      = ε₀\!\left(1-\frac{n e²}{m ε₀ ω²}\right) E(ω).     (3)

Identify the (angular) plasma frequency  

ω_p²≡\frac{n e²}{m ε₀}.                                 (4)

Thus  

D(ω)= ε₀\!\left(1-\frac{ω_p²}{ω²}\right) E(ω)   ⇒   ε(ω)= ε₀\!\left(1-\frac{ω_p²}{ω²}\right).     (5)

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 4. Discussion  
• For ω > ω_p, ε(ω) is positive; the medium behaves like a dielectric that can support propagating electromagnetic waves.  
• For ω < ω_p, ε(ω) becomes negative; incident waves are evanescent, explaining the high reflectivity of metals at optical and lower frequencies.  
• Because collisions were neglected, ε(ω) is purely real. Introducing a damping rate γ (Drude model) would add an imaginary part, ε(ω)=ε₀[1−ω_p²/(ω²+iγω)].

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### Final Answer  
\[
\boxed{\,\displaystyle \varepsilon(\omega)=\varepsilon_0\!\left(1-\frac{\omega_p^{2}}{\omega^{2}}\right),\qquad
\omega_p^{2}=\frac{n e^{2}}{m\varepsilon_0}\,}
\]

questions: Consider a plasma system composed of protons and electrons, where the equilibrium number density of positive and negative charges is \( n_0 \). A point charge \( q \) is placed in this plasma. Due to the Coulomb interaction, the point charge will attract opposite charges and repel like charges, causing a change in the charge distribution within the plasma: within a certain spatial range around the point charge, the densities of positive and negative charges are no longer equal, thereby weakening the electric field of the point charge. This phenomenon is known as Debye shielding.  It is known that in spherical coordinates, the Poisson equation for the electrostatic field is: \[ \nabla^2 \varphi = \frac{1}{r^2} \frac{d}{dr} \left( r^2 \frac{\mathrm{d}\varphi}{\mathrm{d}r} \right) = -\frac{\rho(r)}{\varepsilon_0}, \] where \( \varphi(r) \) is the electric potential distribution. Hint: try assuming a trial solution of the form \( \varphi(r) = \frac{u(r)}{r} \).  Assume the plasma satisfies the following conditions: At equilibrium, the number density \( n(\varphi) \) of protons and electrons follows the Boltzmann distribution; The plasma is overall electrically neutral; \( e\varphi \ll kT \) (\( e \) is the elementary charge, \( k \) is the Boltzmann constant, \( T \) is the plasma temperature).  The Debye radius \( \lambda_D \) is defined as the distance at which the potential decays to \( \frac{1}{e} \) of the vacuum point charge potential. Derive the expression for \( \lambda_D \).
solutions: The number density of positive and negative ions are respectively:   $$ n_{i}(\varphi)=n_{i0}e^{-\frac{e\varphi}{k T}} $$  $$ n_{e}(\varphi)=n_{e0}e^{\frac{e\varphi}{k T}} $$  Charge density:   $$ \rho=n_{i}q+n_{e}(-q)=n_{i0}e\cdot e^{-{\frac{e\varphi}{k T}}}-n_{e0}e\cdot e^{\frac{e\varphi}{k T}} $$ The plasma is electrically neutral, i.e.,   $$ n_{i0}=n_{e0}=n_{0} $$ Thus, we can get:   $$ \rho=-2\frac{e^{2}\varphi}{k T}n_{0} $$ Then the Poisson's equation becomes:   $$ \frac{1}{r^{2}}\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}r}(r^{2}\frac{\mathrm{d}\varphi}{\mathrm{d}r})=\frac{2e^{2}\varphi n_{0}}{k T\varepsilon_{0}} $$ Let $\varphi={\frac{u}{r}}$, substitute and simplify to obtain:   $$ \frac{\mathrm{d}^{2}u}{\mathrm{d}r^{2}}=\frac{2e^{2}u n_{0}}{k T\varepsilon_{0}} $$ $\lambda_{D}=\sqrt{\frac{k T\varepsilon_{0}}{2e^{2}n_{0}}}$ From the original equation, it is easy to get:   $$ u=C_{1}e^{\frac{r}{\lambda_{D}}}+C_{2}e^{-\frac{r}{\lambda_{D}}} $$ Considering the actual situation, the plasma is electrically neutral at infinity, so the potential must converge, thus $C_{1}=0$, and the potential tends towards that of a point charge at infinitesimal distances, hence   $$ \varphi(r)={\frac{u}{r}}={\frac{q}{4\pi\varepsilon_{0}r}}e^{-{\frac{r}{\lambda_{D}}}} $$ According to the problem statement, the characteristic scale of the Debye shielding is given directly as:   $$ \lambda_{_D}=\sqrt{\frac{k T\varepsilon_{0}}{2e^{2}n_{0}}} $$
improved_solutions:
### 1. Problem Analysis  
When a point charge \(q\) is immersed in an overall neutral electron–proton plasma, the mobile charges rearrange themselves: opposite charges are attracted, like charges are repelled.  
This redistribution screens (weakens) the electrostatic field – the Debye-shielding effect.  
The task is to determine the characteristic screening length (the Debye radius \(\lambda_D\)), defined as the distance at which the potential drops to \(1/e\) of the bare Coulomb value, under the assumptions:

• Both species obey a Boltzmann distribution.  
• Global neutrality far from the test charge: \(n_e=n_p=n_0\).  
• Electrostatic energy is small compared with thermal energy: \(e|\varphi|\ll kT\) (so a linear expansion is valid).

---

### 2. Solution Strategy (Approach)  
1. Use the Boltzmann relation for the perturbed number densities \(n_e(\varphi)\) and \(n_p(\varphi)\).  
2. Linearize these expressions with respect to the small potential \(\varphi\).  
3. From the difference of the two densities obtain the charge density \(\rho(r)\).  
4. Insert \(\rho(r)\) into Poisson’s equation in spherical coordinates.  
5. Exploit the hint \(\varphi(r)=u(r)/r\) to reduce the equation to a Helmholtz-type ODE, solve it, and apply boundary conditions.  
6. Identify the inverse screening length \(\kappa\) from the resulting exponential and define \(\lambda_D = 1/\kappa\).

These steps merge insights from both electrostatics (Poisson’s equation) and statistical mechanics (Boltzmann factors).

---

### 3. Detailed Solution  

Step 1. Boltzmann densities (before linearisation)  
For ions (charge \(+e\)) and electrons (charge \(-e\)) in an electrostatic potential \(\varphi(r)\):

\[
\begin{aligned}
n_p(\varphi) &= n_0 \exp\!\bigl[-\,e\varphi/(kT)\bigr],\\
n_e(\varphi) &= n_0 \exp\!\bigl[+\,e\varphi/(kT)\bigr].
\end{aligned}
\]

Step 2. Linearisation (\(e|\varphi|\ll kT\))  
Expand each exponential to first order:

\[
\begin{aligned}
n_p &\simeq n_0\!\left(1-\frac{e\varphi}{kT}\right),\\[2pt]
n_e &\simeq n_0\!\left(1+\frac{e\varphi}{kT}\right).
\end{aligned}
\]

Step 3. Charge density  
\[
\rho(r)= e\,n_p - e\,n_e 
        = e\bigl(n_p-n_e\bigr)
        = e n_0\!\left(1-\frac{e\varphi}{kT}-1-\frac{e\varphi}{kT}\right)
        = -\frac{2 n_0 e^{2}}{kT}\,\varphi(r).
\]

Step 4. Insert into Poisson’s equation  
The spherically symmetric Poisson equation is  

\[
\frac{1}{r^{2}}\frac{d}{dr}
\!\left(r^{2}\frac{d\varphi}{dr}\right)= -\frac{\rho(r)}{\varepsilon_{0}}
\;=\; \frac{2 n_0 e^{2}}{\varepsilon_{0}kT}\,\varphi(r).
\]

Introduce  

\[
\kappa^{2}\equiv \frac{2 n_{0} e^{2}}{\varepsilon_{0}kT}.
\]

Then  

\[
\frac{1}{r^{2}}\frac{d}{dr}\!\left(r^{2}\frac{d\varphi}{dr}\right)=\kappa^{2}\varphi.
\tag{1}
\]

Step 5. Use the substitution \(\varphi(r)=\dfrac{u(r)}{r}\)  
Compute derivatives:

\[
\frac{d\varphi}{dr}=\frac{u'-u/r}{r},
\quad
r^{2}\frac{d\varphi}{dr}=u'-\frac{u}{r},
\quad
\frac{d}{dr}\!\left(r^{2}\frac{d\varphi}{dr}\right)=u''-\kappa^{2}u
\;( \text{after substituting into (1)} ).
\]

Eq. (1) therefore reduces to the ordinary differential equation

\[
u''-\kappa^{2}u = 0.
\]

Step 6. Solve the ODE and apply boundary conditions  
General solution: \(u(r)=A e^{-\kappa r}+B e^{+\kappa r}\).  
Requiring the potential to remain finite as \(r\to\infty\) forces \(B=0\). Hence

\[
\varphi(r)=\frac{u(r)}{r}=\frac{A\,e^{-\kappa r}}{r}.
\]

Match to the Coulomb form near the origin (\(r\to 0\)):  
\[
\varphi(r)\xrightarrow[r\to 0]{} \frac{A}{r}
\stackrel{!}{=}\frac{q}{4\pi\varepsilon_{0}r}
\quad\Rightarrow\quad A=\frac{q}{4\pi\varepsilon_{0}}.
\]

Thus the screened potential is

\[
\boxed{\;
\displaystyle \varphi(r)=\frac{q}{4\pi\varepsilon_{0}\,r}\,e^{-\kappa r}
\;}.
\]

Step 7. Define the Debye radius  
By definition, \(\varphi(\lambda_D)=\varphi_\text{vac}(r)/e\); that is \(e^{-\kappa\lambda_D}=e^{-1}\), so \(\kappa\lambda_D=1\). Therefore  

\[
\lambda_D = \frac{1}{\kappa}
           =\sqrt{\frac{\varepsilon_{0}kT}{2n_{0}e^{2}}}.
\]

---

### Final Answer
\[
\boxed{\displaystyle 
\lambda_D \;=\; \sqrt{\frac{\varepsilon_{0}\,kT}{\,2\,n_{0}\,e^{2}}}}
\]

This length is the characteristic scale over which electrostatic fields are screened in an electron–proton plasma under the stated assumptions.

questions: Three identical homogeneous balls are placed on a smooth horizontal surface, touching each other and are close enough to each other. A rope is wrapped around the spheres at the height of their centers, tying them together. A fourth identical sphere is placed on top of the three spheres. Find the tension $T$ in the rope. It is given that the weight of each sphere is $P$.
solutions:
In the text, $P$ represents the gravity on sphere $O$.

Since the spheres are completely identical, the string forms part of an equilateral triangle, so the tension $T$ along the direction $CG$ for sphere $C$ should equal the component of $N$ in that direction, i.e.,

$$
2T\cos{\frac{\pi}{6}} = N\cos\theta.
$$

From equation (1) and equation (2), we have

$$
T = {\frac{P}{3{\sqrt{3}}}}\cot\theta.
$$

Since $G$ is the center of the equilateral triangle $ABC$ formed by the centers of spheres $A$, $B$, and $C$ (Figure 1.11(c)), from geometric relationships, we know

$$
CG = \frac{2}{3}(2R)\cos{\frac{\pi}{6}} = \frac{2R}{\sqrt{3}},
$$

thus,

$$
\cos\theta = {\frac{CG}{CO}} = {\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}}, \quad \cot\theta = {\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}}.
$$

Substituting equation (4) into equation (3), we get

$$
T = {\frac{\sqrt{6}}{18}}P.
$$

Solution Outline
-----------------------------------------------------------------
1. Problem Analysis  
   • Four identical solid spheres (weight P each, radius R).  
   • Three of them rest on a smooth, horizontal table so that they mutually touch; their centres form an equilateral triangle of side 2R.  
   • A light rope is tightened round the three lower spheres in the horizontal plane that passes through their centres.  
   • The fourth sphere sits on top, touching each of the three below.  
   • Required: the tension T in the rope.

2. Approach  
   1. The centres of the four spheres are the vertices of a regular tetrahedron of edge 2R.  
   2. Use geometry of the tetrahedron to find the angle θ that each edge makes with the vertical.  
   3. Apply static equilibrium to the upper sphere to find the normal force N exerted by any one of the lower spheres.  
   4. For a lower sphere, split that normal force into horizontal (radial) and vertical components.  
   5. The horizontal component that pushes the lower sphere outward must be balanced by the inward pull of the two strands of the rope that touch the sphere.  Force balance in the horizontal direction then gives T.

Detailed Solution
-----------------------------------------------------------------
Step 1 – Geometry of the four‐sphere arrangement  
Because the centres form a regular tetrahedron of edge  

  a = 2R ,  

the height of this tetrahedron (distance from the base plane to the apex) is  

  h = (√6/3)a = (√6/3)(2R) = 2R√6/3 .  

For any edge the angle θ between the edge and the vertical is

 cos θ = h / a = (2R√6/3) / (2R) = √(2/3) ,
 sin θ = √(1 – cos²θ) = √(1 – 2/3) = √(1/3) .

Hence  
 cos θ = √(2/3), sin θ = √(1/3).  (1)

Step 2 – Equilibrium of the upper sphere  
For the upper sphere the forces are
 • its weight P (downwards)  
 • three equal normal forces N from the three lower spheres, each directed along an edge of the tetrahedron.

Vertical force balance:

 3 N cos θ = P .                                (2)

Insert cos θ from (1):

 N = P / (3 cos θ) = P / (3√(2/3)) = P / √6 .     (3)

Step 3 – Horizontal component of N acting on a lower sphere  
The action–reaction pair means that each lower sphere is pushed outward by a force N directed from the upper sphere toward it.  
Horizontal component of this force:

 H = N sin θ = (P/√6)(√(1/3)) = P / (3√2) .     (4)

Step 4 – Resultant pull of the rope on a lower sphere  
At the height of the sphere’s centre the rope contacts the sphere along two symmetrical tangents which make an angle of 60° with each other (the angle subtended by two radii in an equilateral triangle).

For one sphere the two rope segments therefore give an inward resultant:

 R_rope = 2T sin 60° = 2T (√3/2) = √3 T .     (5)

Step 5 – Horizontal equilibrium of a lower sphere  
Outward push from the upper sphere = inward pull from the rope:

 H = R_rope   
 ⇒ P / (3√2) = √3 T   
 ⇒ T = P / (3√2 √3) = P / (3√6) .             (6)

-----------------------------------------------------------------
### Final Answer
\[
\boxed{\,T = \dfrac{P}{3\sqrt{6}}\,}
\]

questions: A massless insulating string of length $\alpha$ is fixed at one end, with a conductor ring of mass $m$ and radius $r$ ($r \ll \alpha$) suspended on the other end, forming a simple pendulum. Initially, the pendulum string is vertical, and the ring is just inside a sector of a uniform magnetic field. The center of the sector is at the suspension point, with its edges just tangent to the ring. The magnetic field is perpendicular to the plane of the ring and directed inward, with a magnetic flux density of $B$. If the ring is given an initial horizontal velocity (perpendicular to the magnetic field) with a magnitude of $v$, what is the minimum initial velocity $v_{0}$ required for the pendulum string to reach the horizontal direction? The gravitational acceleration is $g$, the magnetic field is sufficiently strong, and the torque due to the Ampere force is much greater than the torque due to gravity when the ring moves within the magnetic field. The ring is a superconducting ring with a self-inductance coefficient $L$.
solutions: If the ring is a superconducting ring, when it moves in a magnetic field, due to the properties of the superconductor, the magnetic flux in the ring remains unchanged, i.e.:  $$ L I + B S = B \cdot \pi r^2 $$  Thus, the current in the ring is:  $$ \begin{array}{l}{I = \displaystyle\frac{B}{L}(\pi r^{2} - S)}\ = \displaystyle\frac{B}{L}\left\{r^{2}\arcsin\left[\frac{a(\theta_{0}-\theta)}{r}\right] - \sqrt{2r a\theta-a^{2}\theta^{2}} \cdot a(\theta_{0}-\theta)\right\}\end{array} $$  $$ \phi = \operatorname{arccos}\left[\frac{a(\theta_{0}-\theta)}{r}\right] $$  We have:  $$ \cos\phi = \frac{a(\theta_{0}-\theta)}{r}, \sin\phi = \sqrt{1-\cos^{2}\phi} = \sqrt{1-\frac{a^{2}(\theta_{0}-\theta)^{2}}{r^{2}}} $$  Thus:  $$ I = \frac{B}{L}(r^{2}\phi - r^{2}\sin\phi\cos\phi), l = 2r\sin\phi $$  The torque about the suspension point due to the Ampère force acting on the part of the ring within the magnetic field is approximately:  $$ \tau = I B l a = \frac{2B^{2}r a}{L}(r^{2}\phi - r^{2}\sin\phi\cos\phi)\sin\phi $$  The dynamic equation of the ring is:  $$ m a^{2}\frac{d\omega}{dt} = -\frac{2B^{2}r a}{L}(r^{2}\phi - r^{2}\sin\phi\cos\phi)\sin\phi $$  Since $\frac{d\omega}{dt} = \omega\frac{d\omega}{d\theta}$, we have:  $$ d\theta = \frac{r}{a} \sin (\phi) d\phi $$  Thus:  Integrating both sides, given that initially when $\theta = 0$, $\phi = 0$, and $\omega \approx \frac{v_{0}}{a}$, we have:  $$ m a^{2}\int_{\frac{v_{0}}{a}}^{\omega}\omega d\omega = -\frac{2B^{2}r^{4}}{L}\int_{0}^{\phi}\left(\phi - \sin\phi\cos\phi\right)\sin^{2}\phi d\phi $$  We obtain:  $$ \frac{1}{2}m a^{2}\left(\omega^{2}-\frac{v_{0}^{2}}{a^{2}}\right) = -\frac{B^{2}r^{4}}{2L}\left[\phi^{2} - \phi\sin2\phi - \frac{1}{2}(\cos2\phi - 1) - \sin^{4}\phi\right] $$  Thus:  $$ \omega^{2} = \frac{v_{0}^{2}}{a^{2}} - \frac{B^{2}r^{4}}{m a^{2}L}\left[\phi^{2} - \phi\sin2\phi - \frac{1}{2}(\cos2\phi - 1) - \sin^{4}\phi\right] $$  When the ring has just completely left the magnetic field area, $\theta = 2\theta_{0}$, corresponding to $\phi = \pi$, substituting into the above equation, we get:  $$ \omega_{2}^{2} = \frac{v_{0}^{2}}{a^{2}} - \frac{\pi^{2}B^{2}r^{4}}{m a^{2}L} $$  To make the pendulum reach the horizontal direction, it should satisfy:  $$ v_{0} = \sqrt{2g a + \frac{\pi^{2}B^{2}r^{4}}{m L}} $$
improved_solutions:
────────────────────────────────────────────
1. Problem Analysis  
────────────────────────────────────────────  
We have a simple pendulum (length α, bob mass m) whose bob is a thin superconducting ring of small radius r (r ≪ α).  
• At the lowest (vertical) position the ring sits just inside a sector of a uniform magnetic field B that is perpendicular to the ring.  
• The suspension point is at the centre of the field sector, so as soon as the pendulum starts to swing the ring very quickly leaves the field region (the edge of the sector is tangent to the ring).  
• Because the ring is superconducting, the magnetic flux threading it must remain constant. Hence a current is induced when the external flux changes.  
• The Ampère forces associated with that current are assumed to dominate gravity while the ring is still inside the field, so the gravitational work done over that small angular interval can be neglected.  

Question:  What minimum initial horizontal speed v₀ (applied at the lowest point) allows the string to rise to the horizontal position (θ = 90°)?  

────────────────────────────────────────────  
2. Approach (key physical ideas)  
────────────────────────────────────────────  
A. Flux conservation in a superconducting ring  
 Total flux Φ through the ring must stay equal to its initial value Φ₀ = Bπr².  
 When the ring has just left the field, the external flux Φext = 0, so L I = Φ₀ ⇒ I = Φ₀ / L.  
 Energy stored in the ring’s self-inductance is  
  Umag = ½ L I² = ½ (Φ₀² / L) = (B² π² r⁴) / (2L).  
 This energy comes at the expense of the ring’s mechanical energy while it is crossing the field boundary.  

B. Energy bookkeeping  
 Initial kinetic energy (½ m v₀²) must provide  
  1. The magnetic energy Umag created during exit from the field, and  
  2. The gravitational potential m g α gained when the bob rises from vertical to horizontal.  

 Hence ½ m v₀² = Umag + m g α.  

────────────────────────────────────────────  
3. Detailed Solution Steps  
────────────────────────────────────────────  
Step 1: Initial magnetic flux through the ring  
 Φ₀ = B · (area) = B · π r².  

Step 2: Induced current after the ring has completely left the field  
 Flux conservation (Lenz’s law in a super-conductor):  
  L I + Φext = Φ₀ .  
 Outside the field Φext = 0 ⇒ I = Φ₀ / L = (B π r²) / L.  

Step 3: Magnetic energy stored in the ring  
 Umag = ½ L I²  
    = ½ L (Φ₀ / L)²  
    = Φ₀² / (2L)  
    = (B² π² r⁴) / (2L).  

Step 4: Mechanical energy just after leaving the field  
 Let v_out be the speed immediately after the field is left.  
 Energy lost to magnetism: ½ m v₀² − ½ m v_out² = Umag.  
 Therefore ½ m v_out² = ½ m v₀² − Umag.  

Step 5: Condition for reaching the horizontal position  
 To swing up to θ = 90° the bob must climb a height Δh = α (length of the string), so  
  m g Δh = m g α = gravitational potential required.  
 Using energy conservation after the ring is out of the field:  
  ½ m v_out² = m g α.  

Step 6: Eliminate v_out and solve for v₀  
 From Steps 4 and 5:  
  ½ m v₀² − Umag = m g α  
  ⇒ ½ m v₀² = m g α + Umag  
  ⇒ v₀² = 2 g α + 2 Umag / m.  

 Insert Umag from Step 3:  
  v₀² = 2 g α + (B² π² r⁴) / (m L).  

 Hence the minimum initial speed is  

 v₀(min) = √[ 2 g α + (B² π² r⁴)/(m L) ].  

────────────────────────────────────────────  
4. Check of Assumptions  
────────────────────────────────────────────  
• The angle traversed inside the magnetic sector is of order θ_c ≈ r/α ≪ 1, so the change in gravitational potential while inside the field is ∼ m g α θ_c² /2 ≪ Umag (given “field is sufficiently strong”), justifying its neglect.  
• The statement “torque due to the Ampère force is much larger than the gravitational torque” confirms that ignoring gravity during the brief exit from the field is self-consistent.  

────────────────────────────────────────────  
### Final Answer  
\[
\boxed{\,v_{0,\text{min}} = \sqrt{\,2 g \alpha + \dfrac{B^{2}\pi^{2} r^{4}}{m L}\,}\;}
\]

questions: The martian atmosphere can be considered as composed only of very thin $CO_{2}$. The mass of Mars is $M_{m}$ (far greater than the total mass of the martian atmosphere), and its radius is $R_{m}$. Express the result using the following physical quantities: the mass of Mars $M_{m}$, radius $R_{m}$, molar mass of the atmosphere $\mu$, constant $n$, gravitational constant $G$, and ideal gas constant $R$.
solutions: (1) Basic Assumptions and Ideal Gas Law  In the atmosphere at a certain height \( h \) on Mars, a thin horizontally placed box-shaped region is defined. The volume of this region is \( V \), the mass of the atmosphere inside is \( M \), the pressure is \( P(h) \), and the temperature is \( T(h) \). Because the box is very thin, the density, pressure, and temperature of the gas can be considered constant.  According to the ideal gas law:  $$ P(h)V = n R T(h)  $$  The volume of the atmosphere inside the box is:  $$ V = \frac{M}{\rho(h)}  $$  The number of moles of the Mars atmosphere inside the box is:  $$ n = \frac{M}{\mu}  $$  By combining equations (1), (2), and (3), we get:  $$ T(h) = \frac{P(h) \mu}{\rho(h) R}  $$  (2) Determine the Pressure \( P(h) \)  Consider a thin spherical cap-shaped atmospheric layer from height \( x \) to \( x + dx \), subtending a solid angle \( \Delta \Omega \). Let \( \Delta \Omega \) be very small, so that the radial lines on the side of the spherical cap can be considered parallel to each other.  From the force analysis, we know:  $$ [P(x + dx) - P(x)] \cdot \Delta \Omega (R_m + x)^2 + \rho(x) g(x) \cdot \Delta \Omega (R_m + x)^2 dx = 0 $$  That is:  $$ \frac{dP}{dx} = - \rho(x) g(x)  $$  Where the gravitational acceleration from the surface of Mars to height \( x \) is:  $$ g(x) = \frac{G M_m}{(R_m + x)^2} $$  Substituting into equation (6) and integrating, we obtain:  $$ P(h) = G M_m \int_h^{\infty} \frac{\rho(x)}{(R_m + x)^2} dx  $$  (3) Substitute and Determine the Temperature Expression  Substitute equation (7′) into equation (4), and use the density distribution expression provided in the problem:  $$ \rho(x) = \rho_0 \left(1 + \frac{x}{R_m}\right)^{1 - n} $$  Finally, we get:  $$ T(h) = \frac{\mu G M_m}{n R (R_m + h)}  $$  Final Result (Temperature Distribution of Martian Atmosphere)  $$ \boxed{T(h) = \frac{\mu G M_m}{n R (R_m + h)}} $$  This result indicates that the temperature of Mars' atmosphere decreases inversely with height \( h \).

Problem Analysis  
We are told that the (very thin) martian atmosphere
• is made essentially of CO₂, so that its molar mass is μ,  
• behaves as an ideal gas in static equilibrium,  
• has a mass-density (mass per unit volume)

  α(h)=ρ₀ ( 1+ h/R_m )^{1−n},  n>4 (ρ₀ and n are constants)

at the geometrical height h measured from the martian surface.  
Mars has mass M_m and radius R_m (M_m ≫ total atmospheric mass).  
We must find the temperature T as a function of h, expressed only with the given physical constants G, M_m, R_m, μ, n and the ideal-gas constant R.

Approach  
1. Use hydrostatic equilibrium  

  dp/dh = –ρ(h) g(h),  g(h)=G M_m /(R_m + h)²,

where ρ(h)=α(h) is already given.  

2. Integrate the hydrostatic equation to obtain the pressure p(h).  

3. Relate p(h) to ρ(h) and T(h) through the ideal-gas law  

  p = ρ R T / μ,

and solve for T(h).  

4. Impose the physical requirement that T must not diverge at large heights; this yields the temperature profile uniquely.

Detailed Solution  

1. Hydrostatic equilibrium  
ρ(h)=ρ₀ (1+ h/R_m )^{1−n}.  
g(h)=G M_m /(R_m + h)².

Hence  

dp/dh = –ρ₀ (1+ h/R_m )^{1−n} · G M_m /(R_m + h)².  (1)

2. Convenient variable  
Introduce  

x ≡ 1+ h/R_m  ⇔ h = R_m (x−1),  dh = R_m dx,  R_m + h = R_m x.

With this, Eq.(1) becomes  

dp/dh = –ρ₀ G M_m /(R_m²) · x^{−1−n}.  

Using dh = R_m dx → dp/dx = (dp/dh) R_m,  

dp/dx = –(ρ₀ G M_m /R_m) x^{−1−n}.  (2)

3. Pressure as a function of height  
Integrate (2) from x = 1 (surface) to an arbitrary x:

∫_{p(1)=p₀}^{p(x)} dp = –(ρ₀ G M_m /R_m) ∫_{1}^{x} x^{′−1−n} dx′

⇒ p(x) = p₀ + ρ₀ G M_m /(n R_m) (x^{−n} − 1).  (3)

4. Ideal-gas relation  
p = ρ R T / μ  ⇒ T(h)= μ p(h) /[R ρ(h)].

Insert ρ(h)=ρ₀ x^{1−n} and expression (3):

T(x)= μ/R · [p₀ + ρ₀ G M_m /(n R_m) (x^{−n} − 1)] / [ρ₀ x^{1−n}]  
    = μ/R { [p₀/ρ₀] x^{n−1} + G M_m /(n R_m) [x^{−1} − x^{n−1}] }.  (4)

5. Eliminating the unknown surface pressure  
Because the atmosphere is “very thin”, density and pressure fall rapidly (n>4).  
For a physically acceptable atmosphere the temperature must remain finite as h→∞ (x→∞).  
In Eq.(4) the term proportional to x^{n−1} (with n>4) would diverge unless its coefficient vanishes:

p₀/ρ₀ – G M_m /(n R_m) = 0  
⇒ p₀ = ρ₀ G M_m /(n R_m).  (5)

With this condition Eq.(4) simplifies to

T(x)= μ/R · G M_m /(n R_m) · x^{−1}.  (6)

6. Re-express T in terms of h  
x = 1 + h/R_m, hence

T(h)= (μ G M_m)/(n R R_m) · ( 1 + h/R_m )^{−1}.  (7)

The factor μπG M_m /(n R R_m) is, in particular, the temperature at the martian surface (h=0).

### Final Answer
\[
\boxed{\, T(h)=\frac{\mu G M_m}{n R R_m}\left(1+\frac{h}{R_m}\right)^{-1} \,}
\]

questions:
In the ground frame S, two trains with an intrinsic length of $L_{0}$ are stationary along the $x$ axis, with the left side of train A located at $x=0$. The gap between the left side of train B and the right side of train A is $D$. At time $t=0$ in the ground frame S, both trains A and B synchronize their carriage times to $t_{A}=t_{B}=0$, and the clocks are located on the left side of each train. At this moment, the two trains start moving with constant accelerations relative to themselves, $a_{A}$ and $a_{B}$.

Let the distance between train carriages AB in frame S be $D(t)$. Express the value of $a_{B}$ when $D(t)\equiv D$ in terms of $L_{0}$, $a_{A}$, and the speed of light $c$.
solutions:
Since the left end of the train is aligned with the ground clock, the left end of the train can be regarded as a point mass, and thus we can study uniform accelerated motion.

Let the velocity of the left end at time $t$ in the ground frame be $v(t)$, at time $t+d t$, first perform a Lorentz transformation to the rest frame with velocity $v(t)$. In the rest frame, obtain an infinitesimal velocity $adτ$:

Using the proper time formula:

$$
v+dv={\frac{v+adτ}{1+{\frac{v\times adτ}{c^{2}}}}}\rightarrow dv=adτ\left(1-{\frac{v^{2}}{c^{2}}}\right)
$$

$$
dτ={\sqrt{1-{\frac{v^{2}}{c^{2}}}}}dt \to dv=a{\sqrt{1-{\frac{v^{2}}{c^{2}}}^{3}}}dt
$$ 

Separate variables on both sides, yielding:

$$
at=\int_{0}^{v}{\frac{dV}{1-{V}^{2}/{c}^{2}}}={\frac{v}{1-{v}^{2}/{c}^{2}}}
$$

Solving for the velocity function:

$$
v(t)={\frac{at}{\sqrt{1+\left({\frac{at}{c}}\right)^{2}}}}\to x(t)=x_{0}+\int_{0}^{t}v(t)dt=x_{0}+{\frac{c^{2}}{a}}\left({\sqrt{1+\left({\frac{at}{c}}\right)^{2}}}-1\right)
$$

Select special cases A, B to write the displacement function:

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}{\displaystyle x_{l A}=\frac{c^{2}}{a_{A}}\left(\sqrt{1+\left(\frac{a_{A}t}{c}\right)^{2}}-1\right)}\ {\displaystyle x_{l B}=L_{0}+D+\frac{c^{2}}{a_{B}}\left(\sqrt{1+\left(\frac{a_{B}t}{c}\right)^{2}}-1\right)}\end{array}\right.
$$

Using the motion on the left side, we can calculate the proper time:

$$
τ=\int_{0}^{t}{\sqrt{1-\left({\frac{v}{c}}\right)^{2}}}dt=\int_{0}^{t}{\frac{dt}{\sqrt{1+\left({\frac{at}{c}}\right)^{2}}}}={\frac{c}{a}}\mathrm{arcsinh}{\frac{at}{c}}
$$

Apply to special cases A, B:

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l l}{{\displaystyleτ_{A}=\frac{c}{a_{A}}\mathrm{arcsinh}\frac{a_{A}t}{c}}}\ {{\displaystyleτ_{B}=\frac{c}{a_{B}}\mathrm{arcsinh}\frac{a_{B}t}{c}}}\end{array}\right.
$$

Taking train A as an example, given the proper time $τ_{A}$, the speed of A at this time is:

$$
v_{A}(τ)={\frac{a_{A}t}{\sqrt{1+\left({\frac{a_{A}t}{c}}\right)^{2}}}}=c\operatorname{tanh}{\frac{a_{A}τ}{c}}
$$

The left side of the train system $(0,τ)$ and the ground frame $(x_{l A},t)$ are aligned, allowing for easy writing of the Lorentz transformation for the right end time and coordinates in the ground frame:

$$
t_{r,A}=t+{\frac{v_{A}L_{0}/c^{2}}{1-v_{A}^{2}/c^{2}}}=t+\cosh{\frac{a_{A}τ}{c}}\left({\frac{L_{0}}{c}}\operatorname{tanh}{\frac{a_{A}τ}{c}}\right)=t+{\frac{L_{0}}{c}}\sinh{\frac{a_{A}τ}{c}}=\left(1+{\frac{a_{A}L_{0}}{c^{2}}}\right)t
$$

$$
x_{r,A}=x_{l,A}+\frac{L_{0}}{1-v_{A}^{2}/c^{2}}=\left(\frac{c^{2}}{a_{A}}+L_{0}\right)\sqrt{1+\left(\frac{a_{A}t}{c}\right)^{2}}-\frac{c^{2}}{a_{A}}
$$

Since $x_{r,A}$ occurs at event S frame $t=t_{r,A}$, the correct $x_{r,A}(t)$ function should replace $t$:

$$
x_{r,A}={\frac{c^{2}}{{\frac{a_{A}}{1+{\frac{a_{A}L_{0}}{c^{2}}}}}}}{\sqrt{1+\left({\frac{a_{A}t/c}{1+{\frac{a_{A}L_{0}}{c^{2}}}}}\right)^{2}}}-{\frac{c^{2}}{a_{A}}
$$

At this moment, the distance between the right side of A and the left side of B is:

$$
=x_{l,B}-x_{r,A}=L_{0}+D+{\frac{c^{2}}{a_{B}}}\left(\sqrt{1+\left({\frac{a_{B}t}{c}}\right)^{2}}-1\right)+{\frac{c^{2}}{a_{A}}}-{\frac{c^{2}}{{\frac{a_{A}}{1+{\frac{a_{A}L_{0}}{c^{2}}}}}}}\sqrt{1+\left({\frac{a_{A}t/c}{1+{\frac{a_{A}L_{0}}{c^{2}}}}}\right)^{2}}
$$

If the distance is constant, then naturally:

$$
a_{B}={\frac{a_{A}}{1+{\frac{a_{A}L_{0}}{c^{2}}}}}
$$
