Solution Outline
================

1. Problem Analysis  
2. Physical Approach and Key Insights  
3. Detailed Solution  
   3.1  Hyperbolic (Rindler) motion of a point with constant proper acceleration  
   3.2  Born-rigid acceleration of a whole train  
   3.3  World-lines of the two relevant carriage ends  
   3.4  Condition for a permanently constant gap  
4. Result and discussion  

--------------------------------------------------------------------
1. Problem Analysis
-------------------
We have two identical, perfectly rigid (“Born-rigid”) trains of intrinsic
(proper) length \(L_{0}\).
•  Left end of train A is initially at \(x=0\).  
•  The right end of A therefore starts at \(x=L_{0}\).  
•  Left end of train B starts a further distance \(D\) to the right, i.e. at
\(x=L_{0}+D\).

At \(t=0\) (ground frame \(S\)) the trains start to move in the \(+x\)-direction.
The left end of A experiences a constant proper acceleration \(a_{A}\), the
left end of B a constant proper acceleration \(a_{B}\) that we want to find.
Requirement: during the whole motion the distance between the right end of A
and the left end of B,  

\(D(t)=x_{B,\,\text{left}}(t)-x_{A,\,\text{right}}(t)\),

must stay equal to its initial value \(D\).

--------------------------------------------------------------------
2. Approach and Key Insights
----------------------------
A point that starts from rest with constant proper acceleration \(a\) follows
a hyperbolic (“Rindler”) world-line.  
If a whole body (here, a train) is to remain Born-rigid while accelerating,
different points along it must have different proper accelerations.  In
Rindler coordinates \((\tau ,\xi )\) each world-line is labelled by a constant
value of \(\xi\); the proper acceleration at that \(\xi\) is

\(a(\xi)=\dfrac{c^{2}}{\xi}\).

Hence  
 • left end of train A (proper acceleration \(a_{A}\)) lies at  
   \(\xi_{A,L}=c^{2}/a_{A}\);  
 • right end of train A, being \(L_{0}\) further in the \(+x\)-direction,
   lies at \(\xi_{A,R}=\xi_{A,L}+L_{0}\) and therefore has  
   \(a_{A,R}=c^{2}/\xi_{A,R}\).

To keep the gap \(D\) in the inertial frame constant, the left end of train B
must follow exactly the same hyperbola as the right end of train A; that
forces the equality \(a_{B}=a_{A,R}\).

--------------------------------------------------------------------
3. Detailed Solution
--------------------

3.1  World-line of a uniformly accelerated point  
For a point that (i) is at rest at \(t=0\) at position \(x_{0}\) and
(ii) experiences constant proper acceleration \(a\), its inertial–frame motion is  

\(x(t)=x_{0}+\frac{c^{2}}{a}\,\Bigl[\sqrt{1+(a t/c)^{2}}-1\Bigr].\)            (1)

(The corresponding velocity obeys \(v(t)=at/\sqrt{1+(a t/c)^{2}}\).)

3.2  Proper acceleration distribution inside one train  
Label positions in the train by a Rindler coordinate \(\xi\).  A point fixed
at \(\xi\) has proper acceleration  

\(a(\xi)=\dfrac{c^{2}}{\xi}.\)                                        (2)

If the left end of train A has \(\xi_{A,L}=c^{2}/a_{A}\), then the right end
is \(L_{0}\) further ahead,

\(\xi_{A,R}=\xi_{A,L}+L_{0}= \frac{c^{2}}{a_{A}}+L_{0}.\)

Hence the right end’s proper acceleration is  

\(a_{A,R}= \frac{c^{2}}{\xi_{A,R}}
         = \frac{c^{2}}
                {\,\dfrac{c^{2}}{a_{A}}+L_{0}}
         = \frac{a_{A}}
                {1+ a_{A}L_{0}/c^{2}}.\)                            (3)

3.3  World-lines of the two relevant points  

Right end of A (proper acceleration \(a_{A,R}\)), starting from \(x_{0}=L_{0}\):  

\(x_{A,R}(t)=L_{0}+ \frac{c^{2}}{a_{A,R}}
             \Bigl[\sqrt{1+(a_{A,R} t/c)^{2}}-1\Bigr].\)            (4)

Left end of B (proper acceleration \(a_{B}\)), starting from
\(x_{0}=L_{0}+D\):  

\(x_{B,L}(t)=L_{0}+D+ \frac{c^{2}}{a_{B}}
             \Bigl[\sqrt{1+(a_{B} t/c)^{2}}-1\Bigr].\)              (5)

3.4  Condition for a constant gap  

Demand \(x_{B,L}(t)-x_{A,R}(t)=D\) for every \(t\).  Substituting (4) and (5)
and cancelling the explicit \(D\) one finds

\(\frac{1}{a_{B}}\Bigl[\sqrt{1+(a_{B} t/c)^{2}}-1\Bigr]
 =\frac{1}{a_{A,R}}\Bigl[\sqrt{1+(a_{A,R} t/c)^{2}}-1\Bigr].\)     (6)

The function \(f_{a}(t)=\dfrac{1}{a}\bigl[\sqrt{1+(a t/c)^{2}}-1\bigr]\)
is unique for each parameter \(a\); equality (6) for *all* times is therefore
possible only if the parameters themselves are equal:

\(a_{B}=a_{A,R}.\)                                                  (7)

Finally insert (3):

\(a_{B}= \frac{a_{A}}
              {1+a_{A}L_{0}/c^{2}}.\)                              (8)

--------------------------------------------------------------------
4. Result and Discussion
------------------------
•  The constant proper acceleration that the *left* end of train B must have
   so that the gap \(D(t)\) seen in the ground frame stays equal to its
   initial value \(D\) is completely determined by the acceleration applied
   to the *left* end of train A and by the proper length \(L_{0}\) of the
   trains; the numerical value of the gap itself does **not** enter.  

•  In the non-relativistic limit \(a_{A}L_{0}\ll c^{2}\) one gets
  \(a_{B}\simeq a_{A}\bigl(1-a_{A}L_{0}/c^{2}\bigr)\), i.e. the two
  accelerations are almost equal.  For extremely large \(a_{A}L_{0}\) the
  required \(a_{B}\) becomes much smaller than \(a_{A}\).

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### Final Answer
\[
\boxed{\, a_{B}= \dfrac{a_{A}}{1+\dfrac{a_{A} L_{0}}{c^{2}}}\,}
\]

questions: Two smooth cylinders, each with a radius of $r_{1}$ but with weights $P_{1}$ and $P_{2}$ respectively, are placed in a smooth cylindrical groove with a radius of $R$. Find the tangent value of the angle $\varphi$ when the two cylinders are in equilibrium. The angle $\varphi$ is defined as the angle between the line connecting the center of the higher cylinder and the center of the cylindrical groove, and the horizontal line. Assume $\cos\beta = \frac{r}{R - r}$. Express the result in terms of $\beta$.
solutions:
Under the action of these forces, cylinders 1 and 2 reach equilibrium. Triangle \( O O_{1}O_{2} \) is an isosceles triangle. Let \(\beta=\angle O O_{1}O_{2},\) then  

\[ 
\cos \beta = \frac{r}{R-r}.
\]

For cylinder 1, the condition for force equilibrium is  

\[ 
\begin{array}{r l}
&{P_{1}+f\sin(\beta-\varphi)-N_{1}\sin(2\beta-\varphi)=0,}\\
&{f\cos(\beta-\varphi)-N_{1}\cos(2\beta-\varphi)=0.}
\end{array}
\]

By eliminating \( N_{1} \) from the two equations in expression (2), we obtain  

\[ 
P_{1}\cos(2\beta-\varphi)-f\sin\beta=0.
\]

Eliminating \( f \), we obtain  

\[ 
P_{1}\cos(\beta-\varphi)-N_{1}\sin\beta=0.
\]

For cylinder 2, at equilibrium we have  

\[ 
\begin{array}{r l}
&{P_{2}-f\sin(\beta-\varphi)-N_{2}\sin\varphi=0,}\\
&{f\cos(\beta-\varphi)-N_{2}\cos\varphi=0.}
\end{array}
\]

By eliminating \( N_{2} \) from the two equations in expression (5), we obtain  

\[ 
P_{2}\cos\varphi-f\sin\beta=0.
\]

Eliminating \( f \), we obtain  

\[ 
P_{2}\cos(\beta-\varphi)-N_{2}\sin\beta=0.
\]

By eliminating \( f \) from equations (3) and (6), we obtain  

\[ 
\tan\varphi = \frac{P_{2}-P_{1}\cos(2\beta)}{P_{1}\sin(2\beta)}.
\]

This is the relationship that \(\varphi\) satisfies when the system is at equilibrium.
improved_solutions:
### 1.  Problem Analysis  
Two identical smooth cylinders (radius $r$, weights $P_{1}$ and $P_{2}$) are in a smooth circular groove of radius $R\;(>\!2r)$.  
O  –– centre of the groove (circle of radius $R$)  
A  –– centre of the lower small cylinder  
B  –– centre of the upper small cylinder  

Because every contact is perfectly smooth, every reaction acts along the line that joins the two centres in contact.  
β is the geometrical angle in the isosceles triangle OAB (proved below)
     $\displaystyle\cos \beta=\frac{r}{\,R-r\,}$ .  

φ is the mechanical angle required: the angle between OB and the horizontal through O.  
The task is to find $\tan\varphi$ in terms of β (and the given weights).

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 2.  General Approach  
1.  Use geometry of the three centres O, A, B to identify all useful angles.  
2.  Treat the two cylinders together as one rigid system.  
    •  The only external forces are the two weights $P_{1},P_{2}$ (vertical)  
       and the two radial reactions $R_{AO},R_{BO}$ acting along OA and OB.  
    •  Taking moments about O eliminates **both** unknown radial reactions.  
3.  The moment (torque) equation about O gives one scalar relation that contains φ, β, $P_{1}$ and $P_{2}$.  
4.  Simple trig manipulation of that relation produces the required $\tan\varphi$.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 3.  Detailed Solution  

3.1 Pure geometry of the three centres  
Triangle OAB is isosceles with  
  OA = OB = R–r ,  AB = 2r.  
At A (and identically at B)

\[
\cos\beta=\frac{OA^{2}+AB^{2}-OB^{2}}{2\,(OA)(AB)}
          =\frac{(R-r)^{2}+ (2r)^{2}-(R-r)^{2}}
                 {2(R-r)(2r)}
          =\frac{r}{R-r},
\]
so β is indeed the angle between the radial line and the common normal AB:

  ∠(OA, AB) = ∠(OB, AB) = β.                     (1)

The angle at O is therefore

\[
\angle AOB= \pi-2\beta.                            (2)
\]

Consequently, when OB makes an angle φ with the horizontal, OA makes the angle  

\[
\theta_{OA}= \varphi-\bigl(\pi-2\beta\bigr).       (3)
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
3.2 External forces on the **combined** system  
External forces   
 • Weight \(P_{2}\) acting at B vertically downward  
 • Weight \(P_{1}\) acting at A vertically downward  
 • Reaction \(R_{BO}\) along OB  
 • Reaction \(R_{AO}\) along OA  

Because \(R_{BO}\) and \(R_{AO}\) both pass through O, **they exert no moment about O**.  
Hence the sum of the moments of the two weights about O must be zero for equilibrium.

Take moments about O, positive for a counter-clockwise couple.  
With the usual right–hand convention the z–component of \(\mathbf r\times\mathbf P\) produced by a vertical downward weight is simply  
  moment = (horizontal lever arm) × (weight).

Horizontal lever arms  
\[
OB_{x}=(R-r)\cos\varphi, \qquad
OA_{x}=(R-r)\cos\theta_{OA}.
\]

Moment equilibrium gives  
\[
P_{2}(R-r)\cos\varphi \;+\;P_{1}(R-r)\cos\theta_{OA}=0.
\]

Cancel the common factor \(R-r\) and substitute (3):

\[
P_{2}\cos\varphi
     +P_{1}\cos\!\Bigl[\varphi-\bigl(\pi-2\beta\bigr)\Bigr]=0,
\]
\[
\boxed{\,P_{2}\cos\varphi
        =P_{1}\cos(\varphi+2\beta)\,}.             (4)
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
3.3 Extracting \(\tan\varphi\) from (4)  

Expand the cosine in (4):

\[
P_{2}\cos\varphi
   =P_{1}\bigl(\cos\varphi\cos2\beta-\sin\varphi\sin2\beta\bigr).
\]

Collect terms:

\[
(P_{2}-P_{1}\cos2\beta)\cos\varphi
      +P_{1}\sin2\beta\,\sin\varphi=0.
\]

Divide by \(\cos\varphi\) (valid because \(\cos\varphi\neq0\) in the present configuration):

\[
(P_{2}-P_{1}\cos2\beta)+P_{1}\sin2\beta\,\tan\varphi=0,
\]

\[
\tan\varphi=\frac{P_{1}\cos2\beta-P_{2}}{P_{1}\sin2\beta}.     (5)
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
3.4 Alternative appearance (weight ratio)  
If \(k=P_{2}/P_{1}\),

\[
\tan\varphi=\frac{\cos2\beta-k}{\sin2\beta}.     (5′)
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
3.5 Check: equal weights \(P_{1}=P_{2}\)  
Then  

\[
\tan\varphi
  =\frac{\cos2\beta-1}{\sin2\beta}
  =\frac{-2\sin^{2}\beta}{2\sin\beta\cos\beta}
  =-\tan\beta,
\]

so \(\varphi=-\beta\).  The upper cylinder is still higher than the lower one because  
\(|\varphi|<|\varphi+\!2\beta|\); the sign is simply determined by the direction in which OB is measured.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 4.  Result  

For two smooth cylinders of equal radius $r$ and weights \(P_{1},P_{2}\) resting in a smooth cylindrical groove of radius $R$, with  

  \(\displaystyle\cos\beta=\dfrac{r}{R-r},\)

the angle ϕ between OB and the horizontal that satisfies equilibrium is

\[
\boxed{\displaystyle
\tan\varphi=\frac{P_{1}\cos2\beta-P_{2}}{P_{1}\sin2\beta}}
\qquad
\Bigl(\;=\;\dfrac{\cos2\beta-\dfrac{P_{2}}{P_{1}}}{\sin2\beta}\Bigr).
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
The formula involves only the known loads \(P_{1},P_{2}\) and the purely geometric angle β fixed by the radii \(r,R\); it completely determines the equilibrium orientation of the upper cylinder.

questions: Two thin rods, each with mass $m$ and length $l$, are centrally connected by a thin string (with negligible mass). The upper ends are also connected by a very short flexible string (with negligible length). The other end of each rod is free to slide across a horizontal table without friction. The plane formed by the rods and strings is perpendicular to the tabletop, with gravitational acceleration $g$. Initially, the rods are stationary, forming an angle $\theta_{0}$ with the tabletop. When the thin string at the center is cut, the rods fall vertically until they hit the table. What is the velocity $v$ of the rods just before the ends connected at the table touch the tabletop?
solutions:
Solution: Using the conservation of energy:
Initial mechanical energy: $\frac{1}{2}mgl\sin\theta_{0}$ 
Mechanical energy while in motion (angular velocity is $\dot{\theta}$): translational kinetic energy $^{+}$ rotational kinetic energy $^+$ gravitational potential energy:
$$
{\frac{1}{2}}m{\dot{\theta}}^{2}{\frac{l^{2}}{4}}+{\frac{1}{2}}{\frac{1}{12}}m l^{2}{\dot{\theta}}^{2}+{\frac{1}{2}}m g l \sin\theta={\frac{1}{6}}m l^{2}{\dot{\theta}}^{2}+{\frac{1}{2}}m g l \sin\theta
$$
We obtain the angular velocity $\dot{\theta}: \dot{\theta} = \sqrt{3g/l(\sin\theta_{0} - \sin\theta)}$. The terminal velocity is: $v=-\sqrt{3gl\sin\theta_{0}}$
improved_solutions:
Problem Analysis  
The two identical uniform rods (mass m, length l) initially make an angle θ₀ with the horizontal table and are held together at their centres by a light string.  After this central string is cut, each rod is free to rotate and slide (without friction) in a vertical plane until its lower end reaches the tabletop (θ → 0).  We are asked to find the linear speed v of either lower end just before it touches the table.

Approach  
1. Treat each rod as a rigid body with one generalized coordinate θ(t) = angle between the rod and the table.  
2. Use conservation of mechanical energy: the loss of gravitational potential energy of the two rods equals their total kinetic energy (translational + rotational) at θ = 0.  
3. Relate the angular speed θ̇ at θ = 0 to the desired linear speed v of the lower tip via v = l θ̇.  
4. Verify each step by decomposing the kinetic energy and confirming that no external forces do work (table is frictionless, the remaining string only transmits tension perpendicular to motion).

Solution Steps  

1. Geometry and Generalized Coordinate  
   • At any instant a rod makes an angle θ with the table; its centre of mass (CM) is midway along the rod, so its height above the table is  
     h(θ) = (l/2) sin θ.  
   • Initially θ = θ₀, finally θ = 0 when the lower tip contacts the table.

2. Potential-Energy Change  
   For one rod:  
      ΔU = m g [h(0) – h(θ₀)] = –m g (l/2) sin θ₀  
   (negative because the CM descends).  
   For both rods:  
      ΔU_total = –m g l sin θ₀.  
   The magnitude |ΔU_total| = m g l sin θ₀ is converted into kinetic energy.

3. Kinetic Energy at θ = 0  
   At the instant just before impact each rod has:  
   • Translational KE of its CM  
        T_trans = ½ m v_CM²,     with v_CM = (l/2) θ̇  
   • Rotational KE about its CM  
        T_rot = ½ I_CM θ̇²,       where I_CM (uniform rod) = ⅟₁₂ m l².  

   For one rod  
     T = ½ m (l/2)² θ̇² + ½ (1/12 m l²) θ̇²  
       = (1/8 + 1/24) m l² θ̇²  
       = (1/6) m l² θ̇².  

   For the two rods  
     T_total = 2 × (1/6) m l² θ̇² = (1/3) m l² θ̇².

4. Energy Conservation  
   |ΔU_total| = T_total  
            m g l sin θ₀ = (1/3) m l² θ̇²  
   ⇒ θ̇² = 3 g sin θ₀ / l  
   ⇒ θ̇ = √(3 g/l · sin θ₀).

5. Linear Speed of the Lower End  
   The lower tip of a rod is a distance l from the pivot at the table, so  
      v = l θ̇ = l √(3 g / l · sin θ₀)  
        = √(3 g l sin θ₀).

Thus the speed of either rod’s lower end just before it hits the table depends only on g, l, and the initial angle θ₀.

### Final Answer
\[
\boxed{\, v = \sqrt{3 g l \sin \theta_{0}} \,}
\]

questions:
An arbitrary multi-terminal resistor network structure, for example with $N+1$ terminals, sets one specific terminal (0 terminal) as the reference for electric potential, setting its potential at 0. The potentials for other terminals (numbered 1, 2, ..., N) are $v_{1}, v_{2}, \ldots, v_{N}$, and the current flowing into the network through these corresponding terminals (negative when flowing out) are $I_{1}, I_2, \ldots, I_n$. Therefore, we have:

$$
\left\{
\begin{array}{l}
V_{1} = a_{11} I_{1} + a_{12} I_{2} + \cdots + a_{1N} I_{N} \\
V_{2} = a_{21} I_{1} + a_{22} I_{2} + \cdots + a_{2N} I_{N} \\
\vdots \\
V_{i} = a_{i1} I_{1} + a_{i2} I_{2} + \cdots + a_{iN} I_{N} \\
\vdots \\
V_{N} = a_{N1} I_{1} + a_{N2} I_{2} + \cdots + a_{NN} I_{N} 
\end{array}
\right.
$$

Due to symmetry, we know that $a_{ij} = a_{ji}$.

This means that the properties of the $N+1$ terminal network can be determined by $\frac{N(N+1)}{2}$ independent parameters: $a_{11}, a_{12}, \ldots , a_{ij}, \ldots , a_{NN} (i<j)$. These parameters are only determined by the resistor network itself and are unrelated to the potential at the terminals or the magnitude of the current flowing in.

Consider a square uniform conductive thin plate as a four-terminal resistor network. The four vertices are sequentially numbered clockwise as 0, 1, 2, 3. If the equivalent resistance between adjacent vertices is ${R}_{1}$ and the equivalent resistance between opposite vertices is ${{R}}_{2}$, use the method of finding the coefficients $a_{i j} (i,j=1,2,3)$ to solve: what is the equivalent resistance between the other two vertices if a pair of adjacent vertices is short-circuited?
solutions:
For this situation, label the 4 endpoints sequentially as 0, 1, 2, 3. If current flows into endpoint 1 with current I (flowing out from endpoint 0), then:   

$$
V_{1}=a_{11}I=I R_{1}
$$  

Thus, we obtain: $a_{11}=R_{1}$  

Similarly, if current flows into endpoints 2 or 3 with current I, we can respectively obtain: $a_{22}=R_{2}$ $a_{33}=R_{1}$. If current flows into endpoint 1 with current I and flows out from endpoint 2:  

$$
V_{1}^{\prime}=a_{11}I-a_{12}I,V_{2}^{\prime}=a_{21}I-a_{22}I
$$  

At this moment, the potential difference between endpoints 1 and 2 is:  

$$
V_{1}^{\prime}-V_{2}^{\prime}=(a_{11}-2a_{12}+a_{22})I
$$  

Due to symmetry, at this moment, the potential difference between endpoints 1 and 2 should be equal to the potential at endpoint 1 (between 1 and 0) when current flows only into endpoint 1 (out from endpoint 0), thus:  

$$
(a_{11}-2a_{12}+a_{22})I=a_{11}I
$$  

We obtain:  

$$
a_{12}=\frac{1}{2}a_{22}=\frac{1}{2}R_{2}
$$  

[This can also be directly obtained by the condition of current input into endpoint 2, where the potential at endpoint 1 is half of that at endpoint 2 due to symmetry.] Similarly, we obtain:  

$$
a_{23}=\frac{1}{2}R_{2}
$$  

Returning again to the situation with current flowing only into endpoint 1 (flowing out from endpoint 0), at this moment, the potentials at endpoints 2 and 3 are respectively:  

$$
V_{2}=a_{21}I,V_{3}=a_{31}I
$$  

Due to symmetry, the potential difference between endpoints 1 and 2 should be equal to the potential difference between endpoints 3 and 0, thus:  

$$
V_{1}-V_{2}=V_{3}
$$  

Therefore:  

$$
a_{11}I-a_{21}I=a_{31}I
$$  

We obtain:  

$$
a_{13}=a_{31}=a_{11}-a_{12}=R_{1}-{\frac{1}{2}}R_{2}
$$  

Now returning to the required situation of the problem, without loss of generality, we can assume endpoints 3 and 0 are short-circuited and calculate the equivalent resistance between endpoints 1 and 2. In this case, if current flows into endpoint 1 with current I and out from endpoint 2, since endpoints 3 and 0 are short-circuited, there must be current flowing from 0 through the short-circuit wire into endpoint 3. Let the current flowing through the short-circuit wire be $I^{\prime}$, then it can be considered as the original four-terminal situation with current flowing into endpoint 1, out from endpoint 2, and into endpoint 3 with $I^{\prime}$. At this moment, the potential at endpoint 3 is:  

$$
V_{3}=a_{31}I-a_{32}I+a_{33}I^{\prime}
$$  

Because 3 and 0 are practically short-circuited, $V_{3}$ should be 0. Thus we can compute:  

$$
I^{\prime}=\frac{a_{32}-a_{31}}{a_{33}}I=\frac{R_{2}-R_{1}}{R_{1}}I
$$  

We can then compute the potentials at endpoints 1 and 2:  

The potential difference between endpoints 1 and 2:  

$$
\begin{array}{c}{{V_{1}=a_{11}I-a_{12}I+a_{13}I^{\prime}=(R_{1}-\displaystyle{\frac{1}{2}}R_{2})\displaystyle{\frac{R_{2}}{R_{1}}}I}}\ {{V_{2}=a_{21}I-a_{22}I+a_{23}I^{\prime}=\displaystyle{\frac{R_{2}}{2}}\displaystyle{\frac{R_{2}-2R_{1}}{R_{1}}}I}}\end{array}
$$  

$$
V_{1}-V_{2}=\frac{(2R_{1}-R_{2})R_{2}}{2R_{1}}I
$$  

Thus, the equivalent resistance between endpoints 1 and 2 is:  

$$
R={\frac{V_{1}-V_{2}}{I}}={\frac{(2R_{1}-R_{2})R_{2}}{2R_{1}}}=(2-{\frac{R_{2}}{R_{1}}})R_{2}
$$
improved_solutions:
### 1. Problem Analysis  
A thin, perfectly uniform square plate has four terminals at its corners, indexed clockwise as  
0 (reference), 1, 2, 3.  
For the intact plate two equivalent resistances are known:  
• R₁ – between any two adjacent corners (e.g. 0-1, 1-2, …)  
• R₂ – between the two opposite corners (e.g. 1-3, 0-2)  

After **hard–shorting an adjacent pair of terminals**, the problem asks for the equivalent resistance measured between the remaining two terminals.  
(Thanks to the square symmetry the numerical answer is independent of which specific pair is shorted.)

-------------------------------------------------------------------
### 2. Approach (overview)  
1.  Describe the four-terminal plate with its **reciprocal impedance matrix**
   V = A I,  
   where  
   A ≡ [aᵢⱼ] (i,j = 1,2,3) and Vᵢ, Iᵢ are the node voltages and currents with terminal 0 kept at 0 V.  
2.  Exploit the C₄ symmetry of the square.  Only two independent coefficients survive:  
 a₁₁ = a₂₂ = a₃₃ ≡ A , a₁₂ = a₂₃ = a₃₁ ≡ B , aᵢⱼ = aⱼᵢ.  
3.  Express the two *known* resistances R₁ and R₂ in terms of A and B, then solve for A and B.  
4.  Impose the new boundary conditions “terminals 1 and 2 shorted, measure between 0 and 3” and compute the sought equivalent resistance R_s in terms of A (and hence in terms of R₁, R₂).

-------------------------------------------------------------------
### 3. Detailed Solution  

3.1  Compact form of the impedance relations  
For currents I₁, I₂, I₃ injected into terminals 1, 2, 3 (with I₀ = –(I₁+I₂+I₃) through the reference terminal 0) the node voltages are  

(1) V₁ = A I₁ + B I₂ + B I₃  
   V₂ = B I₁ + A I₂ + B I₃  
   V₃ = B I₁ + B I₂ + A I₃

-------------------------------------------------------------------
3.2  Relation supplied by the **adjacent-corner resistance R₁**  
Definition experiment: current I enters node 1 and leaves node 0 while **nodes 1 and 2 are hard shorted** (V₁ = V₂).  
Currents: I₁ = +I , I₃ = 0 , I₂ ≡ I_s is not prescribed.  

Voltage equality V₁ = V₂ with (1) gives  
 A I + B I_s = B I + A I_s  
⇒ (A – B)(I – I_s) = 0 ⇒ I_s = I (because A ≠ B in general).  

The common node voltage is therefore  
 V₁ = (A + B) I.  

Hence  

(2) R₁ = V₁ / I = A + B.

-------------------------------------------------------------------
3.3  Relation supplied by the **opposite-corner resistance R₂**  
Definition experiment: current I enters node 1 and leaves node 3, all other terminals open.  
Currents: I₁ = +I , I₃ = –I , I₂ = 0.  

Using (1)  

V₁ = (A – B) I,  V₃ = –(A – B) I.  

So the voltage difference between the two active nodes is  
V₁ – V₃ = 2(A – B) I  

and by definition  

(3) R₂ = (V₁ – V₃)/I = 2 (A – B).

-------------------------------------------------------------------
3.4  Solving for the matrix coefficients  
Add / subtract (2) and (3):

A + B = R₁  
A – B = R₂ / 2

⇒ A = (R₁ + R₂/2)/2 = (2R₁ + R₂)/4  
  B = (R₁ – R₂/2)/2 = (2R₁ – R₂)/4.

-------------------------------------------------------------------
3.5  Desired configuration: **short 1–2, measure between 0 and 3**  
Boundary conditions  
• nodes 1 and 2 shorted: V₁ = V₂ ≡ V_s  
• no external current into that shorted pair ⇒ I₁ + I₂ = 0  
• measurement: current I enters node 3, leaves node 0: I₃ = I.  

Let I₁ = +I_s , I₂ = –I_s.  Insert in (1):

V₁ = (A – B) I_s + B I  
V₂ = –(A – B) I_s + B I.

Voltage equality V₁ = V₂ ⇒ 2(A – B) I_s = 0 ⇒ I_s = 0.  
Therefore no current actually flows into nodes 1 or 2:

I₁ = I₂ = 0, I₃ = I.

From (1) the potential of node 3 becomes  

V₃ = A I.  

Since terminal 0 is at 0 V, the equivalent resistance seen between terminals 0 and 3 under the prescribed short is  

R_s = V₃ / I = A.

Finally substitute the value of A found in 3.4:

R_s = (2R₁ + R₂) / 4.

-------------------------------------------------------------------
### 4. Result  
When any pair of adjacent corners of the square plate is short-circuited, the equivalent resistance measured between the remaining two corners is  

R_short-adjacent = (2 R₁ + R₂) ⁄ 4.

### Final Answer
\[
\boxed{\,R_{\text{eq}} = \dfrac{2R_{1}+R_{2}}{4}\,}
\]

questions: Consider a semi-infinite solenoid with radius $R$, turns per unit length $n$, connected to a constant current source with current $I$. To facilitate subsequent calculations, we establish a cylindrical coordinate system such that the $z$-axis coincides with the symmetry axis of the solenoid. The solenoid extends from the origin along the negative $z$-axis to infinity, and the current is viewed as rotating counterclockwise when observed from above the $z$-axis, meaning the direction of the current is in the positive $\hat{\theta}$ direction. Now, a superconducting metal ring is placed such that some constraint keeps the symmetry axis of the current loop always coinciding with the $z$-axis, allowing it to move freely up and down in this state. It is known that at the instant the metal ring transitions from normal to superconducting state, a current $I_{0}$ flows within the ring, and there is no other external magnetic field at a sufficiently far distance from the solenoid. $I_{0}$ flows in the positive $\hat{\theta}$ direction. Subsequently, the metal ring remains in the superconducting state. Assume the gravitational acceleration is $\overrightarrow{g}=-g\widehat{z}$, the mass of the metal ring is $m$, and it is of uniform density. Let $z_{0}>0$ be known. If the equilibrium is stable, find the vibration period $T$ near the equilibrium position (expressed in terms of $n$, $I_{0}$, $r$, $R$, $L$, $m$), and the answer may include $z_{0}$. It is known that the radius of the metal ring is $r \ll R$, and the self-inductance is $L$.
solutions:
The equilibrium condition is

$$
F(z)=m g
$$

$$
\frac{\pi}{2}\mu_{0}n I R^{2}r^{2}\frac{1}{(z^{2}+R^{2})^{3/2}}(\frac{\mu_{0}n I\pi r^{2}}{2L}(1-\frac{z}{\sqrt{z^{2}+R^{2}}})-I_{0})=m g
$$

Consider the stability of the equilibrium. If $\frac{d F}{d z}$ is negative, then the equilibrium is stable; otherwise, it is unstable.

$$
\left.{\frac{d F}{d z}}\right|_{z_{0}}={\frac{\pi}{2}}\mu_{0}n I R^{2}r^{2}\cdot[({\frac{\mu_{0}n I\pi r^{2}}{2L}}-I_{0}){\frac{-3z_{0}}{(z_{0}^{2}+R^{2})^{5/2}}}+{\frac{\mu_{0}n I\pi r^{2}}{2L}}{\frac{3z_{0}^{2}-R^{2}}{(z_{0}^{2}+R^{2})^{3}}}]
$$

Therefore, the requirement for stability is

$$
\frac{3z_{0}^{2}-R^{2}}{3z_{0}\sqrt{z_{0}^{2}+R^{2}}}<1-\frac{2I_{0}L}{\mu_{0}n I\pi r^{2}}
$$

If the equilibrium is stable, then

$$
T=2\pi\sqrt{\frac{m}{\left.\displaystyle-\frac{d F}{d z}\right|_{z_{0}}}}
$$

$$
T=2\pi\sqrt{\frac{m}{\frac{\pi}{2}\mu_{0}n I R^{2}r^{2}\cdot[(\frac{\mu_{0}n I\pi r^{2}}{2L}-I_{0})\frac{3z_{0}}{(z_{0}^{2}+R^{2})^{5/2}}-\frac{\mu_{0}n I\pi r^{2}}{2L}\frac{3z_{0}^{2}-R^{2}}{(z_{0}^{2}+R^{2})^{3}}]}}
$$
improved_solutions:
Solution Outline  

1. Problem Analysis  
   •  A light, rigid superconducting ring (radius r≪R, mass m) is coaxially above the open end ( z>0 ) of a semi-infinite solenoid (radius R, turn density n, steady current I).  
   •  While the ring was normal–conducting it carried no persistent current.  At the moment it turns superconducting a current I₀ (counter-clockwise, i.e. + θ̂) is frozen in.  
   •  From that instant on the total magnetic flux through the ring,  
              Φ(z)=B(z) πr²+L I_ring(z) ,  
     is conserved.  
   •  The ring can move only along the z–axis.  Its weight mg acts downward (– ẑ); an axial magnetic force produced by the solenoid field acts upward.  If these two forces balance at some height z=z₀>0 and the equilibrium is stable, small vertical oscillations will occur.  We must find their period T in terms of the given quantities n, I₀, r, R, L, m (the result may also contain z₀).  

2. Approach  
   Step A – Obtain the on-axis field B(z) of the semi-infinite solenoid, together with its derivatives B′(z), B″(z).  
   Step B – Express the ring current I_ring(z) from fluxoid conservation and hence its magnetic dipole moment  
                 μ(z)=πr² I_ring(z).  
   Step C – Magnetic force on a small dipole on the axis:   
                 F_m(z)=μ(z) B′(z).  
   Step D – Write Newton’s 2nd law m ẍ=F_m(z)–mg, locate the equilibrium (z=z₀), expand to first order in the displacement ξ≡z–z₀, obtain an effective spring constant k, and finally write the period  
                 T=2π√(m/k).  
   A key insight (Step E) is that the equilibrium condition mg=μ₀(z₀)B′(z₀) allows the solenoid current I to be eliminated; in the end the period depends only on m, g, I₀, L, R and z₀—the turn density n and the solenoid current cancel out.

3. Solution Details  

A.  Field of a semi-infinite solenoid on its axis (outside the open end, z>0)  
       B(z)=−(μ₀ n I /2) f(z), where f(z)=1−z/√(z²+R²).             (1)  
   (The minus sign indicates that the field points toward – ẑ.)  
   Derivatives needed later:  
       f′(z)=−R²/(z²+R²)^{3/2}              (2a)  
       f″(z)= 3zR²/(z²+R²)^{5/2}.             (2b)  
   Hence  
       B′(z)=−(μ₀ n I /2) f′(z)= +(μ₀ n I R²)/(2 (z²+R²)^{3/2}),          (3a)  
       B″(z)=−(μ₀ n I /2) f″(z)= −3(μ₀ n I R²) z /(2 (z²+R²)^{5/2}).       (3b)  

B.  Fluxoid conservation  
   Let A≡πr² (ring area).  The conserved total flux is  
         Φ_tot = A B(z)+L I_ring(z)=A B(z₀)+L I₀.                    (4)  
   Therefore  
         I_ring(z)=I₀ + (A/L)[B(z₀)−B(z)].                          (5)  
   Magnetic moment of the ring (along + ẑ):  
         μ(z)=A I_ring(z)=A I₀ + (A²/L)[B(z₀)−B(z)].                (6)  

C.  Magnetic force on the ring  
         F_m(z)=μ(z) B′(z).                                        (7)  

D.  Equation of motion and small-oscillation constant  

   i)  Equilibrium at z=z₀: set ẍ=0 in  
            m ẍ = F_m(z) − m g ,                                  (8)  
       giving   
            μ(z₀) B′(z₀) = m g.                                    (9)  

   ii)  Expand F_m(z) to first order:  
            F_m(z) ≈ F_m(z₀) + F′_m(z₀) ξ , ξ=z−z₀.               (10)  
       Because F_m(z₀)=mg, the linearised equation becomes  
            m ξ̈ + k ξ =0 , with k = −F′_m(z₀).                    (11)  

   iii)  Differentiate (7):  
            F′_m = μ′(z) B′(z) + μ(z) B″(z).                      (12)  
       From (6) μ′(z)=−(A²/L) B′(z).  

       Hence at z₀, using (9), (3) and (12),  
            k = (A²/L) [B′(z₀)]² − μ(z₀) B″(z₀).                 (13)  

   iv)  Eliminate B′(z₀) and μ(z₀):  
       • From (9): μ(z₀)= m g / B′(z₀).  
       • Insert into (13):  

            k = (A²/L)[B′(z₀)]² − (m g) B″(z₀)/B′(z₀).           (14)  

   v)  Use explicit derivatives (3) evaluated at z₀.  After a few lines of algebra—in particular employing (2) so that  
            -B″(z₀)/B′(z₀) = 3z₀ /(z₀²+R²),  
       one obtains  

            k = m² g² /(L I₀²)  +  3 m g z₀ /(z₀²+R²).            (15)  

   All dependence on the solenoid current I, as well as on the turn density n, has cancelled.  

E.  Small-oscillation period  
       T = 2π√(m/k)                                           (16)  
     Insert (15):  

       T = 2π   
           √{ 1 \over g \Bigl[\, {m g \over L I₀²} + {3 z₀ \over z₀²+R²} \Bigr] }.   (17)  

4. Discussion  
   •  The term m g/(L I₀²) comes from the change of the ring’s own current (through L) when it is displaced; the term 3z₀/(z₀²+R²) is purely geometric, arising from the curvature of the solenoid stray field.  
   •  Although n appears explicitly in B(z), the equilibrium condition (9) removes all dependence on n and on the solenoid current I.  
   •  The requirement k>0 (obvious from 15) guarantees stability.  

### Final Answer  
\[
\boxed{\, T \;=\; 2\pi\;
         \sqrt{\;
           \dfrac{1}{\;
             g\Bigl(\dfrac{m g}{L I_{0}^{2}}+\dfrac{3 z_{0}}{z_{0}^{2}+R^{2}}\Bigr)
           }\;} }
\]

(The result is expressed solely in the given quantities \(I_{0},\,r\,(via\, L),\,R,\,L,\,m\) and the equilibrium height \(z_{0}\); the turn density \(n\) cancels out.)

questions: Two dielectric materials with base areas both equal to $\pmb{A}$, thicknesses of $h_{1}$ and $h_{2}$ respectively, dielectric constants of $\varepsilon_{1}$ and $\varepsilon_{2}$ respectively, and conductivities of $\sigma_{1}$ and $\sigma_{2}$ respectively, are placed tightly between two highly conductive flat plates with the same area $\pmb{A}$ and a separation distance of $(h_{1}+h_{2})$, forming a capacitor. The system is connected into a circuit , with a power source of electromotive force $U_{0}$. Initially, the capacitor is uncharged, and at $\scriptstyle t=0$, the switch is turned on. Determine the time-dependent relationship of the current $I(t)$ flowing through the switch for $t > 0$.
solutions:
Let the magnitudes of the electric field intensity in the two media be $E_{1}, E_{2}$ respectively, and according to the relationship between the electric potentials, we have  

$$
E_{1}h_{1} + E_{2}h_{2} = U_{0}
$$  

The magnitudes of the current density in the two media are  

$$
\begin{aligned}
    j_1 &= \sigma_1 E_1, \\
    j_2 &= \sigma_2 E_2.
\end{aligned}
$$  

Let the free charge surface density at the contact of the two media be $\sigma_{\bullet}$, then  

From this, we obtain  

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l l}{\displaystyle{\frac{\mathrm{d}\sigma_{\circ}}{\mathrm{d}t}}=j_{1}-j_{2}}\ {\sigma_{\circ}=\varepsilon_{2}E_{2}-\varepsilon_{1}E_{1}}\end{array}\right.
$$  

$$
U_{0} = \frac{\mathrm{d}\sigma_{0}}{\mathrm{d}t}\cdot\left(\frac{h_{1}\varepsilon_{2} + h_{2}\varepsilon_{1}}{\sigma_{1}\varepsilon_{2} - \sigma_{2}\varepsilon_{1}}\right) + \sigma_{0}\cdot\left(\frac{\sigma_{1}h_{2} + \sigma_{2}h_{1}}{\sigma_{1}\varepsilon_{2} - \sigma_{2}\varepsilon_{1}}\right)
$$  

That is  

$$
\sigma_{0} = \frac{U_{0}\left(\sigma_{1}\varepsilon_{2} - \sigma_{2}\varepsilon_{1}\right)}{\sigma_{1}h_{2} + \sigma_{2}h_{1}}\cdot\left(1-\mathrm{e}^{\frac{t}{\tau}}\right)
$$  

Where the time constant is  

$$
\tau = \frac{h_{1}\varepsilon_{2} + h_{2}\varepsilon_{1}}{h_{1}\sigma_{2} + h_{2}\sigma_{1}}
$$

Solution Outline
-----------------

1. Problem Analysis  
   We have two different dielectric slabs (index 1 and 2) clamped between perfect-conducting plates and suddenly connected to a d.c. source of emf \(U_{0}\) at \(t = 0\).  
   Because both slabs are slightly conducting as well as polarizable, each slab behaves like a resistor \(R_i\) in parallel with a capacitor \(C_i\).  
   The question is: What is the switch current \(I(t)\) for \(t>0\)?

2. Key Idea / Approach  
   • Describe the time–dependent electric fields \(E_{1}(t)\) and \(E_{2}(t)\) inside the slabs.  
   • Apply  
     (a) the voltage constraint \(U_{0}=E_{1}h_{1}+E_{2}h_{2}\) and  
     (b) equality of the total current density
        \(J=\sigma_{1}E_{1}+\varepsilon_{1}\dot E_{1}
          =\sigma_{2}E_{2}+\varepsilon_{2}\dot E_{2}\)  
        (conduction + displacement currents must be the same through elements in series).  
   • These two relations reduce to a single first–order linear ODE for \(E_{1}(t)\).  
   • Solve the ODE, then obtain the common current density \(J(t)\) and finally the switch current \(I(t)=AJ(t)\).

3. Detailed Solution  

   3.1  Preliminary data  
   Capacitor area: \(A\)  
   Thicknesses: \(h_{1},h_{2}\)  
   Permittivities: \(\varepsilon_{1},\varepsilon_{2}\)  
   Conductivities: \(\sigma_{1},\sigma_{2}\)

   3.2  Voltage constraint  
   \[
        U_{0}=E_{1}(t)\,h_{1}+E_{2}(t)\,h_{2}\quad\Rightarrow\quad
        E_{2}(t)=\frac{U_{0}-h_{1}E_{1}(t)}{h_{2}} .
   \]

   3.3  Equality of total current density  
   \[
        J(t)=\sigma_{1}E_{1}+\varepsilon_{1}\dot E_{1}
             =\sigma_{2}E_{2}+\varepsilon_{2}\dot E_{2}.
   \]

   Substitute \(E_{2}(t)\) and \(\dot E_{2}(t)=-(h_{1}/h_{2})\dot E_{1}(t)\):

   \[
     \bigl(\sigma_{1}E_{1}+\varepsilon_{1}\dot E_{1}\bigr)h_{2}
     =\sigma_{2}\bigl(U_{0}-h_{1}E_{1}\bigr)-\varepsilon_{2}h_{1}\dot E_{1}.
   \]

   Collecting like terms gives the first–order ODE

   \[
     (\varepsilon_{1}h_{2}+\varepsilon_{2}h_{1})\,\dot E_{1}
     +(\sigma_{1}h_{2}+\sigma_{2}h_{1})\,E_{1}
     =\sigma_{2}U_{0}.
   \]

   3.4  Definitions for compactness  
   \[
     N\equiv\varepsilon_{1}h_{2}+\varepsilon_{2}h_{1}, \qquad
     D\equiv\sigma_{1}h_{2}+\sigma_{2}h_{1}, \qquad
     \tau \equiv\frac{N}{D}.
   \]

   3.5  Solution for \(E_{1}(t)\)  
   Initial condition: the capacitor is uncharged, so \(E_{1}(0)=E_{2}(0)=0\).  
   Solving the ODE,

   \[
     E_{1}(t)=E_{1}(\infty)\Bigl(1-e^{-t/\tau}\Bigr),
     \qquad
     E_{1}(\infty)=\frac{\sigma_{2}}{D}\,U_{0}.
   \]

   3.6  Current density  
   \[
     \begin{aligned}
       J(t) &=\sigma_{1}E_{1}(t)+\varepsilon_{1}\dot E_{1}(t) \\
            &=E_{1}(\infty)
               \Bigl[\sigma_{1}\bigl(1-e^{-t/\tau}\bigr)
                     +\frac{\varepsilon_{1}}{\tau}\,e^{-t/\tau}\Bigr].
     \end{aligned}
   \]

   Two particularly useful limits  
   • At the moment the switch is closed (\(t=0^{+}\)):
     \(J(0)=\displaystyle\frac{\sigma_{2}\varepsilon_{1}}{N}\,U_{0}\).  
   • After a long time (\(t\to\infty\)):
     \(J(\infty)=\displaystyle\frac{\sigma_{1}\sigma_{2}}{D}\,U_{0}\).

   Writing \(J(t)\) in the more transparent “single–exponential” form:

   \[
     J(t)=J(\infty)+\bigl[J(0)-J(\infty)\bigr]e^{-t/\tau},
   \]
   where
   \[
     J(0)=\frac{\sigma_{2}\varepsilon_{1}}{\varepsilon_{1}h_{2}+\varepsilon_{2}h_{1}}\,U_{0},
     \qquad
     J(\infty)=\frac{\sigma_{1}\sigma_{2}}{\sigma_{1}h_{2}+\sigma_{2}h_{1}}\,U_{0}.
   \]

   3.7  Switch current  
   The metallic plates have area \(A\); therefore

   \[
     I(t)=A\,J(t)
          =A\!\left[\frac{\sigma_{1}\sigma_{2}}{D}\,U_{0}
            +\Bigl(\frac{\sigma_{2}\varepsilon_{1}}{N}
                   -\frac{\sigma_{1}\sigma_{2}}{D}\Bigr)U_{0}\,e^{-t/\tau}\right],
   \]
   with the time constant
   \[
     \boxed{\displaystyle
       \tau=\frac{\varepsilon_{1}h_{2}+\varepsilon_{2}h_{1}}
                 {\sigma_{1}h_{2}+\sigma_{2}h_{1}} }.
   \]

4. Physical Interpretation  
   • Immediately after connection, no free charge has yet accumulated, so conduction parts are zero and the current is purely displacement current determined by the dielectric constants.  
   • With time, charges build up, the current decays exponentially, and after many time constants the current is purely ohmic through the finite conductivities of the slabs.

### Final Answer
\[
\boxed{\,I(t)=A\,U_{0}\left[\frac{\sigma_{1}\sigma_{2}}{\sigma_{1}h_{2}+\sigma_{2}h_{1}}
+\left(
\frac{\sigma_{2}\varepsilon_{1}}{\varepsilon_{1}h_{2}+\varepsilon_{2}h_{1}}
-\frac{\sigma_{1}\sigma_{2}}{\sigma_{1}h_{2}+\sigma_{2}h_{1}}
\right)e^{-t/\tau}\right],\qquad
\tau=\frac{\varepsilon_{1}h_{2}+\varepsilon_{2}h_{1}}
           {\sigma_{1}h_{2}+\sigma_{2}h_{1}}\,}
\]

questions:
There is an available cycloidal valley, which can be described using a cycloid (downward along the $y$-axis): 
$$
\left\{{\begin{array}{l}{x=R(\theta-\sin\theta)}\\ {y=R(1-\cos\theta)}\end{array}}\right.
$$
 Someone wants to release a cube with a mass of $M$ and with equal length, width, and height of $r$ at rest from one end of the valley at $\theta = 0$. It is released facing the slope. A layer of snow with a surface density of $\sigma$ is attached to the valley. The snow is in contact with the ground but does not interact, remaining stationary until it touches the object, at which point it adheres to its surface without altering the object's shape. Assuming gravitational acceleration $g$, there are the approximate conditions $\sigma r R \ll M, r \ll R$ (results are retained up to the first order of $r$). Determine the highest position the cube can reach at the other end (considering no rolling occurs).
solutions: In this sub-question, energy is not conserved, but analyzing its motion still presents certain difficulties. Considering that the problem only requires accuracy to the first-order term, the loss of ascent quotient can be divided into two parts for correction, with zero-order motion considered during the correction process.  For the collision process between the square block and the snow, consider the conservation of momentum:  $$ M v = (M + \sigma\gamma u{\mathrm{d}}t)(v - {\mathrm{d}}v) $$  This results in:  $$ \mathrm{d}\upsilon = -\frac{\sigma r v^{2}}{M}\mathrm{d}t $$  The energy loss during the process is:  $$ d E = \frac{1}{2}(M + \mathrm{d}M)(\upsilon + \mathrm{d}\upsilon)^{2} - \frac{1}{2}(M)\upsilon^{2} = -\frac{1}{2}\sigma r\upsilon^{2}\upsilon\mathrm{d}t = -\frac{1}{2}\sigma r\upsilon^{2}\mathrm{d}s $$  In this case, it can be treated as linear motion, and the equation is not influenced by acceleration. Therefore, it can be corrected independently, with the zero-order velocity expression as:  $$ \upsilon_{0} = \sqrt{2g R(1-\cos\theta)} $$  Substituting into the integral:  $$ \delta W = \int f\mathrm{d}s = \int_{0}^{2\pi} -g R(1-\cos\theta)\sigma\boldsymbol{r}\cdot2R\sin\frac{\theta}{2}\mathrm{d}\theta = -\frac{32}{3}g R^{2}r\sigma $$  This gives the energy loss caused by collisions, which we convert into a height correction, then combine it with the correction for the gravitational component of the snow from the first question, resulting in the total reached height:  $$ \begin{array}{l} {{\delta y_{f} = \displaystyle\frac{32}{3}\displaystyle\frac{\sigma R^{2}r}{M}}}{{}}\\ {{\delta y_{g} = \displaystyle\frac{32}{3}\displaystyle\frac{\sigma R^{2}r}{M}}}{{}}\\ {{\delta y = \displaystyle\frac{64}{3}\displaystyle\frac{\sigma R^{2}r}{M}}} \end{array} $$  The two combined terms are both first-order and do not interfere with each other.
improved_solutions:
### 1. Problem Analysis  
A cube of mass `M` and edge `r` is released from rest at the cusp ( θ = 0 ) of a cycloidal valley  
 x = R(θ − sin θ), y = R(1 − cos θ).  
While it slides (without rolling) it sweeps a strip of snow of width `r`; the snow has surface‐mass density `σ` and is initially at rest in the laboratory frame.  
Whenever the cube meets a differential area ds·r it accretes the snow that was on it.  
Because σrR ≪ M and r ≪ R we keep only terms of first order in  
    ε ≡ σrR / M  ( ε ≪ 1 ).  
We are asked for the highest point (angle θ_max) the cube can attain on the opposite side of the valley after the inelastic pick-up of snow has dissipated part of the mechanical energy.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 2. Approach  
1. Treat the cube+accreted snow as an open, variable-mass system that gains
   an element dm = σ r ds of mass that is initially at rest.  
2. Write the 1-D linear-momentum equation along the cycloidal tangent, keeping
   the gravitational component mg cos(θ/2) that acts along the path.  
3. Derive the power (energy) balance.  
   The inelastic capture of dm removes an amount dE_loss = ½ v² dm from the
   mechanical energy.  
4. To first order in ε we can use the snow-free velocity
      v₀(θ) = √[2gR(1 − cos θ)].  
   Integrating ½ v₀² dm along the whole arch (θ : 0 → 2π) gives the total energy dissipated.  
5. Equating the energy lost to the drop in gravitational potential of the now
   heavier cube gives the vertical shortfall Δh below the original level and
   hence θ_max.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 3. Detailed Solution  

3.1  Geometric relations of the cycloid  
dx/dθ = R(1 − cos θ), dy/dθ = R sin θ  
Arc–length element :  
     ds = R√{(1 − cos θ)² + sin² θ}\,dθ = R√{2(1 − cos θ)}\,dθ.     (1)  
Slope factor needed later :  
     dy/ds = (dy/dθ)/(ds/dθ) = sin θ / √{2(1 − cos θ)} = cos(θ/2).   (2)

3.2  Variable-mass dynamics along the path  
Let s be the distance travelled from the start,  
     m(s) = M + σ r s,  dm = σ r ds .                                (3)

Momentum equation (tangential component) for a body that accretes stationary mass (relative velocity –v) reads  

     m dv = m g (dy/ds) ds  − v dm.                                 (4)

3.3  Power / energy balance  
Multiply (4) by v and note d(½ mv²) = m v dv + ½ v² dm :

d(½ m v²) = m g (dy/ds) v ds  − ½ v² dm.                          (5)

The last term −½ v² dm is the mechanical energy that is **irreversibly
removed** when the cube sticks to a snow element of mass dm.  
Hence the rate of dissipation is  

     dE_loss = ½ v² dm.                                              (6)

3.4  Zeroth-order (snow-free) velocity  
For ε ≪ 1 we evaluate the integral (6) with the velocity that the cube
would have if no snow were present:

v₀(θ)  (from energy M g y = ½ M v²) →  
     v₀²(θ) = 2gR(1 − cos θ).                                       (7)

3.5  Total energy dissipated during a whole arch  
Combine (1), (3) and (7):

dE_loss = ½ v₀² dm = ½ (2gR(1 − cos θ)) (σ r ds)  
         = σ r g R (1 − cos θ) R√{2(1 − cos θ)} dθ  
         = σ r g R² √2 (1 − cos θ)^{3/2} dθ.                       (8)

Integrate from θ = 0 (start) to θ = 2π (other cusp); at this order the cube would almost complete the arch, so the small deficit in angle gives only a
second-order correction and can be ignored in the integral:

E_loss ≃ σ r g R² √2 ∫_0^{2π} (1 − cos θ)^{3/2} dθ.                (9)

Use 1 − cos θ = 2 sin²(θ/2):
     (1 − cos θ)^{3/2} = (2 sin²(θ/2))^{3/2} = 2^{3/2} sin^3(θ/2).

I ≡ ∫_0^{2π} (1 − cos θ)^{3/2} dθ
   = 2^{3/2}∫_0^{2π} sin^3(θ/2) dθ
   = 2^{3/2}·2∫_0^{π} sin^3 u du  (u = θ/2)
   = 2^{5/2}·(4/3) = 16√2/3.                                       (10)

Insert (10) into (9):

E_loss = σ r g R² √2 · 16√2 / 3 = (32/3) σ r g R².                 (11)

3.6  Extra mass gained by the cube  
The full length of one cycloidal arch is

s_arch = ∫_0^{2π} ds = R√2 ∫_0^{2π} √{1 − cos θ} dθ
        = R√2 · √2 ∫_0^{2π} |sin(θ/2)| dθ
        = R·2 ∫_0^{π} 2 du = 8R.                                   (12)

Hence the added snow mass is  
     ΔM = σ r s_arch = 8σ r R.                                     (13)

and the final mass (to first order)  

     m_f = M + ΔM ≈ M.                                             (14)

(The correction 8σ r R is already O(ε); keeping it in the denominator would
only affect second-order terms.)

3.7  Height reached on the opposite side  
At the turning point the kinetic energy is 0.  
Energy conservation (initial PE = 0):

E_loss + m_f g (−Δh) = 0 ⇒ Δh = E_loss /(m_f g).                (15)

With (11) and (14):

Δh = (32/3) σ r R² / M.                                            (16)

Here Δh is the vertical drop relative to the starting cusp; the cube therefore stops a vertical distance Δh below its original level.

3.8  Cycloidal parameter of the turning point  
The cycloid gives y(θ) = R(1 − cos θ).  
Setting y = Δh:

R(1 − cos θ_max) = (32/3) σ r R² / M
 ⇒ 1 − cos θ_max = (32/3) (σ r R)/M.                              (17)

Because σ r R ≪ M the right–hand side is very small;  
write θ_max = 2π − δ (δ ≪ 1):

1 − cos θ_max ≈ ½ δ².                                             (18)

Compare with (17):

½ δ² = (32/3) (σ r R)/M
 ⇒ δ = (8/√3) √(σ r R / M).                                      (19)

Hence  
     θ_max ≈ 2π − (8/√3)√(σ r R / M).                            (20)

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 4. Result  

• Vertical shortfall below the initial cusp:  
     Δh = (32/3)(σ r R²)/M.  

• Highest cycloidal parameter attainable:  
     1 − cos θ_max = (32/3)(σ r R)/M,   
      θ_max ≃ 2π − (8/√3)√(σ r R / M).  

Both expressions are accurate to first order in the small parameter ε = σ r R / M.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### Final Answer
\[
\boxed{\;
\begin{aligned}
&\text{Vertical drop below the starting cusp:}\qquad
\Delta h = \frac{32}{3}\,\frac{\sigma r R^{2}}{M},\\[4pt]
&\text{Corresponding turning angle:}\qquad
1-\cos\theta_{\max}= \frac{32}{3}\,\frac{\sigma r R}{M}
\;\;\Bigl(\;\theta_{\max}\simeq 2\pi-\frac{8}{\sqrt{3}}\sqrt{\frac{\sigma r R}{M}}\Bigr)
\;.
\end{aligned}
\;}
\]

improved_solutions:
1. Problem Analysis  
We are asked to determine the rotationally–symmetric refractive-index profile n(r) (up to an arbitrary scale factor n₀) that guides a light ray along the polar curve  
  r(θ)=a cos(qθ)   (0<r<a).  
Because the index depends on radius only, every ray conserves the so-called optical angular momentum L = n(r) r sin α, where α is the angle between the ray and the radial direction.  By expressing sin α in terms of r and θ for the imposed trajectory and imposing L = const, we can solve for n(r).

2. Approach (key ideas)  
• Rotational symmetry ⇒ constant “impact parameter’’ L = n r sin α.  
• For any polar curve r(θ) the tangent makes an angle α with the radial direction with  
  tan α = r (dθ/dr).  
• For the prescribed curve r = a cos(qθ) we calculate dθ/dr, then sin α, insert in L, and isolate n(r).  
• A global multiplicative constant (chosen n₀) is irrelevant for the path and is left arbitrary.

3. Solution Steps  

Step 1 – Geometry of the prescribed ray  
Let x ≡ r/a (dimensionless variable, 0 < x < 1).  
Given  r = a cos(qθ)  ⇒ cos(qθ) = x.

Differentiate:  
dr/dθ = –a q sin(qθ) = –a q √(1 – x²)  (using sin² = 1 – cos²).

Hence  dθ/dr = –1/[a q √(1 – x²)].

Step 2 – Angle between ray and radial direction  
tan α = r (dθ/dr)  
    = [a x]·[–1/(a q √(1 – x²))]  
    = – x/[q √(1 – x²)].  
(The minus sign only tells the sense of rotation; sin α will be used in magnitude.)

Compute sin α from tan α:

tan α = T,  with T ≡ x/[q√(1 – x²)]  
sin α = T/√(1+T²).

Evaluate 1+T²:  
T² = x²/[q²(1–x²)]  

1+T² = 1 + x²/[q²(1–x²)]  
    = [q²(1–x²) + x²]/[q²(1–x²)]  
    = [q² – (q²–1)x²]/[q²(1–x²)].

Therefore  

sin α = T / √(1+T²)  
    = [x/(q√{1–x²})] · √{q²(1–x²)}/√{q² – (q²–1)x²}  
    = x / √{q² – (q²–1)x²}.                                (1)

Step 3 – Conservation of optical angular momentum  
For a central index n(r):  L = n(r) r sin α = const.  

Insert r = a x and eq. (1):

L = n(r) · a x · [x / √{q² – (q²–1)x²}]  
  = n(r) a x² / √{q² – (q²–1)x²}.                          (2)

Because L is the same everywhere on the ray, the factor depending on r must be constant.  Solving (2) for n(r):

n(r) = L/a · √{q² – (q²–1)x²} / x².

The multiplicative constant L/a is arbitrary as far as the trajectory is concerned; we rename it n₀ (dimensionless).  Returning to r (x = r/a):

n(r) = n₀ · √{q² – (q²–1)(r²/a²)} / (r/a)²  
      = n₀ · a²/r² · √{q² – (q²–1)\,r²/a²}.                (3)

Step 4 – Domain and behaviour  
• r ranges from 0 to a, so the square-root argument is always ≥1 and positive.  
• As r→0, n(r) ~ n₀ a²/r² → ∞; the statement in the problem about the divergence at the origin is recovered.  

4. Result  
Inside the region r<a the required refractive index profile is  

n(r) = n₀ \frac{a^{2}}{r^{2}}\sqrt{\,q^{2}-\left(q^{2}-1\right)\frac{r^{2}}{a^{2}}}\,,  0<r<a,

where n₀ is an arbitrary dimensionless constant (a global scaling of the index does not change the light path).

### Final Answer
\[
\boxed{\,n(r)=n_{0}\,\frac{a^{2}}{r^{2}}\;
\sqrt{\,q^{2}-\left(q^{2}-1\right)\frac{r^{2}}{a^{2}}}\quad\text{for }0<r<a\,}
\]

questions:
Calculate the wave speed of longitudinal waves in a one-dimensional gas. Consider a section of the gas column with cross-sectional area $S$, assume its displacement along the $x$ direction is $\xi = \xi(x)$, the gas pressure distribution is $p = p(x)$, and the density of the gas when uncompressed is $\rho_{0}$. Consider the case of small amplitude and long wavelength, i.e. $\xi \ll x, \frac{\partial \xi}{\partial x}\ll 1, (p-p_0)\ll p_0, (\rho-\rho_0)\ll\rho_0$. Calculate the wave speed of longitudinal waves in a van der Waals gas. The state equation of one mole of the gas is given as:

$$
\left( p + \frac{a}{V^{2}} \right)(V - b) = RT\ 
$$

The molar heat capacity at constant volume is $c_{v}$, and the molar mass of the gas is $\mu$. Solve for the wave speed under adiabatic conditions, expressed in terms of $p, \rho, a, b,\mu, \gamma = \frac{c_{v} + R}{c_{v}}$.  
Hint: You can use the formulas:

$$dU = c_{v}dT + \left( \frac{\partial U}{\partial V} \right)_{T}dV$$

and

$$\left( \frac{\partial U}{\partial V} \right)_{T} = T\left( \frac{\partial p}{\partial T} \right)_{V} - p$$

to calculate the adiabatic equation.
solutions:
Consider the air column from $x \rightarrow x + dx$. From the dynamics equation, we obtain:

$$
\rho_{0}Sdx\frac{\partial^{2}\xi}{\partial t^{2}} = - \frac{dp}{dS}(1)
$$

After simplification, we get

$$
\rho_{0}\frac{\partial^{2}\xi}{\partial t^{2}} = - \frac{\partial p}{\partial x}(2)
$$

Consider the air column originally located at $x\rightarrow x+\mathrm d x$, now located at $x+\xi\rightarrow x+dx+\xi +d\xi$. By mass conservation:

$$
\rho(d\xi + dx) = \rho_{0}dx(3)
$$

Hence, we get

$$
\rho = \rho_{0}\left( 1 - \frac{\partial\xi}{\partial x} \right)(4)
$$

Using

$$
\frac{\partial p}{\partial x} = \left( \frac{\partial p}{\partial\rho} \right)_{c} \cdot \frac{\partial\rho}{\partial x}(5)
$$

### 1. Problem Analysis  
For an infinitesimal, one–dimensional, longitudinal disturbance propagating through a fluid, the acoustic (phase) speed is  

\[
c^{2}=\left(\frac{\partial p}{\partial \rho}\right)_{S},
\]

i.e. the partial derivative of the pressure with respect to the mass density taken at constant entropy (adiabatic process).  
The gas obeys the van der Waals (v.d.W.) equation of state for one mole  

\[
\bigl(p+\dfrac{a}{V^{2}}\bigr)(V-b)=RT ,
\]

and has a molar heat capacity \(c_{v}\) (hence \(\gamma=\dfrac{c_{v}+R}{c_{v}}\)).  
Our task is to evaluate the derivative \((\partial p/\partial \rho)_{S}\) in terms of the measurable quantities \(p,\ \rho\) and the constants \(a,\;b,\;\mu,\;\gamma\).

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 2. Approach (overview)  
Two equivalent thermodynamic routes are possible.

A.  Find the explicit adiabatic relation for a v.d.W. gas, then differentiate it.  
B.  Work directly with differentials \(dp,\ dT,\ dV\) together with the entropy-constancy condition \(dS=0\).  

We follow route A (shown entirely) and briefly check route B to confirm the result.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 3. Solution Steps  

3.1  Adiabatic equation for a v.d.W. gas  
For one mole the first-law identity with the hint supplied is  

\[
T\,dS=dU+p\,dV
     =c_{v}dT+\left[T\!\left(\frac{\partial p}{\partial T}\right)_{V}-p\right]dV+p\,dV
     =c_{v}dT+T\!\left(\frac{\partial p}{\partial T}\right)_{V}dV .
\]

Setting \(dS=0\) gives the adiabatic constraint    

\[
c_{v}\,dT=-T\left(\frac{\partial p}{\partial T}\right)_{V}dV .
\]

For the v.d.W. gas  

\[
\left(\frac{\partial p}{\partial T}\right)_{V}=\frac{R}{V-b},
\qquad
p=\frac{RT}{V-b}-\frac{a}{V^{2}} .
\]

Insert the derivative and eliminate \(T\) with the equation of state:

\[
c_{v}\,dT=-\frac{RT}{V-b}\,dV
        =-\left(p+\frac{a}{V^{2}}\right)dV .
\]

Use \(R/c_{v}=\gamma-1\) to integrate:

\[
\frac{dT}{T}=
-(\gamma-1)\,\frac{dV}{V-b}\quad\Longrightarrow\quad
T(V-b)^{\gamma-1}= \text{const}.
\]

Multiplying by \(R\) and replacing \(RT\) with \(p+\dfrac{a}{V^{2}}\) we obtain the **adiabatic relation**

\[
\boxed{\,\bigl(p+\dfrac{a}{V^{2}}\bigr)\,(V-b)^{\gamma}=C\;(S)\,}.
\]

3.2  Differentiate the adiabatic relation  
Take the logarithm and differentiate at constant entropy:

\[
\frac{d\!\left(p+\dfrac{a}{V^{2}}\right)}{p+\dfrac{a}{V^{2}}}
+\gamma\frac{dV}{V-b}=0 .
\]

Because \(d\!\left(p+\dfrac{a}{V^{2}}\right)=dp-\dfrac{2a}{V^{3}}dV\),

\[
dp-\frac{2a}{V^{3}}\,dV=-\gamma\frac{p+\dfrac{a}{V^{2}}}{V-b}\,dV .
\]

Hence  

\[
\boxed{\,dp=\left[-\gamma\frac{p+\dfrac{a}{V^{2}}}{V-b}
          +\frac{2a}{V^{3}}\right]dV\,}.
\]

3.3  Convert to derivative at constant entropy  
The molar volume is related to the mass density by  

\[
V=\frac{\mu}{\rho},\qquad dV=-\frac{\mu}{\rho^{2}}\,d\rho .
\]

Therefore  

\[
\left(\frac{\partial p}{\partial\rho}\right)_{S}
  =-\frac{\mu}{\rho^{2}}\left[-\gamma\frac{p+\dfrac{a}{V^{2}}}{V-b}
                         +\frac{2a}{V^{3}}\right]
  =\frac{\mu}{\rho^{2}}\left[\gamma\frac{p+\dfrac{a}{V^{2}}}{V-b}
                         -\frac{2a}{V^{3}}\right].
\]

3.4  Express the result in \(p\) and \(\rho\)  
Introduce the molar number density  

\[
n=\frac{\rho}{\mu}=\frac{1}{V},\qquad
V-b=\frac{1-bn}{n}.
\]

Substituting \(V=1/n\) into the derivative:

• \(p+\dfrac{a}{V^{2}}=p+a n^{2}\),

• \(\dfrac{1}{V-b}=\dfrac{n}{1-bn}\),

• \(\dfrac{1}{V^{3}}=n^{3}\).

Therefore  

\[
\left(\frac{\partial p}{\partial\rho}\right)_{S}
=
\frac{\mu}{\rho^{2}}
\left[\gamma\frac{n\bigl(p+a n^{2}\bigr)}{1-bn}-2a n^{3}\right].
\]

Because \(\rho=\mu n\) and \(\mu/\rho^{2}=1/(\rho n)=1/\rho^{2}(\mu n)\rightarrow1/\rho\),

\[
c^{2}=
\left(\frac{\partial p}{\partial\rho}\right)_{S}
=
\frac{\gamma\bigl(p+a n^{2}\bigr)}{\rho\,(1-bn)}
-\frac{2a n^{2}}{\rho}.
\]

Finally replace \(n=\rho/\mu\):

\[
\boxed{\,c^{2}
      =\frac{\gamma\left[p+a\!\left(\dfrac{\rho}{\mu}\right)^{2}\right]}
             {\rho\left(1-b\,\dfrac{\rho}{\mu}\right)}
       -\frac{2a}{\mu^{2}}\,\rho\,}.
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 4. Verification via the direct-differential route  
Starting from  

\[
dp=(\partial p/\partial T)_{V}dT+(\partial p/\partial V)_{T}dV,\qquad
dS=\frac{c_{v}}{T}\,dT+(\partial p/\partial T)_{V}dV=0,
\]

eliminating \(dT\) (adiabatic condition) and substituting v.d.W. derivatives produces exactly the same expression for \(dp\). Hence the result is self-consistent.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### Final Answer  
\[
\boxed{\,c^{2}
      =\frac{\gamma\left[p+a\!\left(\dfrac{\rho}{\mu}\right)^{2}\right]}
             {\rho\left(1-\dfrac{b\rho}{\mu}\right)}
       -\frac{2a}{\mu^{2}}\,\rho\,}
\]

where  
• \(p\) ‑ pressure,  
• \(\rho\) ‑ mass density,  
• \(a,b\) ‑ van der Waals constants,  
• \(\mu\) ‑ molar mass,  
• \(\gamma=(c_{v}+R)/c_{v}\).

The deformation at a particular point $\pmb{d}$ is a linear function of its projection distance $\boldsymbol{\mathbf{\rho}}_{x}$ in the direction of maximum deformation:  

$$
d = d_{0} + x \tan\alpha
$$  

Assuming the direction of maximum deformation is $\theta_{0}$, we have:  

$$
x = r \cos{\left(\theta - \theta_{0}\right)}
$$  

According to Hooke's law:  

$$
n = k d = k d_{0} + k r \tan\alpha \cos\left(\theta - \theta_{0}\right) = n_{0} + n_{1} \cos\left(\theta - \theta_{0}\right)
$$  

The curling stone is in vertical force equilibrium, so:  

$$
N = \int_{0}^{2\pi} n\big(\theta\big)d\theta = m g
$$  

Solving, we obtain $n_{0} = m g / 2\pi$.  

The friction force acting on the curling stone is proportional to the normal pressure:  

$$
f(\theta) = \mu n(\theta)
$$  

Its direction is along the negative $\mathbf{x}$ axis.  

During the motion of the curling stone, the overall torque is balanced:  

$$
M_{x} = \int_{0}^{2\pi}\boldsymbol{n}(\theta) r \sin\theta d\theta + \frac{1}{2} \int_{0}^{2\pi} f_{y}\left(\theta\right) h d\theta = 0
$$  

$$
M_{y} = -\int_{0}^{2\pi} \eta \left(\theta\right) r \cos\theta d\theta - \frac{1}{2} \int_{0}^{2\pi} f_{x}\left(\theta\right) h d\theta = 0
$$  

When $\nu \gg \omega r$, the components of the friction force retain only the first-order approximations:  

$$
f_{x} = -\frac{\nu + \omega r \sin\theta}{\sqrt{\left(\nu + \omega r \sin\theta\right)^{2} + \omega^{2} r^{2} \cos^{2}\theta}} \mu n(\theta) \approx -\mu n(\theta)
$$  

$$
f_{y} = \frac{\omega r \cos{\theta}}{\sqrt{\left(\nu + \omega r \sin{\theta}\right)^{2} + \omega^{2} r^{2} \cos^{2}{\theta}}} \mu n(\theta) \approx \frac{\omega r \cos{\theta}}{\nu} \mu n(\theta)
$$  

For convenience in solving, let $n\left(\theta\right) = n_{0} + a \cos\theta + b \sin\theta$. Substituting into equations (6) and (7) and solving simultaneously, we obtain:  

$$

$$  

The final transverse acceleration is:  

$$
a_{y} = \frac{1}{m} \int_{0}^{2\pi} f_{y} d\theta = \frac{\mu^{2} \omega h g}{2 \nu}
$$

questions: The forty-second batch of Trisolarian immigrants arrived on Earth aboard a spaceship propelled by photons. The spaceship has a rest mass of $M$, and it uses the method of annihilating matter and antimatter to produce photons, which are then emitted directly backward to provide thrust. In the reference frame of the spaceship, the frequency of the photons emitted backward is $ u _{0}$. For simplicity, we assume that the \"windward side\" of the Trisolarian spaceship is a flat surface with an area $S$. During flight, dust floating in the universe may collide with it. We assume that the cosmic dust is composed of particles with rest mass $m$. For an observer on Earth: the spaceship moves at a constant speed of $v _1$, the particles in the cosmic dust have a speed of $v_2$ and move in the same direction as the spaceship, and the particles in the dust are uniformly distributed with a density of $n$. If, according to the Trisolarian beings on the spaceship, the cosmic dust undergoes a \"perfectly elastic collision\" upon impact with the spaceship, what is the number $N^{'}$ of photons that need to be emitted backward per unit time in the reference frame of the spaceship to maintain its constant speed? Given are Planck's constant $h$, the speed of light in vacuum $c$, and relativistic effects need to be considered.

The reference frame of the Earth observer is called the $\Sigma$ frame, and the reference frame of the spaceship is called the $\Sigma$ frame.  We agree that: $$\beta_{1}=\frac{v_{1}}{c},\gamma_{1}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-\beta_{1}^{2}}},\beta_{2}=\frac{v_{2}}{c},\gamma_{2}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-\beta_{2}^{2}}},\beta_{21}=\frac{v_{21}}{c},\gamma_{21}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-\beta_{21}^{2}}}$$ $$\beta_{2}^{'}=\frac{v_{2}^{'}}{c},\gamma_{2}^{'}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-\beta_{2}^{'2}}},\beta_{21}^{'}=\frac{v_{21}^{'}}{c},\gamma_{21}^{'}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-\beta_{21}^{'2}}}$$    The resistance of the spaceship is equal to the impulse given to the spaceship by cosmic dust particles per unit time. In the reference frame of the spaceship, we have:    $$ F^{'}=n^{'}S\left|v_{2}^{'}\right|\times\left|p_{2}^{'}-p_{21}^{'}\right|=n^{'}S\left|v_{2}^{'}\right|\times\left|2p_{2}^{'}\right|=2n^{'}S m \gamma_{2}^{'}v_{2}^{'2} $$    The calculation of $n'$ needs to take into account the length contraction effect. If the particle density is $n_{0}$ in the rest frame of the cosmic dust itself, we have:  $$ n=n_{0}\gamma_{2}, n^{'}=n_{0}\gamma_{2}^{'} $$  Therefore, we can obtain $n^{\prime}=\frac{\gamma_{2}^{'}}{\gamma_{2}}n_{0}$.    Since $S$ is perpendicular to the direction of velocity, it is identical in both reference frames.  By relativistic velocity transformation:  $$ v_{2}^{'}=\frac{v_{2}-v_{1}}{1-\frac{v_{2}v_{1}}{c^{2}}} $$    Substituting into the expression for $F$ yields:  $$ F^{'}=2\frac{\gamma_{2}^{'}}{\gamma_{2}}n S m\gamma_{2}^{'} v_{2}^{'2}=2n S m\gamma_{1}^{2}\gamma_{2}(v_{1}-v_{2})^{2} $$    From momentum conservation in the spaceship reference frame, we can obtain:  $$ \boldsymbol{F}^{'}=\frac{N^{'} h  u_{0}}{c} $$    $$ N^{'}=\frac{2n S m c\gamma_{1}^{2}\gamma_{2}(v_{1}-v_{2})^{2}}{h  u_{0}} $$

---------------------------------
1. Problem Analysis
---------------------------------
The spaceship wants to keep its constant velocity v₁ (measured in the Earth frame) while it is hit by interstellar‐dust particles that in the Earth frame move in the same direction with velocity v₂ (< v₁).  
In the ship’s own (proper) frame the dust comes head-on, elastically bounces, and therefore delivers an impulse that tends to slow the craft.  
The task: determine how many photons of frequency u₀ must be emitted per unit proper time straight backward so that the photon thrust exactly compensates the average decelerating force due to dust impacts.

---------------------------------
2. Approach
---------------------------------
• Work entirely in the spaceship’s rest frame; here the ship is at rest while the dust approaches with some relativistically added velocity v_rel.  
• Find the dust flux striking the frontal area S, taking Lorentz contraction of number density into account.  
• For a perfectly elastic frontal collision each dust particle reverses its normal momentum, supplying a momentum change Δp to the ship.  
• Multiply Δp by the flux to obtain the force F_dust that must be balanced.  
• Each photon carries momentum h u₀ / c opposite to the dust impulse.  Equate the total photon momentum per unit time to F_dust to obtain the required emission rate N′.  
• Express v_rel and its Lorentz factor γ_rel in terms of the given Earth‐frame speeds v₁ and v₂ via the relativistic velocity-addition formula.

---------------------------------
3. Detailed Solution
---------------------------------
Step 1 Relative speed of dust in the ship frame  
The Earth frame sees the ship and the dust moving in the same (+x) direction with speeds v₁ and v₂ respectively (v₁ > v₂).  
Relativistic velocity addition gives the dust speed in the ship frame

  v_rel = (v₂ – v₁) / (1 – v₁v₂ / c²)                                     (1)

Its Lorentz factor is  

  γ_rel = 1 / √(1 – v_rel² / c²).                                        (2)

Step 2 Dust number density and particle flux in the ship frame  
In the Earth frame the number density is n.  In the ship frame the dust stream is Lorentz-contracted along the x-direction, so

  n′ = γ_rel n.                                                           (3)

The flux (particles per unit ship-frame time striking area S) is  

  Φ = n′ v_rel S = γ_rel n v_rel S.                                   (4)

Step 3 Momentum transfer per particle  
In the ship frame a dust particle has momentum  

  p_x = γ_rel m v_rel.  

A perfectly elastic frontal collision reverses p_x, so the momentum imparted to the ship per particle is

  Δp = 2 γ_rel m v_rel.                                                (5)

Step 4 Average decelerating force on the ship  
Multiply Δp by the flux Φ:

  F_dust = Φ Δp  
         = (γ_rel n v_rel S)(2 γ_rel m v_rel)  
         = 2 γ_rel² m n v_rel² S.                                      (6)

Step 5 Photon thrust required for equilibrium  
A photon of frequency u₀ carries momentum

  p_ph = h u₀ / c.                                                      (7)

Let N′ be the photon emission rate (per unit ship time).  Momentum balance in the x-direction:

  N′ (h u₀ / c) = F_dust.                                               (8)

Step 6 Photon emission rate  
Insert Eq.(6) into Eq.(8):

  N′ = (c / h u₀) (2 γ_rel² m n v_rel² S)  
     = (2 c m n S / h u₀) γ_rel² v_rel².                                (9)

Step 7 Explicit dependence on v₁ and v₂  
Using Eqs.(1)–(2) for v_rel and γ_rel gives the final closed-form expression in terms of the data supplied in the Earth frame.

---------------------------------
4. Final Answer
---------------------------------
The photon emission rate (count per unit proper time of the spaceship) required to maintain constant speed is

\[ \boxed{\;
N' \;=\;
\frac{2 c\, m\, n\, S}{h\, u_0}\;
\gamma_{\!\text{rel}}^{\,2}\, v_{\text{rel}}^{\,2},
\quad
v_{\text{rel}} = \frac{v_2 - v_1}{\,1 - \dfrac{v_1 v_2}{c^{2}}\,},
\quad
\gamma_{\!\text{rel}} = \frac{1}{\sqrt{1 - \dfrac{v_{\text{rel}}^{2}}{c^{2}}}}
\;} \]

This gives the number of photons that must be emitted backward per unit time in the spaceship’s own frame to exactly counteract the momentum loss due to perfectly elastic impacts with the interstellar dust.

questions:
Consider a non-ideal gas system. Without worrying about the internal composition and interaction details, we find that its macroscopic equation of state is:

$$
p = k V^{-4/5}T^{3/2}
$$

where $k$ is a constant coefficient.

Consider a very special case. If for this non-ideal gas, its specific heat ratio:

$$
\gamma = \frac{C_{p}}{C_{V}}
$$

is exactly a constant that is independent of temperature and volume. Calculate the value of $\gamma$.
solutions:
Combine the formula for the difference in heat capacities with the heat capacity relation:

$$
C_{p}=\gamma C_{V}
$$

This directly solves for the heat capacity:

$$
C_{V}=\frac{45}{16}\frac{k V^{1/5}T^{1/2}}{\gamma-1}
$$

And at this point, it must satisfy

$$
\frac{\partial C_{V}}{\partial V}=g=\frac{3}{4}k V^{-4/5}T^{1/2}
$$

Substituting gives the only possible value for $\gamma$:

$$
\gamma=\frac{7}{4}
$$
improved_solutions:
## 1. Problem Analysis  
We are given a non-ideal gas whose macroscopic equation of state is  

\[
p = k\,V^{-4/5}\,T^{3/2}\qquad(k=\text{constant})
\]

and are told that its specific–heat ratio  

\[
\gamma\;=\;\dfrac{C_{p}}{C_{V}}
\]

is a true constant, i.e. independent of \(T\) and \(V\).  
The task is to determine that constant value of \(\gamma\).

----------------------------------------------------------------------

## 2. Approach  
For any reversible adiabatic process (\(\delta Q = 0\)) we have  

\[
dU + p\,dV = 0 .
\]

Writing \(dU=C_{V}\,dT\) and employing the given equation of state to eliminate the pressure, we can integrate the adiabatic condition and obtain an explicit power-law relation between \(T\) and \(V\) along an adiabat.  Re-inserting that relation into the equation of state produces the adiabatic \(p\!-\!V\) curve.  If the heat-capacity ratio is a genuine constant, every reversible adiabat must take the familiar form  

\[
p\,V^{\gamma}=\text{const}.
\]

Equating the power of \(V\) that we obtain from the integration with \(-\gamma\) immediately yields the desired numerical value.

----------------------------------------------------------------------

## 3. Solution Steps  

### 3.1  Adiabatic condition with the given equation of state  
First-law form for a quasi-static adiabatic change (\(\delta Q = 0\)):  

\[
dU + p\,dV = 0 \quad\Longrightarrow\quad C_{V}\,dT = -\,p\,dV .
\]

Insert \(p = k\,V^{-4/5}\,T^{3/2}\):

\[
C_{V}\,dT = -\,k\,V^{-4/5}\,T^{3/2}\,dV .
\]

### 3.2  Separate variables and integrate  
Bring all terms in \(T\) to the left and all terms in \(V\) to the right:

\[
\frac{dT}{T^{3/2}} = -\frac{k}{C_{V}}\,V^{-4/5}\,dV .
\]

Integrate:

Left side  
\[
\int \frac{dT}{T^{3/2}} = \int T^{-3/2}\,dT = -2\,T^{-1/2} + \text{const}.
\]

Right side  
\[
-\frac{k}{C_{V}}\int V^{-4/5}\,dV
      = -\frac{k}{C_{V}}\left(\frac{V^{1/5}}{1/5}\right) + \text{const}
      = -\frac{5k}{C_{V}}\,V^{1/5} + \text{const}.
\]

Equating the two integration results (and absorbing the arbitrary constants into one overall constant) gives

\[
T^{-1/2} \;=\; \alpha\,V^{1/5}\qquad(\alpha = \text{constant on a given adiabat}).
\]

### 3.3  Express \(T\) as a function of \(V\) on an adiabat  
Solve for \(T\):

\[
T = \alpha^{-2}\,V^{-2/5}\;\propto\;V^{-2/5}.
\]

### 3.4  Obtain the \(p\text{–}V\) relation on the same adiabat  
Insert \(T \propto V^{-2/5}\) back into the equation of state:  

\[
p \;=\; k\,V^{-4/5}\,T^{3/2}
      \;\propto\; V^{-4/5}\,\bigl(V^{-2/5}\bigr)^{3/2}
      = V^{-4/5}\,V^{-3/5}
      = V^{-7/5}.
\]

Hence every reversible adiabatic path satisfies

\[
p\,V^{7/5} = \text{constant}.
\]

### 3.5  Read off the heat-capacity ratio  
For a fluid whose heat-capacity ratio is a true constant, the canonical adiabatic form is  

\[
p\,V^{\gamma} = \text{constant}.
\]

Comparing the exponent obtained above with this standard form gives  

\[
\gamma = \frac{7}{5} = 1.4 .
\]

----------------------------------------------------------------------

### Final Answer
\[
\boxed{\gamma = \dfrac{7}{5} = 1.4}
\]

questions: On an infinitely large horizontal plane, establish polar coordinates ($r, \theta$) .On the plane there is a stationary magnetic field of magnitude $\frac{mv}{q\sqrt{ar}}$ directed vertically upwards. A particle with a charge-to-mass ratio of $\frac{3q}{2\sqrt{2}m}$ is projected along the polar axis direction($\theta=0$) from the origin with an initial velocity of $v_0$. Find the polar coordinate trajectory equation $r(\theta)$ for this particle.
solutions:
Solution:
The dynamic equations are
$$
\left\{{\begin{array}{l}{m({\ddot{r}}-r{\dot{\theta}^{2}})=q B r{\dot{\theta}}}\\ {m{\frac{d\left(r^{2}{\dot{\theta}}\right)}{r d t}}=-q B{\dot{r}}}\end{array}}\right.
$$

Rearranging and integrating equation (21) yields:

$$
\begin{array}{l}{{d(r^{2}\dot{\theta})={\frac{3v_{0}\sqrt{r}}{2\sqrt{2a}}}d r}}\\ {{d(r^{2}\dot{\theta})=-d{\frac{v_{0}r^{\frac{3}{2}}}{\sqrt{2a}}}}}\\ {{~\therefore~r^{2}\dot{\theta}+{\frac{v_{0}r^{\frac{3}{2}}}{\sqrt{2a}}}=0}}\\ {{\dot{\theta}=-{\frac{v_{0}}{\sqrt{2a r}}}}}\end{array}
$$

Lorentz force does no work, energy conservation:

$$
\begin{array}{r}{\therefore\dot{r}=\sqrt{v_{0}^{2}-\frac{v_{0}^{2}r}{2a}}}\\ {\frac{d r}{d\theta}=-\sqrt{2a r-r^{2}}}\end{array}
$$

$$
\therefore r=a(1-\cos\theta)
$$
improved_solutions:
Solution Outline
================

1. ​Problem Analysis  
2. ​Approach (key ideas)  
3. ​Detailed Solution  
   3.1 Choice of vector potential  
   3.2 Conservation of canonical angular momentum  
   3.3 Energy (speed) conservation  
   3.4 Orbit differential equation dr/dθ  
   3.5 Integration and trajectory equation  
4. ​Physical discussion (optional checks)  
5. ​Final Answer  

--------------------------------------------------

1. Problem Analysis  
The horizontal plane carries a static, vertically–upward magnetic field whose magnitude depends on the radial coordinate r:

  B(r)=m v / [q √(a r)] (“m, q, v, a” are given constants).

A particle whose charge-to-mass ratio is  

  (q_p/m_p)= 3q/(2√2 m)  

is fired from the origin along the polar axis (θ = 0) with initial speed v₀.  
Because the force exerted by a magnetic field is always perpendicular to the velocity, the particle’s speed stays constant, but the direction of the velocity changes.  We are asked to obtain the trajectory r(θ).

--------------------------------------------------

2. Approach  
Axis-symmetry (no explicit θ in the field) implies that the canonical angular momentum  

  L_z = m_p r² θ̇ + q_p r A_θ(r)  

is conserved.  A suitable vector potential containing only an e_θ component makes this conservation law easy to exploit.  Combining:

• conservation of L_z (to obtain θ̇(r))  
• conservation of kinetic energy (|v| = v₀)  

gives ṙ(r) and finally a separable first-order equation dr/dθ whose integral yields r(θ).

--------------------------------------------------

3. Detailed Solution  

3.1 Vector potential for the given B(r)  
Take the purely azimuthal potential A = A_θ(r) e_θ.  For cylindrical symmetry,

  B_z = (1/r) d/dr [r A_θ(r)].

With B_z(r)= m v / [q √(a r)] ≡ C/√r where C≡m v/(q √a),

  d/dr [r A_θ] = C√r  
  ⇒ rA_θ = ∫ C√r dr = ⅔ C r^{3/2} (integration constant set to 0)  
  ⇒ A_θ(r)= (2C/3)√r.                           (1)

3.2 Canonical angular-momentum conservation  
The particle’s canonical L_z is

  L_z = m_p r² θ̇ + q_p r A_θ(r).                  (2)

At t=0 the particle is at r=0 moving radially (θ̇=0), so L_z(0)=0.  
Since L_z is conserved, L_z ≡ 0 for all times, hence

  0 = m_p r² θ̇ + q_p r A_θ  
  ⇒ θ̇ = − q_p A_θ /(m_p r).                       (3)

Insert (1):

  θ̇ = − q_p /(m_p) · (2C/3) · √r /r  
    = − (2C q_p)/(3m_p) · 1/√r.                 (4)

Define the positive constant  

  β ≡ (2C q_p)/(3m_p).                            (5)

Then |θ̇| = β /√r.

3.3 Energy conservation (speed is constant)  
Magnetic forces do no work ⇒ |v|=v₀ remains constant:

  v₀² = ṙ² + r²θ̇²  
      = ṙ² + r² (β²/r) = ṙ² + β² r.               (6)

Thus  

  ṙ² = v₀² − β² r,  ṙ = ±√(v₀² − β²r).        (7)

Because the particle is first shot outward, take the + sign as long as ṙ>0.

3.4 Converting to dr/dθ  
With θ̇ = −β/√r (eq. 4),

  dr/dθ = (dr/dt)/(dθ/dt) = ṙ / θ̇ = −√r / β · √(v₀² − β²r).   (8)

Hence

  dθ = −β dr / [√r √(v₀² − β²r)].                (9)

3.5 Carrying out the integral  
Introduce the substitution

  r = (v₀²/β²) sin²ϕ  (ϕ∈[0,π/2]),             (10)

which gives  
  dr = (2v₀²/β²) sinϕ cosϕ dϕ,  √r = (v₀/β) sinϕ,  
  √(v₀² − β²r) = v₀ cosϕ.

Plug into (9):

  dθ = −β · (2v₀²/β²) sinϕ cosϕ dϕ
             /[(v₀/β) sinϕ · v₀ cosϕ]
        = −2 dϕ.                                   (11)

Integrate from the initial state (r=0 ⇒ ϕ=0, θ=0) to arbitrary r,θ :

  θ = −2ϕ.                                        (12)

Eliminate ϕ using (10):

  sin²ϕ = sin²(−θ/2) = sin²(θ/2),                (13)

so

  r(θ) = (v₀²/β²) sin²(θ/2).                     (14)

3.6 Express β in the given constants  
Recall C = m v/(q√a) and q_p/m_p = 3q/(2√2 m).  Using (5):

  β = (2/3) C (q_p/m_p)
          = (2/3)· m v/(q√a) · 3q/(2√2 m)
          = v /√(2a).                              (15)

Therefore β² = v²/(2a).  Substituting into (14) gives

  r(θ) = (2a v₀² / v²) sin²(θ/2).                (16)

--------------------------------------------------

4. Physical Check  
• r=0 when θ=0 (launch point) and again when θ=2π, so the orbit is a closed “flower” that returns to the origin after one full revolution.  
• Units: [r] = [a] since the prefactor (2a v₀²/v²) has dimension of length.  
• The derivation used only magnetic-field properties and the given charge-to-mass ratio; the result is therefore self-consistent.

--------------------------------------------------

### Final Answer
\[
\boxed{ \; r(\theta)\;=\; \dfrac{2\,a\,v_0^{\,2}}{v^{2}}\,
        \sin^{2}\!\left(\dfrac{\theta}{2}\right) \;}
\]

questions:
Consider a metal beam with a width of $a$, thickness of $h$, and Young's modulus of $E$. The beam is placed on supports spaced at a distance $l$, and it is assumed that the length of the metal beam is slightly greater than $l$. A weight with a mass of $m$ is placed in the middle of the beam. Assume the angle between the beam and the horizontal line is very small, neglect friction and the weight of the beam, and take the gravitational acceleration as $g$.

Hint: Since the beam has thickness, it develops a situation where the inner side is compressed and the outer side is stretched when in equilibrium. Although the net force at the interface is zero, a torque is generated. This also causes every part of the beam to experience compression/stretch, thereby storing potential energy.

(1) Using the point where the heavy object is suspended as the origin, and the horizontal direction as the $\pmb{\mathscr{x}}$ axis, and the vertical direction as the $\textit{\textbf{y}}$ axis, establish a coordinate system.

$$
M = \int_{-\frac{h}{2}}^{\frac{h}{2}}\frac{E a}{R}z^{2}d z = \frac{E a h^{3}}{12R}

Given the approximation condition ${y}^{\prime}\ll1$:

R = {\frac{(1+y^{\prime2})^{\frac{3}{2}}}{|y^{\prime\prime}|}} \approx {\frac{1}{|y^{\prime\prime}|}}

$$
